View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-30 16:20:56 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (79): Europe (Albania) wild bird, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20220330.8702303AVIAN INFLUENZA (79): EUROPE (ALBANIA) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, OIE****************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 28 Mar 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=51189Influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Albania--------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 18 Mar 2022Confirmed: 24 Mar 2022Reported: 24 Mar 2022Reason for notification: recurrenceCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Liqenas, KorceStarted: 18 Mar 2022Epidemiological unit: body of waterAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedDalmatian pelican (_Pelecanus crispus_): Pelecanidae-Phaethontiformes / - / 3 / 3 / - / - / -Affected population: 3 pelicans were found dead on a lake called Prespa e Madhe-Prespa e vogel.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive.Epidemiological comments: the date of last occurrence of H5N1 in the country is 23 Jun 2006.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: zoning; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; movement control.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultInstitute of Food Safety and Veterinary National Laboratory / birds / 1 real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 24 Mar 2022 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[Since October 2020, Europe has experienced the most severe avian influenza epidemic to date. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in its spread and maintenance. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Liqenas, Korçë, Albania: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702303,68701] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-28 16:45:22 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (77): Americas (USA) wild birds, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220328.8702266AVIAN INFLUENZA (77): AMERICAS (USA) WILD BIRDS, HPAI H5N1**********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] Michigan: wild swan and goose[2] Colorado (Sedgwick County): wild goose[3] South Dakota: wild goose[4] Pennsylvania: bald eagle******[1] Michigan: wild swan and gooseDate: Thu 24 Mar 2022Source: 9&10 News [edited]https://www.9and10news.com/2022/03/24/dnr-confirms-avian-influenza-in-wild-birds-in-st-clair-macomb-and-monroe-counties/The highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) is confirmed in the state's wild bird population according to the Michigan Department of Natural Resources (DNR).The disease was identified in free-ranging Canada geese and tundra swans from St Clair County, snowy owls from Macomb County, and a mute swan from Monroe County.The mute swan was identified as a positive case on [15 Mar 2022].Then, on [24 Mar 2022], the DNR received confirmation that 6 geese, 2 tundra swans, and 2 snowy owls were positive for HPAI.This comes after the state's 1st HPAI detection from a non-commercial, backyard poultry flock in Kalamazoo County in late February [2022].The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (MDARD) has continued to urge poultry owners to "step up their own biosecurity precautions by minimizing the number of people coming in contact with birds, isolating birds from wild birds whenever possible, and disinfecting hands and clothing after coming in contact with poultry.""This confirmed positive finding of highly pathogenic avian influenza in wild birds prompts several steps that are informed by Michigan's Surveillance and Response Plan for HPAI in wildlife," said DNR Director Dan Eichinger. "The DNR and MDARD are working that plan with other experts and stakeholders and taking advantage of every available resource that aims to limit the spread of HPAI."Eichinger also said the state's ongoing focus is to prevent the disease's spread.According to the state's wildlife HPAI plan, the DNR has already canceled the roundup and relocation of Canada geese for the year, and will only make limited exceptions in approved situations. The DNR is also refunding application fees for sites that have received roundup permits.Due to the cancellation, the DNR is also encouraging nest and egg destruction to resolve conflicts. There is no eligibility requirements for nest and egg destruction in 2022, nor is there any charge for permits for this activity.MDARD, the DNR, Michigan State University, the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services, and the US Department of Agriculture's Veterinary Services and Wildlife Services are working together to conduct avian influenza surveillance and to monitor health of poultry, livestock, wildlife, and residents in Michigan.As of right now, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention consider the risk to people from HPAI viruses to be low since there are no detections of infections in people within the US.DNR is asking Michiganders who notice the death of 3 or more free-ranging birds to report it to the DNR either through the Eyes in the Field app [https://www2.dnr.state.mi.us/ors/Home?utm_campaign=avian%20influenza%20wild%20birds%203counties&utm_medium=pr&utm_source=govdelivery] or by calling 517-336-5030.And if your domestic poultry is experiencing severe illness or multiple death losses they are asking for you to contact MDARD at 800-292-3939.--Communicated by:ProMED[HealthMap/ProMED map of Michigan, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702266,225Michigan county map: https://geology.com/county-map/michigan-county-map.gif]******[2] Colorado (Sedgwick County): wild gooseDate: Fri 25 Mar 2022 3:23 PM MDTSource: Julesburg Advocate [edited]https://www.julesburgadvocate.com/2022/03/25/avian-influenza-confirmed-in-dead-geese-at-jumbo-reservoir/The Colorado Department of Agriculture has confirmed the presence of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, known as HPA, in wild Snow and Ross's geese in Sedgwick County.The confirmation comes after testing done by CDA, the Colorado Department of Parks and Wildlife, and the US Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service.The birds were collected by CPW [Colorado Parks and Wildlife] [17 Mar 2022] after several sick and dead geese were found at Jumbo Reservoir. The birds were necropsied at the CPW Wildlife Health Laboratory and samples were submitted to the Colorado State University Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory. The samples tested positive and these results were confirmed by the USDA National Veterinary Services Laboratory on March 24, 2022. This is the 1st confirmed case of HPAI in wild birds in Colorado.According to a release issued Friday [25 Mar 2022], there have been no detections of HPAI in commercial or backyard poultry flocks in Colorado. The USDA publishes all detections of HPAI in wild and domestic birds on its website.Dr Maggie Baldwin, Colorado State Veterinarian, said it's not surprising to find cases of HPAI in northeast Colorado."With the number of cases of HPAI we have seen across many eastern and Midwest states, it is not unexpected to have a detection in wild birds in Colorado," Baldwin said. "However, this detection emphasizes the importance for all poultry and bird owners to increase their biosecurity to protect the domestic poultry in the state. While our primary goal is prevention, we are also working to increase preparedness in the event that we do have a domestic poultry detection of HPAI in the state to respond quickly and eliminate the virus. Rapid detection and response is the best way to protect and safeguard animals and the food supply."HPAI is a reportable disease. It is important for veterinarians and producers to report any suspicious disease events in poultry flocks to the State Veterinarian's office at 303-869-9130. If it is after hours, the voicemail message will indicate which veterinarian is on call.HPAI is a highly contagious and fatal foreign animal disease in domestic poultry. Wild birds can spread this virus to domestic poultry and certain strains of avian influenza can be transmitted to humans. This does not present a food safety risk; properly prepared and cooked poultry products and eggs are safe for human consumption.Poultry producers and bird owners should increase biosecurity measures to help prevent HPAI from occurring in Colorado's domestic poultry flocks. The most important biosecurity practices include limiting exposure of domestic birds to wild birds and other poultry flocks and limiting introduction of new birds into flocks. People, equipment, vehicles, and other objects can also serve as a mechanism for transmission of disease and are important considerations when implementing biosecurity measures.[Byline: Jeff Rice]--Communicated by:ProMED[HealthMap/ProMED map of Colorado, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702266,68699Colorado county map: https://geology.com/county-map/colorado-county-map.gif]******[3] South Dakota: wild gooseDate: Fri 25 Mar 2022 10:57 AMSource: Mitchell Republic [edited]https://www.mitchellrepublic.com/sports/northland-outdoors/avian-flu-confirmed-in-canada-goose-near-mitchell-cemeteryCity officials say a case of avian flu has been detected in a goose near the Mitchell cemetery.According to Parks and Recreation Director Kevin Nelson, the investigation began after a city official noticed a goose acting strange Thursday [24 Mar 2022].Nelson said a wildlife biologist confirmed the suspected goose that was roaming around the cemetery near Lake Mitchell tested positive for avian flu, more commonly known as bird flu."They contacted a wildlife biologist, and they were able to do some testing with a mask and gloves. It turned out that it had avian flu," Nelson in an interview with the Mitchell Republic. "There were droppings in the area by the cemetery that they were able to identify."According to the South Dakota Game, Fish and Parks, the state's 1st case of avian influenza was confirmed in 2015 at a commercial turkey farm in Beadle County, which is about 50 miles [about 80 km] north of the Mitchell area.The latest cases of bird flu were detected in several snow geese and Canada geese in early March [2022] at 2 commercial turkey plants in Charles Mix County, GF&P [Game, Fish and Parks] officials say."As in past outbreaks, significant impacts to commercial poultry operations and backyard poultry flocks have been seen. We have also seen confirmed and suspected mortality several migratory waterfowl and raptor species in SD over the past several weeks," said Rocco Murano, a senior waterfowl biologist with GF&P. "Common symptoms are lethargy, tremors, inability to walk/fly and a twisted neck."Luckily, Murano said, the migration of arctic geese is progressing extremely rapidly this year [2022]. While the state could expect low levels interspecies transmission, Murano hopes the mortality rate will remain low."It is generally thought that the avian influenza virus doesn't tolerate warm conditions as well which should slow spread as spring weather warms into summer," Murano said. "It remains to be seen if this outbreak fizzles out over the summer or re-emerges in the fall. It is likely that a cooperative monitoring effort involving state and federal agencies will begin prior to fall migration."State GF&P has been working with the South Dakota Animal Industry Board (AIB) and the United States Department of Agriculture Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service to monitor and respond to additional outbreaks of avian influenza.According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention, avian influenza is transmissible from birds to humans. The virus can be transmitted to humans through a person's eyes, nose, and mouth. Mild symptoms of the bird flu can range from upper respiratory sickness such as coughing, sore throat, fatigue, and headaches. More severe symptoms in humans include pneumonia, vomiting, fevers, and seizures.While bird flu is transmissible to humans, the CDC says the spread of bird flu viruses from one infected person to another "is very rare." According to the CDC, bird flu in humans can only be detected through lab testing, meaning doctors are not able to clinically diagnose a human with the virus.[Byline: Meredith Radford]--Communicated by:ProMED[HealthMap/ProMED map of South Dakota, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702266,243South Dakota county map: https://geology.com/county-map/south-dakota-county-map.gif]******[4] Pennsylvania: bald eagleDate: Sat 26 Mar 2022 9:18 AM EDTSource: CBS Pittsburgh [edited]https://pittsburgh.cbslocal.com/2022/03/26/avian-flu-pennsylvania/The Pennsylvania Game Commission announced on Friday [25 Mar 2022] that a bald eagle found dead near Philadelphia tested positive for the highly contagious virus, also known as highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI H5N1).This is the 1st known case of HPAI H5N1 in the state since the disease was first discovered in the United States in late 2021, according to the commission.Another 5 deceased birds from Kahle Lake on the border of Clarion and Venango Counties are being tested for the flu as well.The virus can be deadly for multiple species of birds, including but not limited to turkey, hawks, eagles, gulls, ducks, and geese.Birds can be experiencing the virus while seeming totally healthy, but some symptoms include losing control of flight or other obvious signs of neurological dysfunction."While this HPAI outbreak does not appear to have significantly impacted wild bird populations, it has the potential to significantly affect the commercial poultry industry and international trade," the Pennsylvania Game Commission said.Earlier this month [March 2022], the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) stated that the risk of H5N1 to humans is low but that they are continuing to monitor the situation.--Communicated by:ProMED[HealthMap/ProMED map of Pennsylvania, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702266,240Pennsylvania county map: https://geology.com/county-map/pennsylvania-county-map.gifThe HPAI H5N1 Eurasian variant first detected in January 2022 on the Atlantic coast of North America continues to spread. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. During the 1st weeks, the propagation of H5N1 in the Americas seems to have been associated with the Atlantic Americas flyway, but it has been showing up in western states.It is important to acknowledge that only a few bird species may play a role in the propagation of HPAI viruses. Most wild bird species, as well as poultry and other domestic birds, are neither tolerant nor resistant to HPAI viruses, and thus they become ill and do not move much, which implies that they are poor spreaders and instead they may act as sentinels of viral circulation. Only a few species that migrate and can tolerate these viruses, presumably some Anseriformes, are key players driving the spread of this epidemic. - Mod.PMB] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-26 14:40:33 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (76): Americas (USA) poultry, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220326.8702236AVIAN INFLUENZA (76): AMERICAS (USA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1*******************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] Iowa (Buena Vista County): commercial turkeys[2] Missouri (Lawrence County): commercial turkeys[3] Missouri (Ralls County): backyard flock[4] Maine (Cumberland County): mixed flocks******[1] Iowa (Buena Vista County): commercial turkeysDate: Thu 24 Mar 2022 17:28 CDTSource: Des Moines Register [edited]https://eu.desmoinesregister.com/story/money/agriculture/2022/03/24/bird-flu-iowa-2022-symptoms-outbreak-turkey-buena-vista-county/7158334001/Bird flu has hit another commercial turkey operation in north west Iowa, the 3rd outbreak in Buena Vista County and the 6th in the state since the beginning of March [2022], the Iowa Department of Agriculture said on Thursday [24 Mar 2022]. The state said the facility has nearly 54 000 turkeys being destroyed to prevent the spread of the highly contagious disease. The virus can wipe out a flock within 48 hours.Buena Vista County has been under a state disaster proclamation since 6 Mar 2022 when the first outbreak was reported in a commercial flock of nearly 50 000 turkeys. And a week ago, the state said the deadly disease hit an egg-laying operation with 5.3 million hens.The disaster proclamation enables the state agriculture department and other agencies to help track, monitor and contain the disease. Officials are testing 7 flocks in a 6-mile area around the infected site, and monitoring 14 others, said Chloe Carson, the department's spokeswoman.Midwestern states are struggling to contain a virulent strain of bird flu having doomed millions of turkeys and chickens since March [2022]. Iowa has struggled with avian influenza outbreaks in backyard flocks in Pottawattamie and Warren counties, and at a Taylor County operation with about 916 000 pullets, or young laying hens.On Wednesday [23 Mar 2022], the agriculture department canceled all live bird competitions and exhibits at county fairs and the Iowa State Fair. The agency said it was prohibiting live bird sales at auctions, markets, swap meets and exotic sales. State officials believe wild birds are infecting domestic poultry with highly pathogenic avian influenza. Iowa is part of the Mississippi flyway, a migration route for millions of birds each year.State and federal agencies said none of the birds nor any poultry products from flocks where avian influenza is detected will reach US food supplies. No human cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza have been detected in the United States. "This is a difficult time for poultry producers as HPAI (highly pathogen avian influenza) continues to impact farms across Iowa and the United States," said Iowa agriculture secretary Mike Naig. Nationally, 17 states have reported outbreaks of bird flu among commercial or backyard flocks, with about 14 million birds destroyed to prevent the virus' spread, the US Department of Agriculture reported on Thursday [24 Mar 2022].Iowa leads the nation in egg production, with 55 million laying hens producing 16 billion eggs annually, and it ranks 7th nationally for turkey production, raising 12 million birds a year. A 2015 outbreak led to the destruction of 32.7 million laying hens, turkeys and other birds in Iowa. That was about two-thirds of the 50.5 million destroyed nationally.Officials urge flock owners to prevent contact between their birds and wild birds and to immediately report sick birds or unusual deaths.[byline: Donnelle Eller]--communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts******[2] Missouri (Lawrence County): commercial turkeysDate: Thu 24 Mar 2022 07:00 CDTSource: Lawrence County Record [edited]http://www.lawrencecountyrecord.com/content/avian-influenza-infects-flock-almost-38000-turkeys-law-coA flock of 37 770 commercial turkeys that were being raised in Lawrence County were confirmed to be infected with avian influenza (AI). The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) stated on their website the birds were confirmed to be infected on Wed 9 Mar 2022. The flock has since been "depopulated," a commonly used term for killed.According to information from the Missouri Department of Agriculture (MDA), AI viruses are influenza type A viruses that naturally occur in bird populations and transmitted from bird to bird "through fecal droppings, saliva, and nasal discharges." Infections in humans are rare.Besides the case in Lawrence County, 4 other cases of AI have been confirmed in Missouri, according to the USDA website. The first confirmed case was in Stoddard County, where the USDA confirmed on 4 Mar 2022 a flock of 360 000 commercial broiler chickens were infected. That same day, they also confirmed a flock of 51 "backyard mixed species" of non-poultry birds in Bates County were also infected. A flock of 25 015 commercial turkeys in Jasper County were discovered to be infected on 8 Mar 2022, and the latest confirmation was in Ralls County, where 75 non-poultry birds were found to be infected on 15 Mar 2022. All of the infected birds were depopulated.Christi Miller, communications director for the MDA, said it was unknown how the birds in the confirmed cases were infected. According to information from the MDA website, the virus can be transmitted to birds in the North American flyways when they intermingle with birds from Europe and Asia. "Positive tests in wild waterfowl can occur, and waterfowl can be infected and show no signs of illness," website stated. "There is a risk for spillover from wild birds into domestic poultry and then spill back from poultry to wild birds, resulting in further spread." The MDA stated some of the warning signs a flock has been infected include a decrease in water or feed consumption, respiratory signs such as coughing and sneezing, quietness among the flock, a decrease in egg production and a sudden increase of death in the flock.Poultry growers are being asked to take precautions to prevent the spread of AI. Among these are restricting visitors from access to their flocks, preventing flocks from having contact from wild birds, and refraining from visiting other poultry growers. Other suggestions include having a set of clothing and footwear only worn when working with their birds, disinfecting footwear before entering barns or coops, and washing hands before and after handling birds.Poultry growers are also asked to reduce any availability of food, water and nesting areas for wild birds and to fix any holes in roofs, screens and walls of poultry coops to keep wild birds from entering. Likewise, it is recommended that poultry growers clean and disinfect the wheels of any vehicle that has been to another poultry farm, as well as clean and disinfect any equipment that another poultry grower has borrowed and returned.Any poultry grower who suspects their birds may be infected should immediately contact their local veterinarian or MDA Animal Health Division. Miller stated the names of all poultry growers whose flocks are found to be infected are kept confidential. The MDA also stated chicken and other poultry products are safe to eat if cooked properly, and none of the infected birds are in the food supply. They also stated US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention considers the risk for infection to the general public to be low.[byline: Steve Chapman]--communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts******[3] Missouri (Ralls County): backyard flockDate: Thu 24 Mar 2022Source: Hannibal Courier Post [edited]https://www.hannibal.net/news/avian-flu-reported-in-ralls-county/article_0e64aefa-aaf0-11ec-a971-23f660df6d62.htmlThe Missouri Department of Agriculture has reported 5 cases of avian influenza in Ralls County. The cases were confirmed on 15 Mar 2022, and poultry owners in Ralls County received a visit from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) encouraging them to keep their poultry locked up.Christi Miller, communications director at Missouri Department of Agriculture, said the avian flu comes in various strains, just like the human influenza. This particular strain of the avian flu is what they call a highly pathogenic avian influenza, which means it is a highly contagious and deadly strand.The last highly pathogenic virus reported was in 2020 and spreads when poultry mingles with waterfowl migrating for the season. Miller confirmed the virus impacts poultry only and will not spread to other livestock. She reports that the 5 chickens affected by the virus are within the same flock and it has not spread to any other premises in Ralls County. [It is unclear if this 5 birds or 5 cases of chickens being affected. - Mod.TG]The virus has been found in 4 other Missouri counties, including Stoddard, Bates, Jasper and Lawrence counties. Miller said all cases have been contained to one premises and have not spread to date. "We have been very fortunate this year [2022] in the locations where we have had it in our state, there has only been one premise having been impacted and I think it's a real testament to the biosecurity of those producers," she said. "They are doing a good job of keeping their animals and flock contained and mitigating that spread."Signs of the avian influenza include a quieting of the flock, a refusal to eat or drink, a decrease of egg production, and sudden deaths within the flock.[MJ] and [JJ] raise chickens on a farm in Ralls County. They had just released their flocks to free-range after the winter 2 days before they received a personal visit earlier this week from the USDA informing them of the outbreak. It is the first time they have dealt with avian flu, and they are taking the precautions suggested by the USDA. "We have several different coops with different breeds of chickens. So we're just keeping everything separate," [MJ] said. "We've got all our layers in one coop and the special breeds in other coops." They were told it might be a while before they can release their flocks again.Miller said a specific time can't be pinpointed, but hopes to see a decrease by April or May [2022]. She believes the virus will slow down as the weather heats up, as it doesn't pronounce itself as much in heat. "When the weather is warming up and those birds have moved on through that's when we usually start seeing a decrease and we certainly hope is the case this year," she said.Officials from the USDA or Missouri Department of Agriculture will make at least one more round of visits to check on the status of area poultry, and Miller said these officials will always have a marked vehicle and badges to identify themselves. She encourages all livestock owners to fill out a premises ID form on their website in order to ensure they receive important information and updates when things like this happen. Miller assured consumers the food supply is not affected by the avian flu and the eggs and poultry in the supermarket and local grocery stores are safe to eat. She added poultry and eggs should always be cooked to the proper temperature.If someone suspects the avian flu in their flock, they can talk to their local veterinarian who will then get in touch with the Missouri Department of Agriculture. They can also call the Missouri Department of Agriculture's animal health division.[byline: Meg Duncan]--communicated by:ProMED rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi******[4] Maine (Cumberland County): mixed flocksDate: Fri 25 Mar 2022Source: Bangor Daily News [edited]https://bangordailynews.com/2022/03/25/news/cumberland-is-5th-maine-county-to-report-avian-flu-cases/More cases of the deadly avian influenza have been reported in Cumberland County. The cases affected a mixed flock of about 150 poultry and were reported on 22 Mar 2022, according to the US Department of Agriculture. The H5N1 avian influenza, a deadly disease that was first identified in Maine in a small flock in Knox County in February [2022], has the state on high alert. Keepers of backyard poultry flocks are being urged to take every precaution to prevent its spread. Cases also have been detected in Washington, Knox, Lincoln and York counties. So far in Maine it has been found in both domestic and wild birds.Symptoms include swollen heads, blue coloration of combs and wattles, lack of appetite, respiratory distress and diarrhea with a significant drop in egg production. These symptoms are particularly severe in chickens and turkeys.If there is any question about the health of an individual bird or entire flock, it is crucial to report those cases to state officials.[byline: Leela Stockley]--communicated by:ProMED rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi[If possible, keep your flocks inside to protect them from co-mingling with wild birds. And remember you can transport this virus on boots, or hands or even your coveralls. Be sure you are in clean gear before entering your birdhouses, and also blow your nose before entering a poultry house. - Mod.TGProMED map of the United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702236,106.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-26 10:27:23 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (75): Europe (UK,Spain) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread Archive Number: 20220326.8702234AVIAN INFLUENZA (75): EUROPE (UK, SPAIN) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD*******************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] UK (Suffolk): ducks, HPAI H5N1[2] Spain (Andalucia): turkeys, HPAI H5N1 ******[1] UK (Suffolk): ducks, HPAI H5N1Date: Tue 22 Mar 2022Source: BBC News [edited]https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-suffolk-60833544More than 82 000 ducks are to be culled amid an outbreak of bird flu, Suffolk Trading Standards said. The H5N1 strain was found at the Gressingham Foods site at Debach, near Woodbridge, over the weekend. The company's Redgrave site was affected earlier this month [March 2022], and 35 000 ducks had to be culled there.The Department of Environment, Food and Rural Affairs has urged poultry keepers in Suffolk to "step up their efforts" as the UK faces its "largest outbreak". Chief veterinary officer Dr Christine Middlemiss said the UK was seeing its "worst" ever avian flu outbreak. She said Suffolk in particular had seen a large increase in infections amongst wild birds. Although there was "no direct evidence" people were helping to spread the virus, Dr Middlemiss urged farmers and keepers to be "absolutely, scrupulously clean" when moving between sheds and bird housing.Sasha Watson, from Trading Standards, who described the latest case -- the 5th in the county in a month -- as a "very big outbreak", said the 82 400 ducks would be culled over the next few days.--communicated by: ProMED[The above outbreak in Suffolk has been listed as No 100 since the start of the ongoing HPAI epizootic in the UK, in DEFRA's outbreak assessment No 19, updated 21 Mar 2022 (URL in the commentary below). - Mod.ASProMED map: Suffolk, England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702234,2141]******[2] Spain (Andalucia): turkeys, HPAI H5N1 Date: Tue 22 Mar 2022Source: Euro Weekly News [edited]https://euroweeklynews.com/2022/03/22/another-case-of-avian-flu-detected-in-andalucia/The Central Laboratory of Algete, in Madrid, has today [22 Mar 2022], confirmed a new outbreak of avian flu in Andalucia. On this occasion, it has been detected in a fattening turkey farm in the Sevillian municipality of Arahal. A total of about 17 700 birds are believed to be on the farm. It is located within the radius of the surveillance zone previously declared by the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock, Fisheries and Sustainable Development in a neighbouring municipality.This latest outbreak brings the total of [outbreaks] detected in Andalusia to 28. As detailed by the Junta de Andalucia, 22 of them are in the province of Sevilla, and the remaining 6 in Huelva.An abnormal increase in the mortality of animals on the Arahal farm was detected last Tuesday [15 Mar 2022]. The official veterinary services of the Junta de Andalucia were notified, and the established protocol was followed, with samples taken and sent to the Central Laboratory of Algete for analysis. The veterinary services of the Andalucian administration immediately proceeded to isolate the affected farm. A rigorous epidemiological survey was conducted to find out the possible origin of the outbreaks.This can help to establish if other farms are at risk due to the movement of people and vehicles from the affected facility. In addition, all the birds on the farm were slaughtered, while the feed and other materials that could carry the virus were disposed of. Similarly, a restriction zone has been established around the outbreak, with a 3 km [1.9 mi] protection zone, and a 10 km [6.2 mi] surveillance zone.As in the previous outbreaks detected in the provinces of Sevilla and Huelva, the analysis carried out has shown that it is avian influenza of the H5N1 subtype. This is the one that has been affecting Europe in recent months. Although it has not shown any zoonotic potential, exposure to birds showing any symptoms consistent with the disease or found dead in the field is not recommended.[byline: Chris King]--communicated by:ProMED[The current HPAI H5N1 epizootic, which started in Europe in September 2021, seemed to have peaked during the 2nd week of 2022, decreasing until the 8th week; the number of outbreaks has again been increasing across Europe since the 9th week of 2022. During the 10th week, a total of around 230 outbreaks in poultry have been reported to the OIE in Europe (see Figure 3 in DEFRA's weekly outbreak assessment No 19, dated 21 Mar 2022, at https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1062932/hpai-europe-220321.pdf).The increase is mainly due to the outbreak in France. Cases of HPAI infection in wild birds are decreasing week on week.For a map, presenting HPAI in poultry and captive and wild birds across Europe, September 2021 to 21 Mar 2022, see Map 3 in the said updated DEFRA assessment. - Mod.ASProMED map: Andalusia, Spain: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702234,2376.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-23 10:44:25 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (74): Americas (USA) mixed flocks, HPAI, H5N1 Archive Number: 20220323.8702172AVIAN INFLUENZA (74): AMERICAS (USA) MIXED FLOCKS HPAI, H5N1************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] Delaware (Kent County): commercial broiler flock[2] Maine (Lincoln, York, Knox counties): backyard flocks[3] Iowa (Buena Vista County): commercial poultry[4] Iowa (Warren County): back yard flock[5] New Hampshire (Derry): sanctuary, non-commercial birds[6] Nebraska (Butler County): commercial flock[7] Kansas (Dickinson, Sedgwick counties): non-commercial flocks******[1] Delaware (Kent County): commercial broiler flockDate: Thu 17 Mar 2022Source: Delaware Business Now [edited]https://delawarebusinessnow.com/2022/03/bird-flu-found-in-kent-county-broiler-flock/Federal laboratory testing has confirmed a highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza (HPAI) case at a commercial broiler farm in Kent County, Delaware. Previously, cases had been found on the northern edge of the nation's largest broiler chicken area.This avian influenza detection follows previously announced cases on farms in New Castle County and Cecil and Queen Anne's Counties, Maryland. Since the cases were found, federal and state partners have expanded their surveillance sampling and testing regimen.State officials have quarantined all affected premises, and the birds have been killed to prevent the spread of the disease. Birds from affected flocks will not enter the food system.Avian influenza is a highly contagious airborne respiratory virus spreading quickly among birds through nasal and eye secretions and manure. The virus can be spread in various ways from flock to flock, including by wild birds, through contact with infected poultry, by equipment, and on the clothing and shoes of caretakers. The virus affects poultry, like chickens, ducks, turkeys, and wild bird species such as ducks, geese, shorebirds, and raptors.--communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of Delaware, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702172,16965Delaware county map: https://geology.com/county-map/delaware-county-map.gif]******[2] Maine (Lincoln, York, Knox counties): backyard flocksDate: Fri 18 Mar 2022Source: WGME Portland [edited]https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/cases-of-avian-flu-found-in-two-more-maine-counties/ar-AAVdgtqNew cases of the highly contagious bird flu have been discovered in Maine. This time, the cases have been found in birds in 2 more counties. So far, nearly 7 million chickens and turkeys in the US have been killed this year [2022] because of the virus.In Maine, officials confirmed reports of it last month [February 2022] in Knox County. Now it's been found in flocks in Lincoln and York Counties. In York County, there are 2 new confirmed cases in a backyard flock of 173 birds. There are also 2 confirmed cases in Lincoln County in a backyard flock of 70 birds. In Knox County, cases have been confirmed in backyard pet chickens in a flock of 96. Also in Knox County, cases have been confirmed in a flock of 27.The Maine Department of Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry has placed the properties under quarantine and have implemented safety measures. Those safety measures include monitoring properties with domestic flocks and notifying bird owners of the importance of safety measures to help prevent disease.They say the risk remains high, and backyard flocks and commercial operators should keep their birds indoors to prevent the spread of the disease. Jim Britt with the Department of Agriculture says, unfortunately, death is a primary indicator of the avian flu. "The best thing a bird owner of or a backyard flock owner or a commercial flock owner is to keep those birds inside to keep them away from wild birds," Britt said. "Migratory wild birds are the culprit of bringing the flu to Maine." Britt says the avian flu is a very low risk to humans and as long as poultry and eggs are cooked properly, there should be no concerns if your food is safe.--communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of Maine, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702172,222Maine county map: https://geology.com/county-map/maine-county-map.gif]******[3] Iowa (Buena Vista County): commercial poultryDate: Sat 19 Mar 2022 9:27 AM CDTSource: The Gazette, Iowa Capital Dispatch report [edited]https://www.thegazette.com/agriculture/bird-flu-hits-flock-of-5-3-million-iowa-hens/A highly contagious and deadly avian influenza has been detected in an immense flock of egg-laying chickens in Northwest Iowa, the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship reported on Friday [18 Mar 2022]. The Buena Vista County flock has 5.3 million birds, said Chloe Carson, a spokesperson for the department. The virus was confirmed on Thursday [17 Mar 2022]. It is the 2nd flock in the county to be infected and the 4th in Iowa this year [2022].The county was among the hardest hit in Iowa by a bird flu outbreak in 2015 and is under a governor's disaster proclamation to assist with the detection and containment of the disease. State agricultural officials have said they have a goal to cull infected flocks within 24 hours of detection to prevent the virus' spread.Migrating wild birds -- which often don't suffer the same deadly symptoms as domestic birds -- are the likely sources of the outbreaks, State Veterinarian Jeff Kaisand has said. The state agriculture department doesn't identify the specific locations of the outbreaks.The virus was previously identified in a Taylor County flock of about 919 000 egg-laying chickens on [10 Mar 2022], a Buena Vista flock of 50 000 turkeys on [6 Mar 2022], and a backyard flock of 42 chickens and ducks in Pottawattamie County on [1 Mar 2022].It has been identified in a total of 39 commercial and backyard flocks in 17 states, with new confirmations coming on a nearly daily basis, according to the US Department of Agriculture. The latest affected flock in Iowa is the largest among them.The series of outbreaks in 2015 led to the culling of more than 30 million birds in Iowa. Iowa is the nation's leading egg producer.[byline: Jared Strong]--communicated by:ProMED rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi******[4] Iowa (Warren County): back yard flockDate: Sun 20 Mar 2022Source: KKWL [edited]https://www.kwwl.com/townnews/medicine/fifth-statewide-confirmed-case-of-bird-flu-in-warren-county/article_137770f8-a889-11ec-bbc5-db16376314d9.htmlThe Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship, as well as the United States Department of Agriculture, are both confirming another positive case of avian influenza (HPAI) in Warren County, Iowa. The virus was found in a non-commercial backyard flock. This marks the 5th case recorded by the state thus far.Flock owners are recommended to prevent contact between their birds and wild birds and report sick birds or unusual deaths to state/federal officials. A list of signs of the disease can be found at Avian Influenza | Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (http://www.iowaagriculture.gov).If producers suspect signs of HPAI in their flocks, they should contact their veterinarian immediately. Possible cases should also be reported to the Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship at (515) 281-5305. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, these HPAI detections do not present an immediate cause for public health concern.The list of counties with confirmed cases as of 20 Mar 2022 are as follows: Buena Vista, Taylor, Warren, and Pottawattamie.[byline: Austin Ellis]--communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of Iowa, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702172,3627Iowa county map: https://geology.com/county-map/iowa-county-map.gif]******[5] New Hampshire (Derry): sanctuary, non-commercial birdsDate: Fri 18 Mar 2022 08:55 PM EDTSource: WMUR [edited]https://www.wmur.com/article/birds-derry-sanctuary-euthanized-turkeys-avian-flu/39478771#Dozens of birds have been euthanized after New Hampshire's first confirmed case of the current avian flu strain in domestic birds. The owners of Pumpkin Wall Farm animal sanctuary said they're devastated dozens of their animals have to be euthanized, but they're hoping it can be a teaching moment for other farm owners.[BF] said she rescues all kinds of animals and brings them to Pumpkin Wall Farm. This week, 5 of her turkeys suddenly died. She said she contacted the state veterinarian, who determined they had avian flu."All our animals at the sanctuary have their own habitats," [BF] said. "It's not a farm where everybody's mixed together." She said wild ducks carrying the disease landed in their pond and infected the flock. The rest of her chickens, ducks, geese, and turkeys then had to be put down."They said, 'Your farm is amazing. It's immaculate. It's clean. You did everything right. This isn't your fault,'" [BF] said. "We're not set up to have nets over an acre of land."State officials said this was the first confirmed diagnosis of this strain of avian flu in domestic birds in New Hampshire. They said there's not a concern for food safety, and the risk to people is low.BF said by state law, they can't do anything on the farm for about 5 months. The owners said they might consider releasing some geese into the pond on Labor Day weekend [3-5 Sep 2022].[byline: Mike Cronin]--communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of New Hampshire, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702172,29932]******[6] Nebraska (Butler County): commercial flockDate: Tue 22 Mar 2022Source: Southernminn, Lincoln Journal Star report [edited]https://www.southernminn.com/around_the_web/news/article_d7acc13b-f0df-5b35-9ea4-9ed728256efe.htmlNebraska has confirmed its 1st case of the bird flu in a commercial flock of chickens. The state Department of Agriculture said the highly contagious disease has been found in a flock of 570 000 broiler chickens in Butler County.The Agriculture Department said the farm has been quarantined and all 570 000 birds will be destroyed. It also has set up a 6.2-mile [10 km] control zone around the farm, and poultry producers within that radius will not be allowed to move poultry products on or off their premises without permission of the department. State veterinarian Roger Dudley said the farm had increased its safety practices and heightened observational testing. It quarantined itself after noticing higher-than-normal mortality among its flock and notified the department."Having a second farm in Nebraska confirmed to have HPAI is unfortunate but not completely unexpected," said agriculture director Steve Wellman. "NDA will use all the resources at our disposal, in coordination with our federal partners, to manage a quick response."Bird flu so far has infected nearly 15 million birds in the US, the worst outbreak since 2015.That outbreak led to nearly 5 million laying hens being euthanized at 6 farms in Dixon County [Nebraska]. Nationwide, more than 50 million birds were killed in what is considered the worst outbreak on record. An outbreak now could be even more devastating in Nebraska, as the state has since added dozens of operations raising millions of broiler chickens for the Costco processing plant in Fremont.[byline: Matt Olberding]--communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of Nebraska, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702172,39885Nebraska county map: https://geology.com/county-map/nebraska-county-map.gif]******[7] Kansas (Dickinson, Sedgwick counties): non-commercial flocksDate: Tue 22 Mar 2022Source: Hiawatha World Online [edited]https://www.hiawathaworldonline.com/news/highly-pathogenic-avian-influenza-continues-to-spread-in-kansas/article_a5c92d00-a9e9-11ec-ac3a-7b574f41fd2f.htmlThe Kansas Department of Agriculture (KDA) has now identified 2 new counties which have confirmed cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) as the disease outbreak continues in Kansas and nationwide. Samples from birds exhibiting HPAI signs in a non-commercial backyard mixed-species flock (poultry) in Dickinson County and also in a non-commercial backyard mixed-species flock (non-poultry) in rural Sedgwick County were confirmed today by the National Veterinary Services Laboratories in Ames, Iowa.KDA is working closely with USDA-APHIS on a joint incident response in both of the new locations. KDA officials quarantined the affected premises, and birds on both properties will be depopulated to prevent the spread of the disease.Anyone involved with poultry production from the small backyard chicken owner to the large commercial producer should review their biosecurity activities to assure the health of their birds. Find guidance on biosecurity on the KDA Division of Animal Health webpage at https://www.agriculture.ks.gov/AvianInfluenza. Going forward, any additional confirmed cases will be shared directly with local communities and announced on the KDA Avian Influenza webpage, rather than through a statewide news release.Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) is a highly contagious viral disease which can infect chickens, turkeys, and other birds and can cause severe illness and/or sudden death in infected birds. Attentively monitor your birds for signs of HPAI which include coughing, sneezing, nasal discharge, and other signs of respiratory distress; lack of energy and appetite; decreased water consumption; decreased egg production and/or soft-shelled, misshapen eggs; incoordination; and diarrhea. Avian influenza can also cause sudden death in birds even if they aren't showing other signs.According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), the recent HPAI detections do not present an immediate public health concern. No human cases of these avian influenza viruses have been detected in the United States. Birds and eggs from the infected flock will not enter the food system. As a reminder, the proper handling and cooking of all poultry and eggs to an internal temperature of 165 deg F [74 deg C] is recommended as a general food safety precaution.As part of existing avian influenza response plans, federal and state partners are working jointly on additional surveillance and testing in areas around the affected flocks. The United States has the strongest AI surveillance program in the world, and USDA is working with its partners to actively look for the disease in commercial poultry operations, live bird markets, and in migratory wild bird populations.For more information about HPAI, including current status of the confirmed cases in other states as well as more information about biosecurity for your flock, go to KDA's avian influenza webpage at https://www.agriculture.ks.gov/AvianInfluenza.--communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of Kansas, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702172,219Kansas county map: https://geology.com/county-map/kansas-county-map.gifIn early 2022, the highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 made its way on migratory pathways into the United States. This virus continues to fly westward, spreading death and destruction to commercial and non-commercial birds. Many wild birds and almost all commercial birds in North America have little defense against this virus.To help your flocks, raise your level of biosecurity. Keep your birds inside, in a closed building with good ventilation. Be sure you are not tracking this virus into your birds. Change clothes, boots, gloves, and cover your hair and hands before entering the area where your birds are. Be sure to blow your nose before entering the birdhouses as well. Don't track this virus around. While flu flies, we each have to be careful to protect our birds at home or on the job. - Mod.TG] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-22 19:11:39 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (73): Europe (UK,Greece) wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220322.8702159AVIAN INFLUENZA (73): EUROPE (UK, GREECE) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1**************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] Greece: pelican[2] UK (Scotland): wild birds******[1] Greece: pelicanDate: Sun 20 Mar 2022Source: Keep Talking Greece [edited]https://www.keeptalkinggreece.com/2022/03/20/pelicans-dalmatian-dead-bird-flu-prespa-lakes-greece/An operation to collect hundreds of dead Dalmatian pelicans killed by avian flu was under way in northern Greece on [Sat 19 Mar 2022], around the Prespa Lakes, as well as Lake Heimaditida, Kastoria, and Zazari. The operation to remove the dead birds, many of them in their nests, took place under stringent biosecurity measures to minimize further contamination.Speaking to state-run news agency Amna, deputy mayor of Amynteos Eleni Gyriki, said that 80 dead birds had been collected by fishermen going out on their boats, and placed in special bags to minimize transmission of the virus in order to be incinerated.An operation by a private company on Little Prespa Lake has collected so far 748 dead pelicans in the 4 days of operation. This is where the problem is most acute, as the reed beds in the lake house one of Europe's largest colonies of pelicans. The aim is to contain the [situation] before the second wave of migrating birds arrives at the lake in April [2022].The first dead birds were located in mid-February [2022] and the phenomenon "exploded" quickly. In the first 2.5 weeks 574 dead pelicans and another 24 in Lake Heimaditida were recorded, the director of the Prespa Protection Company, Myrsini Malakou, told Amna [news agency] beginning of March [2022]. She said that a total of 70 dead pelicans were found last year [2021].Authorities in Greece have been on alert this year [2022] due to the death of more than 6000 cranes in Israel, at the end of the year [2021], from bird flu. "In the measures we make every year in the colonies, using drones and telescopes, we saw the dead birds, in a number that has never been seen before," Malakou said.Samples of dead animals, in collaboration with the Prespa National Park Management Agency and the municipality of Prespa, were sent to the Veterinary Service of the regional unit of Florina where it was confirmed that it is the H5N1 virus.--communicated by:ProMED******[2] UK (Scotland): wild birdsDate: Mon 21 Mar 2022Source: Ardossan & Saltcoats Herald [edited]https://www.ardrossanherald.com/news/20007910.bird-flu-avian-influenza-confirmed-north-ayrshire-disease-spreads/Cases of bird flu have been confirmed at a rescue centre in North Ayrshire as the disease continues to spread across the country. Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 has been detected at Hessilhead Wildlife Rescue Centre, near Beith, with a 3km [about 1.8mi] protection zone and a 10km [about 6mi] surveillance zone now in place.The security measures, which took effect from 7.30pm on [Fri 18 Mar 2022] mean movement restrictions within these zones -- for example, poultry, carcasses, eggs, used poultry litter and manure -- to prevent any further spread of disease.Advice shared by the Scottish Government said: "Vigilance by bird keepers is important and any suspicion of disease should be reported immediately to the local Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) office." The Scottish Government's chief vet, Sheila Voas, urged bird owners to take extra steps to protect their animals.Several cases have also been confirmed in Aberdeenshire, as well as in Angus and Dumfriesshire. A Great Britain-wide prevention zone has been in place since November [2021] and includes the requirement to house birds within the protection zones to prevent the spread of the disease.Highly pathogenic avian influenza is said to present suddenly, often with very high mortality, with affected birds developing swollen heads, blue colouration of the comb and wattles, dullness, lack of appetite, respiratory distress, diarrhoea and a significant drop in egg production. However, there can be considerable variation in the clinical picture and severity of the disease.If you are suspicious your flock has any form of avian influenza you must contact your local animal health office immediately.[byline: Ross Hanvidge]--communicated by:ProMED[Since October 2020, Europe has experienced the most severe avian influenza epidemic to date. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in its spread and maintenance. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. - Mod.PMBProMED maps:United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702159,40Greece: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702159,83] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-22 17:22:37 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (72): Americas (USA) poultry, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220322.8702154AVIAN INFLUENZA (72): AMERICAS (USA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1*******************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sun 20 Mar 2022Source: KEZI.com [edited]https://www.kezi.com/news/new-bird-flu-strain-found-in-pacific-northwest/article_9a8516b0-a7f6-11ec-83b1-676d54e21c7c.htmlThe Oregon Department of Agriculture has confirmed that a highly pathogenic avian influenza strain has been found in the Pacific north west. According to officials, the Eurasian strain called H5N1 is highly contagious and deadly. It is found in domestic poultry.If you raise chickens or domestic poultry, officials said to be aware of this novel disease, practice biosecurity, and track any unusual cases. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said HPAI detections do not present an immediate public health concern. No human cases of these viruses have been found in the US.--communicated by:ProMED[The Eurasian H5N1 first detected in January [2022] in the Atlantic coast of North America now has reached the Pacific coast. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. The current propagation of H5N1 in the Americas seems to be associated with the Atlantic Americas flyway, although the findings of infected wild birds first in Nebraska, Missouri, and now Oregon show that the virus is quickly moving westwards.It is important to acknowledge that only a few bird species may play a role in the propagation of HPAI viruses. Most wild bird species, as well as poultry and other domestic birds, are neither tolerant nor resistant to HPAI viruses, and thus they become ill and do not move much, which implies that they are poor spreaders and instead may act as sentinels of viral circulation. Only a few species that migrate and can tolerate these viruses, presumably some Anseriformes, are key players driving the spread of this epidemic. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Pacific Northwest, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702154,68029] See Also

The location of the outbreak is Branistea, Oinacu, Giurgiu.Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 33 925 / 33 925 / 6770 / - / - / -[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED[ProMED map of Romania: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702142,68695[The latest PowerPoint report with the current situation of HPAI in Romania presented on 14 Mar 2022 at the ScoPAFF [Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food, and Feed] meeting to the European Commission is available at https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2022-03/reg-com_ahw_20220314_hpai_rou.pdf. - Mod CRD]A map of avian influenza in Europe observed since 1 Oct 2021 (current wave) and as of 21 Mar 2022 is available at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2022/Map_AI_EU_2022-03-21.jpg. - Mod.CRD] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-22 22:31:52 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (11): Asia (China) H5N6 Archive Number: 20220322.8702026AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (11): ASIA (CHINA) H5N6**********************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 15 Mar 2022Source: Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region [edited]https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202203/15/P2022031500452.htmThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today (15 Mar [2022]) closely monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in mainland [China], and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food, and environmental hygiene, both locally and during travel.The case involves a 51 year old female, living in Nanchang in Jiangxi Province, who had exposure to live domestic poultry before onset. She developed symptoms on 20 Feb [2022] and was admitted for treatment on 23 Feb [2022]. She is in a critical condition.From 2014 to date [15 Mar 2022], 74 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by mainland health authorities. "All novel influenza A infections, including H5N6, are notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong," a spokesman for the CHP said.Travellers to the mainland or other affected areas must avoid visiting wet markets, live poultry markets, or farms. They should be alert to the presence of backyard poultry when visiting relatives and friends. They should also avoid purchasing live or freshly slaughtered poultry and avoid touching poultry/birds or their droppings. They should strictly observe personal and hand hygiene when visiting any place with live poultry.Travellers returning from affected areas should consult a doctor promptly if symptoms develop and inform the doctor of their travel history for prompt diagnosis and treatment of potential diseases. It is essential to tell the doctor if they have seen any live poultry during travel, which may imply possible exposure to contaminated environments. This will enable the doctor to assess the possibility of avian influenza and arrange necessary investigations and appropriate treatment in a timely manner.While local surveillance, prevention, and control measures are in place, the CHP will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments.The public should maintain strict personal, hand, food, and environmental hygiene and take heed of the advice below when handling poultry:- avoid touching poultry, birds, animals, or their droppings;- when buying live chickens, do not touch them and their droppings. Do not blow at their bottoms. Wash eggs with detergent if soiled with faecal matter and cook and consume the eggs immediately. Always wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling chickens and eggs;- eggs should be cooked well until the white and yolk become firm. Do not eat raw eggs or dip cooked food into any sauce with raw eggs. Poultry should be cooked thoroughly. If there is pinkish juice running from the cooked poultry or the middle part of its bone is still red, the poultry should be cooked again until fully done;- wash hands frequently, especially before touching the mouth, nose, or eyes; before handling food or eating; and after going to the toilet, touching public installations or equipment such as escalator handrails, elevator control panels, or door knobs, or when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing; and- wear a mask if fever or respiratory symptoms develop, when going to a hospital or clinic, or while taking care of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms.The public may visit the CHP's pages for more information: the avian influenza page, the weekly Avian Influenza Report, global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza, the Facebook Page, and the YouTube Channel.--communicated by:ProMED rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi[The above report mentions one new case of avian influenza A/H5N6 in critical condition in mainland China, increasing the total cases in 2022 to 10 (the last 2 cases are now included in the 2021 tally). Accordingly, from 2014 to date, 74 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by health authorities in mainland China.Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Intensive surveillance should be continued to detect cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of these viruses, as the frequency of cases appears to be increasing. - Mod.UBAProMED map of China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702026,155.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-20 03:23:32 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (70): Americas (USA) wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220320.8702088AVIAN INFLUENZA (70): AMERICAS (USA) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1*********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this report:[1] Missouri: pelican[2] North Carolina: wild duck and goose[3] Florida: wild duck******[1] Missouri: pelicanDate: Tue 15 Mar 2022 07:33 CDTSource: Springfield News Leader [edited]https://www.news-leader.com/story/sports/outdoors/2022/03/14/avian-flu-found-missouri-birds/6988624001/The highly pathogenic avian influenza has been found in an American white pelican and other birds across at least 4 counties. The Missouri Department of Conservation (MDC) confirmed a case in Clay County using the National Veterinary Services Lab in Ames, Iowa. The University of Missouri Veterinary Medical Diagnostic Lab confirmed positive birds in Pettis, Randolph and St. Charles counties.Highly pathogenic avian influenza, commonly referred to as bird flu, was first confirmed 3 Mar 2022 in a poultry flock in Stoddard County and a backyard flock in Bates County 4 Mar 2022, according to MDC."Avian influenza viruses naturally occur in bird populations, especially waterfowl, shorebirds, and domestic birds such as chickens and turkeys," said Sherri Russell, MDC State Wildlife Veterinarian, via a news release. "We have been monitoring this strain since early January [2022], when it was detected in the eastern United States and Canada."The virus spreads as birds along the North American flyways intermingle with infected birds from other parts of the world, according to MDC. Viruses are transmitted through fecal droppings, saliva and nasal droppings among birds."There is a risk for spillover from wild birds into domestic poultry and then back again from poultry to wild birds, resulting in further spread," MDC stated. MDC is working with the Missouri Department of Agriculture and other state and federal agencies to monitor the spread of the virus."Fortunately, avian influenza does not present an immediate public health concern, although on rare occasions it has infected humans and other animals," Russell stated. "We recommend you avoid handling sick or dead birds, and to report sick or dead wild birds, especially waterfowl to MDC."Look for signs of tremors, head tilting, lethargy, loss of coordination, inability to fly or walk properly, or standing upright. Wildlife Health staff are interested in reports of single waterfowl, raptor or avian scavengers. They are also interested in waterfowl or other waterbird deaths involving more than 5 birds where the cause of death is unknown.Folks can report sick or dead birds by emailing <WildlifeHealth@mdc.mo.gov> or calling their local MDC office.When it comes to hunting, MDC urges people to take "common sense precautions" when handling harvested birds in the field or at home. "They should be aware that it is possible to transport avian influenza viruses on boats, waders, or other equipment, especially if it isn't dry before moving it from one site to another," MDC stated. "Allowing hunting equipment to dry between outings will reduce this chance." Russell said poultry and wild game birds are safe to eat after being cooked to an internal temperature of 165 degrees F.Situation updates of ongoing avian influenza in wild birds can be found by visiting https://mdc.mo.gov/wildlife/wildlife-diseases/highly-pathogenic-avian-influenza-hpai.[Byline: Sara Karnes]--Communicated by:ProMED******[2] North Carolina: wild duck and gooseDate: Thu 17 Mar 2022 15:07 EDTSource: Public Radio for Eastern North Carolina [edited]https://www.publicradioeast.org/pre-news/2022-03-17/nc-wild-birds-are-first-confirmed-deaths-due-to-avian-fluThe 1st documented wild bird mortalities due to a highly infectious avian flu were confirmed by North Carolina natural resource agencies Wednesday [16 Mar 2022].Highly pathogenic avian influenza, commonly known as bird flu, has killed at least 4 wild birds in North Carolina. According to the North Carolina Wildlife Resources Commission, a redhead duck in Carteret County was among these birds and was observed with neurological signs consistent with bird flu before it was euthanized. The other birds were found in Dare, Hyde, and Wake counties.In January [2022], the commission confirmed a positive test in a wild duck for bird flu in Hyde County, along with a 2nd positive test in South Carolina. According to a news release, these were the 1st wild birds in the United States to have that strain of bird flu since 2016.This type of virus is considered low risk to people, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, but can be dangerous to other birds including domestic poultry. The public is encouraged to report unusual wild bird behavior.For more information, visit the NC Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services website (http://www.ncagr.gov/avianflu/).[Byline: Meredith Radford]--Communicated by:ProMED Rapporteur Mahmoud Orabi******[3] Florida: wild duckDate: Fri 18 Mar 2022 12:37 EDTSource: WPBF News [edited]https://www.wpbf.com/article/avian-flu-case-confirmed-martin-county/39467292#Wildlife experts in Florida have confirmed that avian influenza is present in Martin County. Savannah Steckler, a wildlife rehabilitator at the Treasure Coast Wildlife Center in Palm City, said a dead duck that was dropped off at the facility earlier this month [March 2022] had the virus. "We actually did have, I think, 2 or 3 positive cases coming back from ducks around the Martin County area," Steckler said.Experts said this is an extremely infectious avian flu strain and can be deadly. "We do get it a little bit every year," Steckler said. "But not as bad as we're seeing it right now." Steckler said they have set up a quarantine area at the wildlife center where all new arrivals will be placed and tested before being moved to the general population.According to the Florida Fish and Wildlife, there is a low risk the avian flu can spread to humans. To prevent the spread of avian flu, the public should avoid handling sick or dead wildlife.[Byline: Angela Rozier]--Communicated by:ProMED[The Eurasian H5N1 first detected in January 2022 in the Atlantic coast of North America continues to spread. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. The current propagation of H5N1 in the Americas seems to be associated with the Atlantic Americas flyway, although the findings of infected wild birds first in Nebraska and then in Missouri show that the virus is already moving westwards.It is important to acknowledge that only a few bird species may play a role in the propagation of HPAI viruses. Most wild bird species, as well as poultry and other domestic birds, are neither tolerant nor resistant to HPAI viruses, and thus they become ill and do not move much, which implies that are poor spreaders and instead they may act as sentinels of viral circulation. Only a few species that migrate and can tolerate these viruses, presumably some Anseriformes, are key players driving the spread of this epidemic. - Mod.PMBProMED map:United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702088,106] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-03-17 15:20:36 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (69): Europe (UK) poultry, backyard, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220317.8702048AVIAN INFLUENZA (69): EUROPE (UK) POULTRY, BACKYARD, HPAI H5N1**************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 16 Mar 2022 07:48 AM GMTSource: The Ellon Times [edited]https://www.ellontimes.co.uk/news/people/surveillance-zone-imposed-as-collieston-poultry-flock-is-found-to-have-bird-flu-3613174A backyard flock of mixed poultry near Collieston [Aberdeenshire, Scotland] has tested positive for highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 -- commonly known as 'bird flu'.To limit the risk of spread of the disease, the remaining birds at the premises have been humanely culled and a 3 km [2 mi] protection zone and 10 km [6 mi] surveillance zone have been declared around the infected premises.Within these zones, a range of different controls are now in place. These include restrictions on the movement of poultry, carcasses, eggs, used poultry litter and manure, and restrictions on bird gatherings.Scotland's Chief Veterinary Officer Sheila Voas said: "We have already made clear that all bird keepers -- whether major businesses or small keepers with just a few birds -- must ensure that their biosecurity is up to scratch to protect their birds from disease and prevent any contact between their birds and wild birds."Keepers who are concerned about the health or welfare of their flock should seek veterinary advice immediately. Your private vet, or your local Animal and Plant Health Agency office, will also be able to provide practical advice on keeping your birds safe from infection."The risk to the general public's health from avian influenza is very low. However, the risk to people with intensive exposure to infected birds is considered to be low."Food Standards Scotland advises that avian influenzas pose a very low food safety risk for consumers, and it does not affect the consumption of poultry products, including eggs."Producers and bird keepers must comply with the Order to House Birds, which came into effect on 29 Nov 2021 or to ensure their birds are kept separate from wild birds. The Order is in addition to regulations that were brought in across Britain as part of the Avian Influenza Prevention Zone (AIPZ) on 3 Nov 2021.Members of the public should not touch or pick up any dead or sick birds that they find. If you find a single dead wild waterfowl, a single dead bird of prey, or 5 or more dead wild birds of any other species, including gulls, at the same place at the same time, you should report them by calling the Defra helpline on 03459 33 55 77.[Byline: Kevin McRoberts]--Communicated by:ProMED[The HPAI H5N1 epizootic of the current season in the UK started in Worcester (England) on 15 Oct 2021. So far, 89 outbreaks have been confirmed in England, including 2 shared with Wales and 2 with Scotland.According to DEFRA's (Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs) continuously updated HPAI situation report, available at https://www.gov.uk/guidance/avian-influenza-bird-flu#latest-situation, the following 7 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 have been confirmed at premises in Scotland as of 16 Mar 2022:- in the Angus constituency- near Gretna, Dumfriesshire, Dumfries, and Galloway- near Annan, Dumfriesshire, Dumfries, and Galloway- near Moffat, Dumfriesshire, Dumfries, and Galloway- near Gretna, Dumfriesshire, Dumfries, and Galloway- near Inverurie, Aberdeenshire- near Collieston, AberdeenshireHPAI H5 outbreaks in poultry and captive birds across the United Kingdom (map 1) and Europe (map 3) since the start of the epizootic and as of 6 Mar 2022, are presented athttps://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1060076/hpai-europe-220307.pdf.The continuing epizootic peaked in Europe during the 2nd week of 2022 (week of 10 Jan 2022). - Mod.ASProMED map:Aberdeenshire, Scotland, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8702048,1902] See Also
