View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-02-10 16:55:52 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (40): Americas (USA) wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220210.8701387AVIAN INFLUENZA (40): AMERICAS (USA) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1*********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 8 Feb 2022Source: WATTPoultry [edited]https://www.wattagnet.com/articles/44465-avian-flu-confirmed-in-wild-waterfowl-in-marylandHighly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) has been confirmed in wild birds in Maryland, bringing the total number of states to have positive detections of the virus in 2022 to 5.The Maryland Department of Agriculture (MDA) informed the Delmarva Chicken Association that wild waterfowl hunted near Rock Hall had been tested for HPAI and found to be positive.--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[Maryland was the 5th state in the USA to report the virus, following South Carolina, North Carolina, Virginia, and Florida. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-02-09 22:13:20 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (39): Americas (USA) turkey, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220209.8701372AVIAN INFLUENZA (39): AMERICAS (USA) TURKEY, HPAI H5N1******************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Wed 9 Feb 2022 15:34 ESTSource: Reuters [abridged, edited]https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/us-confirms-highly-pathogenic-bird-flu-indiana-turkey-farm-2022-02-09/The US Department of Agriculture on Wednesday [9 Feb 2022] reported an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian flu in an Indiana turkey flock, the nation's first case in a commercial poultry operation since 2020. Cases of the disease, known as bird flu, can hurt the US farm sector because poultry are killed and trading partners can limit imports from infected areas. China said on Monday [7 Feb 2022] it banned imports of poultry from Spain and Moldova due to outbreaks.Bird flu does not present an immediate public health concern, the USDA said. But the infected turkey flock in Dubois County, Indiana, in the south of the state, suffered increased mortality, according to the agency.Indiana said the strain of the virus was H5N1 and this was the state's first case of highly pathogenic bird flu in commercial poultry since 2016. The H5N1 strain has also been found in wild birds along the US east coast this year [2022].[byline: Tom Polansek]--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>******[2]Date: Wed 9 Feb 2022Source: APHIS (Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service) [edited]https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/newsroom/stakeholder-info/sa_by_date/sa-2022/hpai-indianaThe United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS) has confirmed the presence of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in a commercial turkey flock in Dubois County, Indiana. This is the first confirmed case of HPAI in commercial poultry in the United States since 2020.Avian influenza does not present an immediate public health concern. No human cases of these avian influenza viruses have been detected in the United States. As a reminder, the proper handling and cooking of poultry and eggs to an internal temperature of 165 deg F [74 deg C] kills bacteria and viruses.Samples from the affected flock, which experienced increased mortality, were tested at the Indiana Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory at Purdue University, part of the National Animal Health Laboratory Network, and confirmed at the APHIS National Veterinary Services Laboratories (NVSL) in Ames, Iowa. Virus isolation is ongoing.APHIS is working closely with the Indiana Board of Animal Health (BOAH) on a joint incident response. State officials quarantined the affected premises, and birds on the property were depopulated to prevent the spread of the disease. Birds from the flock will not enter the food system.As part of existing avian influenza response plans, federal and state partners are working jointly on additional surveillance and testing in the nearby area. The United States has the strongest AI surveillance program in the world, and USDA is working with its partners to actively look for the disease in commercial poultry operations, live bird markets and in migratory wild bird populations.Anyone involved with poultry production from the small backyard to the large commercial producer should review their biosecurity activities to [ensure] the health of their birds. APHIS has materials about biosecurity, including videos, checklists, and a toolkit available at https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/animal-disease-information/avian/defend-the-flock-program/dtf-resources/dtf-resources.USDA will report this finding to the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) as well as international trading partners. USDA also continues to communicate with trading partners to encourage adherence to OIE standards and minimize trade impacts. OIE trade guidelines call on countries to base trade restrictions on sound science and, whenever possible, limit restrictions to those animals and animal products within a defined region that pose a risk of spreading disease of concern.In addition to practicing good biosecurity, all bird owners should prevent contact between their birds and wild birds and report sick birds or unusual bird deaths to state/federal officials, either through their state veterinarian or through USDA's toll-free number. Additional information on biosecurity for backyard flocks can be found at http://healthybirds.aphis.usda.gov.Additional background---------------------Avian influenza (AI) is caused by an influenza type A virus which can infect poultry (such as chickens, turkeys, pheasants, quail, domestic ducks, geese, and guinea fowl) and is carried by free flying waterfowl such as ducks, geese and shorebirds. AI viruses are classified by a combination of 2 groups of proteins: hemagglutinin or "H" proteins, of which there are 16 (H1-H16), and neuraminidase or "N" proteins, of which there are 9 (N1-N9). Many different combinations of "H" and "N" proteins are possible. Each combination is considered a different subtype and can be further broken down into different strains which circulate within flyways/geographic regions. AI viruses are further classified by their pathogenicity (low or high) -- the ability of a particular virus strain to produce disease in domestic poultry.--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi[Vigilance is very important at this time. Keep a close eye on your birds. Report the slightest hint of illness to your veterinarian. Early identification of signs of illness can help stop the spread of this very contagious virus, and lessen losses on a larger scale."Avian influenza refers to infection of birds with avian influenza type A viruses. These viruses occur naturally among wild aquatic birds worldwide and can infect domestic poultry and other bird and animal species. Wild aquatic birds can be infected with avian influenza A viruses in their intestines and respiratory tract, but usually do not get sick. However, avian influenza A viruses are very contagious among birds, and some of these viruses can sicken and even kill certain domesticated bird species including chickens, ducks, and turkeys."Infected birds can shed avian influenza A viruses in their saliva, nasal secretions, and feces. Susceptible birds become infected when they have contact with the virus as it is shed by infected birds. They also can become infected through contact with surfaces that are contaminated with virus from infected birds" (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/avianflu/avian-in-birds.htm).Biosecurity is not just a happy thought. It is an active practice of not tracking a disease around. If there is an ill bird and you handled it or its food/water containers, then you should not handle other birds and should carefully wash your hands, change coveralls and boots and even blow your nose before being near other birds. Report any illness immediately to the supervisor and/or your veterinarian. - Mod.TGProMED map of Indiana, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701372,217.] See Also

/ 10 / 10 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: 10 dead _C. macrohynchos_ (large-billed crow) were found and 5 out of 10 were tested.Outbreak location 2: Tomamae-Town 1, Tomamae, HokkaidoStarted: 2 Jan 2022Ended: 2 Jan 2022Epidemiological unit: not applicableAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedWhite-tailed eagle (_Haliaeetus albicilla_): Accipitridae-Accipitriformes / - / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: a weakened _H. albicilla_ (white-tailed eagle) was found and tested positive.Outbreak location 3: Nemuro-City 1, Nemuro, HokkaidoStarted: 20 Jan 2022Ended: 20 Jan 2022Epidemiological unit: not applicableAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedLarge-billed crow (_Corvus macrorhynchos_): Corvidae-Passeriformes / - / 5 / 5 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: 5 dead _C. macrohynchos_ (large-billed crow) were found and 3 out of 5 were tested.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: Tomamae-Town1; On [2 Jan 2022], a weakened _Haliaeetus albicilla_ (white-tailed eagle) was collected and tested against avian influenza virus. On [7 Jan 2022] National Institute for Environmental Studies conducted RT-PCR. On [22 Jan 2022], Hokkaido University conducted gene sequencing and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N1. Nemuro-City1; on [20 Jan 2022], five dead _Corvus macrorhynchos_ (jungle crow) were collected and tested against avian influenza virus. On [26 and 27 Jan 2022], Hokkaido University conducted RT-PCR and gene sequencing respectively, and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N1. Nemuro-City2. On [23 Jan 2022], 10 dead _C. macrorhynchos_ (jungle crow) were collected and tested against avian influenza virus. On [28 Jan 2022], Hokkaido University conducted RT-PCR and gene sequencing, and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N1.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: screeningWild control measures applied: screening, disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultNational Institute for Environmental Studies National Laboratory / white-tailed eagle / 1 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 7 Jan 2022 / positiveHokkaido University, JPN (private laboratory) / white-tailed eagle/large-billed crow / 3 / gene sequencing / 28 Jan 2022 / positiveHokkaido University, JPN (private laboratory) / large-billed crow / 2 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 28 Jan 2022 / positive[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED[Birds of prey and crows have been often reported dead or diseased due to HPAI viruses. Virus transmission between prey and predators and scavengers has been shown for HPAI virus (H5N1), with reported deaths in crows, birds of prey, and even mammals (carnivores). However, transmission of avian influenza viruses has not been sustained within predator and scavenger populations, suggesting that these represent a dead-end hosts. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Hokkaido Prefecture, Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701340,16672] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-02-08 17:35:45 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (36): Americas (USA) wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220208.8701339AVIAN INFLUENZA (36): AMERICAS (USA) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1*********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 7 Feb 2022Source: Feedstuffs [edited]https://www.feedstuffs.com/news/florida-confirms-case-highly-pathogenic-avian-influenzaAccording to the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission [FWC], samples collected in January [2022] by USDA-Wildlife Services from a hunter-harvested blue-winged teal in Palm Beach County have tested positive for highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] strain: H5N1 2.3.4.4b Eurasian. This follows similar reports of the H5N1 Eurasian strain from South Carolina, North Carolina, Virginia, and Canada (Newfoundland and Labrador) this past fall and winter (2021-2022).This strain has been documented in Europe since early 2021. No known human infections with Eurasian H5 viruses have occurred in the United States.The USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service [APHIS] says these findings are not unexpected, as wild birds can be infected with HPAI and show no signs of illness. They can carry the disease to new areas when migrating. APHIS anticipates additional wild bird findings as robust wild bird sampling program continues into the spring.FWC is monitoring for HPAI in birds found sick or dead of unknown causes and highlights ways to help prevent HPAI spread:- Report bird mortalities so die-offs can be investigated and tested.- Prevent contact of domestic or captive birds with wild birds (especially waterfowl).- Do not handle sick/dead wildlife. If it is necessary to do so then wear impermeable gloves, wash hands with soap and water, and change clothing before having any contact with healthy domestic poultry and birds.- Hunters and others handling birds should follow routine precautions listed below when handling wild birds.--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[This new report from Florida attests to the spread of Eurasian HPAI H5 viruses are spreading in North America, previously reported in Nova Scotia, South Carolina, North Carolina, and Virginia.From 2014 onwards, HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses caused outbreaks across the Eurasian region, affecting both poultry and wild birds, with abundant genetic reassortments yielding subtypes H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8. So far, the subtype reported in the Americas is H5N1.Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Numerous species of birds that migrate along Nearctic and Palearctic flyways breed in Arctic tundra regions, providing opportunities for HPAI viruses to be introduced into another continent. Thus, the migration of those species could have been the cause of the introduction of HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 into the Americas. - Mod.PMBProMED map of Florida, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701339,974Florida county map: https://geology.com/county-map/florida-county-map.gif] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-02-07 01:51:02 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (35): Americas (Canada) poultry, HPAI  Archive Number: 20220207.8701308AVIAN INFLUENZA (35): AMERICAS (CANADA) POULTRY, HPAI ******************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 4 Feb 2022 1:07 p.m. ATSource: CBC News [edited]https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/nova-scotia/avian-influenza-bird-flu-nova-scotia-commercial-turkey-barn-1.6339576Officials with the Canadian Food Inspection Agency say 12 000 turkeys at a commercial barn in western Nova Scotia had to be euthanized after avian influenza was discovered at the farm.The news was revealed during a Friday [4 Feb 2022] media briefing.Avian influenza, also known as bird flu, is a highly contagious viral strain. [Probably it is avian influenza H5N1. - Mod.TG]Prior to today [4 Feb 2022], cases were discovered in a wild goose and a backyard flock of chickens not meant for commercial production.Speaking on CBC's Maritime Noon, Dr. Margaret McGeoghegan, a veterinarian with the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's Atlantic division, said she wasn't at liberty to disclose a specific location for the barn.She said there are other commercial producers in the area, and restrictions are in place for commercial operations within 10 km [6.2 mi] of the affected barn to prevent the virus from spreading."Because of the intensity of the production system, the risk there is very high, and also considering the fact there are lots of waterways and lots of exposure to wild birds," said McGeoghegan.She said people in the industry are extremely concerned about the cases.McGeoghegan said farms have strict biosecurity measures to try to prevent the virus from entering a farm. The virus, which is spread through airborne transmission, can be brought in inadvertently on shoes, equipment, and clothing, she said."Because this strain is as highly pathogenic as it is, when it hits, sometimes there are no clinical signs other than the birds are dead," said McGeoghegan.On Friday [4 Feb 2022], the Nova Scotia Poultry Emergency Response Planning Committee -- which includes Chicken Farmers of Nova Scotia, Egg Farmers of Nova Scotia, and Hatching Egg Farmers of Nova Scotia -- released a statement saying the poultry industry is on high alert and asking for help from neighbors to help prevent the spread of avian flu.It said the industry has been following "advanced biosecurity protocols" to prevent spread since the 1st suspected case was found in a wild goose east of Halifax. The industry is cooperating with the Canadian Food Inspection Agency's instructions.It is also putting out a call to anyone raising domestic fowl on their property to watch for signs of avian flu and take all precautions to keep their birds away from wild birds. It said if anyone sees a sick or dead wild bird, to report it online through the Canadian Wildlife Health Cooperative.--Communicated by:ProMED[Avian influenza spreads very easily between birds, from wild to domestic, or domestic to domestic birds. This is certainly a time to be practicing biosecurity: washing boots between barns, changing coveralls, even showering between barns, if possible. Vehicles need to be sprayed with an antimicrobial agent on tires, in the wheel wells, etc. to prevent tracking the virus into the facility. Although it is an airborne virus, one cannot be too careful. While some of these suggestions seem either obvious or over the top, the point is that biosecurity encompasses all aspects of the poultry facility. While the virus may be airborne, our movements are capable of carrying it into a facility, and awareness of this is the 1st step in prevention. Do not be around any backyard poultry while off-duty from your poultry employment. The risk of transmitting this virus is too great. Also, your health is important.Please note, avian influenza can also be a human health issue."How can avian influenza (H5N1) infections be prevented?"If you travel to an area where avian influenza (H5N1) is a concern, you should take the proper precautions. See your health-care provider or visit a travel health clinic 6 weeks before you leave."If you travel to an affected area, follow the precautions below:Avoid high-risk areas (poultry farms and live animal markets).Avoid contact with birds, including- chickens- ducks- wild birdsAvoid surfaces that may have bird droppings or secretions on them.Make sure that all poultry dishes, including eggs, are cooked well.Wash your hands frequently:- use soap under warm running water for at least 20 seconds- if soap is not available, use alcohol-based hand sanitizer (carry travel-sized dispensers)Monitor your health:- see a health-care provider if you develop flu-like symptoms while travelling or upon returning to Canada- explain that you have been travelling or living in an area where avian influenza (H5N1) is a concern."(https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/avian-influenza-h5n1/prevention-avian-influenza-h5n1.html) - Mod.TGProMED map of Nova Scotia Province, Canada: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701308,271] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-02-04 23:21:24 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (34): Americas (Canada) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20220204.8701269AVIAN INFLUENZA (34): AMERICAS (CANADA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 4 Feb 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=47982High pathogenicity avian influenza viruses (poultry) (Inf. with), Canada------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: Immediate notificationStarted: 30 Jan 2022Confirmed: 3 Feb 2022Reported: 4 Feb 2022Reason for notification: RecurrenceLast occurrence: 28 Jul 2015Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaksTotal outbreaks (1)Outbreak location: Western Nova Scotia, Kings, Subd. A, Kings, Nova ScotiaStarted: 30 Jan 2022Epidemiological unit: FarmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 11 800 / 6146 / 6146 / 0 / 0 / -Affected population: NS-HPAIP-2022-001 Commercial turkey farm with 2 groups of 5900 birds each: 98% mortality in the 9-week-old birds and 6% mortality in the 3-week-old birds. The geographic coordinates do not represent the actual location of the premises.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive, contact with wild birdEpidemiological comments: On 30 Jan 2022, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) was notified of high mortality in a commercial turkey farm in Western Nova Scotia. The CFIA National Centre for Foreign Animal Disease has confirmed that the virus was H5N1, similar to the viruses reported in non-poultry and wild birds recently in the provinces of Newfoundland and Nova Scotia. The virus has HA cleavage site motif "PLREKRRK/GLF" consistent with highly pathogenic avian influenza strains of H5 subtype. The HA gene segment is A/goose/Guangdong/1996 (Gs/GD) lineage belonging to 2.3.4.4B clade. Phylogenic analysis indicates this virus corresponds to the Eurasian lineage circulating in 2021 in Europe. The CFIA has immediately quarantined the infected farm and is implementing strict movement controls and a stamping out policy. A protection zone (3 km [1.86 mi]) and a surveillance zone (10 km [6.21 mi]) are being put in place around the infected premises. Wildlife surveillance as well as the Canadian Avian Influenza Surveillance System (CanNAISS) activities for poultry are ongoing in Canada.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: Traceability; quarantine; surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and/or the protection zoneDomestic control measures to be applied: Disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; zoningWild control measures applied: Surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and/or the protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Outbreaks / Test date / ResultNational Centre for Foreign Animal Disease (NCFAD), Winnipeg, Manitoba (national laboratory) / Birds / Gene sequencing / 1 / 3 Feb 2022 / PositiveNational Centre for Foreign Animal Disease (NCFAD), Winnipeg, Manitoba (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 1 / 3 Feb 2022 / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[On 4 Feb 2022, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA) mentioned that "This situation serves as a strong reminder that avian influenza is spreading across the globe in wild birds as they migrate to and from Canada, and that anyone with poultry or other susceptible birds should practice good biosecurity habits to protect them from animal diseases" (https://bit.ly/3uvMtGj). For more information of the current situation of HPAI subtype H5N1 in Canada, see the following CFIA pages: Detection of high pathogenic avian influenza (H5N1) in Newfoundland and Labrador 2021 and Nova Scotia 2022 at https://bit.ly/3uvMtGj and Avian influenza (bird flu) at https://bit.ly/34zF65E. - Mod.CRDProMED map:Canada: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701269,12] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-02-02 15:21:00 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (32): Americas (Canada) wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220202.8701217AVIAN INFLUENZA (32): AMERICAS (CANADA) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue, 1 Feb 2022 9:37 AM ASTSource: Nova Scotia Natural Resources and Renewables [edited]https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20220201001The Department [Natural Resources and Renewables] is notifying the public that avian influenza has been detected in Nova Scotia.On Friday, [28 Jan 2022], the Canadian Food Inspection Agency confirmed a Canada goose in the Grand Desert area of Halifax Regional Municipality tested positive.Avian influenza is a viral infection that can spread easily and quickly among birds. There are at least 15 types of avian influenza. Some wild bird species, such as ducks, can carry the virus and infect other birds without getting sick themselves. Other bird species are more likely to become severely ill and die when infected with some types of avian influenza.As a general guideline, the public should not handle live, sick, or dead wild birds. People should contact the Department of Natural Resources and Renewables at 1-800-565-2224 to report sick or dead birds.The Province is working with the federal government and other agencies to monitor and respond to the situation."Avian influenza poses little risk to people, but the virus is highly infectious and potentially deadly in wild and domestic birds. We urge the public to avoid feeding or handling wild birds like ducks, geese, pheasants, pigeons, and gulls to prevent disease spread," said Bob Petrie, Director of Wildlife, Natural Resources and Renewables.Quick facts------------ Birds that meet testing criteria will be collected and sent to the lab at the Atlantic Veterinary College in Charlottetown.- Avian flu has been detected recently in other parts of Canada and the eastern United States.--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[This news report from Canada confirms that Eurasian HPAI H5 viruses are spreading in North America. From 2014 onwards HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses caused outbreaks across the Eurasian region, affecting both poultry and wild birds, with abundant genetic reassortments yielding subtypes H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8.So far, the subtype reported in the Americas is H5N1. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swans, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Numerous species of birds that migrate along Nearctic and Palearctic flyways breed in Arctic tundra regions, providing opportunities for HPAI viruses to be introduced into another continent. Thus, the migration of those species could have been the cause of the introduction of HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 into the Americas. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Grand Desert, Nova Scotia, Canada: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701217,68667] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-02-01 19:20:26 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (31): Africa (Cote d'Ivoire) HPAI H5N1, poultry, OIE Archive Number: 20220201.8701196AVIAN INFLUENZA (31): AFRICA (COTE D'IVOIRE) HPAI H5N1, POULTRY, OIE********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 31 Jan 2022Source: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) News [abridged, edited]https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2022/01/news-scan-jan-31-2022Animal health officials in Ivory Coast reported highly pathogenic H5N1 avian flu outbreaks in poultry, according to the latest notifications from the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE).Ivory Coast reported 2 separate events, both linked to the introduction of new poultry into flocks. One of the outbreaks began on 10 Nov 2021 at a layer farm in Grand-Bassam [Comoé district], about 25 miles [about 40 km] east of Abidjan. The virus killed 174 of 11 000 susceptible birds.The other event started on 21 Nov 2021 at a poultry breeding farm in Abidjan, killing 5000 of 32 000 susceptible birds.--Communicated byMary Marshall<mjm2020@googlemail.com>[The OIE-WAHIS immediate notification addressing the outbreak on a layer farm in Grand-Bassam is available, with a map, at https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=47588.The OIE-WAHIS immediate notification addressing the outbreak on a poultry breeding farm in Abidjan is available, with a map, at https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=47587.The current HPAI H5N1, which started in October 2021, has been spreading in Asia, Europe, Africa, and North America, luckily without human cases, except for a single confirmed infection in the UK.The global distribution of all outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 (red dots), officially reported since 1 Oct 2021 and as of 26 Jan 2022, are presented on the FAO/EMPRES map at https://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/Global_AIV_Zoonotic_Update/img/map1_2022_01_26.jpg. - Mod.ASProMED map:Cote d'Ivoire: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701196,52] See Also

The risk to the public is low, and people should be mindful that they properly prepare and handle meat and eggs.Avian influenza can negatively impact poultry, which can harm backyard farmers and commercial productions. The department of wildlife said people who are farming poultry should review their biosecurity efforts to keep their birds separate from possibly infected wild birds.If your birds become ill, you can report it to the State Veterinarian's Office at (804) 692-0601 or at <vastatevet@vdacs.virginia.gov>.[Byline: Emma North]--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[New reports show that Eurasian HPAI H5 viruses are spreading in North America. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Numerous species of birds that migrate along Nearctic and Palearctic flyways breed in Arctic tundra regions, providing opportunities for HPAI viruses to be introduced into another continent. Thus, migration of those species could have been the cause of the introduction of HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 into the Americas. - Mod.PMBProMED map of Virginia, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701178,247] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-31 01:59:28 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (06): Asia (China) H9N2, H5N6 Archive Number: 20220131.8701114AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): ASIA (CHINA) H9N2, H5N6****************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1] Avian influenza H9N2Date: Tue 25 Jan 2022Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]https://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-additional-h9n2-avian-influenza-case-for-2021/China reports additional H9N2 avian influenza case for 2021-----------------------------------------------------------In a follow-up to the number of H9N2 avian influenza cases reported in China in 2021, Hong Kong health officials reported an additional case this past week in a 5-year-old boy from Anhui Province. The patient had onset of disease on [13 Nov 2021].To date [24 Jan 2022], 24 cases of avian influenza A(H9N2) have been reported to WHO from China in 2021.In most human cases of H9N2 avian flu, the associated disease symptoms have been mild and there has been no evidence of human-to-human transmission. Influenza A(H9N2) viruses are enzootic in poultry populations in parts of Africa, Asia, and the Middle East.Most human cases are exposed to the A(H9N2) virus through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments. Human infection tends to result in mild clinical illness.--Communicated by:ProMED[Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Intensive surveillance should be continued to detect cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of these viruses, as the frequency of cases is increasing. - Mod.UBA]******[2] Avian influenza H5N6[A]Date: Thu 27 Jan 2022Source: The Government of Hong Kong Special Administrative Region [edited]https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202201/27/P2022012700624.htmCHP closely monitors two human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) in Mainland---------------------------------------------------------------------------The Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today [27 Jan 2022] closely monitoring 2 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) on the Mainland, and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.The 1st case involves a 68-year-old man living in Langzhong in Sichuan. He developed symptoms on [3 Jan 2022], and was admitted for treatment on [4 Jan 2022]. The patient is in critical condition.The 2nd case involves a 55-year-old woman living in Hangzhou, Zhejiang, who had exposure to slaughtered poultry before onset. She developed symptoms on [6 Jan 2022], and was admitted for treatment on [9 Jan 2022]. The patient is in critical condition.From 2014 to date [27 Jan 2022], 65 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by Mainland health authorities."All novel influenza A infections, including H5N6, are notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong," a spokesman for the CHP said.Travellers to the Mainland or other affected areas must avoid visiting wet markets, live poultry markets or farms. They should be alert to the presence of backyard poultry when visiting relatives and friends. They should also avoid purchasing live or freshly slaughtered poultry, and avoid touching poultry/birds or their droppings. They should strictly observe personal and hand hygiene when visiting any place with live poultry.Travellers returning from affected areas should consult a doctor promptly if symptoms develop, and inform the doctor of their travel history for prompt diagnosis and treatment of potential diseases. It is essential to tell the doctor if they have seen any live poultry during travel, which may imply possible exposure to contaminated environments. This will enable the doctor to assess the possibility of avian influenza and arrange necessary investigations and appropriate treatment in a timely manner.While local surveillance, prevention and control measures are in place, the CHP will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments.The public should maintain strict personal, hand, food and environmental hygiene and take heed of the advice below when handling poultry:- Avoid touching poultry, birds, animals or their droppings;- When buying live chickens, do not touch them and their droppings. Do not blow at their bottoms;- Wash eggs with detergent if soiled with faecal matter and cook and consume the eggs immediately; - Always wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling chickens and eggs;- Eggs should be cooked well until the white and yolk become firm. Do not eat raw eggs or dip cooked food into any sauce with raw eggs. Poultry should be cooked thoroughly. If there is pinkish juice running from the cooked poultry or the middle part of its bone is still red, the poultry should be cooked again until fully done;- Wash hands frequently, especially before touching the mouth, nose or eyes, before handling food or eating, and after going to the toilet, touching public installations or equipment such as escalator handrails, elevator control panels or door knobs, or when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing; and- Wear a mask if fever or respiratory symptoms develop, when going to a hospital or clinic, or while taking care of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms.--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>---[B]Date: Thu 27 Jan 2022Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-two-additional-h5n6-avian-influenza-cases-in-2022/China reports 2 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6)------------------------------------------------------The Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health reports closely monitoring two human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) in the Mainland.The 1st case involves a 68-year-old man living in Langzhong in Sichuan. He developed symptoms on [3 Jan 2022], and was admitted for treatment on [4 Jan 2022]. The patient is in critical condition.The 2nd case involves a 55-year-old woman living in Hangzhou, Zhejiang, who had exposure to slaughtered poultry before onset. She developed symptoms on [6 Jan 2022], and was admitted for treatment on [9 Jan 2022]. The patient is in critical condition.This is the 2nd and 3rd cases reported in 2022 and since 2014, 65 human cases have been reported in China.Avian influenza is caused by those influenza viruses that mainly affect birds and poultry, such as chickens or ducks. Clinical presentation of avian influenza in humans may range from flu-like symptoms (e.g. fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches) to severe respiratory illness (e.g. chest infection). Eye infection (conjunctivitis) and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g. nausea, vomiting and diarrhea) have also been reported. The incubation period ranges from 7 to 10 days. The more virulent forms can result in respiratory failure, multi-organ failure and even death.--Communicated by:ProMED[According to reports received by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), various influenza A(H5) subtypes continue to be detected in birds in Africa, Europe, and Asia. There has been an increase in the number of human H5N6 cases in 2021; at least 5 cases were confirmed in December 2021, and 3 more in January 2022 based on the information in the reports above.The identified exposures in nearly all cases are related to handling live poultry, and there appears to be an increase in transmission events. Is there more H5N6 avian influenza virus circulating in poultry and/or more importantly, is the virus now more easily transmissible? High level of vigilance and active surveillance in both animal and human health is required. - Mod.UBAProMED map:China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701114,155] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-28 15:44:35 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (27): Asia, China (Hong Kong) wild bird, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20220128.8701128AVIAN INFLUENZA (27): ASIA, CHINA (HONG KONG) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, OIE***********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 26 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=47401Influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Hong Kong--------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 21 Jan 2022Confirmed: 26 Jan 2022Reported: 26 Jan 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: [16 Dec 2021]Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, necropsy, laboratoryThis event pertains to the whole country.New outbreaksSummary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Mai Po Nature Reserve, Yuen LongStarted: 21 Jan 2022Epidemiological unit: natural parkTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedEurasian curlew (_Numenius arquata_): Scolopacidae-Charadriiformes / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: a dead Eurasian curlew was collected on [21 Jan 2022] at a gei wai in the Mai Po Nature Reserve. The species is an abundant winter visitor mainly found in the intertidal area of Deep Bay, including Mai Po, with a small number recorded in summer.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: an intensive surveillance system is in place for all poultry farms, poultry markets, and pet bird shops in Hong Kong. The H5N1 infected bird was detected in the ongoing territory wide surveillance program on wild birds. No spread of the disease was evident. There are no chicken farms within three kilometers of where the dead bird was found. The end date of the outbreak was the same as the date the bird was found (21 Jan 2022). Note: The date of the last occurrence of the H5N1 strain in wild birds in Hong Kong is 16 Dec 2021.Control measures at event levelWild control measures applied: screening; disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultTai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture Fisheries and Conservation Department national laboratory / Eurasian curlew / virus isolation / 26 Jan 2022 / positiveTai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture Fisheries and Conservation Department national laboratory / Eurasian curlew / immunohistochemistry (IHC) / 24 Jan 2022 / positiveTai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture Fisheries and Conservation Department national laboratory / Eurasian curlew / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 24 Jan 2022 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the spread and maintenance of HPAI H5N1. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. The Eurasian curlew (_Numenius arquata_) is a wader (see image at https://www.flickr.com/photos/32504429@N06/38278085466). Waders are aquatic migratory birds in the Order Charadriiformes. They also have been frequently reported infected by HPAI viruses. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Mai Po Nature Reserve, New Territories, Hong Kong: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701128,3488] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-28 02:05:25 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (26): Europe (UK) poultry, wild, HPAI H5N1, spread, assessment Archive Number: 20220128.8701123AVIAN INFLUENZA (26): EUROPE (UK) POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD, ASSESSMENT***********************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this post:[1] HPAI H5N1: poultry, Herefordshire, preventive medication of in-contact personnel[2] HPAI H5: outbreak assessment, DEFRA, conclusions******[1] HPAI H5N1: poultry, Herefordshire, preventive medication of in-contact personnelDate: Mon 24 Jan 2022Source: Hereford Times [abridged, edited]https://www.herefordtimes.com/news/19869534.herefordshire-farm-workers-given-medication-bird-flu-found/All chickens, geese and ducks at a Herefordshire small farm will be killed after bird flu was found at the site.It is the 3rd site in Herefordshire where bird flu has been confirmed this winter, with the other farms in Shobdon, near Leominster, and Clifford, near Hay-on-Wye.Dr James Chipwete, consultant in communicable disease control with the UKHSA in the West Midlands, said: "The A(H5N1) strain is highly pathogenic to poultry and other birds, which is why it is important that poultry owners stick to the Defra [Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs] guidance."While the risk to human health is considered very low, it is possible for humans to catch the virus through close contact with an infected bird, dead or alive."Therefore, it is very important that people do not touch birds infected with avian flu, their carcasses, droppings, bedding or eggs -- and infection control measures may be necessary if they do."As a precaution, the farm workers who have been in contact with the infected birds have been given a course of antiviral medication and are undergoing close monitoring for 10 days from last contact with infected birds."[Byline: James Thomas]--Communicated by: ProMED from HealthMap Alerts[According to DEFRA's recent, 11th update of the avian influenza outbreak assessment (the source of item 2), published 24 Jan 2022, 3 new outbreaks in domestic poultry have been reported in the UK since their previous update of 17 Jan 2022. One outbreak affected a commercial turkey premises in Cheshire, England while the other 2 outbreaks occurred in backyard premises, one in Herefordshire, England (covered in the above media report) and one in Aberdeenshire, Scotland. The circulation of the virus in wild birds was continuing (see commentary of item 2). There have been no further HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in Northern Ireland since 17 Jan 2022. - Mod.AS]******[2] HPAI H5: outbreak assessment, DEFRA, conclusionsDate: Mon 24 Jan 2022Source: DEFRA Outbreak Assessment #11, Ref: VITT/1200 HPAI in the UK and Europe [conclusion chapter, abridged, edited]https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1050668/hpai-europe-220124.pdfConclusion----------Cases of HPAI H5 in wild birds and outbreaks in poultry continue to be reported across Europe and also in GB since our last assessment [17 Jan 2022]. Total numbers of migrating wild water birds (ducks, geese, and some swan species) will now have peaked in GB and the majority of wintering water birds have now arrived.There have been 537 confirmed cases of HPAI H5 in wild birds in GB to 24 Jan 2022 across a range of species, including a significant number of resident sedentary birds of species such as mute swan, Canada goose and some raptors indicating that they had been exposed to infection in GB itself. Furthermore, potential bridging species such as gulls, pheasants and some raptors have tested positive. In continental Europe, corvids and sparrows which could also serve as bridging species continue to be reported as infected. A recent European Food Safety Agency (EFSA) presentation reported that between 15 Sep and 1 Dec 2021, 219 poultry HPAI outbreaks were reported across Europe (and the UK). Of these, 35% had been observed in fattening turkeys, compared to 9% during the same time period in 2020, with a large increase also observed in broilers, representing 15% of outbreaks in 2021 compared to 6% in 2020. The majority (198) of poultry HPAI outbreaks in this period were reported from commercial farms, 78 of which did not have outdoor access and raises concern regarding the stringency of applied biosecurity measures.Further virus detections are expected across northeast and southeast Europe over the coming months, following incursions from migratory waterbirds, with the epizootic potentially extending the southern and western limits observed in previous seasons.The increased rate of HPAI detection in the greylag and barnacle goose initially observed in the 2020/21 season has continued into the 2021/22 season. In light of this, EFSA is currently in the process of revising the list of target species for passive surveillance in wild birds.More wild bird HPAI H5 infections are expected in sedentary species and potential bridging species in GB. HPAI H5 will continue to circulate in both susceptible migrant water birds and sedentary bird species within GB over the next few months, with a greater number of events likely to be observed around water bird wintering sites. The risk level of HPAI H5 in wild birds is therefore maintained at VERY HIGH across GB. The risk of exposure of poultry across the whole GB is maintained at MEDIUM (with low uncertainty) where good biosecurity is applied, and at HIGH (with low uncertainty) where biosecurity is suboptimal. This assessment takes into consideration the Avian Influenza Protection Zone (AIPZ) and assumes that bird keepers are taking the additional biosecurity measures required.Authors: Dr Lorna Freath, Joe Bowen, Dr Paul Gale & Dr Lauren Perrin--Communicated by:ProMED[According to DEFRA's updated assessment, in continental Europe, since 17 Jan 2022, Germany, Hungary, Italy and Slovakia reported further outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 and Spain reported its 1st outbreak of H5N1 in domestic poultry of the current HPAI season. Wild bird HPAI H5 cases continued to be reported, since the previous assessment, in Belgium, Croatia, Denmark, France, Germany, Hungary, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Russia, Slovakia and Slovenia. The highest number of cases was reported in Denmark (38) which included a single case of HPAI H5N8. Cases of HPAI H5N1 in wild birds have been reported in Latvia for the 1st time this HPAI season.The DEFRA Outbreak Assessment includes also the following:1. Map 1, "HPAI H5 outbreaks in poultry and captive birds across the United Kingdom, October 2021 to 24 Jan 2022."2. Table 1: "Poultry and captive bird outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in Great Britain since 1 Oct 2021, as of 22 Jan 2022 (a total of 79 outbreaks)."3. Map 2: "HPAI H5 cases in wild birds across Great Britain October 2021 to 24 Jan 2022."4. Table 2: "Wild bird species in Great Britain that have tested positive for HPAI H5 as of 24 January 2022."5. Map 3: "HPAI outbreaks (from OIE) in poultry, captive, and wild birds across Europe, September 2021 to 24 Jan 2022" (flyways presented).6. Table 3: "Current outbreaks (to 24 Jan 2022) of HPAI H5 in domestic poultry and cases in wild birds since 1 Oct 2021 in Europe according to OIE report date" (31 countries including the UK).The current wave of HPAI H5N1 has spread, since October 2021, from Asia into Europe, Africa and, recently, North America (wild birds, 3 locations). FAO/EMPRES global map presenting the global distribution of AIV with zoonotic potential (H5N1 in red), observed since 1 Oct 2021 and as of 26 Jan 2022, is available at https://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/Global_AIV_Zoonotic_Update/img/map1_2022_01_26.jpg.Other AIV with zoonotic potential, presented on the map, are the HPAI viruses H5Nx and H7Nx, and the LPAI (low pathogenic avian influenza) viruses are H5Nx, H6N1, H7Nx, H9N2, H10N7 & H10N8. - Mod.ASProMED map:United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701123,40] See Also

2022Epidemiological unit: otherTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedCape cormorant (_Phalacrocorax capensis_): Phalacrocoracidae-Trogoniformes / - / 35 / 33 / - / - / -EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild speciesEpidemiological comments: during active and passive surveillance, wild birds are the ones affected thus far. The ones that are mainly affected are the Cape cormorants, with a few other wild birds also affected including pelicans. Active and passive surveillance is currently on going to determine the extent of the outbreak. The common clinical signs found on the affected wild birds are tremors/shivering, staggering movements and swollen heads. Some sick birds showed signs of tameness and reluctance to flee from humans. Follow up reports will be submitted as soon as updates are received.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: movement control inside the country, quarantine, surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone, ante and post-mortem inspectionsWild control measures applied: official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, official destruction of animal products, disinfection, surveillance within containment and/or the protection zoneDiagnostic test results:Laboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultCentral Veterinary Laboratory (CVL) (National Laboratory) / birds / 2 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 24 Jan 2022 / positive[The locations of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive maps included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[Officially reported HPAI outbreaks (H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8 subtypes) in Sub-Saharan Africa, by date of onset (1 Oct 2021-12 Jan 2022), can be seen at https://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/img/map1_2022_01_12.jpgSub-Saharan Africa HPAI situation update until 12 Jan 2022 is available at https://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/situation_update.html. - Mod.CRDProMED maps:Burkina Faso: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701122,49Namibia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8701122,163] See Also

HPAI subtype H5N1 was detected in a pigeon (_Columba livia domestica_) found dead in the port of Pollen in Arendal, Agder and in a white-tailed eagle (_Haliaeetus albicilla_) found dead on the island of Borilden in Austrheim, Vestland. [The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED******[2] Germany (Hessen): wild bird, HPAI H5N1Date: Thu 20 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=46896Event started on 19 Jan 2022. HPAI subtype H5N1 was detected on 19 Jan 2020 in a Anatidae (unidentified) in Langenselbold, Main-Kinzing-Kreis, Hessen.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED******[3] Latvia (Riga): wild bird, HPAI H5N1Date: Wed 19 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=46897Event started and confirmed on 17 Jan 2022. A total of 2 outbreaks (submitted) has been reported to date [22 Jan 2022]. HPAI subtype H5N1 was detected in 6 mute swans (_Cygnus olor_).Epidemiological comments: 6 dead wild birds (mute swans, _Cygnus olor_) were found on the coast of Daugava River in the Salaspils county and Riga City. Sampling of mute swans have been performed in the framework of enhanced passive surveillance program. Samples were submitted to the National Reference Laboratory of Latvia for laboratory testing to HPAI, and on [17 Jan 2022] HPAI (H5N1) was confirmed in all 6 mute swans by RT-PCR.[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[A map of HPAI detections in Europe during the period of 1 Oct 2021 to 20 Jan 2022 can be seen athttps://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2022/Map_AI_EU_2022-01-20.jpg. - Mod.CRDSince October 2020, Europe has experienced the most severe avian influenza epidemic to date. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in its spread and maintenance. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. - Mod.PMB] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-23 18:46:46 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (05): Asia (China) H9N2 Archive Number: 20220123.8700993AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (05): ASIA (CHINA) H9N2**********************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 14 Jan 2022Source: World Health Organization (Avian influenza weekly update 827) [edited]https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20220114.pdf? sfvrsn= 223ca73f _176Human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) virus--------------------------------------------------Between 7 and 13 Jan 2022, 4 new cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) were reported from China to WHO in the Western Pacific Region.The 1st case is a 7 year old schoolgirl from Zhenjiang City, Jiangsu Province who became ill on 27 Nov 2021. The 2nd case is a 3 year old girl from Huanggang City, Hubei Province who became ill on 7 Dec 2021. The 3rd case is a 14 year old schoolgirl from Nanning City, Guangxi Province who became ill on 9 Dec 2021. The case was hospitalized with a mild condition on 9 Dec 2021. The 4th case is a 3 year old boy from Huanggang City, Hubei Province who became ill on 13 Dec 2021.All of the 4 cases were mild and had already recovered from the disease at the time of reporting to WHO. Before illness onset, the cases had been exposed to poultry. No family members have developed symptoms at the time of reporting. Following investigations, no epidemiological links have been determined among the 4 cases.To date, 24 cases of avian influenza A(H9N2) have been reported to WHO from China in 2021, and a total of 65 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) including 2 deaths (both with underlying conditions) have been reported to WHO in the Western Pacific Region since December 2015. The last case was reported from China with onset date of 13 Dec 2021.--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[Avian H9N2 influenza A viruses have caused repeated human infections in Asia since 1998. Among the earlier cases, an H9N2 influenza virus infected a 5 year old child in Hong Kong in 2003.Influenza A(H9N2) viruses are enzootic in poultry populations in parts of Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. Most human cases are exposed to the A(H9N2) virus through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments. Human infection tends to result in mild clinical illness. The dates of onset for the 4 cases in the report above are in November and December 2021, technically adding these cases to last year's (2021) case count , bringing the total for A/H9N2 cases reported from China to 24. The continued presence of H9N2 influenza viruses in poultry markets in southern China increases the likelihood of avian-to-human interspecies transmission as evidenced by the history of poultry exposure in the cases reported here. - Mod.UBAProMED map:China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700993,155] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-20 17:34:37 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (22): Americas (USA) wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20220120.8700990AVIAN INFLUENZA (22): AMERICAS (USA) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1*********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 18 Jan 2022Source: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/world/us/us-identifies-bird-flu-strain-found-south-carolina-duck-2022-01-18/The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) reported 2 more cases of highly pathogenic avian flu in wild birds on Tuesday [18 Jan 2022], raising risks for potential infections in poultry.The USDA on Friday [14 Jan 2022] reported the nation's first case of a Eurasian H5 type of the virus since 2016 and on Tuesday [18 Jan 2022] said that all 3 cases are the H5N1 strain. That strain has caused a wave of outbreaks of bird flu in poultry across Europe and Asia. H5N1 is one of the few bird flu strains that has passed to humans, though US officials said there was a low risk to people from the case confirmed on Friday [14 Jan 2022].The infections are disappointing because it is rare for a Eurasian strain to make its way to North America, said Carol Cardona, a professor of avian health at the University of Minnesota. "Avian influenza viruses tend to stay in their hemisphere," she said. The latest US cases were in Colleton County in South Carolina, where Friday's infection was found in a wild duck, and in Hyde County in North Carolina, the USDA said.Wild birds can transmit avian flu to each other or to poultry through direct contact and through their feathers or feces. "These findings are not unexpected, as wild birds can be infected with HPAI and show no signs of illness," the USDA said. "They can carry the disease to new areas when migrating." The USDA advised poultry producers to review safety measures to assure the health of their flocks and said people should wear gloves when dealing with wild birds.Cardona said poultry producers need to make sure the virus cannot enter their barns. "Poultry producers are going to be busy this spring," she said. "They have to check the doors and windows every day, twice a day, 10 times a day."The World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) said on Tuesday [18 Jan 2022] that Spain reported an outbreak of H5N1 bird flu on a farm north of Madrid.[byline: Tom Polansek]--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[From 2014 onwards HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses caused outbreaks across the Eurasian region, affecting both poultry and wild birds, with abundant genetic reassortments yielding subtypes H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds have contributed to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Numerous species of birds that migrate along Nearctic and Palearctic flyways breed in tundra regions of the Arctic, providing opportunities for HPAI viruses to be introduced to another continent. Thus, migration of those species could have been the cause of the introduction of HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 into the Americas. - Mod.PMBProMED maps:Colleton County, South Carolina, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700990,13112Hyde County, North Carolina, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700990,14214] See Also

A total of one outbreak (submitted) has been reported to date [18 Jan 2022]. HPAI subtype H5N1 was detected in a backyard holding in settlement Sulby, Ayre, Isle of Man.Affected population: small flock of 42 ornamental ducks and geese. Clinical signs and increased mortality reported. Official samples were H5N1 HPAI positive.Epidemiological comments: This is the 1st confirmed case of H5N1 HPAI in the Isle of Man. Epidemiological investigation ongoing.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED[For further information, the United Kingdom's latest avian influenza situation is available at https://www.gov.uk/guidance/avian-influenza-bird-flu#latest-situation (last updated 18 Jan 2022). - Mod.CRDProMED map of Isle of Man: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700957,575]******[2] Spain (Castilla and Leon): poultry, HPAI H5N1Date: Tue 18 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=46825Event started on 13 Jan 2022 and was confirmed on 18 Jan 2022. A total of one outbreak (submitted) has been reported to date [18 Jan 2022]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a fattening turkey farm with a census of 18 900 turkeys 10 weeks of age. The farm is located in Fuenterrebollo, Cantalejo, province of Segovia, community of Castilla and Leon.Epidemiological comments: The epidemiological survey conducted on the farm indicates that all the birds were brought onto the farm for fattening at the beginning of November 2021, with no animal movements outside the farm since then. A restriction zone has been established around the outbreak: 3 km [1.9 mi] protection zone and 10 km [6.2 mi] surveillance zone.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED[Spain has a National Program for the Surveillance of Avian Influenza (2022), https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/sanidad-animal-higiene-ganadera/programadevigilanciaia2022final_tcm30-437512.pdf in Spanish). The program is based on the recommendations established in the EU Commission decision 2010/367 (https://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2010:166:0022:0032:EN:PDF).Further information regarding avian influenza in Spain can be found at https://www.mapa.gob.es/es/ganaderia/temas/sanidad-animal-higiene-ganadera/sanidad-animal/enfermedades/influenza-aviar/influenza_aviar.aspx.An outbreak map of HPAI in Europe from 1 Oct 2021 to 17 Jan 2022 is available at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2022/Map_AI_EU_2022-01-17.jpg. - Mod.CRDProMED map of Segovia, Castille and Leon, Spain: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700957,4941.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-17 21:36:42 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (18): H7N9 & H9N2 reassortment, zoonotic potential Archive Number: 20220117.8700933AVIAN INFLUENZA (18): AI H7N9 AND AI H9N2 REASSORTMENT, ZOONOTIC POTENTIAL**************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 14 Jan 2022Source: PoultryMed [in Hebrew, trans., edited]https://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=2&TMID=178&FID=14797&PID=0&IID=43460A new study published in the scientific Journal of Virology [see reference below] examined the combined infection of birds with H9N2 and H7N9 avian influenza viruses. The H7N9 avian influenza virus appeared in China in 2013 as a low-pathogenicity virus, initially being asymptomatic in birds or accompanied by mild disease. In contrast, the virus was zoonotic and presented a respiratory manifestation in humans with a considerable infectivity from bird to human. The subclinical presentation in poultry made it very difficult, for the health authorities, to control the spread of the virus in the human population in China.The combined infection, carried out by British researchers, produced 2 H9N2 and H9N9 viruses. The H9N9 virus presented high replication in human cells and in ferrets, the human-compatible model for influenza virus research.The study warns of the possibility of "new" influenza viruses following the endemic status of H9N2 and H7N9 viruses in China: viruses that will be more pathogenic to birds and have a high zoonotic potential.--communicated byProMED[The reference for the 'accepted manuscript' above, authored by researchers from The Pirbright Institute, Woking, Surrey, and the Animal & Plant Health Agency, Weybridge, UK, published online 12 Jan 2022, is:Bhat S, James J, Sadeyen JR, et al. Co-infection of chickens with H9N2 and H7N9 avian influenza viruses leads to emergence of reassortant H9N9 virus with increased fitness for poultry and a zoonotic potential. J Virol 2022; https://journals.asm.org/doi/10.1128/jvi.01856-21.The paper's "Importance" section follows:"We evaluated the consequences of reassortment between the H7N9 and the contemporary H9N2 viruses of G1 lineage that are enzootic in poultry across the Indian sub-continent and the Middle East. Co-infection of chickens with these viruses resulted in emergence of novel reassortant H9N9 viruses with genes derived from both H9N2 and H7N9 viruses. The '6+2' reassortant H9N9 (having NP and NA from H7N9) virus was shed from contact chickens in a significantly higher proportion compared to most of the reassortant viruses, showed significantly increased replication fitness in human A549 cells, receptor binding towards human (α2,6) and avian (α2,3) sialic acid receptor analogues and the potential to transmit via contact among ferrets. This study demonstrated the ability of viruses that already exist in nature to exchange genetic material, highlighting the potential emergence of viruses from these subtypes with zoonotic potential."While the world's attention has been paid during the 2 recent years to the COVID-19 pandemic, the experimental results above as well as other viruses with zoonotic potential already afield should be kept in mind. The current panzootic of HPAI H5N1, a virus that managed to spread within 2-3 months by/to wild and domestic birds in 4 continents, including (sporadic) infections in mammals, is an actual reminder. - Mod.AS] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-17 22:22:20 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (19): Americas (USA) wild bird, HPAI H5, OIE Archive Number: 20220117.8700932AVIAN INFLUENZA (19): AMERICAS (USA) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5, OIE************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 14 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=46688Influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), USA----------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 30 Dec 2021Confirmed: 13 Jan 2022Reported: 14 Jan 2022Reason for notification: new strain in a zone or a compartmentCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5Nature of diagnosis: laboratory testThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Colleton County, South CarolinaStarted: 30 Dec 2021Epidemiological unit: not applicableAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedAmerican wigeon (_Anas americana_): Anatidae-Anseriformes/ - / 1 / - / - / - / -Affected population: wild hunter-harvested American wigeon (_Anas americana_)EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: migratory waterfowl.Epidemiological comments: On [13 Jan 2022], the National Veterinary Services Laboratories (NVSL) confirmed goose/Guangdong lineage H5 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) by partial sequencing of the HA gene from a sample collected as part of the APHIS Wildlife Services Avian Influenza Surveillance in wild birds. APHIS WS collected the sample on [30 Dec 2021] from a hunter harvested American wigeon in Colleton County, South Carolina. The Clemson Veterinary Diagnostic Center (a member of the National Animal Health Laboratory Network) initially tested the sample and forwarded the non-negative H5 sample to NVSL for confirmation. Full genome sequence is in process. According to article 10.4.1.4 of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code, member countries should not impose bans on the international trade of poultry commodities in response to notification of infection with any influenza A viruses in birds other than poultry.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultNational Veterinary Services Laboratories (NVSL), Ames, Iowa (National Laboratory) / American wigeon / 1 / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 13 Jan 2022 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED[Readers will be interested to review a webinar titled "US poultry industry stakeholder update: H5 HPAI in North America", that the US Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service hosted recently (January 2022). This webinar consists of a panel of avian health experts who discussed the recent Canadian highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) detection, APHIS communication and current agreement with the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA), new HPAI restrictions for pet birds from Canada, 2022 US wild bird avian influenza (AI) surveillance plans, as well as US poultry AI surveillance and the importance of biosecurity for prevention of AI outbreaks.The recorded webinar is available at https://youtu.be/7OcY7cnpZc4. - Mod.CRDProMED map:South Carolina, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700932,242] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-17 17:24:17 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (18): H7N9 & H9N2 reassortment, zoonotic potential Archive Number: 20220117.8700929AVIAN INFLUENZA (18): AI H7N9 AND AI H9N2 REASSORTMENT, ZOONOTIC POTENTIAL**************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 14 Jan 2022Source: PoultryMed [in Hebrew, trans., edited]https://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=2&TMID=178&FID=14797&PID=0&IID=43460A new study published in the scientific Journal of Virology [see reference below] examined the combined infection of birds with H9N2 and H7N9 avian influenza viruses.The H7N9 avian influenza virus appeared in China in 2013 as a low-pathogenicity virus, initially being asymptomatic in birds or accompanied by mild disease. In contrast, the virus was zoonotic and presented a respiratory manifestation in humans with a considerable infectivity from bird to human. The subclinical presentation in poultry made it very difficult, for the health authorities, to control the spread of the virus in the human population in China.The combined infection, carried out by British researchers, produced 2 H9N2 and H9N9 viruses. The H9N9 virus presented high replication in human cells and in ferrets, the human-compatible model for influenza virus research.The study warns of the possibility of "new" influenza viruses following the endemic status of H9N2 and H7N9 viruses in China: viruses that will be more pathogenic to birds and have a high zoonotic potential.--communicated byProMED[The reference for the 'accepted manuscript' above, authored by researchers from The Pirbright Institute, Woking, Surrey, and the Animal & Plant Health Agency, Weybridge, UK, published online 12 Jan 2022, is:Bhat S, James J, Sadeyen JR, et al. Co-infection of chickens with H9N2 and H7N9 avian influenza viruses leads to emergence of reassortant H9N9 virus with increased fitness for poultry and a zoonotic potential. J Virol 2022; https://journals.asm.org/doi/10.1128/jvi.01856-21.The paper's "Importance" section follows:"We evaluated the consequences of reassortment between the H7N9 and the contemporary H9N2 viruses of G1 lineage that are enzootic in poultry across the Indian sub-continent and the Middle East. Co-infection of chickens with these viruses resulted in emergence of novel reassortant H9N9 viruses with genes derived from both H9N2 and H7N9 viruses. The '6+2' reassortant H9N9 (having NP and NA from H7N9) virus was shed from contact chickens in a significantly higher proportion compared to most of the reassortant viruses, showed significantly increased replication fitness in human A549 cells, receptor binding towards human (α2,6) and avian (α2,3) sialic acid receptor analogues and the potential to transmit via contact among ferrets. This study demonstrated the ability of viruses that already exist in nature to exchange genetic material, highlighting the potential emergence of viruses from these subtypes with zoonotic potential."While the world's attention has been paid during the 2 recent years to the COVID-19 pandemic, the experimental results above as well as other viruses with zoonotic potential already afield should be kept in mind. The current panzootic of HPAI H5N1, a virus that managed to spread within 2-3 months by/to wild and domestic birds in 4 continents, including (sporadic) infections in mammals, is an actual reminder. - Mod.AS] See Also
