View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-17 22:15:10 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (04): Asia (China) H5N6 Archive Number: 20220117.8700903AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (04): ASIA (CHINA) H5N6**********************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 15 Jan 2022Source: News-24 [in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited]https://news-24.fr/la-grippe-aviaire-craint-alors-que-la-chine-signale-deux-deces-apres-cinq-nouveaux-cas-de-h5n6-alors-que-loms-appelle-a-une-action-urgente/China has reported 2 avian influenza deaths among 5 new confirmed cases of H5N6. The World Health Organzation has called for "urgent" action. A rise in the number of people infected with avian influenza in China last year [2021] has raised concern among experts, who have warned that the strain could be more infectious to humans. Two people in China have now died of bird flu; the other 3 remain in hospital.Hong Kong's health department said 5 people in Sichuan province, Zhejiang province and Guangxi autonomous region were infected with the bird flu strain in December last year [2021].One of the two who died was a 75 year old man from Luzhou in Sichuan Province. He fell ill on [1 Dec 2021] after being exposed to live domestic poultry. He was rushed to hospital 4 days later and died on [12 Dec 2021]. The other was a 54 year old man from Leshan in the same province. He became ill on [8 Dec 2021] and died 3 weeks later on [24 Dec 2021]. He too was reportedly exposed to live domestic fowl.A 51 year old woman from Hangzhou in Zhejiang province fell ill on [15 Dec 2021] after being exposed to live domestic poultry. She was taken to hospital on [18 Dec 2021] and authorities said she was in a critical condition. The other 2 cases were recorded in Liuzhou, a city in Guangxi Autonomous Region, the Hong Kong health department said. A 53 year old man with a history of exposure to dead poultry fell ill on [19 Dec 2021] and remains hospitalized in a serious condition. A 28 year old man from the same city became ill on [23 Dec 2021] and is believed to be in a critical condition. It was not immediately clear how he had become infected. Since 2014, 65 people have been infected with the H5N6 bird flu - over half of them in the past 6 months.WHO says most of the cases had been in contact with poultry and no cases of human-to-human transmission have been confirmed. But WHO says further investigation is "urgent" to understand the risk and understand the growing number of human cases.Thijs Kuiken, professor of comparative pathology at Erasmus University Medical Center Rotterdam, previously warned: "The increase in human cases in China this year [2021] is concerning. It is a virus that causes high mortality. "It could be that this variant is a little more infectious (for people)... or there could be more of this virus in poultry right now and that is why more people are infected."Warning to travellers---------------------China is the world's largest producer of poultry and the top producer of ducks, which act as a reservoir for flu viruses. Backyard farms in China are still common and many people still prefer to buy live chickens from markets. Although avian influenza viruses constantly circulate among domestic and wild birds, they rarely infect humans. But the evolution of the viruses, which have increased as poultry populations increase, is a major concern because they could turn into a virus that spreads easily between people and cause a pandemic. In November last year [2021], British health authorities issued a travel warning to China about the risk of bird flu. Dr Gavin Dabrera, consultant in acute respiratory infections at UKHSA, said: "Anyone visiting China should avoid exposure to birds or live birds in 'wet markets' as a precautionary measure. "We continue to encourage people to avoid touching dead or dying birds and to maintain good hand hygiene when traveling. Bird flu remains a risk in China and if travelers experience flu-like symptoms within 10 days of returning from China they should call their GP or NHS 111 and report their recent travel."[byline: Delmary Delmar]--communicated by:ProMED[Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk of sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Intensive surveillance should be continued to detect cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of these viruses, as the frequency of cases is increasing.According to reports received by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), various influenza A(H5) subtypes continue to be detected in birds in Africa, Europe, and Asia. There has been an increase in the number of human H5N6 cases in 2021 and at least 5 cases were confirmed in December 2021. The identified exposures in nearly all cases are related to handling live poultry, and there appears to be an increase in transmission events... Is there more H5N6 avian influenza virus circulating in poultry and/or more importantly, is the virus now more easily transmissible? Important questions Indeed! - Mod.UBAProMED map:Guangxi Autonomous Region, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700903,355] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-16 17:56:29 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (17): Asia (Israel) HPAI H5N1, wild bird, poultry, epidemiology Archive Number: 20220116.8700909AVIAN INFLUENZA (17): ASIA (ISRAEL) HPAI H5N1, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, EPIDEMIOLOGY*******************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 14 Jan 2022Source: Haaretz [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, abridged, edited]https://www.haaretz.co.il/nature/1.10538475The Ministry of Agriculture announced today [14 Jan 2022] that control has been gained over the outbreak of the bird flu that has hit hard the crane population in the Agamon Hahula area and led to the culling of poultry in farms of northern Israel. This week (16-21 Jan 2022) professionals are expected to concentrate their efforts on cleaning, disinfecting and monitoring the flu.Most of the crane carcasses have already been disposed of. In the coming weeks, monitoring operations will be conducted at the site to make sure there are none left. If conditions allow, the site will be reopened to visitors within a few weeks.The 1st case of the disease in the current outbreak was discovered in a pelican in the north of the country that was apparently infected from contact with migratory birds. The disease then spread to cranes and from there to chicken coops in other areas. About one million chickens had to be killed.During an online meeting of experts held this week at the initiative of the Steinhardt Museum of Nature at Tel Aviv University [see further in the commentary], the director of the Veterinary Services, Dr. Tamir Goshen, indicated that there is a problem with the biosafety level of layer coops in Israel and that they are far from meeting the requirements accepted in developed countries. One of the examples Goshen provided was the ease with which visitors can enter coops in the country, creating risk of infection. Another problem presented was the deficient monitoring activity in wild birds, including systematic collection of wild birds to be tested. The Director of the Science Division at the Nature and Parks Authority, Dr. Yehoshua Shakedi said that the authority has a plan to deal with the issue, but it has not yet been funded. The Ministry of Agriculture has announced that it will formulate a recovery plan and preparations for the next migratory season of wild birds.The ministry noted that avian flu is introduced every year into Israel but its spread during the current season was exceptional and that the virus strain found this year [2022] -- H5N1 -- is regarded hazardous to humans. An expert committee has been assigned by Israel's National Emergency Management Authority (NEMA) to formulate recommendations concerning the preparations for possible future bird flu outbreaks, to include also re-examination of the management of the Agamon Hahula site. This site has become one of Israel's leading attractions as far as number of visitors is concerned. Every year, flocks counting tens of thousands birds arrive at this site. Nature conservation bodies will be required to examine the cranes' feeding policy as applied on the site in order to prevent them from flying to nearby agricultural fields, damaging crops. This policy has led to an increase in the number of migrating birds who remain in the country and do not migrate further to Africa.[Byline: Zafrir Rinat]--Communicated by: ProMED[The mentioned online (zoom) webinar was held by the Tel Aviv University's Museum of Natural History on 11 Jan 2022. It was titled, "How can we prepare for the next wave?" An introductory presentation, based on information from the National Veterinary Services (poultry health division) and, for wild birds, from the Nature and Parks Authority, included the following Outstanding Loss: 1. Poultry: More than 1.1 million birds culled in more than 20 poultry farms.2. Wild birds: a. Common cranes (_Grus grus_, over-wintering) - about 8000 dead birds at the Agamon Hula; all 28 tested birds were H5N1 positive.b. Great white pelican (_Pelecanus onocrotalus_, over-wintering) - tens of dead birds observed, all 7 tested birds were H5N1 positive.c. Eurasian kestrel (_Falco tinnunculus_, mostly resident) - some dead birds observed, all 4 tested birds were H5N1 positive.d. Common buzzard (_Buteo buteo_, over-wintering) - some dead birds observed, 3 or 4 tested birds were H5N1 positive.e. Marbled teal (_Marmaronetta angustirostris_, resident) - one dead bird collected, tested positive for H5N1. Ran Nathan, of the Movement Ecology Lab, Hebrew University, presented the continuous follow-up of tagged cranes from Russia from 1 Dec 2021 to 10 Jan 2022. In 4 of the 10 tagged cranes, measurements indicative of affected health were recorded, eventually terminating in death. The points in time, for each of the 4 adult animals (3-4 years old; 3 males and one female) were presented: a. Beginning of disease according to ODBA (Overall Dynamic Body Acceleration, reflecting energetic expenditure); b. Beginning of disease according to movements; c. bird death. In addition, the date of the beginning of diversionary feeding (obviously, similar for all 4 birds) was included. ODBA seems to be the earliest predictor of disease; the earliest case started 13 December 2021. Notably, the 1st outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 on poultry farms were recorded in mid-November 2021 (in central and southern Israel), thus a month before the start of the crane epizootic in the north. The webinar included also presentations of invited guest speakers: David Swayne, USDA, ARS, USA; Susan Shriner, USDA, National Wildlife Research Center, USA and Thijs Kuiken, Dep Virology, Erasmus Medical Centre, The Netherlands.In case a recording of the webinar's presentations becomes available online, ProMED will publish the link. A video recording of sick cranes in Agamon Hahula (taken 24 Dec 2021) is available at https://youtu.be/MaWuOoiNd3A. - Mod.ASProMED map:Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700909,90] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-15 02:43:01 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (16): Europe, wild bird, poultry, HPAI H5N1, H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20220115.8700874AVIAN INFLUENZA (16): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, H5N8, OIE**********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] Croatia (Osjecko-Baranjska): backyard, HPAI H5N1[2] Finland (South Finland): wild bird, HPAI H5N1[3] Denmark (Central Jutland): poultry, HPAI H5N8[4] Spain (Cataluña): wild bird, HPAI H5N1******[1] Croatia (Osjecko-Baranjska): backyard, HPAI H5N1Date: Fri 14 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=46550Event started on 10 Jan 2022 and was confirmed on 14 Jan 2022. A total of one outbreak (submitted) has been reported to date [14 Jan 2022]. HPAI subtype H5N1 was detected in a backyard holding in settlement Branjin Vrh, municipality of Beli Manastir, county of Osjecko-Baranjska.Affected population: Holdings with 40 laying hens, 3 ducks and 9 ornamental pigeons.Epidemiological comments: On the holding with total 52 mixed species of poultry, 13 animals died. Five carcasses were sampled and tested and influenza A virus, subtype H5N1 was confirmed on 14 Jan 2022, on 12 Jan 2022 and on 13 Jan 2022. Establishment is located near the water surfaces in settlement Branjin Vrh, municipality Beli Manastir. Contact with wild birds cannot be excluded. Preventive culling of all poultry on the affected establishment is implemented. Implementation of disease control measures according to the Delegated Regulation 2020/687 as well as epidemiological investigation is ongoing.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED******[2] Finland (South Finland): wild bird, HPAI H5N1Date: Fri 14 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=46540Event started on 25 Dec 2021 and was confirmed on 29 Dec 2021. A total of 2 outbreaks (submitted) have been reported to date [14 Jan 2022]. HPAI subtype H5N1 was detected in a mallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_) and in a greater white-fronted goose (_Anser albifrons_). The location of the outbreaks is Helsinki, Uusimaa region, South Finland.Epidemiological comments: The date of last occurrence of H5N1 strain in Finland was 14 Nov 2021.[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED******[3] Denmark (Central Jutland): poultry, HPAI H5N8Date: Thu 13 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=46437Event started on 6 Jan 2022. A total of one outbreak (submitted) has been reported to date [14 Jan 2022], located in Stoholm, Viborg. The municipality of Viborg is located in the Central Jutland region.On 6 Jan 2022, a clinical suspicion (increased mortality) was reported to the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration. The population of the holding consist of approximately 100 000 laying hens for egg consumption. On 7 Jan 2022, highly pathogenic avian influenza (subtype H5N8) was confirmed by the national reference laboratory. The culling of all susceptible animals at the holding was completed on 8 Jan 2022. The cleaning and disinfection were approved by the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration on 11 Jan 2022.The Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has established zones of 3 and 10 km [1.8 and 6.2 mi] around the holding and is implementing the necessary measures in accordance with the European Union Animal Health Law. Note: The date of last occurrence of the H5N8 strain in poultry birds in Denmark is 7 Jul 2021.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[A presentation of the latest HPAI situation in Denmark, on 13 Jan 2022, is available at https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2022-01/reg-com_ahw_20220113_hpai_dan.pdf. - Mod.CRD]******[4] Spain (Cataluña): wild bird, HPAI H5N1Date: Wed 12 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=46329Event started on 22 Dec 2021. A total of one outbreak (submitted) has been reported to date [14 Jan 2022]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in a white stork (_Ciconia ciconia_) and 4 mute swans (_Cygnus olor_). The birds were found dead in Soses, municipality of Segria (Lleida), province of Lleida, community of Cataluña.Epidemiological comments: Swab samples from the birds found dead were sent for analysis to the IRTA-CReSA laboratory, where positive results were obtained by PCR for avian influenza virus subtype H5. These results were confirmed by the national reference laboratory for avian influenza in Spain (LCV of Algete), determining that it was an HPAI H5N1 strain.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[The citation and abstract from a scientific report on avian influenza in the EU/EEA and UK, published 22 Dec 2021, follow:European Food Safety Authority, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and European Union Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza. Avian influenza overview September - December 2021; https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/AI-Report-XVIII_draft_published.pdf--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Abstract --------"Between 16 Sep 2021 and 8 Dec 2021, 867 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus detections were reported in 27 EU/EEA countries and the UK in poultry (316), in wild (523) and in captive birds (28). The detections in poultry were mainly reported by Italy (167) followed by Hungary and Poland (35 each). The majority of the detections in wild birds were reported by Germany (280), Netherlands (65) and United Kingdom (53). The observed persistence and continuous circulation of HPAI viruses in migratory and resident wild birds will continue to pose a risk for the poultry industry in Europe for the coming months. The frequent occurrence of HPAI A(H5) incursions in commercial farms (including poultry production types considered at low avian influenza risk) raises concern about the capacity of the applied biosecurity measures to prevent virus introduction. Short-term preparedness and medium- and long-term prevention strategies, including revising and reinforcing biosecurity measures, reduction of the density of commercial poultry farms and possible appropriate vaccination strategies, should be implemented. The results of the genetic analysis indicate that the viruses characterised during this reporting period belong to clade 2.3.4.4b. Some of the characterized HPAI A(H5N1) viruses detected in Sweden, Germany, Poland and United Kingdom are related to the viruses which have been circulating in Europe since October 2020; in North, Central, South and East Europe novel reassortant A(H5N1) virus has been introduced starting from October 2021. HPAI A(H5N1) was also detected in wild mammal species in Sweden, Estonia and Finland; some of these strains characterised so far present an adaptive marker that is associated with increased virulence and replication in mammals. Since the last report, 13 human infections due to HPAI A(H5N6) and 2 human cases due to LPAI A(H9N2) virus have been reported from China. Some of these A(H5N6) cases were caused by a reassortant virus of clade 2.3.4.4b, which possessed an HA gene closely related to the A(H5) viruses circulating in Europe. The risk of infection for the general population in the EU/EEA is assessed as low, and for occupationally exposed people, low to medium, with large uncertainty due to the high diversity of circulating viruses in the bird populations."An outbreak map of HPAI in Europe from 8 Oct 2021 to 14 Jan 2022 is available at https://izsvenezie.com/documents/reference-laboratories/avian-influenza/europe-updates/HPAI/2021-1/maps.pdf. Due to Brexit implementation, the United Kingdom is not included in this map; see https://www.gov.uk/guidance/avian-influenza-bird-flu#latest-situation (last updated 14 Jan 2022) for further information. - Mod.CRDProMED map:Europe: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700874,6010] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-14 03:09:31 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (15): Americas (Canada) poultry  Archive Number: 20220114.8700858AVIAN INFLUENZA (15): AMERICAS (CANADA) POULTRY***********************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 12 Jan 2022Source: CBC [edited]https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/avian-flu-spread-newfoundland-1.6310954A deadly strain of avian influenza has spread to a 2nd location in Newfoundland. Federal officials confirmed Sunday [9 Jan 2022] H5N1 bird flu killed chickens in a small backyard flock.The Canadian Food Inspection Agency [CFIA] says avian flu has killed chickens at a small, backyard farm on the Avalon Peninsula. "This backyard flock owner had just a few chickens and ducks," Dr. Mary-Jane Ireland, the agency's chief veterinary officer, told CBC News on Tuesday [11 Jan 2022]. Last week, CBC News reported Lester's Farm Chalet in St. John's is the first operation that lost hundreds of birds to avian flu before Christmas. More than 350 birds died there and another 60 birds, including geese, peacocks and an emu, were euthanized in an effort to contain the virus.The CFIA says 17 birds died at the 2nd location. Three were hens that were killed by the virus and the rest were ducks which were euthanized.Ireland said both locations had ponds where farm birds could mingle with wild birds, and both owners had chickens dying suddenly.The CFIA euthanized the surviving birds and drew out a 10-kilometre control zone around both facilities, putting them under quarantine. The agency says it continues to monitor wild and domestic birds through surveillance and sampling. Federal officials say they are also contacting farms and people with birds in the area to ask if any birds are showing signs of the disease.Ireland says the H5N1 strain of avian influenza which was identified can, on rare occasions, cause disease in humans."It's almost always acquired through direct contact with infected birds and contaminated environments. Most human cases are limited to mild symptoms, like mild respiratory disease," said Ireland."Some (avian flu) viruses can cause severe illness. So public health officials are recommending people avoid handling live or dead birds and they are also recommending against the feeding of wild birds like ducks, gulls and pigeons at local parks."Ireland said the strain at the 2 locations has also been identified in wild birds in Newfoundland."Through wild bird surveillance that has been undertaken by Environment and Climate Change Canada and the Canadian Wildlife Health Cooperative, we found 2 birds with the same virus. So we know it is in some wild birds we have sampled," she said.Ireland called on people who keep birds to take steps to prevent them from becoming infected."Whether you are a commercial poultry facility or whether you own a small, backyard flock, make sure you are keeping your domestic birds away from areas frequented by wild birds and maintain strict control over access to your birds and chicken coops," she said. "Make sure equipment is cleaned and disinfected before taking it into your chicken coops or enclosures."The CFIA suspects the source of infection at the 2 Avalon Peninsula locations is wild, aquatic, long-range, migratory birds but don't believe the virus has spread to the rest of Canada or North America."There have been a number of outbreaks in Europe at commercial operations and in wild birds but we do not have evidence it is in other locations," said Ireland.[Byline: Mark Quinn]--Communicated by:ProMED[Hopefully, this disease is quickly contained and does not spread any further."AI viruses are classified by a combination of 2 groups of proteins: the hemagglutinin, or H proteins, of which there are 16 (H1-H16), and neuraminidase, or N proteins, of which there are 9 (N1-N9). Many strains of avian influenza (AI) virus exist worldwide. These viruses affect chickens, turkeys, pheasants, quail, ducks, geese, and guinea fowl as well as a wide variety of free-flying species. Migratory waterfowl have been shown to be a natural reservoir for AI. AI strains also are divided into 2 groups based upon the ability of the virus to produce disease."Low pathogenicity or "low path" avian influenza (LPAI)LPAI occurs naturally in wild birds and can spread to domestic birds. In most cases it causes no signs of infection or only minor symptoms in birds. These strains of the disease pose little significant threat to human health. These strains are common in the US and around the world."Highly pathogenicity or 'high path' avian influenza (HPAI)HPAI is often fatal in chickens and turkeys. HPAI spreads rapidly and has a higher death rate in birds than LPAI. HPAI has been detected and eradicated 3 times in US domestic poultry. HPAI H5N1 is the subtype rapidly spreading in some parts of the world. Most of the highly pathogenic AI viruses fall under types H5 or H7; however, most AI infections, including those typed as H5 or H7, are clinically of low pathogenicity. These typically produce few or no clinical signs in affected birds. Sometimes the only evidence of this virus is a minor increase in bird mortality. Aside from the possible mutation of low-pathogenicity strains under field conditions into high-pathogenicity strains, the presence of low-pathogenicity virus can also result in restrictions on exports and serious repercussions on the production economy. Avian influenza of H5 and H7 subtypes are known as notifiable avian influenza (NAI). APHIS works to keep NAI from becoming established in US poultry populations."Identifying infected birdsBirds infected with the HPAI virus may show one or more of the following signs:- sudden death without clinical signs;- lack of energy and appetite;- decreased egg production or soft-shelled or misshapen eggs;- swelling of head, comb, eyelid, wattles, and hocks;- purple discoloration of wattles, comb, and legs;- nasal discharge, coughing, and sneezing;- incoordination; or- diarrhea."EpidemiologyHPAI can strike poultry quickly and spread rapidly from premises to premises. Migratory waterfowl can introduce the disease to US poultry. International visitors or smuggled birds are also risk factors. Once introduced, the disease spreads from bird to bird by direct contact or through contact with contaminated manure, equipment, vehicles, crates, and the clothing or shoes of individuals who have come in contact with the virus. The virus remains viable in the environment for long periods, particularly at lower temperatures, and it can survive indefinitely in frozen material."Biosecurity measures on the farmVeterinarians should work with poultry producers to strengthen biosecurity practices. Established and enforced biosecurity protocols will help prevent introduction of HPAI and other infectious agents. "Recommended biosecurity measures include- establishing an 'all-in, all-out' flock-management policy;- protecting against exposure to wild birds or water or ground contaminated by wild birds;- closing bird areas to nonessential personnel or vehicles; - providing employees with clean clothing and disinfection facilities and directions for their use;- thoroughly cleaning and disinfecting equipment and vehicles (including tires and undercarriage) when entering or leaving the farm;- banning the borrowing or lending of equipment or vehicles;- banning visits to other poultry farms, exhibitions, fairs, and sales or swap meets (if visits must occur, direct workers to change footwear and clothing on their return); and- banning bringing birds in slaughter channels back to the farm."Reporting suspicious diseasesPractitioners are encouraged to educate their poultry clientele and pet bird owners to report all signs of disease. If signs of disease resemble AI or cannot be diagnosed, they should immediately be reported to both the assistant district director and the state animal health official."(https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/nvap/NVAP-Reference-Guide/Poultry/Avian-Influenza). - Mod.TGProMED map:Newfoundland and Labrador Province, Canada: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700858,272] See Also

Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. - Mod.PMB][The following information comes from the Rapid Risk Assessment on HPAIV H5 in Germany on 10 Jan 2022 available at https://www.openagrar.de/servlets/MCRFileNodeServlet/openagrar_derivate_00044031/FLI-Risikoeinschaetzung_HPAIV_H5_2022-01-10_bf.pdf [in German, machine trans., edited]:Between October 2020 and April 2021, Germany and Europe in general experienced the most severe avian influenza epizootic to date. Despite a significant decrease in both cases and outbreaks during the spring of 2021, HPAIV H5 was detected in waterfowl and birds of prey over the summer, especially in the Nordic countries of Europe. In Germany, since mid-October 2021, there have been hundreds of detections of HPAIV-infected wild birds as well as over 50 outbreaks in poultry and kept birds in numerous federal states. The risk of HPAIV H5 spreading in wild birds and transmission to poultry and kept birds in Germany is classified as high. It is strongly recommended that biosecurity measures in poultry holdings be reviewed and, if necessary, strengthened.A map of HPAI detections in Germany during the period of 1 Oct 2021 to 10 Jan 2022 can be seen at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_D/2022/Map_AI_D_2022-01-10.jpg. - Mod.CRDProMED maps:Bremen, Bremen, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700846,9416Saarland, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700846,17987] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-09 17:17:38 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (03): Asia (China) H5N6 Archive Number: 20220109.8700750AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (03): ASIA (CHINA) H5N6**********************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 8 Jan 2022Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/h5n6-avian-influenza-china-reports-1st-case-of-2022/After reporting a record 31 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) in 2021, Chinese health officials are reporting the first case of 2022 in Guangdong Province. According to the Guangdong Provincial Health and Health Commission, the patient is a 43-year-old female from Zhongkai District, Huizhou City. The patient is currently in critical condition and is being admitted to a designated hospital in Huizhou. Health authorities were notified of the case on [7 Jan 2022]. Experts believe that the cases that appear this time are sporadic cases, and the risk of transmission of the virus is low at this stage. Experts remind: the public should continue to remain vigilant and take the following measures to prevent H5N6 and other bird flu. - Wash hands frequently: wash hands after touching birds, before meals and after toileting.- To be cooked: Poultry and eggs should be cooked before eating.- Seek medical treatment early: If you have respiratory symptoms such as fever, cough, headache, general malaise, etc., seek medical treatment at the nearest medical and health institution as soon as possible. If you have been in contact with birds before, you should take the initiative to tell your doctor.- Do not eat dead poultry.- Do not buy poultry products from unknown sources.- Avoid going to live poultry markets as much as possible.This is the 58th human H5N6 avian influenza case reported in China since 2014.--Communicated by:ProMED[To date, a total of 58 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with influenza A(H5N6) virus including 27 deaths have been reported to WHO in the Western Pacific Region since 2014. The rise in numbers of reported human cases of A(H5N6) infection may reflect the continued circulation of the virus in birds, and enhanced surveillance system and diagnostic capacity as a direct outcome from the response to the COVID-19 pandemic (https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20211224.pdf). The zoonotic threat remains elevated due to the spread of the viruses among birds. However, the overall pandemic risk associated with A(H5) is considered not significantly changed in comparison to previous years. WHO recommends Member States to remain vigilant and consider mitigation steps to reduce human exposure to potentially infected birds to reduce risk of additional zoonotic infections.For information about risk assessments on Avian Influenza, visit https://www.who.int/teams/global-influenza-programme/avian-influenza/monthly-risk-assessment-summary (Assessment of risk associated with highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N6) virus). - Mod.UBAProMED map:Guangdong Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700750,334] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-09 16:03:42 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (02): Asia (China) H9N2 Archive Number: 20220109.8700749AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (02): ASIA (CHINA) H9N2**********************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 7 Jan 2022Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-human-h9n2-avian-influenza-case-in-guangdong-province-child-73647/ The World Health Organization (WHO) in the Western Pacific Region were notified of an additional human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) from China.The case is a 7-year-old male from Heyuan City, Guangdong Province with onset of illness on 28 Nov 2021. The case was in a mild condition and was not hospitalized. Prior to onset of illness, the case had exposure to a live poultry market and no further cases were suspected among family members at the time of reporting. To date [7 Jan 2022], 19 cases of avian influenza A(H9N2) have been reported to WHO from China in 2021. As of 20 Dec 2021 and since 1998 a total of 95 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) viruses have been reported: from China (83), Egypt (4), Bangladesh (3), Cambodia (1), Oman (1), Pakistan (1), India (1), and Senegal (1). Most of the cases were children with mild disease.--Communicated by:ProMED[Avian H9N2 influenza A viruses have caused repeated human infections in Asia since 1998. An H9N2 influenza virus infected a 5-year-old child in Hong Kong in 2003.Influenza A(H9N2) viruses are enzootic in poultry populations in parts of Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. Most human cases are exposed to the A(H9N2) virus through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments. Human infection tends to result in mild clinical illness.The continued presence of H9N2 influenza viruses in poultry markets in southern China increases the likelihood of avian-to-human interspecies transmission.The case was reported to WHO Western Pacific Region in the week between 17 Dec and 23 Dec 2021 and is included in the 2021 case count (https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20211224.pdf?sfvrsn=223ca73f_171). The number of human infections with A/H9N2 avian influenza viruses reported from China has been higher in 2021 than in earlier years (20 cases, including the case in the above report). This is a cause for concern and highlights the need for continuous monitoring and risk assessments of these viruses with pandemic potential. - Mod.UBAProMED map:Guangdong Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700749,334] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-08 22:40:03 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (12): Eurasia, poultry, wild bird, HPAI H5N1, epidemiology Archive Number: 20220108.8700740AVIAN INFLUENZA (12): EURASIA, POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, EPIDEMIOLOGY**************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this posting:[1] UK and Europe: poultry and wild birds, spread, epidemiology[2] Israel (Hula Valley): cranes, epidemiology and control, scientists' views******[1] UK and Europe: poultry and wild birds, spread, epidemiologyDate: Fri 7 Jan 2022Source: The Scientist [abridged, edited]https://www.the-scientist.com/news-opinion/avian-flu-case-numbers-soar-in-europe-69588"The Scientist" spoke with UK Chief Veterinary Officer Christine Middlemiss about the current avian flu outbreak, the health and economic effects of the disease, and efforts to combat it.The Scientist (TS): What does a typical avian flu season look like?Christine Middlemiss (CM): I would caution against when we say "typical" avian flu season because what we find is, every season is different and indeed, every [confirmed case] is a bit different. But generally, over the last 15 years or so, what we've seen with bird flu is we [the UK] get infection coming back in migrating wild birds, as do our European neighbors. The birds go to the north of Russia for the summer, and they mix with birds...and they all exchange the viruses and then head back to Europe in the winter and can then potentially directly infect our poultry, our kept birds, or can infect our wild birds.What generally we've been seeing is, every 2 to 3 years, a higher level of virus in the migratory wild birds. And we know that's there because we test them. We have a surveillance program that gives us an early warning of what's happening. That then translates into infection in kept poultry -- whether it's backyard poultry, animal sanctuaries, and sometimes commercial farms.... Last winter season [2020-2021], we had 26 infected premises in the UK, which was our biggest one ever. This year to date [7 Jan 2022], we're at 77. Back in 2003, the Netherlands had over 200 confirmed cases. So it does fluctuate.But in general, this year...we are seeing the highest number of confirmations we've ever had. Italy is at nearly 300 confirmations...Hungary is getting towards 100. It's doubled very recently, the numbers in France and the Netherlands. So what we're seeing across Western Europe really, [is] an increase [in] the number of cases, all being from this subtype H5N1.TS: Are there any ideas about why this year is different?CM: There's lots of theories, but there's no concrete evidence yet. And it is something we will be looking at.... Is it something to do with immunity within the wild birds? Is it something to do with the way they're mixing? And what's driving that? People have suggested it could be climate change, flight pathways...we don't know. So, lots of possibilities and it absolutely is something we will need to internationally look at further.TS: What does infection look like in birds?CM: The highly pathogenic H5N1, what that does is in kept birds -- particularly specific species [in] the Galliformes [order, such as] chickens and turkeys -- it can cause a variety of clinical signs...respiratory signs or neurological signs. They can have twisted necks. They can have discolored combs, and...kind of runny eyes and so on, and maybe diarrhea, and then often rapid death. You get a rapidly increasing mortality, generally, where you keep a large number of birds together. And you may note before that some reduction in food intake or water intake.... And that gives us a heads up. The owner, they report to us that they suspect they have a notifiable avian disease outbreak happening in the premises and we can investigate.TS: Do infections have any impacts on wild populations?CM: It does kill some species of wild birds depending on their infection level. We in the UK asked people to report in found dead wild birds and then we triage them. And some of them we will sample looking to check what has killed them. Is it avian flu? What subtype is it? What species are they? Are they a migratory species? Are they one of our own national wild birds? That helps us understand a bit more about where the infection is across the UK, and then the risk to our poultry.We started off in the autumn [2021], and we could see infection in Eastern Europe raising our risk level of incursion. We went through medium to high and now we're at a very high level of risk of incursion of infected wild birds into the UK. When we got to that level, we put in an avian influenza prevention zone requiring certain biosecurity actions of all bird keepers.... That means that there is a very high infection pressure out there. What we did next was to ask all bird keepers to house their birds, again to try and minimize any contact between them and that infected wild population. That risk level stress is across the whole of Great Britain. We've had infected wild birds detected in the north of the Isle of Skye in Scotland down to the south coast of England.TS: What are some economic effects of the outbreaks?CM: For individual keepers and companies, they're very serious. For people who keep backyard flocks...those infected birds may die. When we confirm infection, we will come in and cull the remaining birds because we need to protect other birds in a facility from getting infection. The same applies for commercial companies keeping birds.We do cull out all the birds on confirmed infected premises and go through a process of cleansing and disinfection. We will also trace all potential spread from that premises -- so, egg trucks, for example, hatcheries, [and] all these sorts of associated premises -- and put them under restriction and have additional requirements around biosecurity if we think there's any chance of disease spread.... If you're in the vicinity of an infected premise, you will be put under restriction and it makes going about daily business harder, because of the biosecurity requirements we put in place. [For example] licensing requirements [are] that you can't move things unless you get a license, and the license says you must do these following biosecurity steps to make it safe, and so on. It has very significant impacts for companies and individuals who keep birds.TS: Are there any efforts right now to develop vaccines or therapeutics for the animals?CM: There is a vaccine available for avian influenza, but like vaccines for human influenza in people, they're not 100% effective. In fact, in birds it's really not terribly effective, and it doesn't cover all the strains that might be out there. The strains change quite often when the birds mix over [the] north of Russia. We are worried about vaccinating birds with a vaccine that's not hugely effective.We do enable its use in some zoo animals under license in the UK, but it's not widely used. And because it's not hugely effective, it does have trade impacts because of the concern that it might mask infection, and the virus could still be there. Therefore, often trade partners wouldn't want to trade with you if you're using a vaccine. It's another area of potential science and research to look at more effective vaccines, but recognizing [that] the influenza virus, as we know from the human world, is a very difficult virus to produce a really effective vaccine for.TS: Are people at risk in general?CM: In terms of their own health, no. Our UK health authorities...have assessed the risk to the general public as very low. But we do advise that people should put in place routine hygiene precautions when they're handling their birds for their own safety.TS: Should the average person be concerned about this increase in outbreaks?CM: The general concern is that we've got this virus that is infecting birds and killing them. It has an economic impact that in itself has a wellbeing impact on those bird keepers. People should be concerned, particularly, if you're a bird keeper especially.The message to everybody is -- general public: don't worry, very low risk. Routine hygiene precautions. If you're a bird keeper, you need to be really, really scrupulously clean all the time.Editor's note: This interview has been edited for brevity.[Byline: Chloe Tenn]--Communicated by:ProMED[During the most recent meeting of EC's PAFF Committee on Animal Health & Welfare, held 15 Dec 2021, the following 9 countries presented their PowerPoint reports on HPAI in poultry and wildlife, covering the chronology, maps, surveillance and control measures, etc. Their respective links, and excerpted data on HPAI in wild birds, follow. Almost all tested wild birds were infected by HPAI H5N1; residual cases of H5N8, the subtype which had been circulating during several previous seasons, were still recorded in the Czech Republic and Sweden.- Czech Republic: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_cze.pdf (wild birds: 15 cases H5N1; during 2021, also cases of H5N8, H5N5)- France: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_fra.pdf (wild birds: 9 cases H5N1)- Germany: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_deu.pdf (wild birds: 327 cases H5N1)- Hungary: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_hun.pdf (wild birds: 5 cases H5N1)- Ireland: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_ire.pdf (wild birds: 57 cases H5N1)- Italy: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_ita.pdf (wild birds: 8 cases H5N1)- Poland: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_pol.pdf (wild birds: 6 cases H5N1)- Portugal: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_prt.pdf (wild birds: not presented)- Sweden: https://ec.europa.eu/food/system/files/2021-12/reg-com_ahw_20211215_hpai_swe.pdf (wild birds: 13 cases H5N1; 1 case H5N8)A map, presenting Europe's officially reported HPAI H5N1 outbreaks in poultry and cases in wild birds, since 1 Oct 2021 and as of 6 Jan 2022, is available at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2022/Map_AI_EU_2022-01-06.jpg. - Mod.AS]******[2] Israel (Hula Valley): cranes, epidemiology and control, scientists' viewsDate: Fri 7 Jan 2022 05:54 ISTSource: Haaretz [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited]http://www.haaretz.co.il/misc/article-print-page/.premium-MAGAZINE-1.10520867Prof. Ran Nathan, from the "movement ecology laboratory" at the Hebrew University, felt that something was wrong with the cranes as early as mid-December [2021]. For a decade he has been following them through transmitters that indicate their movements and location. When the avian flu epidemic broke out, 4 of the 10 cranes he was following ceased movement, and the remaining 6 showed alarming signs of a decline in activity levels, a phenomenon he had never seen before. "At that time only 40 deaths among the cranes were observed," he says. "I raised a shout that it was a huge event, and I hope this shout became helpful."The outbreak -- which killed [in Israel] about 8000 cranes, other birds and more than a million poultry [including culled animals - Mod.AS] -- is unusual by any criteria. Avian influenza has been known for many years, and cases of mass infection and death are known to researchers, but these occur among flocks of chickens and other domestic birds, or in mixed communities of domestic and wild birds. In a flock composed exclusively of wild birds, such an event is very rare. "There has never been such an outbreak, surely not among cranes," says Nathan.The question is how the virus will behave from now on. Are we back to the beginning of 2020, once again confronting a pandemic? Experts in Israel fear that spring migration will become the main engine for the spread of the virus in the coming months: hundreds of millions of birds returning from Africa to Europe will once again pass through the Hula Valley, catch the virus from other birds, from contaminated ground surface and water, potentially spread it throughout Eurasia. Dr. Ron Elazari-Volcani, a veterinarian at the zoological garden of the Tel Aviv University, warns: "There is a mega-veterinary event here, not only at the national level but also internationally."The main question at stake today is whether to continue feeding the cranes in the Hula Valley, as has been done for years to keep them limited to this location -- or to stop feeding to reduce the viral load in the Hula Valley ahead of spring, while probably risking a spread of the disease across the country with moving cranes. Nathan says: "We must reach a situation where in mid-February [2022] we are prepared to take care of the infection centers. We have an international responsibility for what happens."Eleazar-Volcani calls for drastic measures to reduce the risk of a global epidemic, even if these harm the flock of cranes in the Hula. "The health of the migratory flyway passing through the Hula should be prioritized over interests of local chicken coops. This will need securing compensations to the farmers in case affected, while favouring freedom from infection among the huge number of birds that will move northwards from Africa in another 2 months. Feeding them should be stopped in order to decrease their density in the Hula Valley and preventing the breeding of infection. Clearing the area from the virus before spring migration arrives is essential. The disinfection of the contaminated feeding area should be considered. To deter the birds from landing and prevent them from grazing in the area during the spring, the installation of propane cannons or nylon coverage deserve being considered."The Nature and Parks Authority, on the other hand, believes that there is no justification for stopping the feeding of the cranes, and fears that the infected birds will spread to other parts of the country in search of food. Regarding the consequences of spring migration, Uri Nave from the PA's science division says: "During the spring there will be temperatures where the flu is less aggressive and there is a decrease in morbidity and mortality. It is also a migration with a different pattern -- the birds rush to the nesting sites in Europe and spend less time in Israel."One of the factors that has influenced the outbreak of the plague is the global change in the migratory pattern of birds in recent decades. The birds' natural habitats disappeared, and humans provided them with new food sources. This is joined by climate change, which has made winters in Europe and the Middle East relatively warm and allowed the flocks to avoid or shorten their journey south.In the Hula, the change took place following the re-flooding of the reedbed in the 1990s and the shift of farmers in the area from growing cotton to grains such as corn, peanuts and chickpeas, which became food for cranes. With the increased crane population and because many preferred to winter in the country instead of continuing to Africa, the damage caused to farmers also worsened. This is when their feeding venture started.Experts admit that it is difficult to assess the consequences of the current outbreak, and that the lack of a formula for a perfect balance between bird protection and agricultural protection will make it difficult to prevent similar outbreaks. What remains is to learn how to deal more effectively with their consequences, for example, by systematically collecting carcasses at the center of the disease's outbreak."We need one responsible agency who can make decisions," says Dr. Moti Charter of the University of Haifa, who yesterday [6 Jan 2022] documented the carcasses of birds of prey, including owls, falcons and buzzards in the Agamon Hula area. The main concern is the damage to rare birds such as white-tailed eagles, only 2 of which live in the Hula, white-headed ducks, or ferruginous ducks.The decision regarding the feeding of the cranes will have to be made in the coming months. "I do not know if it is possible to return the genie into the bottle", says Elazari-Vulcani, "it remains only to try to reduce damage."[Byline: Tzafrir Rinat and Nir Hasson]--Communicated by:ProMED[The continuing HPAI H5N1 panzootic, which started in the fall of 2021, has reportedly caused at least 3 other mass mortality events in wild birds:- Cormorants in Dyer Island, South Africa (https://mg.co.za/environment/2021-10-20-bird-flu-outbreak-on-dyer-island-causing-mass-deaths/);- Demoiselle cranes in Rajasthan, India (https://www.wti.org.in/news/wti-team-on-ground-as-avian-flu-hits-demoiselle-cranes-in-rajasthan/);- Barnacle geese in Solway Firth, Scotland (https://www.scotsman.com/news/people/bird-flu-fears-around-4000-deaths-in-biggest-outbreak-for-years-3501424; see 20220106.8700696).The HPAI H5N1 panzootic and its impact upon agriculture, public health and wildlife conservation prescribe the need for a One Health approach. - Mod.ASProMED maps:Europe: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700740,6010Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700740,90] See Also

/ - / -Affected population: 100 animals (ducks and wild geese)EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultNational Institute of Agricultural and Veterinary Research (national laboratory) / Wildlife / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 4 Jan 2022 / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[This immediate notification complements the information already published in ProMED posting 20220105.8700676."The dynamic of the spread of influenza viruses is extremely complex and difficult to predict. Several factors can influence it, such as the wild bird migration pattern, unregulated trade, farming systems, biosecurity and immunity status."During the Northern Hemisphere winter, the wild bird movements may increase, and lower temperatures may facilitate the environmental survival of AI viruses, increasing exposure of infection in poultry. Additionally, the mixing of wild birds from different geographic origins during migration can increase the risk of virus spread and genetic reassortment resulting in changes in viral properties. At local level, as the AI viruses can survive for long periods in the environment, they can be easily transmitted from farm to farm by the movement of infected animals, as well as contaminated boots, vehicles and equipment if adequate biosecurity measures are not implemented." https://www.oie.int/en/disease/avian-influenza/#ui-id-2. - Mod.CRDProMED map:Portugal: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700705,42] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-07 01:41:11 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human: Europe (UK) H5N1 Archive Number: 20220107.8700700AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN: EUROPE (UK) H5N1****************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1] Date: Thu 6 Jan 2022Source: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/world/uk/britain-reports-human-case-avian-flu-no-onward-transmission-2022-01-06/The UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) said on Thursday [6 Jan 2022] there had been a confirmed human case of avian flu in southwest England, adding that the person had been in close contact with infected birds and there was no evidence of onward transmission."The person acquired the infection from very close, regular contact with a large number of infected birds, which they kept in and around their home over a prolonged period of time," the UKHSA said."All contacts of the individual, including those who visited the premises, have been traced and there is no evidence of onward spread of the infection to anyone else. The individual is currently well and self-isolating. The risk to the wider public from avian flu continues to be very low."[Byline: Alistair Smout]--Communicated by:ProMED******[2] Date: Thu 6 Jan 2022Source: Evening Standard [edited]https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/avian-flu-confirmed-person-south-west-england-transmission-birds-rare-b975270.htmlA person in the south-west of England has been confirmed to have contracted avian flu, the UK Health Security Agency announced on Thursday [6 Jan 2022].The agency said the person had been in close contact with infected birds and there was no evidence of onward transmission."The person acquired the infection from very close, regular contact with a large number of infected birds, which they kept in and around their home over a prolonged period of time," the UKHSA said."All contacts of the individual, including those who visited the premises, have been traced and there is no evidence of onward spread of the infection to anyone else. The individual is currently well and self-isolating. The risk to the wider public from avian flu continues to be very low."Some strains of bird flu can pass from birds to people, but this is extremely rare, according to the UKHSA.It usually requires close contact with an infected bird, so the risk to humans is generally considered very low.Human-to-human transmission of bird flu is also very rare, the organisation said.The case was detected after the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) identified an outbreak of the H5N1 strain of bird flu in a flock of birds.The infected birds have all been culled. As a precaution, the UKHSA swabbed the person involved and detected low levels of flu.Further lab analysis showed that the virus was the "H5" type found in birds.The UKHSA said that, at this point, it has not been possible to confirm that this is a H5N1 infection (the strain that is currently circulating in birds in the UK).But the UKHSA has notified the World Health Organisation (WHO) as a precaution.It said this is the first human case of this strain in the UK, although there have been cases elsewhere globally.Professor Isabel Oliver, chief scientific officer at the UKHSA, said: "While the risk of avian flu to the general public is very low, we know that some strains do have the potential to spread to humans and that's why we have robust systems in place to detect these early and take action."Currently there is no evidence that this strain detected in the UK can spread from person to person, but we know that viruses evolve all the time and we continue to monitor the situation closely."We have followed up all of this individual's contacts and have not identified any onward spread."In December [2021], environment secretary George Eustice revealed the UK had been hit by a record outbreak of avian flu that led to 500 000 captive birds being culled in previous months.He told MPs an avian influenza prevention zone had been declared across the UK at the start of November [2021], requiring strict biosecurity measures and all birds to be kept indoors.On Wednesday [5 Jan 2022], the World Organisation for Animal Health warned a wave of bird flu in Asia and Europe had a greater risk of spreading to humans because of a high number of variants.The spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza has raised concern among governments and the poultry industry after previous outbreaks led to the culling of tens of millions of birds and trade restrictions."This time the situation is more difficult and more risky because we see more variants emerge, which make them harder to follow," director general Monique Eloit told Reuters."Eventually the risk is that it mutates or that it mixes with a human flu virus that can be transmitted between humans then suddenly it takes on a new dimension," she added.Fifteen countries had reported outbreaks of bird flu in poultry between October [2021] and the end of December [2021], mostly the H5N1 strain. Italy was the worst hit in Europe with 285 outbreaks and nearly 4 million birds culled, data showed.For contacts of an infected person who have the highest risk, the UKHSA contacts them daily to see if they have developed symptoms.People are also offered anti-viral treatment after exposure to infected birds to stop the virus reproducing in their body.Swabs are also carried out on people even if they do not have symptoms.Professor Mike Tildesley, from the University of Warwick, said: "This is clearly going to be big news but the key thing is that human infections with H5N1 are really rare (fewer than 1000 worldwide since 2003) and they almost always occur as a result of direct, long-term contact with poultry."It can result in a nasty infection for the individual concerned but there has never been any evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission of H5N1 so at present I wouldn't consider this to be a significant public health risk."Paul Wigley, professor of avian infection and immunity at the University of Liverpool, said: "Whilst avian influenza has the potential to be transmitted from poultry to humans, it is very rare and, as in this case, usually due to close and long-term contact with infected birds."Avian influenza such as the H5 serotype is largely adapted to infect birds and so is very unlikely to be transmitted from person to person."The advice given by APHA and UKHSA over contact with infected birds is sensible and should be followed. The risk of wider infection in the general public remains low."[Byline: Michael Howie]--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[This is the first human case of avian Influenza A/H5N1 reported from the United Kingdom. In 2006, 20 human cases of influenza A(H5N1) were reported in Azerbaijan (8 cases) and Turkey (12 cases). WHO/Europe, with international partners, supported the governments of Azerbaijan and Turkey in responding to the outbreaks. No human cases have been observed in the WHO European Region since that time, despite continued surveillance for this and other zoonotic influenza viruses (https://www.euro.who.int/en/health-topics/communicable-diseases/influenza/zoonotic-influenza/old-links/human-infection-with-influenza-ah5n1). All human cases infected with a novel influenza strain are notifiable in the EU under EU legislation and the International Health Regulations (IHR) through the Early Warning and Response System (EWRS) and IHR, respectively. Human infections with A(H5N1) are notifiable according to EU Decisions 2012/506/EU and 1082/2013/EU (https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/zoonotic-influenza/facts/factsheet-h5n1).This event overlaps the concurrent reports of a massive outbreak of avian influenza around the Solway Firth that has killed thousands of wildfowl in recent weeks, with over 4000 barnacle goose particularly affected/died, which equates to around 10% of the entire Svalbard population of the species (Avian influenza (09): Europe (UK) wild bird, HPAI, conservation concern 20220106.8700696).The primary risk factor for human infection with avian influenza is direct or indirect exposure to infected poultry (live or dead) or wildlife, as well as contaminated environments such as live bird markets. Additional risk factors include slaughtering, defeathering, handling carcasses of infected poultry, and preparing poultry for consumption, especially in household settings.Given the potential zoonotic risk with this new case, contingency plans for the control of avian influenza in poultry and birds should be reviewed and implemented. Public health and animal health authorities must ensure that persons at risk are sufficiently protected from infection and appropriate measures are taken to prevent widespread transmission.Due to the constantly evolving nature of influenza viruses, WHO continues to stress the importance of global surveillance to detect virological, epidemiological, and clinical changes associated with circulating influenza viruses that may affect human or animal health, as well as timely sharing of viruses to inform risk assessments. - Mod.UBAOther URLs:- https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/breaking-first-brit-infected-bird-25872434- https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2022/01/06/first-case-human-h5-type-bird-flu-found-uk-public-warned-not/- https://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/first-person-infected-bird-flu-25872620- https://www.somersetlive.co.uk/news/somerset-news/first-human-infected-bird-flu-6450808- https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/uk-news/first-human-uk-infected-bird-22665123- https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-10375255/Now-Britain-gets-hit-BIRD-FLU-Health-chiefs-detect-strain-person-South-West-England.html- https://www.mylondon.news/news/health/breaking-human-case-bird-flu-22665952- https://www.thejournal.ie/human-case-bird-flu-england-5647532-Jan2022/- https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/uk-news/person-infected-bird-flu-england-22665365- https://www.express.co.uk/news/science/1545885/bird-flu-case-england-uk-health-security-agencyFor information on HPAI H5N1 in humans (cases, deaths) since 2003 (18 countries), please refer to 'Table 2: Confirmed human cases of avian influenza A(H5N1)' at https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/global_statistics_avian_influenza_e.pdf. The new human case in the UK has not yet been added to the said table. - Mod.ASProMED map:England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700700,279] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-06 17:19:06 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (09): Europe (UK) wild bird, HPAI, conservation concern Archive Number: 20220106.8700696AVIAN INFLUENZA (09): EUROPE (UK) WILD BIRD, HPAI, CONSERVATION CONCERN***********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 20 Dec 2021Source: BirdGuides [edited]https://www.birdguides.com/news/unprecedented-bird-flu-outbreak-kills-thousands-of-barnacle-geese/A devastating outbreak of avian influenza around the Solway Firth has killed thousands of wildfowl in recent weeks, with barnacle goose particularly affected.It is estimated that 4000 or more barnacle geese have already died from the virus, which equates to around 10% of the entire Svalbard population of the species.The scale of the event has been described as 'unprecedented' by the RSPB [Royal Society for the Protection of Birds] and outbreaks are being reported widely across the UK, although the Solway has been especially badly affected.The RSPB said in a statement that "geese have been observed falling from the sky in distress, and lines of dead birds are washing up on the beach after they perish while roosting out on the mudflats," and warned that "the worst could still be to come." The RSPB's reserve at Mersehead has been badly affected, with 700 corpses already removed from the site and numbers still rising.While barnacle geese are bearing the brunt of the outbreak, other species of wildfowl, including wintering whooper swans, have fallen victim, as have gulls, birds of prey, and Eurasian curlews. There is also growing concern for the Solway's wintering Northern Lapwings and Eurasian Wigeon.The RSPB says that it is in desperate need of more trained staff and equipment to aid with the safe removal of dead birds and to help to reduce the risk of the virus spreading and killing more healthy birds. The organisation has launched an urgent fundraising appeal and is asking for any donations that the public may be able to spare.While risk of transmission to humans is low, NHS advice to members of the public is not to handle any dead birds they come across in the field.--Communicated by:ProMED[Outbreaks of HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses have been causing deaths in wild birds in Europe since 2014. Mass mortalities like this one reported in barnacle geese (_Branta leucopsis_) are a concern for the conservation of some bird species. The barnacle goose is not an endangered species, but mass mortality involving a large proportion of a population may determine its decline. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Solway Firth,  Scotland, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700696,3762] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2022-01-05 19:35:27 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (08): Europe (Denmark) wild bird, HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20220105.8700677AVIAN INFLUENZA (08): EUROPE (DENMARK) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N8, OIE****************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 4 Jan 2022Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2022 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=45809Influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity (Inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Denmark--------------------------------------------------------------------------------General informationReport type: Immediate notificationStarted: 13 Dec 2021Confirmed: 30 Dec 2021Reported: 3 Jan 2022Reason for notification: RecurrenceLast occurrence: 5 May 2021Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: LaboratoryThis event pertains to the whole country.Total outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Holstebro, Veterinary Inspection Unit NorthStarted: 13 Dec 2021Ended: 13 Dec 2021Epidemiological unit: Not applicableAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedWhooper swan (_Cygnus cygnus_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: On 13 Dec 2021, a Whooper swan (_Cygnus cygnus_) was found dead near Holstebro in the municipality Holstebro. On 30 Dec 2021, Statens Serum Institute confirmed highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (H5N8) in the samples from the swan.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Contact with wild speciesEpidemiological comments: According to article 10.4.1.4 of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Member Countries should not impose bans on the trade in poultry and poultry commodities in response to notification on the presence of influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity in birds other than poultry. The date of last occurrence of the H5N8 strain in Denmark is 5 May 2021.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultStatens Serum Institute (national laboratory) / Whooper swan / 1 / Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 30 Dec 2021 / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[From 2014 onward, HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses caused outbreaks across the Eurasian region, affecting both poultry and wild birds, with abundant genetic reassortments yielding subtypes H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Denmark: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700677,111] See Also

/ -Affected population: HPAI H5N1 was confirmed in a hobby flock of chicken (40) and ducks (20).EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveControl measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: Zoning, screening, traceability, movement control inside the country, stamping outDomestic control measures to be applied: Disinfection, official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and wasteDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultNational Institute of Agricultural and Veterinary Research (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 3 Jan 2022 / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[In addition to the outbreak reported in Setubal, 4 Jan 2022, a new case of HPAI was confirmed in a wild goose (_Anser_ sp.) found dead in the Patudos Dam, Alpiarça municipality. See press release published on 5 Jan 2022 at https://www.dgav.pt/wp-content/uploads/2022/01/NotaInformativa_GAAP_H5N1_n5rev.pdf (in Portuguese).Since 1 Dec 2021, several outbreaks of HPAI subtype H5N1 in poultry and wild bird have been confirmed by the National Institute of Agricultural and Veterinary Research (national reference laboratory for animal diseases). Mod.AS, edited]https://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=2&TMID=178&FID=14793&PID=0&IID=43438Since the 1st HPAI H5N1 event during Israel's continuing epizootic, which was reported on 12 Oct 2021 from a turkey farm in Nahalal, we have been experiencing a widespread wave of outbreaks of the said virus strain.In the timeline below, the accumulated intermediate data are summarised.No / Date / Location / Poultry type / Quantity / age-----------------------------------------No / Date / Location / Poultry type / Quantity / age-----------------------------------------1 / 12 Oct / Nahalal / Meat turkeys / 42 000 / 13 Weeks2 / 30 Oct / Maayan Tzvi / Breeding turkeys / 5400 / 35 weeks3 / 18 Nov / Kfar Baruch / Ducks / 17 500 / 7 weeks4 / 18 Nov / Ein Tzurim / Meat turkeys / 25 000 / 13 weeks 5 / 05 Dec / Avigdor / Meat turkeys / 10 000 / 13 weeks6 / 19 Dec / Margaliot / Layers / 600 000 / multi age7 / 20 Dec / Neot Golan / Meat turkeys / 17 000 / 13 weeks8 / 26 Dec / Ein Hachoresh / Meat turkeys / 31 850 / 19 weeks9 / 26 Dec / Givat Yoav / Meat turkeys / 38 000 / 13.6 weeks10 / 27 Dec / Ram On / Meat turkeys / 19 400 / 9 weeks11 / 29 Dec / Barak / Layers / 6300 / 92 weeks12 / 30 Dec / Givat Yoav / Meat turkeys / 12 000 / 14 weeks13 / 01 Jan / Dvorah / Layers / 35 000 / 96 weeks14 / 02 Jan / Gadish / Layers / 3500 / 70 weeks15 / 02 Jan / Gadish / Layers / 4000 / 99 weeks16 / 02 Jan / Nahalal / Meat turkeys / 42 000 / 7 weeks17 / 02 Jan / Neot Golan / Meat turkeys / 14 000 / 5 weeks18 / 03 Jan / Ram-On / Meat breeder Chickens / 36 000 / 56 weeks19 / 04 Jan / Ram-On / Broiler chickens / 27 500 / 20 weeks20 / 04 Jan / Aviel / Meat turkeys / 107 000 / 7 weeksTotal quantity (cases + killed): 1 093 450 animals--Communicated by:Nati Elkin<Nati@poultrymed.com>[The current countrywide spread HPAI H5N1 event has become Israel's largest. During each of the previous epizootics, in 2006 and 2015, less than 10 outbreaks on commercial farms were recorded. Similar to the previous events, and in line with observations elsewhere (see citation below), turkey farms have become the most affected. In difference with previous events, table-egg layers have been included among the affected farms during the current event. A total of over a million birds had to be killed; the issue has become widely published and subject to discussions at the state's highest level (see https://www.timesofisrael.com/bennett-holds-security-meeting-on-bird-flu-outbreak-as-disease-continues-to-spread/).The current event included a devastating outbreak among migrating cranes in northern Israel, killing more than 5200 of them. A videoclip is available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0jlZSwzZXzI.The citation referred to above follows:Pillai SPS, Pantin-Jackwood M, Yassine HM, et al. The high susceptibility of turkeys to influenza viruses of different origins implies their importance as potential intermediate hosts. Avian Dis. 2010; 54(1 Suppl): 522-6; doi: 10.1637/8770-033109-Review.1.- Mod.ASProMED map of Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700668,90] See Also
