View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-12-21 00:48:00 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (176): Israel (HZ) poultry, wild bird, HPAI H5N1, spread Archive Number: 20211221.8700388AVIAN INFLUENZA (176): ISRAEL (HAZAFON) POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD*****************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this post:[1] Laying hens, migrating cranes[2] Laying hens, migrating cranes******[1] Laying hens, migrating cranesDate: Sun 19 Dec 2021 17:38 ISTSource: Makor Rishon Daily [in Hebrew, trans., abridged, edited]https://www.makorrishon.co.il/news/435425/The Ministry of Agriculture announced today [19 Dec 2021] an unusual outbreak of bird flu in the locality of Margaliot [see map at <tinyurl.com/mtxksnbr>] in the Upper Galilee. Traffic restrictions on the entry of trucks and equipment into the poultry farms were imposed in the area, and anyone engaged with poultry elsewhere was instructed not to approach the coop complexes.The Veterinary Services fear that they will have to prepare for the extermination of about half a million [240 000, according to other media reports] laying hens in order to prevent the spread of bird flu. The source of the disease is probably in the [migrating] cranes that brought the virus with them to the Hula valley [but see comment below]. Due to the avian influenza outbreak, the entrance of hikers to the Hula Lake Park [known in Hebrew as Agamon HaHula] and to the vicinity of the cranes has been closed.This incident is accompanied by poultry mortality and requires culling and complete isolation until the event's termination is officially announced. This was informed to the owners of the poultry farms and the residents of [the regional Councils] Mevoot Hermon, Merom Hagalil and Ma'ale Yosef.To prevent the spread of the disease, poultry breeders in the Upper Galilee have been instructed to refrain from reaching Margaliot in the coming days to prevent vehicles and trucks that had visited Margaliot, in particular those engaged in the supply of feed concentrates, from entering their premises, and to immediately notify any signs of disease or increased mortality among their birds. The Ministry of Agriculture also instructed the growers to refrain from allowing manure removal contractors to approach the poultry farms until the announcement of the event termination.The source of the outbreak is said to be a disease event in the Hula Lake Park [Agamon; see map at <tinyurl.com/2p9fu9dp>], which started last weekend, where hundreds of cranes were affected by bird flu and many died. The management of the Agamon said that they are constantly in contact with the professionals in the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Agriculture to find a solution to the issue [see comment below].--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>******[2] Laying hens, migrating cranesDate: Sat 18 Dec 2021 08:52 ISTSource: Davar [in Hebrew, machine trans., edited]https://www.davar1.co.il/350513/The Ministry of Agriculture updated the Ministry of Health yesterday [Fri 17 Dec 2021] on dozens of cranes infected with bird flu that were discovered in the Hula Valley. The Ministry of Health asks not to approach the migratory birds and to avoid contact.The initial suspicion arose following an abnormal mortality of cranes at the site. Following this, samples were collected by the Nature and Parks Authority and sent to the Veterinary Institute's laboratory at the Ministry of Agriculture's Veterinary Services, which showed that wild birds were infected with H5N1 bird flu due to widespread morbidity. The Ministry of Agriculture regularly updates the OIE (World Organization for Animal Health).This case joins other recent cases in which H5N1 avian influenza has been identified in wild birds. According to a report published by the (acting) Director of Veterinary Services, Dr. Tamir Goshen, many cases of wild bird disease have been diagnosed recently in several places in the country, including Moshav Hayogev in the Jezreel Valley, Agmon Hahula, Kibbutz Migdal Oz in Gush Etzion and Kibbutz Mishmar Hasharon in the Hefer Valley. The current outbreak was detected in wild birds a few weeks ago, and so far has been diagnosed in cranes, pelicans and marbled ducks.The Ministry of Agriculture also said that all avian influenza events this year [2021], as well as the current one, involved an H5N1 virus that could cause a low risk of human disease. This case joins other recent cases in which H5N1 bird flu has been identified on [5] poultry farms in Kfar Baruch, Kibbutz Ein Tzurim, Avigdor, Maayan Zvi and Nahalal. These events have been long resolved.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The distance between Margaliot (adjacent to the Lebanese border) and the Agamon, on its southeast, is 13.20 km (8.20 mi).The route and direction of introduction of the HPAI H5N1 into Israel and into the poultry farms (hen-to-crane or rather vice versa), and the reason(s) of the severe disease, including mass mortality among the cranes, an event not seen before in a location visited by 5-digit number of migrating cranes each November, are yet to be investigated and clarified. One hypothesis could be the cranes' possible susceptibility, becoming infected in this bird-crowded meeting site from co-visiting infected migrating waterbirds of the order Anseriformes, the latter known to remain subclinical while infective. A One Health approach, incorporating animal health, public health, and ornithologists, is warranted.The Hula Valley is an agricultural region in northern Israel with abundant fresh water, which used to be Lake Hula, prior to its draining. Lake Hula and the marshland surrounding it were a breeding ground for mosquitoes carrying malaria, and so were drained in the 1950s. A small section of the valley was later re-flooded in an attempt to revive a nearly extinct ecosystem.Hula Lake Park, known in Hebrew as Agamon HaHula, is located in the southern part of the Hula Valley. The new site has become the 2nd home for many thousands of migrating birds in the autumn and spring. The lake covers an area of one square kilometer, interspersed with islands that serve as protected bird nesting sites. It has become a major stopover for migrating birds flying from Europe to Africa and back, and also a major birdwatching site. In 2011, Israeli ornithologists confirmed that Lake Hula is the stopover point for tens of thousands of cranes migrating from Finland to Ethiopia every winter. In Israel, farmers set out food for them to keep them from damaging crops near the lake. This likely has contributed to increased density.A 2.51-minute video clip presenting the event in the Agamon is available at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a0QrhaM6X6I (Israel TV, Channel 11 News, 19 Dec 2021; presenter/commentator, Ruby Hammerschlag; in Hebrew). At the beginning, neurological clinical signs in an affected crane are presented. For a picture showing supernatant dead cranes in the Agamon (Hula Lake), see <tinyurl.com/3k24khww>. - Mod.AS][The affected birds are very likely common cranes (_Grus grus_). This species breeds in the northern parts of Europe and across the Palearctic to Siberia. In the boreal spring, these cranes embark on a long migration southward. Most eastern common cranes winter in the river valleys of Sudan, Ethiopia, Tunisia, and Eritrea with smaller numbers in Turkey, northern Israel, Iraq, and parts of Iran. - Mod.PMBProMED map:Hazafon, Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700388,1759] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-12-19 03:23:11 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (26): China (Hong Kong) H5N6 Archive Number: 20211219.8700294AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (26): CHINA (HONG KONG) H5N6***************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 15 Dec 2021Source: Government of Hong Kong [edited]https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202112/15/P2021121500580.htm The Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today [15 Dec 2021] closely monitoring 4 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) in the Mainland, and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.Details of the cases are listed in the table below:Age / Sex / Living place / Onset date / Admission date / Condition / History of exposure to live poultry3 / Male / Nanning, Guangxi / 15 Nov 2021 / 16 Nov 2021 / Serious / Had exposure to live poultry and visited a live poultry market49 / Male / Hengyang, Hunan / 22 Nov 2021 / 25 Nov 2021 / Serious / Had exposure to a live poultry market72 / Male / Yongzhou, Hunan / 24 Nov 2021 / 29 Nov 2021 / Serious / Had exposure to live domestic poultry58 / Male / Hengyang, Hunan / 4 Dec 2021 / N/A / Mild / Had exposure to live domestic poultryFrom 2014 to date [15 Dec 2021], 57 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by Mainland health authorities."All novel influenza A infections, including H5N6, are notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong," a spokesman for the CHP said.Travellers to the Mainland or other affected areas must avoid visiting wet markets, live poultry markets or farms. They should be alert to the presence of backyard poultry when visiting relatives and friends. They should also avoid purchasing live or freshly slaughtered poultry, and avoid touching poultry/birds or their droppings. They should strictly observe personal and hand hygiene when visiting any place with live poultry.Travellers returning from affected areas should consult a doctor promptly if symptoms develop, and inform the doctor of their travel history for prompt diagnosis and treatment of potential diseases. It is essential to tell the doctor if they have seen any live poultry during travel, which may imply possible exposure to contaminated environments. This will enable the doctor to assess the possibility of avian influenza and arrange necessary investigations and appropriate treatment in a timely manner.While local surveillance, prevention and control measures are in place, the CHP will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments.The public should maintain strict personal, hand, food and environmental hygiene and take heed of the advice below when handling poultry:- Avoid touching poultry, birds, animals or their droppings; - When buying live chickens, do not touch them and their droppings. Do not blow at their bottoms. Wash eggs with detergent if soiled with faecal matter and cook and consume the eggs immediately. Always wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling chickens and eggs;- Eggs should be cooked well until the white and yolk become firm. Do not eat raw eggs or dip cooked food into any sauce with raw eggs. Poultry should be cooked thoroughly. If there is pinkish juice running from the cooked poultry or the middle part of its bone is still red, the poultry should be cooked again until fully done;- Wash hands frequently, especially before touching the mouth, nose or eyes, before handling food or eating, and after going to the toilet, touching public installations or equipment such as escalator handrails, elevator control panels or door knobs, or when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing; and - Wear a mask if fever or respiratory symptoms develop, when going to a hospital or clinic, or while taking care of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms.The public may visit the CHP's pages for more information: the avian influenza page, the weekly Avian Influenza Report, global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza, the Facebook Page and the YouTube Channel.--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[ProMED thanks Mahmoud Orabi for the latest reports on 4 human cases of avian influenza A/H5N6 from China.To date (15 Dec 2021), since 2014, 57 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported in mainland China, the latest reported cases being the 25-28th cases in 2021.According to reports received by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), various influenza A(H5) subtypes continue to be detected in birds in Africa, Europe, and Asia.Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Intensive surveillance should be continued to detect cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of these viruses, as the frequency of cases appears to be increasing. - Mod.UBAProMED maps:Guangxi Autonomous Region, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700294,355Hunan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700294,341] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-12-11 21:47:08 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (25): China (SC, GD) H5N6 Archive Number: 20211211.8700163AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (25): CHINA (SICHUAN, GUANGDONG) H5N6************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Wed 8 Dec 2021Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-human-h5n6-avian-influenza-case-in-sichuan-province-27th-case-this-year-34601/Hong Kong health authorities report monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in a 54-year-old woman living in Zigong, Sichuan Province. The woman had exposure to deceased backyard poultry before the onset of symptoms. She developed symptoms on 17 Nov 2021, was admitted for treatment on 21 Nov 2021, and died on 23 Nov 2021.This is the 27th human case reported on Mainland China in the past year and the 52nd case reported since the 1st case was reported in 2014. Avian influenza is caused by those influenza viruses that mainly affect birds and poultry, such as chickens or ducks.Clinical presentation of avian influenza in humans includes eye infection (conjunctivitis), flulike symptoms (e.g., fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches), or severe respiratory illness (e.g., chest infection). The incubation period ranges from 7 to 10 days.The more virulent forms can result in respiratory failure, multiorgan failure, and even death. People mainly become infected with avian influenza virus through contact with infected birds and poultry (live or dead) or their droppings or contact with contaminated environments (such as wet markets and live poultry markets). Human-to-human transmission is inefficient.People in close contact with poultry are more susceptible to contracting avian influenza. The elderly, children and people with chronic illness have a higher risk of developing complications such as bronchitis and chest infection.--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<mahmoud.s.orabi@gmail.com>******[2]Date: Wed 8 Dec 2021 23:15 ESTSource: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/world/china/chinese-woman-dies-h5n6-strain-bird-flu-2021-12-09/A woman in China's Sichuan province died from the H5N6 strain of avian influenza last month [November 2021], a regional health bureau said this week, in the latest human fatality from the lethal disease.The 54-year-old woman from Zigong city developed symptoms on 17 Nov 2021 and was admitted to hospital on 21 Nov 2021. She died on 23 Nov 2021, according to a Wednesday [8 Dec 2021] statement on the website of the health bureau of semi-autonomous region Macau. She had been exposed to dead poultry before the onset of illness, it added.The number of people in China infected with H5N6 bird flu this year [2021] has jumped, raising concern among experts, who say a previously circulating strain appears to have changed and may be more infectious to people (https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/rise-human-bird-flu-cases-china-shows-risk-fast-changing-variants-health-experts-2021-10-26/).Of 26 infections reported by various government departments this year [2021], most have been in Sichuan province, though cases have also been reported in neighboring Chongqing and Guangxi, as well as Guangdong, Anhui and Hunan provinces.[Byline: Dominique Patton]--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<mahmoud.s.orabi@gmail.com>[Other related URLs:- https://sports.yahoo.com/chinese-woman-dies-h5n6-strain-041353213.html- https://wabx.net/2021/12/08/chinese-woman-dies-from-h5n6-strain-of-bird-flu/- https://radiousa.com/2021/12/08/chinese-woman-dies-from-h5n6-strain-of-bird-flu/- https://www.theanimalreader.com/2021/12/09/woman-dies-from-h5n6-avian-influenza-in-china/- https://b975.com/2021/12/08/chinese-woman-dies-from-h5n6-strain-of-bird-flu/]******[3]Date: Sat 11 Dec 2021 19:58 CSTSource: Hong Kong Chinese News Agency [in Chinese, machine trans., edited]http://www.hkcna.hk/docDetail.jsp?id=100025330&channel=2813According to a report from the Guangdong Provincial Health Commission on 11 Dec 2021, Huizhou City has reported one case of H5N6. The patient [W], male, 68 years old, from Huizhou City, currently lives in Huicheng District, Huizhou City, and is currently undergoing active treatment in a designated hospital in Huizhou City.Experts judged that the case this time was an accidental case, and the risk of transmission of the virus is low at this stage. Experts remind: In winter and spring, H5N6, H9N2 and other epidemic-prone seasons, citizens should continue to stay vigilant and take the following measures to prevent H5N6 and other bird flu.Wash your hands frequently: wash your hands after touching poultry, before eating, and after going to the toilet. To be cooked: poultry and eggs must be cooked before eating. Seek medical attention early: If you have respiratory symptoms such as fever, cough, headache, and general malaise, you should go to the nearest medical and health institution as soon as possible. If you have been in contact with poultry before, you should take the initiative to tell your doctor. Do not eat dead poultry meat. Do not buy poultry and bird products of unknown origin. Avoid going to live poultry markets as much as possible.--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<mahmoud.s.orabi@gmail.com>******[4]Date: Sat 11 Dec 2021Source: Nouvelles du Monde from Reuters [in French, machine trans., edited]https://www.nouvelles-du-monde.com/le-guangdong-chine-signale-une-infection-humaine-a-la-grippe-aviaire-h5n6-3/The health authority in southern China's Guangdong Province said on Saturday [11 Dec 2021] that a human case infected with the H5N6 strain of bird flu had been reported in Huizhou City. The Guangdong Province Health Commission said in a statement that experts consider the risk of transmission to be low at this stage.Still, he said experts have advised citizens to remain vigilant and take preventive measures such as avoiding visiting markets with live poultry, as infections with the H5N6 and H9N2 viruses are likely to occur during the winter and spring.The 68-year-old infected man was being treated in a hospital, the statement said. The number of people infected with H5N6 bird flu in China this year [2021] has jumped, raising concern among some experts, who say a strain that was previously circulating appears to have changed and could be more contagious to humans.Several H5N6 infections in China have died this year [2021], according to local government statements and WHO reports.[Byline: Roxanne Liu and Dominique Patton]--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<mahmoud.s.orabi@gmail.com>[To date, 48 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported in mainland China, the latest reported cases being the 23rd and 24th cases in 2021.The public may visit the following Centre for Health Protection (CHP) pages for more information: the avian influenza page (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/features/24244.html), the weekly Avian Influenza Report (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/resources/29/332.html), global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza (https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/global_statistics_avian_influenza_e.pdf), the Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/CentreforHealthProtection), and the YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/c/ChpGovHkChannel). - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED maps of Sichuan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700163,350 and Guangdong Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700163,334] See Also

All the holdings are backyard (non-poultry).Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: Zoning; traceability; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; movement control inside the country; disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultInstituto Nacional de Investigação Agrária e Veterinária National Laboratory/ Birds / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR)/ 30 Nov 2021 / Not available[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[An outbreak map of HPAI in Europe from 8 Oct 2021 to 9 Dec 2021 is available at https://izsvenezie.com/documents/reference-laboratories/avian-influenza/europe-updates/HPAI/2021-1/maps.pdf. Due to Brexit implementation, the United Kingdom is not included in this map, see https://www.gov.uk/guidance/avian-influenza-bird-flu#latest-situation (last updated 8 Dec 2021) for further information. According to the OIE Terrestrial Code, the definition of poultry, "means all birds reared or kept in captivity for the production of any commercial animal products or for breeding for this purpose, fighting cocks used for any purpose, and all birds used for restocking supplies of game or for breeding for this purpose, until they are released from captivity."Birds that are kept in a single household, the products of which are used within the same household exclusively, are not considered poultry, provided that they have no direct or indirect contact with poultry or poultry facilities."Birds that are kept in captivity for other reasons, including those that are kept for shows, racing, exhibitions, zoological collections and competitions, and for breeding or selling for these purposes, as well as pet birds, are not considered poultry, provided that they have no direct or indirect contact with poultry or poultry facilities". Source: OIE Terrestrial Code 2021, Glossary section (https://www.oie.int/en/what-we-do/standards/codes-and-manuals/terrestrial-code-online-access/?id=169&L=1&htmfile=glossaire.htm). - Mod CRDProMED maps:Russia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700162,98Belgium: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700162,99Portugal: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700162,42] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-12-09 17:27:08 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (171): India (MP) wild bird, HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20211209.8700157AVIAN INFLUENZA (171): INDIA (MADHYA PRADESH) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N8, OIE***********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 8 Dec 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=44023Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), India--------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 28 Nov 2021Confirmed: 29 Nov 2021Reported: 7 Dec 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 5 Jun 2017Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Urban Area (Mutton Market) Agar, Agar Malva, Madhya PradeshStarted: 28 Nov 2021Epidemiological unit: not applicableTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedHouse crow (_Corvus splendens_): Corvidae-Passeriformes / - / 8 / 8 / - / - / -EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; surveillance within containment and or the protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultNational Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD), Bhopal, India (OIE reference laboratory) / house crow / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 29 Nov 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[Many species of migratory waterfowl winter in India, and it is also year-round habitat for several resident waterfowl species. A recent study showed that HPAI outbreaks are strongly demarcated by wild waterfowl and their interface with domestic poultry in specific wetland habitat in India (https://doi.org/10.3390/v12111290). - Mod.PMBProMED map:Agar, Madhya Pradesh, India: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700157,56700] See Also

Active surveillance is ongoingControl measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: traceability; screening; quarantine; disinfection; disinfestationDomestic control measures to be applied: surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultCentral Veterinary Reference laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (IVO) national laboratory / birds / 2 / real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / [28 Nov 2021] / positive[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[Iran may represent a hotspot for HPAI virus introduction, dissemination, and for the generation of new genetic variability. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-12-06 01:50:03 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (169): Europe (France) poultry, HPAI H5N1, control Archive Number: 20211206.8700090AVIAN INFLUENZA (169): EUROPE (FRANCE) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, CONTROL******************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 3 Dec 2021Source: Agrazeitungt/Feed Magazine [edited]https://www.agrarzeitung.de/feedmagazine/feedmagazine-news/france-avian-influenza-in-livestock-98593In France, the latest epidemic has hit a farm with laying hens. It is the 1st case in a commercial livestock farm.According to the Ministry of Agriculture, highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) was detected last Friday [27 Nov 2021] on a laying hen farm in the Nord department, just a few kilometres from the Belgian border. Investigations were currently underway to trace the route of infection.According to the ministry, the flock was culled and the farm immediately disinfected. A protection zone and a surveillance zone had been set up around the outbreak. This is connected with strict biosecurity regulations for poultry farmers and a transport ban for birds.The alliance of the Confederation Paysanne (Conf), an association of small farmers, and the Federation of Organic Farmers (FNAB), meanwhile, stressed that the farm in question was a commercial one with 160 000 birds and was also located in a region with close links to Belgium, Germany, and the Netherlands. The organisations had jointly lodged a complaint with the Supreme Administrative Court in order to bring down the new disease protection requirements. Among other things, they see high hurdles for exemptions from the stall obligation endangering animal welfare and the existence of free-range farms.According to Conf and FNAB, there is scientific evidence that the risk of introducing avian influenza into free-range systems is generally low. The spread of the disease depends mainly on the density of the flock, and the transport of goods and animals and the introduction of people also play an important role in the spread of the virus. It is also criticised that exemptions from the obligation to keep animals in confined areas are only possible if a veterinarian has previously certified that the animals are suffering from the disease.In France, according to official data, 4 cases of avian influenza in wild birds and 3 cases in backyard flocks have been registered so far. Lac de Madine in the Grand-Est region [map at <tinyurl.com/2hsb33ah>] is currently experiencing high mortality in swans, according to the ministry. Of the population of more than 1000 individuals, about 1/5 have died, it said. The previous epidemic, which came to a halt only last spring, had been concentrated in the southwest of the country and affected 492 commercial livestock farms, according to the ministry. By official order, a total of about 3.5 million birds, mostly ducks, had been killed at the time [see comment].--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The above outbreak was reported by France to the OIE on Fri 27 Nov 2021, following the confirmation of HPAI H5N1 in the commercial laying hen farm on 26 Nov 2021; see item [10] in 20211205.8700016. The immediate notification included the following information on the affected population: "Increase in mortality in a laying hen farm (15 000 deaths out of 80 000). The farm is composed of 2 separate buildings (2 x 80 000 hens). Depopulation is in progress in the outbreak, and preliminary disinfection will be applied. An epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Movements of poultry and poultry products from farms keeping poultry in the protection and surveillance zones is prohibited. The origin of the infection is not known at this time."The above media addresses the reservations of the farming industry, challenging the applied control and prevention measures. These measures are prescribed by EU legislation, based upon scientific opinion. Some of the measures have been recently reviewed; see Nielsen S S, Alvarez J, Bicout D J, et al. Scientific Opinion on the assessment of the control measures of the category A diseases of Animal Health Law: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza. EFSA Journal. 2021; 19(1): 6372, 78 pp; https://doi.org/10.2903/j.efsa.2021.6372.The current epizootic, involving many European and other countries, is caused by HPAI H5N1. The earlier epizootic in France, mainly affecting the duck industry in the southwest, was caused by HPAI H5N8; see Guinat C, Artois J, Bronner A, et al. Duck production systems and highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 in France, 2016-2017. Sci Rep. 2019; 9: 6177; https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-019-42607-x. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of France: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700090,100] See Also

Outbreak ID ob_93343 - HPAI was confirmed in a backyard.Outbreak ID ob_93342 - HPAI was confirmed in a farm.Outbreak ID ob_93348 - HPAI was confirmed in the public hunting area in Trakiya, Chekeritsa.Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / VaccinatedBirds / 119 187 / 1 / 1113 / 118 074 / - / -Phasianidae (unidentified) (Phasianidae (incognita)): Phasianidae-Galliformes / 685 / 205 / 205 / 480 / - / ---Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. According to the media report (https://www.reuters.com/markets/commodities/bulgaria-reports-bird-flu-outbreak-industrial-farm-2021-12-03/), Bulgarian veterinary authorities will cull more than 80 000 chickens in the southern village of Tsalapitsa after a bird flu outbreak was confirmed at an industrial farm there, the food safety agency said on Friday [3 Dec 2021]. The agency said it had also found the highly contagious disease at a backyard farm in the same village and at a backyard farm in the nearby village of Varvara and would cull about 100 chickens there. We believe the outbreaks detected in Tsalapitsa correspond to the outbreak identified in the OIE report as ID ob_93350 (laying hen commercial farm) and ID ob_93343 (backyard). This is because the village of Tsalapitsa (Plovdiv district) is part of Rodopi municipality. - Mod.CRD]******[14] Slovakia (Banskobystricky): wild bird, HPAI H5N1Date: Fri 3 Dec 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43731Event started on 24 Nov 2021. A total of 2 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [3 Dec 2021]. HPAI H5N1 has been detected in 7 mute swans (_Cygnus olor_) in the nature park of Lonjsko Polje, Sisacko-Moslavacka County.[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The latest ECDC's communicable disease threat report (CDTR), week 46, 14 -20 Nov 2021 available at https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Communicable-disease-threats-report-week%2046-2021.pdf, mentioned that: "Following the autumn bird migration, an increasing number of outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) have been reported from many countries across the EU/EEA, with large outbreaks in the poultry sector in Italy and in wild birds and poultry in Germany. Sweden declared the risk as very high and raised its threat level to 2. In the United Kingdom, an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone was declared across Great Britain on 3 Nov 2021. To date, no human cases have been reported in the EU/EEA. Outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry and wild birds have recently been reported for the first time in Japan and South Korea. According to WHO, between January 2003 and 4 Nov 2021, 863 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported globally, from 18 countries. Of these, 456 were fatal (CFR: 53%). The most recent case was reported from India in July 2021. No human infections with the currently circulating A(H5N1) viruses of clade 2.3.4.4b have been reported to date. A new publication (C. Adlhoch et al., 2021 at https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S1198743X21006327) outlines the latest situation and aims to raise awareness among clinicians to test for avian influenza in cases with previous exposure to possibly infected birds". - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED maps:Baden-Württemberg, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,4181Saxony-Anhalt, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,5189Saxony, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,4206Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,9631Brandenburg, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,10517Thuringia, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,5186Bavaria, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,3744Luxembourg: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,103Slovakia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,114Croatia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,74North Rhine-Westphalia, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,2238Hamburg, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,3715Pazardzhik, Pazardzhit, Bulgaria: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,6035Plovdiv, Bulgaria: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,63444Hauts-de-France, France: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700016,59405] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-12-03 19:46:51 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (167): Israel (HM) wild bird, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20211203.8700041AVIAN INFLUENZA (167): ISRAEL (HAMERKAZ) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, OIE******************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 2 Dec 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43604Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Israel--------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 29 Nov 2021Confirmed: 30 Nov 2021Reported: 1 Dec 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 9 Apr 2021Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Mishmar Hasharon, HaMerkazStarted: 29 Nov 2021Epidemiological unit: natural parkAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedGreat white pelican (_Pelecanus onocrotalus_): Pelecanidae-Phaethontiformes / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: the pelican was found near a water pond. It was transferred to the wildlife hospital and died there.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species.Epidemiological comments: several outbreaks in poultry have occurred in Israel in the past few weeks. The hypothesis is that the domestic birds are infected by fomites sourced from wild birds. Israel is a migration route for about 500 million birds twice a year between Africa and Asia. The pond where the pelican was found is about 20 km [12.4 mi] from one of the outbreaks in poultry (Maayan Zvi).Control measures at event levelWild control measures to be applied: surveillance within containment and/or the protection zoneAdditional measures: zoning, disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Division (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 1 Dec 2021 / positiveNorthern Poultry Health Laboratory (regional laboratory) / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [12-13 Oct 2021] / positiveKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Division (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [12-13 Oct 2021] / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED[The great white pelican (_Pelecanus onocrotalus_) is a huge bird that breeds from southeastern Europe through Asia and Africa, in swamps and shallow lakes. It is highly sociable and often forms large flocks. Wintering takes place in northeastern Africa through Iraq to north India, with a particularly large number of breeders from Asia wintering around Pakistan and Sri Lanka. - Mod.PMBThe location of the water pond where the sick pelican was collected is available at http://tinyurl.com/bdhb59pm. This is one of 2 water bodies, countrywide, that have become "pelican-friendly reservoirs" within a cooperative effort by Israel's Ministry of Agriculture (fisheries division), the Fish Farmers' Organization, the National Parks & Nature Reserves, and respective regional municipalities, to minimise the friction between man and pelican. Until 2012, serious economic losses caused by the pelicans to fish farms compelled farmers to take drastic measures driving the birds away. Since 2013, the pelicans, mostly arriving in October and staying to early December, are provided in the 2 locations a substitute food source. Tonnes of second-rate fish that are destined to be thrown away/recycled because they are not commercial while the ponds are seasonally emptied, are purchased at the cost of labor and transportation and moved to the 2 reservoirs (the other one is in northern Israel). A byproduct is reducing hazard to air traffic by encouraging the birds to remain, before continuing their flight to Africa, at a single location (https://www.iaf.org.il/4374-38053-EN/IAF.aspx).Israel's "when and where" regarding the great white pelican is available at https://www.birds.org.il/en/species-page/95/species-trends.A recent feeding session of the pelicans, late October 2021, can be viewed at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dcnxFsfmC-c.The thousands of pelicans in the Mishmar Hasharon reservoir have become, during the current and previous seasons, a national public attraction. During their recent stay, terminating at this time (early December), no overt disease or excessive deaths have been reported. The detection of a single HPAI H5N1 sick, infected bird (date of its initial collection not available) underlines the need for an enhanced One Health approach, including animal and public health authorities, ornithologists, nature protection and water supply agencies, during the seasons ahead. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of HaMerkaz, Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8700041,17787] See Also

Plt)Started on: 20 Nov 2021Confirmed on: 25 Nov 2021Reported on: 30 Nov 2021Species: common shelduckCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusGenotype / serotype / subtype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryReason for notification: 1st occurrence in a zone or a compartmentThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaksSummary of outbreakTotal outbreaks (1)Outbreak locations: Caofeidian Wetland and Bird Provincial Nature Reserve [Tangshan, Hebei]Date of the start of the outbreak: 20 Nov 2021Status: ongoingTotal animals affected:Species / susceptible / cases / deaths / killed and disposed of / slaughtered or killed for commercial use / vaccinated / morbidity (calculated) / mortality (calculated)Common shelduck (_Tadorna tadorna_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 134 / 134 / 0 / 0 / 0 / - / -EpidemiologySource of event or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; zoningDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and typeHarbin National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory (OIE reference laboratory)Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultCommon shelduck / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 25 Nov 2021 / positiveCommon shelduck / 1 / virus isolation / 25 Nov 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The common shelduck (_Tadorna tadorna_) is a waterfowl species widespread and common in the Euro-Siberian region of the Palearctic, mainly breeding in temperate and wintering in subtropical regions. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-12-01 02:12:56 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (165): Europe (UK) poultry, wild, HPAI H5N1, spread Archive Number: 20211201.8699982AVIAN INFLUENZA (165): EUROPE (UK) POULTRY, WILD, HPAI HPN1, SPREAD*******************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 29 Nov 2021Source: Melton Times [edited]https://www.meltontimes.co.uk/country-and-farming/warning-to-the-public-after-bird-flu-found-in-hickling-swan-3474888Residents in the Hickling area are being urged not to touch or pick up sick birds after bird flu was detected in a swan in the village.The warning follows a 3 km [1.9 mi] and 10 km [6.2 mi] temporary control zone being put in place in Charnwood District, affecting many villages west of Melton, after a case was found in a poultry farm at Barrow upon Soar.These are among a number of confirmed cases of avian influenza across Great Britain in recent weeks, and from today (Monday [29 Nov 2021]) onwards, it will be a legal requirement for all bird keepers to keep their birds indoors and to follow strict biosecurity measures in order to limit the spread of the disease.All poultry and captive bird keepers must also continue taking extra precautions to keep their flocks safe, including regularly cleaning and disinfecting equipment.Wild birds migrating to the UK from mainland Europe during the winter months can carry the disease, and this can lead to cases in poultry and other captive birds.Following the Hickling case coming to light, Councillor John Cottee, chair of Nottinghamshire County Council's communities committee, said: "The news that a swan has tested positive for avian flu will obviously be of concern to residents; however, the risk of the disease transferring from birds to humans is considered to be very low."That said, it is important that people do not touch any sick or dead birds, and I would also urge people not to feed any swans, particularly in the Hickling area, as feeding encourages them to congregate, and that increases the risk of the disease spreading."As well as issuing an appeal for the public not to touch or move dead birds, I am also asking dog owners to keep their pets away from them."Rushcliffe Borough Council's cabinet portfolio holder for environment and safety, Councillor Rob Inglis, said: "Whilst the risk is considered to be very low, it's important everyone including pet owners take these steps to ensure they or their pets do not touch or go near sick or dying birds."Posters are being put up across the area asking the public not to feed ducks or swans and reminding residents to keep to footpaths and to keep dogs on leads.Anyone who finds dead wild waterfowl (swans, geese, or ducks) or other dead wild birds, such as gulls or birds of prey, should report them to the DEFRA helpline (03459 335577).--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[A steadily increasing number of HPAI H5N1-infected wild birds has been reported from the UK since the 43rd week of 2021. This was followed by introductions into poultry farms.ProMED's post 20211126.8699877 included a list of the 13 locations (15 holdings) in England where HPAI H5N1 had been confirmed on poultry farms. An additional suspected farm was mentioned, recorded near Barrow upon Soar, Charnwood, Leicestershire, of which the pathogenicity, as of 25 Nov 2021, was pending. According to the above media report, the said farm has been added to the list, becoming England's 16th affected poultry farm (14th location).The details of wild birds confirmed positive for HPAI H5N1 since the start of the epizootic are available at https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1034245/ai-findings-2021.csv/preview. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Leicestershire, England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699982,15174] See Also

N-type has not been yet identified.Outbreak location 3: Proximity of Angut city - GharehAghaj- Mollalar, Germi, ArdebilStarted: 30 Oct 2021Ended: 1 Nov 2021Epidemiological unit: villageAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 500 / 500 / 250 / 250 / 0 / 0Affected population: ducks, turkeys, chicken, geese.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive.Epidemiological comments: the event was reported according to the Iran passive surveillance in place.A post-outbreak investigation to trace the source of infection is ongoing to detect the probable spread and circulation of this subtype. Active surveillance is ongoingControl measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: traceability; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; stamping out; disinfection; ante and post-mortem inspections; disinfestation; movement control inside the country; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; quarantine; screening; selective killing and disposal.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultCentral Veterinary Reference laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (IVO) national laboratory / birds / 1 / real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / [23 - 30 Oct 2021] / positive[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Some countries in the Middle East are located along wild bird migratory routes, suggesting a likely source of transmission and spread of the avian influenza virus along such routes.The following abstract is from Marashi SM, Sheykhi N, Modirrousta H, et al. Surveillance of highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (H5Nx Subtypes) in wild birds in Iran, 2014-2019." Arch Razi Inst. 2021 Sep 1;76(3):487-498; https://doi.org/10.22092/ari.2020.341897.1441--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Abstract--------"After the emergence of the highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses (HPAIV) subtypes H5N6 in 2013 and H5N8 in 2014, a surveillance study using molecular epidemiology approaches was carried out during 2014-2019 in Iran to discover any potential introduction or outbreak of HPAIV in wild bird populations. All sick and dead wild birds found in nature, or in cases of an outbreak, a collection of representative samples was tested using the specific molecular methods for HPAIV H5 subtypes. Additionally, wild bird species in wetlands, several zoos, zoological gardens, or rehabilitation centers were tested for HPAIV. During the active surveillance plan, several individual and outbreak cases of HPAIV and orthoavulaviruses were identified. In general, more than 900 fecal materials, cloacal and oropharyngeal swabs, and/or tissue samples were collected from apparently healthy live birds representing several different species and families. In addition, tissue and swab samples were collected and investigated from any reported wild bird mortality cases in different parts of Iran in the framework of this study. No positive bird was found among apparently healthy live birds; however, the highly pathogenic influenza viruses of H5N1, H5N2, H5N6, and H5N8 were found in individual dead birds or mass die-off cases." - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Iran: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699976,128] See Also

On 22 Nov 2021, the Kagoshima University conducted RT-PCR and gene sequencing tests and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N8.Control measures at event levelDomestic and wild control measures applied: screeningDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultKagoshima University (private laboratory) / birds / 1 / gene sequencing / 22 Nov 2021 / positiveKagoshima University (private laboratory) / birds / 1 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 22 Nov 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Since the end of August 2020, H5N8 highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses have been detected in wild bird and poultry species in Russia, Kazakhstan, Israel, European Union countries, South Korea and Japan. Introductions of HPAIVs circulating in Europe into Japan are believed to be caused by migratory birds, such as the white-fronted goose. These species of migratory wild birds tend to winter in Europe and breed in Siberia during the summer, where they may co-mingle with migratory birds that winter in Asia. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699918,6775.] See Also

HPAI H5N1 was detected in a backyard in Huntwangen, Bulach, Zurich.Epidemiological comments: Two backyard chicken were found dead at the sanctuary and a sample was sent to the National Reference Center for Poultry and Rabbit Diseases (NRGK, Zurich, Switzerland), where it tested positive for avian influenza of the subtype H5N1 by RT-qPCR. Confirmation of the pathogenicity and further sequencing analyses are currently being carried out at the Institute of Virology and Immunology (IVI, Mittelhäusern, Switzerland). The animal sanctuary provides shelter for chicken, wild ducks, breeding ducks, pigeons, ornamental birds and other non-avian animals. Until Wednesday noon [24 Nov 2021], 22 of 30 symptomatic poultry have died. The remaining 8 will be culled immediately. The establishment has been put under movement restriction and further measures such as establishing protection and surveillance zones are foreseen for the coming days. Today, we have provided an alert to all holdings to implement biosafety measures.Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / VaccinatedBirds / 30 / 22 / 22 / 8 / 0 / 0[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org> ******[8] Austria (Lower Austria): backyard, HPAI H5N1Date: Fri 26 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=43304Event started on 23 Nov 2021. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-26 10:02:15 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (160): Europe (UK) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread, control Archive Number: 20211126.8699877AVIAN INFLUENZA (160): EUROPE (UK) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD, CONTROL**********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 24 Nov 2021Source: South West Farmer [edited]https://www.southwestfarmer.co.uk/news/19738977.bird-flu-confirmed-dorset/A case [see comment] of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 has been confirmed in commercial poultry near Pokesdown, Bournemouth. Temporary Control Zones of 3 km (4.8 miles) and 10 km (6.2 miles) have been put in force around an area centred on Castlemain Avenue. This is the first outbreak in the south west during the resurgence of the disease that began in October [2021].Bird flu has been confirmed in captive birds and commercial and non-commercial poultry in Worcestershire, Warwickshire, Essex, Lancashire, North Yorkshire, Derbyshire, Cumbria, Cheshire and Norfolk. An Avian Influenza Prevention Zone (AIPZ) was declared across the whole of the country on [3 Nov 2021] to mitigate the risk of the disease spreading. It is now a legal requirement for all bird keepers in the UK to follow strict biosecurity measures.Keepers with more than 500 birds will need to restrict access for non-essential people on their sites, workers will need to change clothing and footwear before entering bird enclosures and site vehicles will need to be cleaned and disinfected regularly to limit the risk of the disease spreading.Backyard owners with smaller numbers of poultry including chickens, ducks and geese must also take steps to limit the risk of the disease spreading to their animals.Avian influenza circulates naturally in wild birds and when they migrate to the UK from mainland Europe over the winter they can spread the disease to poultry and other captive birds. The UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) has said that avian influenza is primarily a disease of birds and the risk to the general public's health is very low.[byline: Lisa Young] --communicated by:ProMED <promed@promedmail.org>[The glossary of OIE's Terrestrial Animal Health Code includes the following definitions:- "case" means "an individual animal infected by a pathogenic agent, with or without clinical signs";- "outbreak" means "the occurrence of one or more cases in an epidemiological unit"; - "epidemiological unit" means a group of animals with the same likelihood of exposure to a pathogenic agent. In certain circumstances, the epidemiological unit may be a single animal"; and- "animal" means a mammal, reptile, bird or bee.The applied term "case" (and not "outbreak"), in reference to the event reported from Pokesdown and in other HPAI H5N1 events, is in need of clarification. According to the updated (25 Nov 2021) avian influenza report published by UK's government agencies DEFRA & APH (https://www.gov.uk/guidance/avian-influenza-bird-flu#cases-in-the-uk), the recent confirmed events are the following.A. Poultry and captive birds1. England, H5N1 cases of which pathogenicity has been confirmed:- near Droitwich Spa, Wychavon, Worcestershire (rescue centre - captive birds - non-poultry)- near Alcester, Bidford, Warwickshire (small commercial poultry flock)- near Frinton-on-Sea, Tendring, Essex- near Salwick, Fylde, Lancashire (commercial poultry)- near Leeming Bar, Hambleton, North Yorkshire (commercial poultry)*- near Kirkham, Fylde, Lancashire (non-commercial poultry)- near Willington, South Derbyshire, Derbyshire (commercial poultry)- near Pokesdown, Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole (commercial poultry)- near Silecroft, Copeland, Cumbria (commercial poultry)- near Mouldsworth, Cheshire West and Chester, Cheshire (commercial poultry)- near North Fambridge, Maldon, Essex (backyard poultry)- near Wells-next-the-Sea, North Norfolk, Norfolk- near Thirsk, Hambleton, North Yorkshire**- *second premises near Leeming Bar, Hambleton, North Yorkshire- **second premises near Thirsk, Hambleton, North Yorkshire2. England, H5N1 cases of which pathogenicity is pending (as of 25 Nov 2021): near Barrow upon Soar, Charnwood, Leicestershire.3. Scotland, H5N1 cases of which pathogenicity has been confirmed:- in the Angus constituencySee the Scottish Government website for further information.4. Wales, H5N1 cases of which pathogenicity has been confirmed:- near Chirk, Wrexham, Wales (backyard chickens and wild birds)5. Northern IrelandThere have been no cases of avian influenza confirmed in Northern Ireland during the 2021 to 2022 season.B. Wild birdsSince the 43rd week of 2021, increased numbers of the collected wild birds have tested positive for HPAI H5N1; details are available at https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1034245/ai-findings-2021.csv/preview.In view of the concerning spread of HPAI H5N1 across Great Britain, the chief veterinary officers for England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland have agreed to bring in new measures to help protect poultry and captive birds. The national housing measures, applicable to all birds, whether they are part of a commercial or backyard flock, will come into force across the UK from 00:01 on Mon 29 Nov 2021. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Bournemouth, England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699877,8390] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-25 10:10:53 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (159): USA (MN) turkey, LPAI H5 Archive Number: 20211125.8699867AVIAN INFLUENZA (159): USA (MINNESOTA) TURKEY, LPAI H5******************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 23 Nov 2021Source: KDUZ [edited]https://kduz.com/2021/11/23/kandiyohi-county-turkey-flock-tests-positive-for-avian-influenza/Routine testing by the Minnesota Board of Animal Health has found H5 low-pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) in a commercial turkey flock in Kandiyohi County, which has been confirmed by the USDA National Veterinary Services Laboratories. Officials say it does not pose a risk to the public, and there is no food safety concern for consumers. This is not the same virus causing the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) outbreak in the Midwest in 2015."Testing birds before they go to market is standard protocol for our poultry flocks in Minnesota because it verifies healthy birds are sent to market, and if disease is detected, we can hold the flock and work quickly with producers to address the disease," said state veterinarian Dr Beth Thompson. The board quarantined the flock on Mon 22 Nov [2021] and continues to monitor and test the flock as well as commercial poultry operations and individuals with backyard flocks within 10 km [6.2 mi] for signs of the disease.Avian influenza is not a food safety issue. The board is working with federal, state, and industry partners in its response.[byline: Mark]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>["Low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) viruses typically cause little or no clinical signs in infected poultry. The LPAI virus is excreted through infected birds' feces and respiratory secretions. It spreads primarily through direct contact between healthy and infected birds. It can also be spread through indirect contact with contaminated equipment and materials."To prevent cases of LPAI, poultry producers must use special preventative measures and precautions on the farm. If LPAI is detected, farms must be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected. AI viruses are inactivated by heat and drying. They are also very sensitive to most disinfectants and detergents. To ensure thorough disinfection, organic material must first be cleaned from the environment."When LPAI findings occur, APHIS and its state partners work to address them quickly and keep the disease from spreading to new flocks. Because LPAI does not typically kill poultry the way that HPAI does, there may be additional control options beyond depopulation. Federal and state officials will work with producers to determine what option(s) are available." (https://www.aphis.usda.gov/aphis/ourfocus/animalhealth/animal-disease-information/avian/avian-influenza/defend-the-flock-lpai-info). - Mod.TGHealthMap/ProMED map of Kandiyohi County, Minnesota, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699867,45208.] See Also

HPAI H5N1 has been detected in wild birds and in rescued wild swans (adults and young), rescued and captive geese, ducks, and chickens, in England, Wales, and Scotland.Affected population: mallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_), Anatidae (unidentified) (Anatidae (incognita), Greylag goose (_Anser anser_), pink-footed goose (_Anser brachyrhynchus_), Canada goose (_Branta canadensis_), barnacle goose (_Branta leucopsis_), Eurasian buzzard (common buzzard) (_Buteo buteo_), whooper swan (_Cygnus cygnus_), _Cygnus_ (unidentified), mute swan (_Cygnus olor_), peregrine falcon (_Falco peregrinus_), Laridae (unidentified), herring gull (_Larus argentatus_), Eurasian curlew (_Numenius arquata_), common pheasant (_Phasianus colchicus_), great crested grebe (_Podiceps cristatus_), and rescued wild swans (adults and young), rescued and captive geese, ducks, and chickens.[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>******[10] United Kingdom: poultry, HPAI H5N1Date: Fri 19 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42924Event started on 2 Nov 2021. These outbreaks are located in Bashkortostan (3) and Tatarstan (1).Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / VaccinatedBirds / 142 868 / 8484 / 8484 / - / 0 / 0[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map of Russia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699830,98]Since October 2021, the number of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) cases caused mostly by the H5N1 subtype has continued to increase. Although most detections have been in wild birds, many have also been in poultry.The increase of detections in wild birds points to a period of high risk in countries having migratory flyways this season. Poultry producers, small and large alike, must therefore implement all the necessary biosecurity measures to protect their flocks from exposure and infection. - Mod.CRD] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-24 22:23:19 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (24): China (GZ) H9N2 Archive Number: 20211124.8699804AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (24): CHINA (GUIZHOU) H9N2*************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 19 Nov 2021Source: PoultryMed [edited]https://www.poultrymed.com/templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=178&FID=4970&IID=81886A new case of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) was reported from China. The case is a 39 year old man from Qiandongnan Autonomous Prefecture, Guizhou Prefecture. The case developed symptoms on 29 Oct 2021 and was hospitalised the same day with severe condition. He died on 1 Nov 2021.As of 16 Nov 2021 and since 1998, a total of 94 laboratory-confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) viruses have been reported, from China (82), Egypt (4), Bangladesh (3), Cambodia (1), Oman (1), Pakistan (1), India (1), and Senegal (1). Most of the cases were children with mild disease.--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Influenza A(H9N2) viruses are enzootic in poultry populations in parts of Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. Most human cases are exposed to the A(H9N2) virus through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments. Human infection tends to result in mild clinical illness.The continued presence of H9N2 influenza viruses in poultry markets in southern China increases the likelihood of avian-to-human interspecies transmission.Avian H9N2 influenza A viruses have caused repeated human infections in Asia since 1998. An H9N2 influenza virus infected a 5 year old child in Hong Kong in 2003.Furthermore, the number of human infections with A/H9N2 avian influenza viruses has been higher in 2021 than in earlier years (23 cases, including the case in the above report), which is a cause for concern and highlights the need for continuous monitoring and risk assessments of these viruses with pandemic potential. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map of Guizhou Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699804,335.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-23 17:45:04 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (157): Israel (HD,HZ) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread, RFI Archive Number: 20211123.8699838AVIAN INFLUENZA (157): ISRAEL (HADAROM, HAZAFON) HPAI H5N1, SPREAD, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION*******************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 19 Nov 2021Source: The World News [abridged, edited]https://theworldnews.net/il-news/health-ministry-reports-avian-flu-cases-at-pair-of-bird-farmsThe Health Ministry on Friday [19 Nov 2021] said it has received reports that the H5N1 strain of avian [influenza] has been detected at 2 Israeli farming communities. According to the ministry, the reported cases were at a turkey farm on Ein Tzurim in southern Israel, and on a duck farm at Kfar Baruch in the north. The ministry said "it was decided to provide preventive treatment to those defined as contacts," and that its offices in the north were reaching out to schools and others who visited the petting zoo at Kfar Baruch. There have been no reported cases in Israel of H5N1 among humans [ever].The Health Ministry added that the bird farms were "under the treatment" of the Agriculture Ministry, without elaborating. The H5N1 subtype of avian flu can be deadly if transferred to humans. Israeli and Palestinian growers have dealt with sporadic outbreaks of the virus over the years, with hundreds of thousands of birds culled to stop the virus from spreading.In 2006, southern Israel's poultry industry was brought nearly to the brink of collapse, growers said, after a number of culls following the discovery of bird flu.--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[ProMED thanks Mahmoud Orabi for the submission above.The Ministry of Agriculture published on Sun 21 Nov 2021 the following press release (in Hebrew, translated): "H5N1 avian influenza was detected in 2 foci. The first focus is a duck farm in Kfar Baruch, keeping 17 500 ducks, and a turkey farm in Kibbutz Ein Tzurim, which has 21 000 turkeys."Upon receiving the laboratory test results confirming avian influenza, the veterinary services at the Ministry of Agriculture isolated the holding and started the application of the control measures. The office conducts active monitoring in all the surrounding poultry farms, as well as elsewhere."At the same time, the ministry operates in full coordination with the Ministry of Health."The distance (as the crow flies) between Ein Tzurim (Hadarom district, south west) and Kfar Baruch (Hazafon, centre north) is 100 km (62 mi); for their respective geographic locations, see map at https://tinyurl.com/4zbsew58.With the addition of the 2 new outbreaks, Israel's number of HPAI H5N1 outbreaks, since the start (29 Oct 2021) of the current season's epizootic, totals 4. The last previous H5N1 event in Israel took place in 2015.During the winters 2019/2020 and 2020/2021, HPAI H5N8 was recorded. The final HPAI report of the 2020/2021 season -- during which HPAI H5N8 was predominantly identified in wild, migrating birds -- was submitted to the OIE in June 2021 (available, with map, at https://www.gov.il/BlobFolder/reports/avian-flu-7-21/he/animals_health_avian-influenza_Follow-up-report-7-H5N8-wild-animals-FInal-07-06-21.pdf).Israel is situated on main flyways of migrating birds. No infected birds are known to have been identified (yet) during the current season. Updated information on undertaken surveillance activities will be welcomed. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699838,90] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-22 17:35:17 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (156): South Korea (HB) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread Archive Number: 20211122.8699828AVIAN INFLUENZA (156): SOUTH KOREA (NORTH CHUNGCHEONG) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD*********************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 22 Nov 2021Source: Yonhap News TV [in Korean, machine trans., abridged, edited] https://www.yna.co.kr/view/AKR20211122162500003Avian Influenza (AI) Central Infection Control Headquarters announced on [Mon 22 Nov 2021] that highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] subtype H5N1 has been confirmed at a broiler farm in Eumseong, North Chungcheong Province. The farm, including about 92 000 broilers, is located within a 3km [about 1.9 mi] radius of the Eumseong quail farm, where HPAI was detected on [Mon 8 Nov 2021].This is the 7th confirmed outbreak of HPAI in poultry this fall [2021], and the 4th negative case.Separately, a suspected case of HPAI emerged on the same day [Mon 22 Nov 2021] at a meat duck farm in Damyang, Jeollanam-do. The farm raises about 10 000 ducks.[byline: Lee Young-seop]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[South Korea's first HPAI outbreak this fall/winter season (2021) started, reportedly, on 8 Nov 2021, affecting a quail farm in Eumseong, North Chungcheong Province. The causative pathogen was identified on 10 Nov 2021 as HPAI H5N1 and notified to the OIE. ProMED published the notification (20211116.8699695). Mod CRD's commentary indicated that between 9 and 11 Nov 2021, 2 new outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 were identified in duck farms. One, located on a farm in Gyosan-ri, Naju, Jeollanam-do (South Jeolla Province); the other one located on a farm in Bondae ri, Eumseong, Chungcheongbuk-do (North Chungcheong Province). (OIE's follow-up No 1 is available at https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42594).S Korea's most recent (7th) confirmed HPAI outbreak is situated close to the first outbreak.Since 2004, when HPAI was reported for the 1st time in S Korea, 3 serotypes of the virus have been reported from the country, mainly during the winter seasons: H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8. The most devastating epizootic was caused during the winter season of 2016-2017, by the H5N6 subtype, co-circulating with H5N8; the latter caused fewer outbreaks.The current season's epizootic started earlier than last year's (2020).Some media sources have recently referred to recent H5N8 outbreaks in S Korea; we have, so far, not been able to get this confirmed. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:South Korea: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699828,195] See Also

HPAI H5N1 was detected in wild birds in Ida-Viru, Parnu, Laane, Laane-Viru counties.Affected population: Northern goshawk (_Accipiter gentilis_), Anserinae (unidentified) (Anserinae (unidentified)), Black-headed gull (_Chroicocephalus ridibundus_), White-tailed eagle (_Haliaeetus albicilla_), Laridae (unidentified) (Laridae (incognita)), Herring gull (_Larus argentatus)_, Great cormorant (_Phalacrocorax carbo_).[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[A map of HPAI detection in Europe from 1 Oct 2021 to 19 Nov 2021 is available at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2021/Map_AI_EU_2021-11-18.jpg."Because of the stability of the virus in the environment and highly contagious nature, strict biosecurity measures and good hygiene are essential in protecting against disease outbreaks."Measures include:- Keep poultry away from areas frequented by wild fowl- Do not keep on the premises elements that may attract wild birds, including poultry feed products placed outside the building- Maintain strict control over access to flocks by vehicles, people and equipment- Ensure the sanitation of property, poultry houses and equipment- Avoid the introduction of birds of unknown disease status into the flock- Report any bird illnesses and deaths to the Veterinary Services- Ensure appropriate disposal of manure, litter and dead poultry- Vaccinate animals where appropriate"(Source: OIE Avian Influenza Portal https://www.oie.int/en/disease/avian-influenza/#ui-id-6). - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Europe: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699760,6010] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-18 10:57:46 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (153): Japan (HG) poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread Archive Number: 20211118.8699747AVIAN INFLUENZA (153): JAPAN (HYOGO) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 18 Nov 2021Source: 24/7 News Bulletin, Cumhuriyet (Turkish daily newspaper) report [edited]https://247newsbulletin.com/world/12122.htmlThe bird flu [avian influenza] epidemic, which emerged in a chicken farm in Japan last week and gradually increased its effect, spread to another province of the country. An outbreak of bird flu has been confirmed at a poultry production facility in Himeji city in Hyogo province. It was reported that a large-scale disinfection work was started in the region due to the epidemic that emerged as a result of genetic tests after the death of an abnormal number of chickens suspiciously on the farm. The state administration set up a crisis desk to decide on the measures to be taken.The 1st bird flu outbreak of the year [2021] in Japan was confirmed at a chicken farm in Akita province last week [week of 8 Nov 2021], and 143 000 chickens were killed as a precaution. Then, a total of 49 500 animals perished due to the epidemic that spread to 2 different chicken farms in Kagoshima province. The detection of the highly contagious subtype H5N8 in Kagoshima Prefecture last year [2020], causing the country's largest outbreak of avian flu since the 2005-2006 season, raised concerns. With the latest development, the number of provinces with confirmed avian flu outbreaks in Japan this year has increased to three.The bird flu epidemic in Japan spread to many provinces across the country last year [2020], and it was announced that the number of killed poultry exceeded 6 million, breaking a record. Due to the spread of the epidemic throughout the country, the Japan Self-Defense Forces (SDF) also supported the culling efforts. It was recorded that the previous record belonged to the 2005-2006 season when a total of 5 078 000 chickens were killed due to a less contagious type of the virus.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Japan's Hyogo prefecture is located in the Kansai region of Honshu, bordering Kyoto Prefecture to the east, Osaka Prefecture to the southeast, and Okayama Prefecture and Tottori Prefecture to the west. The new outbreak has already been subtyped as HPAI H5N1 (https://www3.nhk.or.jp/lnews/kobe/20211118/2020016081.html; in Japanese) and is located almost halfway between the earlier HPAI-affected prefectures: Akita (outbreak no 1 of the current AI season; subtyped H5N8), about 700 kilometers (about 440 miles) to the north of Hyogo, and Kagoshima, where outbreaks 2 (subtyped H5N1) and 3 are located, about 550 km (about 340 miles) to the south of Hyogo. For a map presenting Japan's prefectures, see https://vividmaps.com/japanese-prefectures/. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699747,4805] See Also
