View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-18 09:00:51 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (152): Japan (KS) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20211118.8699736AVIAN INFLUENZA (152): JAPAN (KAGOSHIMA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE****************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 16 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42695Highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Japan--------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 12 Nov 2021Confirmed: 15 Nov 2021Reported: 15 Nov 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 30 Jun 2021Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaksSummary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks (1)Outbreak location: Izumi City 1, Izumi, KagoshimaStarted: 12 Nov 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 38 500 / 23 / 23 / 38477 / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: on 12 Nov 2021, the local veterinary service (Livestock Hygiene Service Centre; LHSC) in Kagoshima Prefecture received a notification from a domestic laying hen farm on an increase in the number of dead birds. The samples were collected from dead birds by the LHSC and tested positive for influenza A virus by antigen-capture kits. On [13 Nov 2021], the LHSC conducted RT-PCR and RRT-PCR tests and confirmed that the subtype was H5. Subsequently stamping out on the affected farm was started. On [14 Nov 2021], stamping out was completed. Other control measures (including disinfection) in the affected farm are being implemented. On [15 Nov 2021], the National Institute of Animal Health (NIAH) conducted the sequencing test and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N1 and causative virus was determined as high pathogenicity avian influenza. This is the 2nd subtype of HPAI confirmed in domestic poultry in Japan in the 2021-2022 season after the H5N8 subtype was confirmed on [11 Nov 2021]. Movement and shipment restrictions are imposed on farms within a radius of 3 km [2 mi] and 3-10 km [2-6 mi] of the affected farm respectively. Note: The date of the last occurrence for the H5N1 subtype in Japan is [25 Mar 2011].Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; traceability; quarantine; screening; stamping out; disinfection; movement control inside the country; ante- and post-mortem inspectionsWild control measures applied: screeningDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultNational Institute of Animal Health (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / gene sequencing / 15 Nov 2021 / positiveLivestock Hygiene Service Centre (local laboratory) / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 13 Nov 2021 / positiveLivestock Hygiene Service Centre (local laboratory) / birds / 1 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 13 Nov 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[As mentioned in the epidemiological comments above, this is the 2nd subtype of HPAI confirmed in domestic poultry in Japan in the 2021-2022 season, after the H5N8 subtype was confirmed on 11 Nov 2021.The current avian influenza season began in October 2021, with several countries in Europe and Asia reporting cases of HPAI, mainly subtype H5N1, which differs from the previous season when the HPAI subtype H5N8 predominated.Unfortunately, everything seems to indicate that this new season 2021-2022 will be another challenging situation for the poultry sector in the region. Most cases thus far have been associated with the introduction of the HPAI virus from migratory wild birds, who are considered to be the main reservoir of avian influenza viruses. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699736,15326] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-17 21:26:06 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (151): poultry, vaccines & vaccination, OFFLU Archive Number: 20211117.8699732AVIAN INFLUENZA (151): POULTRY, VACCINES AND VACCINATION, OFFLU***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 17 Nov 2021From: Ian Brown <Ian.Brown@apha.gov.uk> [edited][ProMED posting 20211112.8699608 of 12 Nov 2021, "Announcements (09): OFFLU Avian Influenza Statement, 20170304.4877946," was accompanied by moderators' commentary that included the following:"It has been argued that AIV [avian influenza virus] transmission cycle cannot be fully blocked by mass vaccination if the viruses have a wild bird reservoir. This suggestion was supported by experience in China, where mass vaccination appeared to be more effective to minimize infections of AIV subtype H5 clade 7.2, which had no wild bird reservoir, than to minimize infections of clades 2.3.2 and 2.3.4, which did have wild bird reservoirs."The said comment referred to a linked review paper: Liu S, Zhuang Q, Wang S, et al. Control of avian influenza in China: Strategies and lessons. Transbound Emerg Dis. 2020; 67: 1463-1471; https://doi.org/10.1111/tbed.13515 (article 5.3, Vaccination effectiveness).Subsequently, ProMED received the following clarification from the Chair of OFFLU steering committee: a much appreciated, authoritative update. - Mods.AS/CRD]OFFLU would like to provide clarification regarding the moderators' comment about avian influenza vaccination: "It has been argued that AIV transmission cycle cannot be fully blocked by mass vaccination if the viruses have a wild bird reservoir."Vaccination against high pathogenicity avian influenza (HPAI) has been deployed mainly in places where the virus is endemic in poultry, and where stamping out, movement controls, and biosecurity measures were not, and would never, be sufficient to allow virus elimination, largely because of the nature and structure of the poultry sector. Vaccination in this situation aids in reducing outbreaks and the extent of virus circulation and therefore reduces zoonotic infections in humans (as has been seen from 2005 in Viet Nam against H5N1 HPAI and from late 2017 in China with vaccines against H7N9 viruses). Endemic infection with H5Nx HPAI in these places will likely persist, regardless of whether virus is present in wild birds (although new strains will, on occasion, be introduced). Vaccination is being applied against Goose/Guangdong/1/96-lineage H5Nx viruses in this manner, to selected poultry populations in multiple countries, including Bangladesh, China, Egypt, Indonesia, Iran, Russia, and Viet Nam. Unsanctioned vaccination has also been used in a number of other countries.The only place free from infection in poultry that uses vaccination as an additional preventive measure is Hong Kong SAR. Hong Kong SAR has a zero-tolerance approach to infection with HPAI viruses, in line with other places that do not have endemic infection. Vaccination against Goose/Guangdong/1/96-lineage H5Nx viruses in Hong Kong SAR was first used in 2002 and was made mandatory for all chicken flocks in 2003 when it became evident that measures based on biosecurity alone were not sufficient to prevent infection in farms and live poultry markets.  It has been used continuously since then, with regular updates of vaccine antigens to match strains of virus circulating in the broader region (and addition of a vaccine antigen against H7N9). Despite the presence of virus in wild birds in Hong Kong SAR in most years, there has been only one single farm outbreak in vaccinated poultry in 2008, associated with an antigenic variant strain. Vaccination, once fully deployed, also prevented infections in live bird markets.  The vaccination programme is accompanied by a monitoring programme in farms and markets to ensure that so-called "silent" infection is not occurring and that vaccinated birds have developed an appropriate immune response.Vaccination increases the resistance to infection and reduces the likelihood of transmission in vaccinated flocks. Suitable monitoring systems to detect infection in vaccinated flocks are needed if the goal is to retain freedom from infection in domestic poultry. Under Article 10.4.1.6 in the current OIE Terrestrial Code, vaccination will not affect the high pathogenicity avian influenza status of a free country or zone if (appropriate) surveillance supports the absence of infection.Given the repeated cycles of wild bird introduction of Goose/Guangdong/1/96-lineage H5Nx viruses, vaccination is being considered as an additional preventive measure by a number of countries, especially for higher risk poultry species and production systems. There are no reasons why it cannot be used successfully to prevent infection in poultry, even if present in wild birds, provided suitable vaccines are available, other appropriate biosecurity measures are applied (such as feeding strategies for birds reared outdoors that do not attract wild birds), and an appropriate, cost-effective surveillance system for all vaccinated flocks is in place.--Communicated by:Professor Ian H Brown, OBE, MIBiol PhDChair of OFFLU steering committee<secretariat@offlu.org>Head of Virology DepartmentDirector of OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza and Newcastle Disease; OIE Reference Laboratory for Swine InfluenzaAnimal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) - WeybridgeUnited Kingdom<Ian.Brown@apha.gov.uk>[The moderators' commentary also addressed the need for improved national reporting on HPAI vaccines, indicating the following: "According to OIE's WAHIS database, during 2019, vaccination against HPAI (subtype not specified) was applied in Egypt, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Mexico, and Pakistan. Such information for 2020 has, so far, become available only from Egypt and Pakistan. Reporting should be enhanced, including updated official information from all OIE's member countries."We are indebted to Dr Brown for helping in efforts to bridge the gap of information concerning recent vaccination policies and performance, while naming some of the countries engaged. Hopefully this will encourage OIE members to upgrade their reporting on AI vaccines/vaccination, allowing improvement of vaccines' efficacy. - Mods.AS/CRD] See Also

A total of 1 outbreak (submitted) reported to date [15 Nov 2021]. HPAI H5N1 was detected in a greater white-fronted goose (_Anser albifrons_), in the town of Szentlorinci, Baranya County. The event is continuing.Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered / VaccinatedGreater white-fronted goose (_Anser albifrons_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 1 / 1 / - / - / -[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[As mentioned before, "Wild birds are natural hosts and reservoirs for all types of avian influenza viruses, so play a major role in the evolution, maintenance, and spread of these viruses. The main wild species involved are waterfowls, gulls, and shorebirds; however, the virus seem to pass easily between different bird species."The incidence of infection appears to be seasonal, with the highest isolation rate being in juvenile birds in the fall of the year."Several routes of exposure of wild bird viruses to poultry have been documented or suspected of being the origins of outbreaks. Direct exposure to wild birds is the most likely transmission factor."Therefore, limiting exposure of poultry to wild birds through confinement rearing and other biosecurity measures provides an opportunity to reduce the risk of introduction of avian influenza virus from wild birds, and consequently is key to decrease the risk of evolution into highly pathogenic forms, exposure, and infection of humans, and recombination with human viruses components to form viruses that can not only infect humans but readily transmit among humans."(https://www.oie.int/en/disease/avian-influenza/)A map of HPAI detection in Europe from 1 Oct 2021 to 15 Nov 2021 is available at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2021/Map_AI_EU_2021-11-15.jpg. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Europe: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699685,6010] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-15 18:17:21 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (148): Japan (AK) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20211115.8699682AVIAN INFLUENZA (148): JAPAN (AKITA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, OIE************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 10 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42490Highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Japan------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 9 Nov 2021Confirmed: 10 Nov 2021Reported: 10 Nov 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 19 Jun 2021Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Yokote City, Yokote, AkitaStarted: 9 Nov 2021Epidemiological unit: farmAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 143 000 / 2 / 89 / 142 911 / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: On 9 Nov 2021, the local veterinary service in Akita Prefecture received a notification from a domestic laying hen farm on an increase in the number of dead birds. The samples were collected from dead birds by the local veterinary service (Livestock Hygiene Service Centre; LHSC) and tested positive for influenza A virus by antigen-capture kits. On 10 Nov [2021], the LHSC conducted RT-PCR and RRT-PCR tests and confirmed that the subtype was H5. On 11 Nov [2021], the National Institute of Animal Health (NIAH) conducted the sequencing test and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N8, and causative virus was determined as high pathogenicity avian influenza. Stamping-out policy is applied to the affected farm. Destruction of all the susceptible birds in the affected farm is being implemented. Movement and shipment restrictions are imposed on the farms within a radius of 3 km [1.9 mi] and 3-10 km [1.9-6.2 mi] of the affected farm, respectively.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; traceability; quarantine; screening; stamping out; disinfection; movement control inside the country; ante- and post-mortem inspectionsWild control measures applied: screeningDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultNational Institute of Animal Health (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / gene sequencing / 11 Nov 2021 / positiveLivestock Hygiene Service Centre (local laboratory) / birds / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 10 Nov 2021 / positiveLivestock Hygiene Service Centre (local laboratory) / birds / 1 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 10 Nov 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[As reported in ProMED post 20211112.8699631, an additional HPAI H5 outbreak in poultry was recorded in Japan on 12 Nov 2021, affecting a farm in Izumi City, Kagoshima Prefecture. The distance between Akita (in the Tohoku region of Honshu Island, north Japan) and Kagoshima (on Japan's southern island of Kyushu) is about 1247 kilometers (775 miles). The event in Kagoshima is yet to be officially reported, including the results of a sequencing test identifying the subtype of the HPAI H5 strain reported there.Both events are suspected to have been caused by the introduction of an H5 virus by migrating birds; this deserves further epidemiological investigations. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Akita Prefecture, Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699682,3224] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-13 20:43:13 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (147): Europe (Ireland) wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20211113.8699639AVIAN INFLUENZA (147): EUROPE (IRELAND) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 11 Nov 2021 20:09 GMTSource: Irish Examiner [edited]https://www.irishexaminer.com/farming/arid-40742532.htmlThe Department of Agriculture has confirmed a case of bird flu in County Kerry. The highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 (HPAI H5N1) was confirmed in a white-tailed sea eagle near Tarbert. The eagle was submitted to the Veterinary Laboratory in Limerick as part of the Department's wild bird avian influenza (AI) surveillance programme.The Department also confirmed that wild birds in Donegal and Offaly have also been confirmed positive for H5N1 today [11 Nov 2021], including both mute swans and whooper swans and wild geese. One Minister for State described the confirmations as "very concerning."Last week, a strain of the virus was detected in a peregrine falcon in County Galway. The Minister for Agriculture said it is "very unfortunate that this case has been detected in such a rare bird."However, [Minister for Agriculture] Charlie McConalogue commended the Department's wild bird AI surveillance programme. "It is important that we remain vigilant, and I would also urge that flock owners should also be watchful. We should do everything that we can to ensure that potentially infected wild birds do not have contact with domestic flocks." Members of the public have been urged not to handle any dead birds but to contact the Department of Agriculture or the National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS).Minister of State Malcolm Noonan added: "There is the immediate issue of the direct impacts on birds generally, and also, of course, there may be issues arising that impact on birds of conservation concern, including those being re-introduced to the wild under projects such as the flagship White-Tailed Sea Eagle Re-Introduction Project."The Health Protection Surveillance Centre has confirmed that although the H5N1 subtype can cause serious disease in poultry and other birds, no human infections with this virus have been reported worldwide and therefore consider the risk to humans to be very low. Properly cooked poultry and poultry products, including eggs, are safe to eat.The Department added that the additional findings of H5N1 in wild birds highlights the risk of introduction of avian influenza to the poultry sector. It "remains in close contact with industry stakeholders and reiterates that strict bio-security measures are necessary to prevent the introduction of avian influenza into poultry and captive bird flocks," a statement revealed."Flock owners should remain vigilant for any signs of disease in their flocks and report any disease suspicion to their nearest Department Veterinary Office."[Byline: Steve Neville]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses.The white-tailed sea eagle (_Haliaeetus albicilla_) is a magnificent bird of prey widely distributed across temperate Eurasia. For a picture, go to https://bit.ly/3FdOqJH. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map:Ireland: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699639,39] See Also

20211112.8699631AVIAN INFLUENZA (146): JAPAN (AKITA, KAGOSHIMA) POULTRY, HPAI H5****************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 10 Nov 2021Source: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/japan-reports-first-bird-flu-outbreak-season-culling-143000-chickens-2021-11-10/Japan has detected its 1st outbreak of bird flu for the 2021 winter season, with confirmation of a case of "highly pathogenic avian influenza" [HPAI] at a poultry farm in the northeast of the country, the agriculture ministry said on Wednesday [10 Nov 2021].About 143 000 egg-laying chickens are being exterminated at the farm in Yokote city in Akita Prefecture, the ministry said in a statement on its website, adding that restricted zones up to 10 km (6.2 miles) from the site have been established.Japan has temporarily suspended exports of chicken meat and eggs from all regions following the outbreak, the ministry said."Under the current situation in Japan, we do not believe that there is any possibility of avian influenza being transmitted to humans through the consumption of chicken meat or eggs," the ministry said.But an increase in the number of people in China getting infected from bird flu this year [2021] is turning into a source of concern among epidemiological experts, especially as the world slowly recovers from the COVID-19 pandemic.China has reported 21 human infections with the H5N6 subtype of avian influenza in 2021 to the World Health Organization [WHO], compared with only 5 last year [2020], with 6 dead and many of the others critically ill.--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[According to NHK (Japan Broadcasting Corporation), an additional H5 outbreak affecting poultry has been recorded in Japan on the morning of 12 Nov 2021, affecting a poultry farm in Izumi City, Kagoshima Prefecture, where many chickens were reported dead. Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus H5 was detected in 13 birds examined. In response to this, Kagoshima Prefecture has begun culling chickens at this poultry farm. In addition, the poultry farm has been designated as a "restricted movement area" that prohibits the movement of chickens and eggs within a radius of 3 km (1.86 mi), and a "restricted export area" that prohibits the shipment of chickens and eggs from that area within a radius of 10 km (6.2 mi). Within a 10 km radius of this poultry farm, there are 119 farms and about 5.53 million chickens and other animals are bred. The Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries informed that this is the 2nd outbreak of bird flu in poultry farms nationwide this season, following Akita Prefecture, which was confirmed as infected on 10 Nov 2021 (https://www3.nhk.or.jp/news/html/20211113/k10013346441000.html; in Japanese).The distance between Kagoshima (on Japan's southern island of Kyushu) and Akita (in the Tōhoku region of Honshu Island, north Japan) is about 1247 kilometers (775 miles). The route(s) of introduction and the full identity of the H5 strain in each of the foci have yet to be established and published. Japan has suffered several epizootics of HPAI H5 strains, affecting poultry and wild birds, during the 2 recent decades. This included H5N2 (2005-2006), H5N1 (2007, 2010-2011), H5N6 (2016-2017) and H5N8 (2014-2015, 2020-2021). Several of the said episodes were attributed to be introduced by migratory birds and shared with seasonal HPAI outbreaks in South Korea, China and other eastern and south-eastern Asian countries. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED maps:Akita Prefecture, Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699631,3224Kagoshima Prefecture, Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699631,6775] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-12 22:10:56 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Announcements (09): OFFLU Avian Influenza Statement Archive Number: 20211112.8699608ANNOUNCEMENTS (09): OFFLU AVIAN INFLUENZA STATEMENT***************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 10 Nov 2021From: Ian H. Brown <Ian.Brown@apha.gov.uk>, <secretariat@offlu.org> [abridged, edited]https://www.offlu.org/wp-content/uploads/2021/11/OFFLU-November2021-Final.pdfOFFLU Avian Influenza Statement-------------------------------Forty-one countries in Asia (11), Europe (21) and Africa (9) have reported avian influenza in wild birds and domestic poultry to the OIE since 1 May 2021 to present. These have been confirmed as highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) through molecular pathotyping with most viruses falling within HA clade 2.3.4.4b. A broad range of subtypes has been detected with domestic poultry in Africa affected by H5N1, Europe by H5N1 and H5N8, and in Asia by H5N1, H5N2, H5N6 and H5N8.H5Nx clades have evolved over recent years leading to subtype diversity, multiple genotypes and also antigenic variability. In 2016, a novel H5 clade 2.3.4.4b emerged and was responsible for waves of H5N8 infections in Europe, Asia and Africa in 2016 and 2017. These were caused by novel reassortant viruses containing internal gene segments from Eurasian low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) viruses and H5N8 viruses which were first found in China in 2013. Further reassortment with NA genes from Eurasian LPAI viruses gave rise to H5N5 and H5N6 subtypes. Until 2019, the northern hemisphere experienced reoccurring cycles of infection of predominantly H5N8 in wild birds with spillover events into poultry, with these viruses historically having a relatively stable genotype albeit with internal genes being subject not only to drift but also to reassortment.From mid-2020, H5N8 outbreaks occurred in Iraq, Russia and Kazakhstan caused by new H5 2.3.4.4b variants ("G2") with closest relatives to 2.3.4.4b viruses detected in Israel and Iraq in 2019 and 2020, respectively. There are indications these are derived from reassortment with Eurasian and North African LPAI, however, under surveillance makes it difficult to understand the precise origins. These viruses made up most circulating viruses in wild birds and poultry throughout 2021, involving an unprecedented wide range of subtypes (H5N1, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6 and H5N8) and wide dispersal throughout Asia, Africa and Europe. This was further complicated by increased reassortment creating an epidemiologically and genetically complex landscape. Two genetically distinct clusters of viruses with changes in known antigenic sites circulated in Japan and South Korea from October 2020 and continued to be detected until spring 2021. They are closely related to separate outbreaks seen in European countries in early ("G1") and late ("G2") 2020, respectively.In Europe since September 2021 there has been an increase in H5N1 events. Sequence data from recent H5N1 events in September (Russia and the Czech Republic) and October (Italy and the UK) have a similar 2.3.4.4b HA to H5N5 and H5N1 strains found in Europe and Africa in late 2020/early 2021, linking further back to H5N8 circulating in Eurasia. Long branches to the diverse NP/PB1/PB2 segments would likely indicate under sampling or sequencing of wild bird-derived LPAI. Several phylogenetic groups in internal proteins linked by long branches indicate large diversity in wild birds.Such co-circulation of different H5 lineages in diverse bird populations lends itself to further virus evolution through both drift and reassortment creating an ever-evolving complexity in both virus genetics and spatiotemporal distribution. The constantly changing picture results in significant challenges. Whole genome sequence analyses are important for tracking such evolution and in assessing these emergent events. There are now genetically distinct 2.3.4.4b subclades circulating which are further diversifying, and it is difficult to understand their origins. Human infections with 2.3.4.4.b H5 viruses have also occurred in the past year and although we do not understand the precise origins of these outbreaks, the viruses appear genetically similar to strains circulating in wild birds and poultry. There is also an increased need for regular assessment of contemporary viruses against current vaccines used in poultry in different regions using genetic data and though antigenic characterization using standardized protocols and sera to understand the extent to which antigenic drift leads to reduced vaccine efficacy, by clade. Mitigation strategies based on enhanced farm biosecurity and modifications to production practices are needed when these viruses are carried by wild birds. Enhanced surveillance is needed for early warning and case detection as well as for vaccine antigen matching in places where vaccines are being used or under consideration.--Communicated by:Professor Ian H Brown, OBE, MIBiol PhDChair of OFFLU steering committeeHead of Virology Department<secretariat@offlu.org>Director of OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratoryfor Avian Influenza and Newcastle Disease; OIE Reference Laboratory for Swine InfluenzaAnimal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) - WeybridgeAPHA Weybridge, Woodham Lane, New Haw, Addlestone, Surrey KT15 3NBUnited Kingdom<Ian.Brown@apha.gov.uk>[ProMED thanks Dr. Ian H. Brown, chair of the OFFLU steering committee, for this information and encourages our subscribers to read the complete statement found at the source URL above."OFFLU is the OIE/FAO global network of expertise on animal influenza working to reduce the negative impacts of animal influenza viruses by promoting effective collaboration between animal health experts and the human health sector. Originally launched in April 2005 to support avian influenza, OFFLU was expanded in 2009 to include all animal influenza and to further support to Veterinary Services in their efforts to reduce risks to animals and the public from animal influenza viruses" (https://www.oie.int/en/disease/avian-influenza/#ui-id-3).For more information related to OFFLU, visit its website at https://www.offlu.org/.The 1st HPAI H5N1 epizootic in Europe started in fall 2005, initially in Romania and Croatia, spreading across central Europe while causing high mortality in domestic poultry and wild birds. In 2010, when this event could be finally declared terminated, it had been detected in wild birds and poultry in 21 European countries. Its route of introduction could not be definitely established, though the role of migratory birds underlined.The 2nd avian influenza virus (AIV) epizootic in Europe, caused by an HPAI H5N8 subtype, became larger than the 1st one. Its ancestral strain was initially reported in China in 2010, spreading later to Japan and South Korea. In late 2014, it spread to Germany, Italy, the Netherlands and the UK, causing severe losses in turkeys and chickens, and -- in difference from HPAI H5N1 -- milder disease in Anseriformes poultry (e.g., ducks) and wild birds. It was agreed that the main mode of its spread was migrating birds. This is also the generally accepted view concerning the spread of the current H5N1 strain, prescribing the consequent preventive measures.Vaccination of poultry against "fowl pest" (the former term of HPAI), an OIE-notifiable animal disease with serious economic and trade-related consequences, was obviously considered a main preventive measure for decades. OIE's Terrestrial Manual, updated May 2021, says:"During the 1990s, the prophylactic use of inactivated oil-emulsion vaccines was employed in Mexico and Pakistan to control widespread outbreaks of HPAI and H5/H7 LPAI. During the 1999-2001 outbreak of H7 LPAI in Italy, an inactivated vaccine was used with the same (i.e., homologous) haemagglutinin subtype to the field virus, but with a different (i.e., heterologous) neuraminidase. This allowed the serological differentiation of non-infected vaccinated birds from vaccinated birds infected with the field virus and ultimately resulted in eradication of the field virus. Prophylactic use of H5 and H7 vaccines has been practiced in parts of Italy, aimed at preventing H5/H7 LPAI infections, and several countries in Asia, Africa and the Middle East as an aid in controlling HPAI, in China (People's Rep. of) for H7N9, and in Mexico for H7N3 HPAI virus infections. HPAI viruses should not be used as the seed virus for production of vaccine."(The manual mentions also "Live recombinant virus-vectored vaccines" with H5 influenza A virus haemagglutinin gene inserts, approved and used in a few countries since 1997; since 2015, non-replicating, haemagglutinin based H5 RNA particle, H5 expressed baculovirus and H5 DNA vaccines have been approved for poultry but have had limited use.)It has been argued that AIV transmission cycle cannot be fully blocked by mass vaccination if the viruses have a wild bird reservoir. This suggestion was supported by experience in China, where mass vaccination appeared to be more effective to minimize infections of AIV subtype H5 clade 7.2, which had no wild bird reservoir, than to minimize infections of clades 2.3.2 and 2.3.4, which did have wild bird reservoirs (https://doi.org/10.1111/tbed.13515).As indicated in OFFLU's statement above, "there is an increased need for regular assessment of contemporary viruses against current vaccines used in poultry in different regions, to understand the extent to which antigenic drift leads to reduced vaccine efficacy." However, availability of information about vaccination coverage and vaccine strains included is incomplete. All countries that have reported H5N1 since September 2021 referred to vaccination in their OIE notifications as "not applied." According to OIE's WAHIS database, during 2019, vaccination against HPAI (subtype not specified) was applied in Egypt, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Kazakhstan, Mexico and Pakistan. Such information for 2020 has, so far, become available only from Egypt and Pakistan. Reporting should be enhanced, including updated official information from all OIE's member countries.To better assess the origin(s) of infection and to attempt forecasts, hopefully enabling timely application of precautionary measures, a One Health approach incorporating epidemiologists, ornithologists and virologists is essential. - Mods.AS/CRD] See Also

20211109.8699550AVIAN INFLUENZA (144): EUROPE (POLAND), POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] Media report[2] OIE notifications (3 events, summarized)[A] Masovia Province: poultry, HPAI H5N1[B] Lubusz Province: poultry, HPAI H5N1[C] Silesia Province: poultry, HPAI H5N1******[1] Media reportDate: Mon 8 Nov 2021 4:45 PM CETSource: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/poland-reports-highly-pathogenic-h5n1-bird-flu-poultry-oie-2021-11-08/Poland has reported several outbreaks of highly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu [avian influenza] at poultry farms with flocks totaling nearly 650 000 birds, the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) said on Monday [8 Nov 2021].Poland is the European Union's largest poultry producer.Five outbreaks, of which 4 were at fattening turkey farms and one at a chicken broiler farm, were found in the eastern part of the country while another was discovered at a turkey and geese farm in the western part of the country, the OIE said, citing a report from Polish authorities.Bird flu, most often carried from one country to the other by migrating wild birds, has been spreading rapidly in Europe, raising concern in the poultry industry after previous outbreaks led to the culling of tens of millions of birds and international trade restrictions.The French government on Friday [4 Nov 2021] put the entire country on high alert for bird flu, extending a requirement to keep all poultry flocks indoors.This comes after Dutch authorities last month [October 2021] also ordered commercial farms to keep all flocks inside after bird flu was reported on a farm.Meanwhile, in Britain, an outbreak of highly pathogenic H5 bird flu was reported at a small poultry unit in central England on Monday [8 Nov 2021]. Britain last week [week of 1 Nov 2021] declared a nationwide Avian Influenza Prevention Zone, ordering farms and bird keepers to toughen biosecurity measures.[Byline: Sybille de La Hamaide; editing: Gus Trompiz, Toby Chopra]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>******[2] OIE notifications (3 events, summarized)[A] Masovia Province: poultry, HPAI H5N1Date: Mon 8 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42213Mazowieckie [Masovia Province]: event started 1 Nov 2021. A total of 5 outbreaks (submitted) reported to date [8 Nov 2021]. HPAI detected in commercial farms with fattening turkeys and in a commercial farm with chicken broilers.The event is continuing.Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 638 880 / 90 182 / 2742 / 139 694 / 0Epidemiological comments: the date of the last occurrence of serotype H5N1 in the country is 31 Jan 2008.[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]----[B] Lubusz Province: poultry, HPAI H5N1Date: Mon 8 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42214Lubuskie [Lubusz Province]: event started 3 Nov 2021. A total of one outbreak (submitted) reported to date [8 Nov 2021]. HPAI detected in commercial farms with fattening turkeys and geese.The event is continuing.Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 7000 / 1510 / 1510 / - / 0[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]----[C] Silesia Province: poultry, HPAI H5N1Date: Mon 8 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [abridged, edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42245Slaskie [Silesia Province]: event started 5 Nov 2021. A total of one outbreak (submitted) reported to date [8 Nov 2021]. HPAI detected in a non-commercial farm. In that holding hens, ducks, quails, guinea fowl, and parrots were kept.The event is continuing.Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 384 / 146 / 132 / 252 / 0--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.The following information comes from a scientific report (Conclusion section, page 5) providing an avian influenza overview in the EU/EEA and UK published on 29 Sep 2021, which is available at https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/avian-influenza-overview-september-2021.pdf:"The presence of HPAI virus in western Russia and north of the Mongolian border with Russia, linked to key migration areas of wild waterbirds, is of concern due to the possible spread of the virus via wild birds migrating to the EU. Autumn migration from breeding sites to wintering sites is ongoing, and the low temperature of autumn and winter may facilitate the environmental survival of avian influenza virus potentially introduced to Europe. According to data available, the northern and eastern areas of Europe are likely to be the 1st places of new virus introduction. However, despite the increasing number of HPAI A(H5)-affected countries and outbreaks outside Europe, there is considerable uncertainty about the real geographical distribution of these viruses, particularly in wild birds and along the flyways."During summer, HPAI A(H5) viruses were detected at lower levels than in winter and spring in resident wild bird populations in Europe, primarily in northern areas. HPAI outbreaks also occurred in poultry and captive birds in a few European countries. Despite this, the observed persistence of HPAI in wild birds in northern Europe into September 2021, in contrast with previous years, may indicate a risk for virus entry into poultry farms not only from wild birds migrating into Europe in the autumn and the winter but also from wild birds that are resident in Europe."The occurrence of HPAI A(H5) virus incursions in commercial farms even where birds are kept indoors raises concern about the capacity of applied biosecurity measures in effectively preventing virus exposure. Biosecurity standards should be revised and reinforced, and their implementation regularly checked, primarily in poultry production systems at high risk of avian influenza."The 2020-2021 epidemic with a total of 1298 outbreaks in poultry, 22.9 million birds affected, 85 detections in captive birds, and 2394 events in wild birds in 31 European countries appears to be one of the largest HPAI epidemics that has ever occurred in Europe. Note that the number of reported wild bird events is an underestimate of the total number of wild birds that have died from HPAI during this epidemic."The number of outbreaks and other statistics, presented in the ECDC report above, have increased since its publication.The locations of the HPAI H5N1 outbreaks which have involved poultry, captive, and wild birds across Europe during the period 1 Sep to 2 Nov 2021, are presented in Map 1, on page 3 of DEFRA's updated assessment document, 'Ref: VITT/1200 HPAI in the UK and Europe', available at https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1030888/HPAI-assessment-UK-Europe-2-Nov-2021.pdf (Poland's events yet to be added).As reported (and indicated in the map above), HPAI H5N1 has been reported also from Israel, located on the central (West Asian) flyway of migrating birds. - Mods.CRD/ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Poland: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699550,113] See Also

[edited]https://www.coventrytelegraph.net/news/local-news/warning-public-bird-flu-cases-22087706The public is being urged not to pick up or touch sick or dead wild birds after bird flu [avian inlfuenza] was confirmed among swan populations in Warwickshire and Worcestershire [West Midlands region].The Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) and the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) have now confirmed there is avian influenza A(H5N1) among swans in Stratford town centre and around Diglis Basin in Worcester.Angela Cartwright, consultant in communicable disease control with the UKHSA [UK Health Security Agency] in the West Midlands, said the risk to the public from this strain of avian flu was "very low", but urged people to steer clear of any sick or dead birds."As a precaution, anyone who was not wearing appropriate PPE (personal protective equipment) while in contact with the droppings or birds in an area where the infection has been confirmed, will require close monitoring and a course of antiviral medication for 10 days from the last contact with infected birds," she said.The UKHSA, Worcester City Council, and Stratford District Council are working with APHA and the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals (RSPCA) to manage the situation and protect public health and the risk to other birds.The H5N1 strain, highly pathologic to birds, was first diagnosed in birds at a wild bird rescue centre near Droitwich last week. Swans at the Diglis Basin in Worcester became sick, with this same strain of avian flu confirmed.Dead birds were collected from around the River Avon in Stratford town centre and sent to APHA's laboratory for testing, and the same strain of avian flu was confirmed.Christopher Kettle, Stratford District Council's community protection boss, said: "The outbreak of avian flu in the wild bird population, including swans on the River Avon, is obviously of concern to residents."The UKHSA has made it clear that the risk of the disease transferring from birds to humans is considered to be very low. "To ensure this situation remains, the advice we have received is that members of the public should not touch or go near sick or dying birds and any dead birds found should be reported to the District Council on 01789 267 575 to assist with the disposal."The UK food standards agencies advise that avian influenzas pose a very low food safety risk for UK consumers. Properly cooked poultry and poultry products, including eggs, are safe to eat."We are also looking to put up posters in the area to ask people not to feed the ducks or swans and remind people to keep to footpaths and to keep dogs on leads."Following detection of bird flu in wild birds across the UK, the Chief Veterinary Officers from England, Scotland, and Wales have declared an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone (AIPZ) across Great Britain to try to stop the disease from spreading amongst poultry and captive birds.In areas where the infection has been confirmed or is suspected, anyone who has been in contact with sick or dead birds or their droppings should make sure any footwear is properly cleaned and thoroughly wash their hands in soap and water.They should then notify the UK Health Security Agency's West Midlands Health Protection Team on 0344 225 3560 so that public health experts can determine if antiviral medication and active surveillance of their condition are necessary.[Byline: Paul Stuart]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[From 2014 onwards HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses dominated outbreaks in Europe, with abundant genetic reassortments yielding subtypes H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8. The majority of HPAI H5 virus detections in wild and domestic birds within Europe coincide with a southwest/westward fall migration and large local waterbird aggregations during wintering. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699545,4481] See Also

/ 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / -Affected population: on [29 Oct 2021] a peregrine falcon (_Falco peregrinus_) was found alive in a coastal area of West Ireland but died shortly afterward.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: on [3 Nov 2021] the Irish Central Veterinary Research Laboratory confirmed the presence of highly pathogenic avian influenza subtype H5N1 in samples taken from the peregrine falcon.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultCentral Veterinary Research Laboratory (national laboratory) / Peregrine falcon / 1 / real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 3 Nov 2021 / positiveCentral Veterinary Research Laboratory (national laboratory) / Peregrine falcon / 1 / gene sequencing / 2 Nov 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[A press release published on 4 Nov 2021, from Department of Agriculture, Food and the Marine, Ireland, mentioned that "We are currently in the high-risk period (October to April) for introduction of HPAI into Ireland from migratory wild birds returning to overwinter from areas where HPAI is widespread. Wild birds act as main reservoirs of avian influenza viruses."The Department remains in close contact with industry stakeholders and reiterates that strict bio-security measures are necessary to prevent the introduction of avian influenza into poultry and captive bird flocks. Flock owners should remain vigilant for any signs of disease in their flocks and report any disease suspicion to their nearest Department Veterinary Office."(https://www.gov.ie/en/press-release/551d6-department-confirms-avian-influenza-h5n1-in-a-wild-bird-in-co-galway/).- Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Ireland: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699541,58407]******[2] Czech Republic (South Bohemia): HPAI H5N1Date: Mon 8 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42183Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (Inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Czech Republic--------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 1 Nov 2021Confirmed: 4 Nov 2021Reported: 5 Nov 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 28 Oct 2021Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Luznice river, Tabor, Jihocesky [South Bohemia]Started: 1 Nov 2021Epidemiological unit: not applicableAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedMute swan (_Cygnus olor_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - Wildlife (order unspecified) / - / 1 / - / - / 0 / 0Outbreak location 2: Yongjeong-ri, Cheonan, Chungcheongnam-doStarted: 26 Oct 2021Epidemiological unit: otherAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedMandarin duck (_Aix galericulata_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 1 / - / - / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: Epidemiological investigation is ongoing.Control measures at event levelDomestic and wild control measures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs, disinfection, screening, surveillance outside containment and/or the protection zone, traceability, surveillance within containment and/or the protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultAnimal and Plant Quarantine Agency (APQA), Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs (MAFRA) (national laboratory) / mandarin duck/wildlife (species unspecified) / 2 / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 3 Nov 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>["The dynamic of the spread of influenza viruses is extremely complex and difficult to predict. Several factors can influence it, such as the wild bird migration pattern, unregulated trade, farming systems, biosecurity, and immunity status."During the Northern Hemisphere winter, the wild bird movements may increase, and lower temperatures may facilitate the environmental survival of AI [avian influenza] viruses, increasing exposure of infection in poultry. Additionally, the mixing of wild birds from different geographic origins during migration can increase the risk of virus spread and genetic reassortment resulting in changes in viral properties. At local level, as the AI viruses can survive for long periods in the environment, they can be easily transmitted from farm to farm by the movement of infected animals as well as contaminated boots, vehicles, and equipment if the adequate biosecurity measures are not implemented."(OIE avian influenza portal: https://www.oie.int/en/disease/avian-influenza/#ui-id-2)- Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Chungcheongnam-do, South Korea https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699540,37287 and Jeollabuk-do, South Korea https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699540,37170] See Also

https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699527,19962The HPAI epidemic of 2020-2021 is the largest that has occurred in Europe, with almost 4000 HPAI episodes reported in around 30 European countries. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. - Mod.PMB] See Also

/ 1 / 1 / - / - / -Mute swan (_Cygnus olors_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 1 / 1 / - / - / -EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: movement control inside the country, zoningWild control measures applied: movement control inside the country, control of wildlife reservoirs, surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone, zoningDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultVeterinary Specialized Institute Kraljevo (national laboratory) / black swan, mute swan / 1 / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 20 Oct 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Some wild migratory waterbirds may contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses and may be playing a role in the HPAI epidemic of 2020-2021, which is the largest that has occurred in Europe. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-04 18:51:57 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (138): Europe (UK), poultry, HPAI H5N1, spread Archive Number: 20211104.8699458AVIAN INFLUENZA (138): EUROPE (UNITED KINGDOM), POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, SPREAD**************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 3 Nov 2021Source: BBC [edited]https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-tayside-central-59156120?piano-modalA flock of poultry that tested positive for bird flu has been culled in Angus, the Scottish government has announced. Public health advice is that the risk to human health from the avian influenza (H5N1) virus is very low.However, a UK-wide bird flu prevention zone has come into force meaning bird keepers need to follow strict biosecurity measures to help protect their flocks. The move follows bird flu outbreaks in other parts of the UK. Temporary control zones have also been set up around the infected premises in Angus to limit the risk of the disease.Rural Affairs secretary Mairi Gougeon said: "With the recent disease confirmations in wild and captive birds in the UK, it is not unexpected for avian influenza to be found in birds here. Temporary control zones have been put in place around the infected premises and we ask that the public remain vigilant and report any findings of dead wild birds."Food standards bodies advise that avian influenzas pose a very low food safety risk for UK consumers, and that cooked poultry products including eggs are safe to eat.Scotland's chief veterinary officer, Sheila Voas, said: "We are conducting further tests to establish the pathogenicity of avian influenza H5N1 in a flock of birds in the Angus constituency. "We have already made clear that all bird keepers -- whether major businesses or small keepers with just a few birds -- must ensure that their biosecurity is up to scratch to protect their birds from disease. Keepers who are concerned about the health or welfare of their flock should seek veterinary advice immediately."--communicated by:ProMED <promed@promedmail.org>[The affected animals, in Angus, referred to in the BBC report as "a flock of poultry", have been referred to in other media sources as "captive birds". Specified, official information, including species, number and husbandry data, would be helpful.The locations of the HPAI H5N1 outbreaks which have involved poultry, captive, and wild birds across Europe during the period 1 Sep 2021 to 2 Nov 2021, are presented in Map 1, page 3 of DEFRA's updated assesment document, 'Ref: VITT/1200 HPAI in the UK and Europe', available at https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/1030888/HPAI-assessment-UK-Europe-2-Nov-2021.pdf. The map includes an overlay indicating the migratory birds flyways. The affected countries in Northern Europe, located within the WestAsian flyway (lined black) are UK, France, Belgium, Netherlands, Germany, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, Finland, and Estonia.The DEFRA assesment includes additional information on the current H5 events in GB, as well as in northern and southern Europe, arriving at the following conclusions:"Given the detection of several cases of HPAIV H5N1 in wild birds in England, Wales and Scotland with the increasing number of poultry outbreaks in the Netherlands and in northern Germany, the risk of incursion of HPAI H5 in wild birds in GB has been raised from MEDIUM (event occurs regularly) to HIGH (event occurs often)."The risk of exposure of poultry to HPAI H5 in GB where biosecurity is sub-optimal has been raised from LOW (medium uncertainty) to MEDIUM (medium uncertainty)."The risk of exposure of poultry to HPAI H5 in GB where biosecurity is stringent remains at LOW but the uncertainty is to increase from low to medium uncertainty. This emphasises the importance of maintaining good biosecurity."At this stage last year (30 Oct 2020) the wild bird risk was still medium and the poultry risk low. The wild bird risk was raised to HIGH and the poultry risk to MEDIUM on 4 Nov 2020, so events this year are about a week earlier than last year."We are currently in a period of rapid seasonal change with respect to these risks and will continue to closely monitor the situation as more wild birds from northern Europe will be arriving over the few weeks".Subscribers are referred to FAO's alert at https://listserv.fao.org/scripts/wa-fao.exe?A2=VPH-L;f33cc909.2111&S=, and to Mod. CRD's commentary in 20211104.8699430. - Mod.ASA HealthMap/ProMED map of Angus: <>HealthMap/ProMED map:United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699458,40] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-04 12:53:51 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (137): Europe, poultry, HPAI H5N1, H5, OIE Archive Number: 20211104.8699430AVIAN INFLUENZA (137): EUROPE, POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, H5, OIE**********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this post:[1] Russia: (Kirov) poultry, HPAI H5N1[2] Germany: (Brandenburg) poultry, HPAI H5N1[3] Denmark: (Zealand) poultry, HPAI H5******[1] Russia: (Kirov) poultry, HPAI H5N1Date: Tue 2 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=41988Highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Russia---------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 26 Oct 2021Confirmed: 28 Oct 2021Reported: 2 Nov 2021Reason for notification: 1st occurrence in a zone or a compartmentCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Zuevskoe Lyubimoe, Zuevskiy rayon, KirovStarted: 26 Oct 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 422 015 / 800 / 800 / - / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: zoning; control of wildlife reservoirs; disinfection; movement control inside the country; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; zoning.Wild control measures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs; surveillance outside containment and or the protection zone; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / 1 / Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 30 Oct 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map of Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699430,10517]******[3] Denmark: (Zealand) poultry, HPAI H5Date: Wed 3 Nov 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=42049Highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Denmark----------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 29 Oct 2021Confirmed: 1 Nov 2021Reported: 1 Nov 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 6 Jul 2021Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5Nature of diagnosis: laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaksSummary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks (1)Outbreak location: Sonderupsonder, Slagelse, Sjaelland [Zealand]Started: 30 Oct 2021Ended: ongoingEpidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 27 600 / - / 300 / - / 0 / 0Affected population: On [30 Oct 2021], a clinical suspicion was reported to the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration. The affected population was a turkey holding with approximately 27 600 animals. On [1 Nov 2021], highly pathogenic avian influenza (subtype H5) was confirmed by the national reference laboratory. A 3 km protection zone and a 10 km surveillance zone were established. The animals are planned to be culled on [2 Nov 2021], and carcasses will be disposed of by rendering.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive.Epidemiological comments: the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has established zones of 3 km [2 mi] and 10 km [6 mi] around the holding and are implementing the necessary measures in accordance with the European Union Animal Health Law.Control measures at event levelControl measures applied in domestic: traceability, zoning, movement control inside the countryControl measures to be applied in domestic: surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste, disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institut (national laboratory)Species / Test / Outbreaks / Test date / ResultBirds / Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 1 / 1 Nov 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map of Denmark: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699430,7188.Since October 2021, the number of cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), caused by the H5N1 subtype has increased. Although most detections have been in wild birds, some have also been identified in poultry. HPAI H5N1 has been reported in the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Israel, Italy, Germany, Denmark, Serbia, and Russia.The following information comes from a scientific report (Conclusion section, page 5) providing an avian influenza overview in the EU/EEA and UK published on 29 Sep 2021, which is available at https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/avian-influenza-overview-september-2021.pdf:"The presence of HPAI virus in western Russia and north of the Mongolian border with Russia, linked to key migration areas of wild waterbirds, is of concern due to the possible spread of the virus via wild birds migrating to the EU. Autumn migration from breeding sites to wintering sites is ongoing, and the low temperature of autumn and winter may facilitate the environmental survival of avian influenza virus potentially introduced to Europe. According to data available, the northern and eastern areas of Europe are likely to be the first places of new virus introduction. However, despite the increasing number of HPAI A(H5)-affected countries and outbreaks outside Europe, there is considerable uncertainty about the real geographical distribution of these viruses, particularly in wild birds and along the flyways."During summer, HPAI A(H5) viruses were detected at lower levels than in winter and spring in resident wild bird populations in Europe, primarily in northern areas. HPAI outbreaks also occurred in poultry and captive birds in a few European countries. Despite this, the observed persistence of HPAI in wild birds in northern Europe into September 2021, in contrast with previous years, may indicate a risk for virus entry into poultry farms not only from wild birds migrating into Europe in the autumn and the winter, but also from wild birds that are resident in Europe."The occurrence of HPAI A(H5) virus incursions in commercial farms even where birds are kept indoors raises concern about the capacity of applied biosecurity measures in effectively preventing virus exposure. Biosecurity standards should be revised and reinforced, and their implementation regularly checked, primarily in poultry production systems at high risk of avian influenza."The 2020-2021 epidemic with a total of 1298 outbreaks in poultry, 22,9 million birds affected, 85 detections in captive birds, and 2,394 events in wild birds in 31 European countries appears to be one of the largest HPAI epidemics that has ever occurred in Europe. Note that the number of reported wild bird events is an underestimate of the total number of wild birds that have died from HPAI during this epidemic."- Mod.CRD] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-03 13:19:12 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (136): Europe (UK) wild bird, HPAI Archive Number: 20211103.8699427AVIAN INFLUENZA (136): EUROPE (UNITED KINGDOM) WILD BIRD, HPAI**************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 2 Nov 2021 14:27 GMTSource: Daily Mail [edited]https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-10156263/More-dozen-swans-flock-Stratford-Avon-killed-bird-flu.htmlMore than a dozen swans from a flock popular with tourists in Shakespeare's home town have been killed by bird flu (avian influenza]. Government scientists are currently conducting tests on the birds which died following an outbreak of avian flu in Stratford-upon-Avon.Tens of thousands of tourists visit the Warwickshire town and birthplace of playwright William Shakespeare each year to marvel at the scores of swans living on the River Avon. But in recent weeks, several of the swans - as well as ducks and geese - have been struck down with avian flu leaving wildlife experts fearing Stratford-upon-Avon's swan population could be wiped out.An outbreak was first confirmed at a rescue centre in Wychbold, a 40-minute drive from Stratford-upon-Avon, but now the town's rescue group says their swan population is at risk after several birds also contracted the deadly disease. Cyril Bennis, who runs Stratford-Upon-Avon Swan Rescue group and is a former mayor of the town, warned the current outbreak -- one of 2 currently active in the UK -- was 'beyond control'. Mr Bennis, 72, who has been caring for swans in the Worcestershire town for 40 years, said: 'Three weeks ago one of the sanctuaries that we take our swans to was shut down because of suspected avian flu. The swans that were on the mend there had to be put to sleep. The other rescue centre also had to be shut down because 2 swans there also had suspected avian flu.'Mr Bennis said that officials from the Department for the Environment, Farming and Rural Affairs (Defra) came and collected swans that had already died 2 weeks ago but that more animals were 'dying left, right and centre'. He added: 'I am having to pile them up in order to get some clarity on what I am supposed to do with them. 'At the moment, I have over a dozen dead birds -- not only swans but ducks and geese too. I have had to put 2 swans to sleep today, one last night, 7 others have died of suspected avian flu in the last few days -- it's a daily occurrence. I really fear that the entire population, which is more than 70 swans, could be seriously under threat. It is frustrating and heart-breaking to see any animal suffer in front of you. These animals are perfectly healthy one day and then dead the next. I watched one last night as died in my arms and I could not do anything about it.'Avian flu, more commonly known as bird flu, is not an airborne virus but spreads bird-to-bird through direct contact or through contaminated body fluids and faeces, according to Defra. The virus can also be spread by contaminated feed and water or by dirty vehicles, clothing, and footwear. Cases can spike during the winter months if birds migrating from mainland Europe to the UK are carrying the disease. The virus can, in certain cases, also affect humans although Defra says the risk to the public is low.Defra is currently running tests to determine the strain confirmed in Stratford. Bird flu has also been confirmed at a premises in Wrexham in Wales.Meanwhile, the rescue centre where the disease was first confirmed has been closed while the outbreak is active. Wychbold Swan Rescue said it was 'devastated' by the outbreak and is currently the subject of a Defra control zone. The outbreak meant all birds at the site had to be culled while officers also put in place a 3 km [2 mi] and 10 km [6 mi] control zone measure around the premises.In a statement, Wychbold Swan Rescue told its supporters: 'As you can imagine, we are devastated by recent events. We can't believe this has happened again. This means until further notice, we are unable to attend to any birds. It's an extremely unfortunate situation that everyone at Swan Rescue is thoroughly broken-hearted about.'An outbreak late last year [2020] resulted in the death of around 25 swans in Stratford, as well as others in Worcester and Evesham.[byline: Katie Feehan]--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[The HPAI epidemic of 2020-2021 is the largest that has occurred in Europe, with almost 4000 HPAI episodes reported in around 30 European countries. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swans, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Some wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699427,16484.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-03 06:31:28 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (135): Europe (UK) poultry, wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20211103.8699420AVIAN INFLUENZA (135): EUROPE (UK) POULTRY, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1****************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 2 Nov 2021Source: Farming UK [edited]https://www.farminguk.com/news/h5n1-bird-flu-confirmed-in-poultry-in-north-wales_59246.htmlA case of H5N1 avian influenza has been confirmed in poultry and wild birds in north Wales, just days after the UK recorded its 1st bird flu outbreak of the season. The chief veterinary officer for Wales confirmed the presence of the H5N1 strain at a premises in Wrexham County on Monday evening (1 Nov 2021).Temporary disease control zones of 3 km [1.9 mi] and 10 km [6.2 mi] have been imposed around the premises to limit the risk of disease spread. A veterinary investigation is under way; however, dead wild birds found in the area have tested positive for the virus and are believed to be the source of infection.The Welsh government said the risk to public health from the virus was considered to be very low. This is the 1st confirmation of the disease in Wales since it was discovered in pheasants at a premises on Anglesey in January [2021].--communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[HPAI H5N1, a pathogen known for its zoonotic characteristics on top of its high pathogenicity in poultry, has been spreading in Eurasia and elsewhere since the start of the current autumn bird migration season; infected wild birds and outbreaks on poultry farms have been reported. This alarming development has led the Food and Agriculture Organzation of the United Nations (FAO) to distribute today (Tue 2 Nov 2021), through its <vph-l@listserv.fao.org> distribution list, an alert titled "H5Nx highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) - increased detection likely along wild bird migratory pathways and risk for introduction (multiple regions)."The alert's introduction (references omitted) says: "Based on events monitored over the past weeks, FAO expects increased activity of H5Nx subtype highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in birds across Europe, Asia, the Middle East, and potentially Africa during the autumn and winter of 2021-22. Strains of H5 HPAI virus are being detected in migratory birds in Western Europe, with most recent cases reported in Denmark, Germany, and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The risk of disease introduction into other countries along wild bird migratory flyways is regarded as high. The Netherlands has already issued an order to keep poultry indoors following an outbreak of HPAI on a farm, and Italy has reported an outbreak in domestic turkeys. These reports are the latest in a sequence of detections in wild birds and poultry over the past weeks and months, starting with a notification in the south eastern Russian Federation mid-September [2021], followed by observed westwards movement of virus. Farms in countries that are situated along migratory flyways should put in place enhanced measures for prevention, early detection, and diagnosis of H5 HPAI, and for outbreak response. As other strains of avian influenza virus are also present in wild birds and poultry, co-circulation of multiple avian influenza strains provides opportunity for reassortment, potentially creating novel strains that could be more infectious or more virulent. The HA gene of the viruses from these recent outbreaks falls within H5 Clade 2.3.4.4b. Similar viruses have also been introduced into China via wild birds in late 2020. In this context it is noteworthy that a trend of increased human cases infected with clade 2.3.4.4b H5N6 viruses, associated with severe disease, has been reported from China. The zoonotic potential of avian influenza viruses should therefore be considered and appropriate personal protection measures applied when dealing with suspect cases in wild birds or outbreaks in poultry - or unexplained mortality in either."In its further text, the FAO alert specifies in more detail the countries in which strains of H5Nx HPAI virus have been detected in migratory birds, including Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Latvia, Serbia, Sweden, and the UK, with the most recent cases reported on 16 Oct 2021 in Denmark, affecting a teal (_Anas_ sp.), in Germany, affecting a Eurasian wigeon (_Anas penelope_), and on 26 Oct 2021, at a wild bird rescue centre in the UK.Notably, a fox has recently been found infected by HPAI H5N1 in the Netherlands, and 2 commercial poultry enterprises were reported as infected by HPAI H5N1 in Israel, along the southward flyway.The FAO reminds countries about the importance to share full genome sequences and virus isolates with the scientific community early for further analysis and research so that epidemiological links between outbreaks can be established, virus evolution monitored, and zoonotic potential of emerging viruses assessed. This information is also used to match the appropriate vaccines to currently circulating strains, and novel viruses. There is a possibility that antigens in existing inactivated vaccines, used in several countries to protect poultry, may not be well matched to these novel, currently circulating strains. This is under review by FAO/OIE reference laboratories.It is anticipated that the alert, which includes FAO's advice to countries at risk, will soon be available on the internet. - Mod.ASProMED thanks Mary Marshall for providing a link to FAO's alert: https://listserv.fao.org/scripts/wa-fao.exe?A2=VPH-L;f33cc909.2111&S=. - Mod.SHHealthMap/ProMED map of Wales, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699420,281.] See Also
