View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-02 06:44:32 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (134): Europe (Netherlands) poultry, HPAI H5N1 conf Archive Number: 20211102.8699401AVIAN INFLUENZA (134): EUROPE (NETHERLANDS) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1 CONFIRMED************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 1 Nov 2021Source: Food Ingredients 1st [abridged, edited]https://www.foodingredientsfirst.com/news/highly-pathogenic-h5n1-bird-flu-found-at-dutch-poultry-farm.htmlWageningen Bioveterinary Research (WBVR) has confirmed yet another outbreak of bird flu in the Netherlands. In Grootschermer, highly pathogenic H5N1 avian influenza was found in broiler chicken from a poultry farm.To prevent the virus from spreading, the Dutch Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority (NVWA) culled all 107 000 animals at the site.WBVR has determined the virus as highly pathogenic bird flu (HPAI) subtype H5N1 and will further investigate whether its genetic makeup is similar to HPAI H5N1 viruses that caused outbreaks in the Netherlands and Europe in 2021.[byline: Benjamin Ferrer]--communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[The confirmation of HPAI H5N1 in Grootschermer (Noord-Holland) was initially published on the website of WVBR on Sat 30 Oct 2021. The said official source has published today (Mon 1 Nov 2021) an additional H5 outbreak, yet to be finally serotyped/genotyped, located in Assendelft (municipality of Zaanstad, province Noord-Holland), affecting laying hens on a small-scale holding. It is probably a highly pathogenic variant of bird flu. To prevent the spread of the virus, approximately 140 laying hens and 50 walking ducks are being removed from the infected site. The evacuation is being carried out by the Dutch Food and Commodity Authority (NVWA). Within a radius of 3 km [1.9 mi] around the farm is another poultry farm. This company is being investigated for bird flu. There are no other poultry farms within a 10 km [6.2 mi] radius of the infected farm (in Dutch, at https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/vogelgriep/nieuws/2021/11/01/vogelgriep-vastgesteld-bij-kleinschalige-houderij-in-assendelft).The distance between Grootschermer and Assendelft is about 18.5 km [11.5 mi].Recently, HPAI H5N1 was identified in a fox in north eastern Netherlands, on the German border (ProMED post 20211101.8699389; please refer to Mod.PMB's commentary regarding H5 in mammals). - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Noord-Holland, Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699401,19962.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-11-01 11:45:04 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (133): Europe (Netherlands) fox HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20211101.8699389AVIAN INFLUENZA (133): EUROPE (NETHERLANDS) FOX, HPAI H5N1**********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 1 Nov 2021Source: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal [edited]https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/27/11/21-1281_articleref: Rijks JM, Hesselink H, Lollinga P, et al. Highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) virus in wild red foxes, the Netherlands, 2021. Emerg Infect Dis. 2021; 27(11): 2960-62. ----------------------------------------------------------------------Abstract--------We detected infection with highly pathogenic avian influenza A (H5N1) virus clade 2.3.4.4b in 2 red fox (_Vulpes vulpes_) cubs found in the wild with neurologic signs in the Netherlands. The virus is related to avian influenza viruses found in wild birds in the same area.--communicated by:Mary Marshall<mjm2020@googlemail.com>[From 2014 onwards HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses have caused outbreaks across the Eurasian region, affecting both poultry and wild birds, with abundant genetic reassortments yielding subtypes H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8.Regarding infection of these viruses in mammals, recently, HPAI H5N8 infections were reported in humans in Russia (see ProMED post 20210221.8204014).Several subtypes of AI viruses (H7N7, H4N5, H4N6, H3N3, and H10N7) have caused epidemics in harbour seals and gray seals, but they do not appear to become established in these carnivore species. Regarding terrestrial carnivores, red foxes have been shown to be susceptible to infection by HPAI H5N1, and there was recent documentation of a spill-over of HPAI H5N8 to wild carnivores. Virus evolution and adaptive mutations must be closely monitored to rapidly identify viruses with increased potential to infect mammals. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699389,104.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-10-31 20:56:49 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (132): Europe (Netherlands) poultry, HPAI H5N1 susp, control Archive Number: 20211031.8699376AVIAN INFLUENZA (132): EUROPE (NETHERLANDS) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1 SUSPECTED, CONTROL*********************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 30 Oct 2021Source: NL Times [edited]https://nltimes.nl/2021/10/30/100000-chickens-culled-bird-flu-outbreak-alkmaar-0The Dutch Food and Consumer Safety Authority (NVWA) will cull 107 000 chickens on Saturday [30 Oct 2021] due to a bird flu outbreak at a large poultry farm in Grootschermer in the municipality of Alkmaar, Minister of Agriculture Carola Schouten wrote in a letter to the Tweede Kamer.Schouten wrote it concerns a "broiler farm with 3 sheds: 2 sheds with 40 000 animals and one shed with 27 000 animals. In one barn, the animals showed signs of bird flu," Schouten said.The samples taken show that there is, indeed, a case of contamination.Near the infected farm there is another chicken farm with 18 700 broilers. According to the agriculture minister, it is "responsible" not to clear this company preventively because no other commercial poultry farm is located within a radius of 10 kilometers [6.2 mi] "where the spread could occur."On Tuesday [26 Oct 2021], Schouten announced an obligation of commercial poultry farmers to keep their chickens indoors for the time being to limit the spread of the virus.The Ministry also called on Netherlands residents to report any dead wild birds they come across so that these can be tested for bird flu. Information about how to report can be found on the NVWA website.--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[Grootschermer is a village in the Dutch province of North Holland. Its location is presented in the at map https://tinyurl.com/n9efu9ut.Earlier this week, a national obligation to cage and shield domestic birds in the Netherlands was introduced after a case of HPAI H5N1, a zoonotic pathogen, was identified at an organic poultry farm in Zeewolde, in the province Flevoland. The distance, as the crow flies, between Zeewolde and Grootschermer is about 55 km [34 mi]. Migrating birds are suspected to be the source of infection. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Noord-Holland, the Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699376,24105] See Also

Mod.AS, edited]https://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=2&TMID=178&FID=14756&PID=0&IID=43308A flock of breeding turkeys on a farm in Maayan-Tzvi has been found infected by HPAI H5N1. The affected flock is composed of 35-week-old birds.Preliminary clinical signs were observed on Friday (29 Oct 2021) in the males' coop only, numbering less than 400 birds.The mortality increased, reaching a total of 9% during the same day [29 Oct 2021]. Individual animals presented neurological signs and stumbling. Necropsy revealed enteritis.Samples were submitted to the Kimron Veterinary Institute, where HPAI H5N1 has been identified.--Communicated by:Nati Elkin<nati@poultrymed.com>[A map presenting the location of Maayan Tzvi is presented at <tinyurl.com/3tehj92z>. As can be seen, this Kibbutz is located very close (about 1 km [0.6 mi]) from the large aquacultural farm (fishponds) of Maagan Michael, known to be densely visited by migrating birds during the migration season.The above event is reported 5 days after Israel's official notification to the OIE of HPAI H5N1 affecting meat turkeys in Nahalal, located about 27 km [16.8 mi] to the northeast of Maayan Tzvi. This was the 1st H5N1 outbreak in Israel since 2015.Subscribers are referred to the commentary of Mod.CRD in ProMED post no. 20211016.8699057.Results of the epidemiological investigation of the event and information on the control measures applied are anticipated. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Ma'ayan Tzvi, Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699372,57532] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-10-29 12:06:07 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (129): Europe (Netherlands) poultry, HPAI H5N1, control, OIE Archive Number: 20211029.8699337AVIAN INFLUENZA (129): EUROPE (NETHERLANDS) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, CONTROL, OIE****************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 27 Oct 2021Source: Poultry World [edited]https://www.poultryworld.net/Health/Articles/2021/10/AI-outbreak-in-the-Netherlands-prompts-nationwide-housing-order-809906E/Near the town of Zeewolde [Flevoland], highly pathogenic bird flu [avian inlfuenza] (H5) was diagnosed at a farm with organic laying hens. The Ministry of Agriculture confirmed that it concerns a farm with 2 houses, one with approximately 24 000 birds, the other with approximately 12 000. In one house the hens showed signs of bird flu. Samples were tested and found positive for HPAI serotype H5 [for completed serotyping, see commentary].As a result of this outbreak and due to increasing finds of dead wild birds in northern parts of the Netherlands and of infected wild birds in Germany, the agriculture minister has implemented a nationwide housing order for commercially kept poultry as of 12 noon on [26 Oct 2021]. In this way, it wants to reduce the risk of the bird flu virus being introduced from wild birds to other farms in the Netherlands.To prevent the virus from spreading, the birds on the infected farm in Zeewolde are being culled by the authorities. Minister Schouten has also immediately announced transport restrictions for poultry farms in a zone of 10 kilometers [6 mi] around the affected farm in Zeewolde.This transport ban applies to poultry, eggs, poultry manure, and used litter, as well as other animals and animal products from commercial poultry farms. There are no other poultry farms within a radius of 1 kilometer [0.6 mi] around the infected farm. There are 6 other poultry farms in the area of 3 kilometers [1.9 mi] around the farm. These farms are sampled and examined for bird flu. There are 9 other poultry farms within the 10 kilometre [6.2 mi] zone which are affected by the transport restrictions.[Byline: Fabian Brockotter]--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[The event above was officially notified by the Dutch authorities to the OIE today (29 Oct 2021).According to the report, the outbreak involved 2350 cases among a total of 35 301 susceptible birds; 3 birds died. The remaining (35 298) birds have been killed and disposed of. The causative agent has been identified as HPAI H5N1 by the National Reference Laboratory at the Wageningen Bioveterinary Research, Lelystad. The diagnosis was established by real-time multiplex polymerase chain reaction (real-time multiplex PCR).The following "Description of the affected population" is included in the OIE report:"On 26 Oct 2021, an outbreak of H5N1 was confirmed on an organic layer poultry farm in Zeewolde. A 3 km [1.9 mi] protection zone and a 10 km [6.2 mi] surveillance zone have been established. In the 3 km zone there are 6 other poultry premises. The poultry farms in the 3 km zone have been screened (examined, sampled, and tested) and there were no positive results. The subtype HPAI H5N1 is confirmed by the national reference laboratory. All susceptible animals on the infected premise have been killed."The OIE report, including a map presenting the location of the event, is available at https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=41785. Information about the genotyping of the strain is anticipated.Notably, a total of 863 confirmed human cases of HPAI H5N1 have been recorded in 18 countries (most of them in Asia) since 2003; 456 of the patients died. Further details are available at https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/global_statistics_avian_influenza_e.pdf. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of the Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699337,25424] See Also

/ 1 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveControl measures at event levelWild control measures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (National Laboratory) / Laridae (unidentified) / 1 / Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 21 Oct 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>******[5] United Kingdom (England): captive bird, HPAI H5N1Date: Thu 28 Oct 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=41774SummaryReport type: Immediate notificationStarted: 15 Oct 2021Confirmed: 26 Oct 2021Reported: 28 Oct 2021Reason for notification: RecurrenceLast occurrence: 26 Jul 2021Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Wychavon, Worcestershire, EnglandStarted: 15 Oct 2021Epidemiological unit: OtherAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 49 / 39 / 25 / 24 / - / -Affected population: Rescued wild swans (adults and young), rescued and captive geese, ducks and chickens.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: On [24 Oct 2021] a Wild Bird Rescue Centre reported suspicion of notifiable avian disease in mute swans (_Cygnus olor_) and chickens kept at the premises. From [16 Oct 2021], at least 11 young swans and 14 (out of 17) chickens had died. There were 33 young and adult swans with clinical signs, of which 6 of the adults had neurological signs. Official samples were collected at the official veterinary visit and submitted for testing to APHA Weybridge. On [25 Oct 2021], Avian Influenza M gene, H5 and N1 viral antigens were detected in all but one of the samples submitted, including tissue post mortem samples. No antibodies to AI were detected. The clinical picture continued to deteriorate with more bird deaths. As of [26 Oct 2021], all birds at the affected Wild Bird Rescue Centre have been culled and sampling taken for the epidemiological enquiry. Preliminary cleaning and disinfection completed on [27 Oct 2021]. A full epidemiological investigation is being carried out. Official zoning has been implemented around the affected site (comprising a 3 km [1.9 mi] Protection Zone and a 10 km [6.2 mi] Surveillance Zone), which have been temporarily implemented as a precautionary measure. This notification describes an event of HPAI in captive birds other than poultry. Therefore, and in accordance with Article 10.4.1 (4) of Chapter 10.4 of the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code: - This event does not affect the UK's HPAI freedom status; and -Trading partners should not impose bans on the international trade of poultry commodities in response to this notification.Control measures at event levelWild control measures applied: control of wildlife reservoirs, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultAnimal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) Weybridge, United Kingdom OIE Reference Laboratory / Birds / 1 / Gene sequencing / 26 Oct 2021 / positiveAnimal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) Weybridge, United Kingdom OIE Reference Laboratory / Birds / 1 / Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 25 Oct 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The following information comes from the Rapid Risk Assessment on HPAIV H5 in Germany on 26 Oct 2021, available at https://www.openagrar.de/servlets/MCRFileNodeServlet/openagrar_derivate_00042585/FLI-Risikoeinschaetzung_HPAIV_H5_2021-10-26_bf.pdf in German.Between October 2020 and April 2021, Germany and Europe in general experienced the most severe avian influenza epizootic to date. Despite a significant decrease in both cases and outbreaks during the spring of 2021, HPAIV H5 was detected in waterfowl and birds of prey over the summer, especially in the Nordic countries of Europe. In Germany, since mid-October 2021, there has been an increasing number of detections of HPAIV-infected wild birds in Schleswig-Holstein, Lower Saxony, Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania and Bavaria as well as first occurrences in poultry and kept birds. The risk of HPAIV H5 spreading in wild birds and transmission to poultry and kept birds in Germany is classified as high. It is strongly recommended that biosecurity measures in poultry holdings be reviewed and, if necessary, strengthened.A map of HPAI detections in Germany during the period of 1 Oct 2020 to 28 Oct 2021 can be seen at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_D/2021/Map_AI_D_2021-10-28.jpgA map of HPAI detection in Europe during 1 Oct 2020 to 28 Oct 2021 is available at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2021/Map_AI_EU_2021-10-28.jpgRegarding the outbreak in UK, a press release published on 26 Oct 2021 (https://www.gov.uk/government/news/avian-influenza-bird-flu-identified-at-a-wildbird-rescue-centre-in-worcestershire) from Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs, Food Standards Agency, mentioned that: "The UK Chief Veterinary Officer has confirmed a case of avian influenza (bird flu) at a wild bird rescue center in Worcestershire today."Wild birds migrating to the UK from mainland Europe during the winter months can carry the disease and this can lead to cases in poultry and other captive birds."All birds on site will be humanely culled. A 3 km [1.9 mi] and 10 km [6.2 mi] temporary control zone has also been put in place around the infected premises to limit the risk of the disease spreading."UK Health Security Agency advises that the risk to public health from the virus is very low and the Food Standards Agency has made clear that bird flu poses a very low food safety risk for UK consumers. The premises does not supply poultry, meat or eggs to the commercial food chain". - Mod CRD] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-10-28 17:55:11 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (23): China (Hunan), H5N6 Archive Number: 20211028.8699277AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (23): CHINA (HUNAN), H5N6************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Mon 18 Oct 2021 7:46 PM HKTSource: Department of Health, the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region [edited]https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202110/18/P2021101800661.htmThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health is today [18 Oct 2021] closely monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) on the Mainland, and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.The case involves a 60-year-old woman living in Changde in Hunan Province. She is a farmer and had exposure to dead poultry. She developed symptoms on [3 Oct 2021], and was admitted for treatment on [13 Oct 2021]. The patient is in critical condition.From 2014 to date [18 Oct 2021], 48 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by Mainland health authorities."All novel influenza A infections, including H5N6, are notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong," a spokesman for the CHP said.Travellers to the Mainland or other affected areas must avoid visiting wet markets, live poultry markets or farms. They should be alert to the presence of backyard poultry when visiting relatives and friends. They should also avoid purchasing live or freshly slaughtered poultry, and avoid touching poultry/birds or their droppings. They should strictly observe personal and hand hygiene when visiting any place with live poultry.Travellers returning from affected areas should consult a doctor promptly if symptoms develop, and inform the doctor of their travel history for prompt diagnosis and treatment of potential diseases. It is essential to tell the doctor if they have seen any live poultry during travel, which may imply possible exposure to contaminated environments. This will enable the doctor to assess the possibility of avian influenza and arrange necessary investigations and appropriate treatment in a timely manner.While local surveillance, prevention and control measures are in place, the CHP will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments.The public should maintain strict personal, hand, food and environmental hygiene and take heed of the advice below when handling poultry:- Avoid touching poultry, birds, animals or their droppings;- When buying live chickens, do not touch them and their droppings. Do not blow at their bottoms. Wash eggs with detergent if soiled with faecal matter and cook and consume the eggs immediately. Always wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling chickens and eggs;- Eggs should be cooked well until the white and yolk become firm. Do not eat raw eggs or dip cooked food into any sauce with raw eggs. Poultry should be cooked thoroughly. If there is pinkish juice running from the cooked poultry or the middle part of its bone is still red, the poultry should be cooked again until fully done;- Wash hands frequently, especially before touching the mouth, nose or eyes, before handling food or eating, and after going to the toilet, touching public installations or equipment such as escalator handrails, elevator control panels or door knobs, or when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing; and- Wear a mask if fever or respiratory symptoms develop, when going to a hospital or clinic, or while taking care of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms. The public may visit the CHP's pages for more information: the avian influenza page, the weekly Avian Influenza Report, global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza, the Facebook Page and the YouTube Channel. --Contributed by:ProMED Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka******[2]Date: Tue 26 Oct 2021Source: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/business/environment/rise-human-bird-flu-cases-china-shows-risk-fast-changing-variants-health-experts-2021-10-26/A jump in the number of people in China infected with bird flu this year [2021] is raising concern among experts, who say a previously circulating strain appears to have changed and may be more infectious to people.China has reported 21 human infections with the H5N6 subtype of avian influenza in 2021 to the World Health Organization (WHO), compared with only 5 last year [2020], it said.Though the numbers are much lower than the hundreds infected with H7N9 in 2017, the infections are serious, leaving many critically ill, and at least 6 dead."The increase in human cases in China this year is of concern. It's a virus that causes high mortality," said Thijs Kuiken, professor of comparative pathology at Erasmus University Medical Centre in Rotterdam.Most of the cases had come into contact with poultry, and there are no confirmed cases of human-to-human transmission, said the WHO, which highlighted the rise in cases in a statement on [4 Oct 2021].It said further investigation was "urgently" required to understand the risk and the increase in spill over to people. Since then, a 60-year-old woman in Hunan province was admitted to hospital in a critical condition with H5N6 influenza on [13 Oct 2021], according to a Hong Kong government statement.While human H5N6 cases have been reported, no outbreaks of H5N6 have been reported in poultry in China since February 2020.China is the world's biggest poultry producer and top producer of ducks, which act as a reservoir for flu viruses.The Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) could not be reached for comment on the rise in H5N6 human cases. However, a study published on its website last month [September 2021] said the "increasing genetic diversity and geographical distribution of H5N6 pose a serious threat to the poultry industry and human health".Avian influenza viruses constantly circulate in domestic and wild birds, but rarely infect people. However, the evolution of the viruses, which have increased as poultry populations grow, is a major concern because they could change into a virus that spreads easily between people and cause a pandemic.The largest number of H5N6 infections have been in southwestern Sichuan province, though cases have also been reported in neighbouring Chongqing and Guangxi, as well as Guangdong, Anhui and Hunan provinces.At least 10 were caused by viruses genetically very similar to the H5N8 virus that ravaged poultry farms across Europe last winter and also killed wild birds in China. That suggests the latest H5N6 infections in China may be a new variant."It could be that this variant is a little more infectious (to people)...or there could be more of this virus in poultry at the moment and that's why more people are getting infected," said Kuiken.Four of the Sichuan cases raised poultry at home and had been in contact with dead birds, said a September [2021] report by China's CDC. Another had bought a duck from a live poultry market a week before developing symptoms.China vaccinates poultry against avian influenza but the vaccine used last year [2020] may only partially protect against emerging viruses, preventing large outbreaks but allowing the virus to keep circulating, said Filip Claes, Regional Laboratory Coordinator at the Emergency Centre for Transboundary Animal Diseases at the Food and Agriculture Organization.The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Affairs did not respond to a request for comment.Backyard farms in China are common and many people still prefer to buy live chickens at markets.Guilin city in Guangxi region, which had two human cases in August [2021], said last month [September 2021] it had suspended trading of live poultry in 13 urban markets and would abolish the trade within a year.[Byline: Dominique Patton]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>******[3]Date: Wed 27 Oct 2021Source: [in Chinese, machine trans., edited]https://finance.sina.com.cn/tech/2021-10-27/doc-iktzscyy2109486.shtmlMacau Health Bureau: A man in Yongzhou, Hunan has been infected with H5N6 avian influenza and is now in critical condition.According to the news from the Macau Special Administrative Region Government website on [27 Oct 2021], the Macau Health Bureau said that according to the latest notification from the mainland health department, Hunan Province has confirmed a case of human infection with H5N6 avian influenza. The Health Bureau urged residents to avoid contact with poultry and birds and pay attention to personal and food hygiene.According to the data, the patient is a 66-year-old male farmer living in Yongzhou City, Hunan Province. He developed symptoms on [25 Sep 2021] and was admitted to the hospital on [25 Sept 2021]. He is now in critical condition and had been in contact with poultry before he became ill.Since April 2014, there have been confirmed cases of H5N6 avian influenza in Sichuan, Guangdong, Yunnan, Hubei, Hunan, Anhui, Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region and Jiangsu.--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[To date, 46 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported in mainland China, the latest reported cases being the 21st and 22nd cases in 2021.The public may visit the following CHP pages for more information: the avian influenza page (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/features/24244.html), the weekly Avian Influenza Report (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/resources/29/332.html), global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza (https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/global_statistics_avian_influenza_e.pdf), the Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/CentreforHealthProtection), and the YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/c/ChpGovHkChannel). - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED maps:China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699277,155Hunan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699277,341] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-10-27 14:14:17 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (128): Europe (Denmark) wild bird, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20211027.8699304AVIAN INFLUENZA (128): EUROPE (DENMARK) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1, OIE*****************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 26 Oct 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=41670Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (Inf. with) (non-poultry including wild birds) (2017-), Denmark--------------------------------------------------------------------------------General informationReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 13 Oct 2021Confirmed: 22 Oct 2021Reported: 26 Oct 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 14 May 2021Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: laboratoryThis event pertains to the whole country.Total outbreaks: 2Outbreak location 1: Vilslev, Esbjerg, Syddanmark [South Denmark]Started: 16 Oct 2021Ended: 16 Oct 2021Epidemiological unit: not applicableAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedCommon teal (_Anas crecca_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 1 / 0 / - / 0 / 0Affected population: on [16 Oct 2021], a sample from a common teal (_Anas crecca_) was collected as part of the Danish active surveillance program for HPAI near Vilslev in the municipality of Esbjerg. On [22 Oct 2021], [State's Serum Institute] confirmed infection with highly pathogenic influenza A virus (H5N1) in the sample.Outbreak location 2: Hojer, Tonder, SyddanmarkStarted: 13 Oct 2021Ended: 13 Oct 2021Epidemiological unit: not applicableAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedEurasian wigeon (_Anas Penelope_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 1 / 0 / - / 0 / 0Affected population: on [13 Oct 2021], a pooled sample of bird droppings from 10 Eurasian wigeons (_Anas Penelope_) was taken as part of the Danish active surveillance program for HPAI near Hojer in the municipality of Tonder. On [22 Oct 2021], [State's Serum Institute] confirmed infection with highly pathogenic influenza A virus (H5N1) in the pooled sample.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species.Epidemiological comments: according to article 10.4.1.4 of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Member Countries should not impose bans on the trade in poultry commodities in response to notification on the presence of any influenza A virus in birds other than poultry.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultStatens Serum Institut National Laboratory/ Eurasian Wigeon/Common Teal / 2 / Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 13 to 22 Oct 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The HPAI epidemic of 2020-2021 is the largest that has occurred in Europe, with more than 3500 HPAI episodes reported in almost 30 European countries. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Farmers must apply stringent biosecurity measures. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Denmark: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699304,26142] See Also

/ - / -Affected population: The highly pathogenic avian influenza virus (HPAI), subtype H5N1 - clade 2.3.4.4b has been detected in a commercial farm of fattening turkeys located in the Municipality of Ronco all'Adige, Verona Province, Veneto region.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive.Control measures at event levelDomestic and wild control measures applied: Surveillance within containment and or the protection zone, zoning, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, movement control inside the country, stamping out, quarantine, disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS), Venezie National Laboratory/ Birds / 1 / Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 19 Oct 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>******[3] Sweden (Ostergotland): wild bird, HPAI H5N8Date: Fri 22 Oct 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited] https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=41552SummaryReport type: Immediate notificationStarted: 13 Oct 2021Confirmed: 21 Oct 2021Reported: 22 Oct 2021Reason for notification: RecurrenceLast occurrence: 21 Aug 2021Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Ekangsdalen, Linkoping, OstergotlandStarted: 13 Oct 2021Ended: 13 Oct 2021Epidemiological unit: OtherAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / - / 1 / 1 / - / - / -Affected population: Ten Canada geese were found dead. One was sent to the National Veterinary Institute for laboratory analysis as part of the national surveillance program for avian influenza.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: In accordance with the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Article 10.4.1, point 4, this outbreak does not change the disease-free status of Sweden as this is a wild bird, and therefore do not fall within the OIE definition of poultry.Control measures at event levelWild control measures applied: Official disposal of carcasses, by-products and wasteDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultNational Veterinary Institute (SVA) National Laboratory/ Canada goose / 1 / Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 20 Oct 2021 / positiveNational Veterinary Institute (SVA) National Laboratory/ Canada goose / 1 / Gene sequencing / 21 Oct 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[On the following page: "Avian influenza in Europe; update", available at https://www.izsvenezie.com/reference-laboratories/avian-influenza-newcastle-disease/europe-update/, subscribers can also find information on the epidemiological situation and the provisions adopted by the competent authorities during avian influenza (AI) emergencies in Europe related to highly pathogenic viruses (HPAI) and low pathogenic viruses (LPAI).A series of outbreak maps of the HPAI-affected European countries can be seen at https://izsvenezie.com/documents/reference-laboratories/avian-influenza/europe-updates/HPAI/2020-1/maps.pdf (last update 21 Oct 2021).Outbreak maps of LPAI and HPAI in Italy are available at https://www.izsvenezie.com/documents/reference-laboratories/avian-influenza/italy-updates/LPAI/2021/LPAI-outbreaks-italy-2021-map.pdf and https://www.izsvenezie.com/documents/reference-laboratories/avian-influenza/italy-updates/HPAI/2020-1/italy-maps.pdf, respectively (Last update 19 and 20 Oct 2021). - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED maps:Emilia-Romagna, Italy: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699206,9685Sweden: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699206,108Veneto, Italy: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699206,9175] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-10-16 12:46:17 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (124): Israel (HZ) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20211016.8699057AVIAN INFLUENZA (124): ISRAEL (HAZAFON) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 14 Oct 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=41187Highly pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Israel---------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: Immediate notificationStarted: [11 Oct 2021]Confirmed: [12 Oct 2021]Reported: 14 Oct 2021Reason for notification: RecurrenceLast occurrence: 17 May 2015Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, necropsy, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Nahalal, HazafonStarted: 11 Oct 2021Epidemiological unit: FarmAnimals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 42 000 / 500 / 100 / 25 000 / 0 / 0Affected population: 13-week-old meat turkeys, divided into 5 pens. The mortality (low) has been seen first in one of the pens. The mortality spread to another pen. PM have been done by a private veterinarian and severe lesions in the digestive tract have been seen. Samples have been sent to the laboratory. To date [14 Oct 2021] the stamping out process is ongoing.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive, fomites (humans, vehicles, feed, etc.), contact with wild speciesEpidemiological comments: H5N1 was diagnosed last time in Israel in 2015. H5N8 was present in 2020. October is a month where hundreds of millions of birds are passing over the country during their migration from Europe to Africa, including waterbirds. Around the farm of Nahalal, there are some water points where wild birds can rest and feed.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: ante- and post-mortem inspections, movement control inside the country, quarantine, zoningDomestic control measures to be applied: disinfestation, disinfection, stamping out, surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone, surveillance outside containment and/or the protection zoneWild control measures to be applied: surveillance within containment and/or the protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Division (national laboratory) / Birds / 1 / Gene sequencing / [12-13 Oct 2021] / PendingNorthern Poultry Health Laboratory (regional laboratory) / Birds / 1 / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [12-13 Oct 2021] / PositiveKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Division (national laboratory) / Birds / 1 / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [12-13 Oct 2021] / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[As mentioned in the epidemiological comments, Israel is on the migration route of wild birds coming from Europe to Africa; avian influenza (AI) outbreaks are mostly synchronized with the migration season."Wild birds normally carry AI viruses in their respiratory or intestinal tracts but they do not usually get sick, which allows them to carry the viruses long distances along their migration flyways" (https://www.oie.int/en/disease/avian-influenza/). - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Hazafon, Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699057,1759] See Also

/ [11-12 Oct 2021] / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[As mentioned in a previous report, since October 2020 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI), caused by H5 subtype viruses, has been affecting several countries in Europe.The following information comes from a scientific report (page 37) providing an avian influenza overview in the EU/EEA and UK published on 29 Sep 2021, which is available at https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/avian-influenza-overview-september-2021.pdf:"The 2020-2021 HPAI A(H5) epidemic with a total of 1298 HPAI outbreaks in poultry, 22.9 million birds affected, 85 detections in captive birds, and 2394 HPAI events in wild birds in 31 European countries represents one of the largest and long-lasting HPAI epidemics that has ever occurred in Europe. The epidemiological data presented in this report indicate that the virus is still circulating in domestic and wild bird populations in some European countries and that the epidemic is not over yet. During the summer months, HPAI A(H5) viruses were detected at lower levels than in winter and spring in resident wild bird populations, mainly in northern Europe. HPAI outbreaks also occurred in poultry and captive birds in a few EU countries. Based on these observations, it appears that the persistence of HPAI A(H5) in Europe continues to pose a risk of further virus incursions in domestic bird populations."The HPAI detections in wild birds in the reporting period indicated that the virus is able to persist in wild birds breeding in the EU/EEA, even after a large number of wintering waterbirds (including barnacle geese, greylag geese, Eurasian wigeons, and mallards) have gone away. The persistence of HPAI in wild birds during the 2021 summer (opposite to what occurred in previous years, when HPAI disappeared in spring) suggests that the virus may be adapting to maintenance in wild birds. In coming months, many wild waterbirds, including young birds that hatched in 2021, will again arrive at their wintering areas in the EU/EEA. Because these young birds have never been exposed to HPAI, their presence may result in an increased prevalence of the still present HPAI virus, thereby increasing the risk of incursion into poultry farms." - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED maps of Russia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699066,98 and Ukraine: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8699066,123] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-10-03 16:41:29 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (22): China (GX), H5N6 Archive Number: 20211003.8698793AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (22): CHINA (GUANGXI), H5N6**************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 29 Sep 2021Source: BNO News [edited]https://bnonews.com/index.php/2021/09/young-woman-dies-of-h5n6-bird-flu-in-southern-china/A 26-year-old woman in southern China has died of H5N6 bird flu amid a rise in isolated cases, health officials in Hong Kong reported on Wednesday [29 Sep 2021]. Three other cases were reported earlier this month.The Hong Kong Department of Health said it was notified about the case in Guilin, a city in the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in mainland China, on Wednesday [29 Sep 2021]. There was no immediate word from local officials.The health department said the 26-year-old woman had contact with live domestic poultry before she developed symptoms on 14 Aug 2021. She was admitted to hospital 5 days later and has since died.It was not immediately clear why the case had not been previously reported to the public. The World Health Organization (WHO) did not immediately respond to request for comment.Only 46 human cases of H5N6 bird flu have been confirmed since the first case in 2014, but nearly 1/4 of them have been reported during the last 2.5 months. At least 22 cases, all but one of them in China, were reported during the last year.H5N6 bird flu is known to cause severe illness in humans of all ages and has killed more than half of those infected, according to WHO. There are no confirmed cases of human-to-human transmission."While recently-identified avian influenza viruses do not currently transmit easily from person to person, the ongoing circulation of these viruses in poultry is concerning, as these viruses cause severe disease in humans and have the potential to mutate to become more contagious between people," WHO says on its website. "WHO's Health Emergencies Programme therefore monitors human cases of avian influenza on an ongoing basis."--Communicated by:Ryan McGinnis <ryan@digicana.com>[To date, 44 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported in mainland China, the latest reported case being the 20th case in 2021.The public may visit the following CHP pages for more information: the avian influenza page (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/features/24244.html), the weekly Avian Influenza Report (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/resources/29/332.html), global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza (https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/global_statistics_avian_influenza_e.pdf), the Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/CentreforHealthProtection), and the YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/c/ChpGovHkChannel). - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map:Guangxi Autonomous Region, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8698793,355] See Also

/ Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 33 / 6 / 6 / 27 / 0 / 0Affected population: Avian influenza subtype H5 was confirmed on [27 Sep 2021] in a backyard holding with 33 heads of poultry (16 hens, 5 geese and 12 ducks). 5 geese and 1 duck died, other animals were killed and destroyed in a rendering plant on [28 Sep 2021].EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of country, disinfection, zoningDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result[State Veterinary Institute (SVI) (National Laboratory)] / Birds / 1 / Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / [27 Sep 2021] / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The following abstract and information come from a scientific report on Avian influenza overview in EU/EEA and the UK -- published on 29 Sep 2021, which is available in ref 1:Abstract:"The 2020-2021 avian influenza epidemic with a total of 3777 reported highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) detections and approximately 22 900 000 affected poultry birds in 31 European countries appears to be one of the largest HPAI epidemics that has ever occurred in Europe. Between 15 May and 15 Sep 2021, 162 HPAI virus detections were reported in 17 EU/EEA countries and the UK in poultry (51), in wild (91) and captive birds (20). The detections in poultry were mainly reported by Kosovo (20), Poland (17) and Albania (6). HPAI virus was detected during the summer months in resident wild bird populations mainly in northern Europe. The data presented in this report indicates that HPAI virus is still circulating in domestic and wild bird populations in some European countries and that the epidemic is not over yet. Based on these observations, it appears that the persistence of HPAI A(H5) in Europe continues to pose a risk of further virus incursions in domestic bird populations. Furthermore, during summer, HPAI viruses were detected in poultry and several wild bird species in areas in Russia that are linked to key migration areas of wild water birds; this is of concern due to the possible introduction and spread of novel virus strains via wild birds migrating to the EU countries during the autumn from the eastern breeding to the overwintering sites. 19 different virus genotypes have been identified so far in Europe and Central Asia since July 2020, confirming a high propensity for this virus to undergo reassortment events. Since the last report, 15 human infections due to A(H5N6) HPAI and 5 human cases due to A(H9N2) low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) virus have been reported from China. Some of these cases were caused by a virus with an HA gene closely related to the A(H5) viruses circulating in Europe. The viruses characterized to date retain a preference for avian type receptors; however, the reports of transmission events of A(H5) viruses to mammals and humans in Russia, as well as the recent A(H5N6) human cases in China may indicate a continuous risk of these viruses adapting to mammals. The risk of infection for the general population in the EU/EEA is assessed as very low, and for occupationally exposed people low, with large uncertainty due to the high diversity of circulating viruses in the bird populations".---HPAI A(H5N8)-affected poultry establishments in Czechi:"On 17 and 18 May 2021, 2 HPAI A(H5N8) outbreaks were confirmed in poultry holdings in the Central Bohemian region. The outbreaks occurred both in backyard holdings. The affected holdings were keeping 43 and 198 birds from different species (chickens, domestic ducks, domestic geese, pigeons). Chicken deaths and clinical signs were observed in both the farms, but only in one holding there was mortality in ducks or geese. Pigeons were not affected. In total, 5 people were exposed to the cases. As both farms had outdoor access and birds, feed and water were not protected against contact with wild birds, indirect contact with wild birds was considered the most likely source of virus". (Page 20)Reference:1. European Food Safety Authority, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and European Union Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza. Avian influenza overview May - September 2021. https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/avian-influenza-overview-september-2021.pdfA map of HPAI detections in Europe during the period 1 Oct 2020 to 27 Sep 2021 can be seen at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2021/Map_AI_EU_2021-09-27.jpg. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Czech Republic: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8698822,110] See Also

surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; zoning.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultAnses-Laboratoire de Ploufragan-Plouzane-Niort - site de Ploufragan National Laboratory / Mute Swan / 1 / Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 27 Sep 2021 / positiveAnses-Laboratoire de Ploufragan-Plouzane-Niort - site de Ploufragan National Laboratory / Mute Swan / 1 / Whole genome sequencing (WGS) / 14 Sep 2021 / pending[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED	<promed@promedmail.org>[The HPAI epidemic of 2020-2021 is the largest that has occurred in Europe, with more than 3500 HPAI episodes reported in almost 30 European countries. Wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Farmers must apply stringent biosecurity measures. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map:Moselle, Lorraine, France: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8698799,7711] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-27 19:48:13 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (21): China (GD) H5N6 Archive Number: 20210927.8698701AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (21): CHINA (GUANGDONG) H5N6***************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Wed 22 Sep 2021 6:14 a.m. PDTSource: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/world/china/chinas-guangdong-reports-human-case-n5h6-bird-flu-2021-09-22/The health authority in southern China's Guangdong province said on Wednesday [22 Sep 2021] that a single case of a human being infected with the H5N6 strain of bird flu has been reported in the city of Dongguan.The infected patient, a 53-year-old male, is being treated in hospital, the Health Commission of Guangdong Province said in a statement, adding that experts considered the risk of transmission to be low at this stage.[Byline: Colin Qian and Tom Daly]--Communicated by>Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>******[2]Date: Thu 23 Sep 2021Source: Global Times [edited]https://www.globaltimes.cn/page/202109/1234891.shtmlDongguan, in South China's Guangdong Province, reported one new case of H5N6 bird flu on Tuesday [21 Sep 2021], the 2nd confirmed case in the province after a woman was infected with the virus on 19 Aug [2021] in Huizhou. Experts assessed that the case was a random one, and the risk of transmission of the virus is low at the current stage.According to the Health Commission of Guangdong Province, the diagnosed patient, surnamed [L], a 53-year-old male, is currently being treated at a designated hospital in Dongguan.Experts pointed out that the H5N6 avian influenza virus is highly pathogenic to fowls. Since it was first discovered in poultry in China in 2008, it has gradually replaced the H5N1 avian influenza as the main virus prevalent in China's poultry farms and live poultry markets.But in its natural state, the H5N6 avian influenza virus mainly infects birds, and infections in humans rarely occur. As of the end of March 2021, only 25 human infections have been reported worldwide, and all are dispersed cases.On 12 Apr [2021], the H5N6 avian flu was found in wild birds in Shenyang, a city in Northeast China's Liaoning Province, which marked the 1st confirmed cases of the flu in China this year [2021].After May 2014, H5N6 human infection cases have been reported in several places in China, including Sichuan, Guangdong, Yunnan, and Jiangxi provinces, where at least 4 people have died.Experts from the Health Commission of Guangdong Province concluded that the emergence of the case was random and the risk of transmission of the virus is relatively low now. However, they warned that, although the H5N6 avian influenza virus rarely infects humans, it should be given high priority and remain under surveillance to avoid the spread of the epidemic by human factors.--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[ProMED thanks Mahmoud Orabi for the latest reports on a human case of avian influenza A/H5N6 from China.To date [27 Sep 2021], 44 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported in mainland China, the latest reported case being the 20th case in 2021.The last case from Guangdong was reported in August 2021 [See Avian influenza, human (16): China (Guangdong) H5N6 20210825.8611614].According to reports received by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), various influenza A(H5) subtypes continue to be detected in birds in Africa, Europe, and Asia.Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Intensive surveillance should be continued to detect cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of these viruses, as the frequency of cases is increasing. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map of Guangdong Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8698701,334] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-24 17:05:06 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (117): Europe (Germany) seal, HPAI H5N8 Archive Number: 20210924.8698675AVIAN INFLUENZA (117): EUROPE (GERMANY) SEAL, HPAI H5N8*******************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue, 21 Sep 2021From: Martin Beer <Martin.Beer@fli.de> [edited]HPAIV H5N8 in harbour seals in Germany--------------------------------------During August 2021 slightly increased mortality has been observed among harbour seals (_Phoca vitulina_) as part of an intensive monitoring program in the German Wadden Sea [Lower Saxony]. Several dead harbour seals were collected in the 2nd half of August 2021 by the Institute for Terrestrial and Aquatic Wildlife Research (ITAW) of the University of Veterinary Medicine Hannover, Germany (TiHo). In samples of 2 animals, highly pathogenic H5 avian influenza virus (HPAIV) was detected by RT-qPCR at the Institute of Virology (TiHo) on 3 Sep 2021 and immediately reported to the local authorities. Subsequent examinations led to the detection of HPAIV of the subtype H5N8 in both animals with the highest viral genome loads in the brain. Morbillivirus-specific RNA, in contrast, was not detected. Post mortem and virological investigations of a third carcass, processed at the Veterinary Investigation Centre of the German Federal State of Schleswig-Holstein and the Friedrich-Loeffler-Institut (FLI), likewise revealed high viral loads of HPAIV, subtype H5N8, in the brain of the animal. No or very low viral loads of H5N8 were present in other tissues including the lung. Further intensified surveillance has been initiated and special precautionary advice applies to staff recovering and handling clinically affected and dead seals. Further work characterizing the seal viruses is ongoing at TiHo and FLI.--Paul Becher, Alexander Postel, Ursula Siebert, on behalf of the team at TiHo;Katharina Kramer, Hubert Wonnemann, Markus Weidner, Gabriela Wallner, on behalf of the Veterinary Investigation Centre Schleswig-Holstein and the responsible State Ministry;Timm Harder, Thomas C Mettenleiter, Martin Beer, on behalf of the team at FLI[Several subtypes of AI viruses (H7N7, H4N5, H4N6, H3N3, and H10N7) have caused epidemics in harbour seals, but they do not appear to become established in this carnivore species. HPAI H5N8 closely related to the virus circulating in poultry farms at the time was detected in 2 gray seals (__Halichoerus grypus_) stranded on the Baltic coast of Poland in 2016 and 2017. In November 2020, a harbor seal (_Phoca vitulina_) and a gray seal were found infected by HPAI H5N8 virus in the context of a seal mortality event in the UK. In seals and other wild mammals, HPAI H5N8 causes encephalitis and death. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8698675,68604] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-23 23:37:53 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (03): (CA) waterfowl Archive Number: 20210923.8697142BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (03): (CALIFORNIA) WATERFOWL**************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 14 Sep 2021 12:30 PM PTSource: Patch [edited]https://patch.com/california/lakeforest-ca/lake-forest-ducks-geese-affected-oc-avian-botulism-outbreakA group of [Lake Forest] area professionals is seeking to get to the bottom of an avian botulism outbreak at area creeks and ponds, according to the Wetlands and Wildlife Care Center [WWCC] of north Orange County [OC].Officials have taken to the skies to find birds affected by the disease with the help of a professional drone pilot and OC Parks. At the end of August [2021], a sick mallard hen and a dead mallard drake were found in the Lake Forest area during the avian botulism outbreak, officials say, along with a group of sick Canadian geese.The presence of avian botulism in the area is largely due to the drought, experts say. Outbreaks, according to the Wetland and Wildlife Care Center experts, develop as a result of one or more of the following conditions: flooding of dry land during warm weather, resulting in the drowning of terrestrial invertebrates that then provide a nutrient medium for the bacterium; receding water levels that expose mudflats, causing aquatic invertebrates to die which then provides a suitable nutrient medium; changes in water quality that result in the death of invertebrate fauna; decaying animal carcasses that provide maggots.Botulism toxin kills quickly, so waterfowl succumb within normal weight and no sign of weight loss. Because the birds don't eat while they are ill, bile stains the vent green (as does lead poisoning). Sick birds have difficulty holding their heads erect, so the term "limber neck" is often applied when the caustic agent is unknown, the center says.After the last outing, the survey team was able to rescue the sick hen, reaching her with the aid of a boat and some local residents. The geese are being monitored by residents, and once captured, they will be able to convalesce at the Wetlands and Wildlife Care Center.Many birds have lost their lives to this toxic disease, Debbie McGuire, executive director of the Wetlands and Wildlife Care Center said. "The hen was nearly drowned and at first residents weren't sure if she was even alive," McGuire said.According to the Wildlife Center's veterinarian, Dr Elizabeth Wood, there are 10 mallards and 2 Canada geese in intensive care."The quicker these patients can arrive at WWCC, the better their chances for survival," Wood says. "We expect this outbreak to be ongoing due to the drought and receding water levels throughout Orange County."Thanks to the help of Orange County Supervisor Katrina Foley, a hiccup in the plan was smoothed over, according to McGuire. The drones were able to fly over the research area to identify concentrations of birds in heavy vegetation.[Byline: Ashley Ludwig]--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacteria _Clostridium botulinum_. These bacteria are widespread in soil and require warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of these bacteria; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of California, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8697142,20759] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-19 16:21:10 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (19): China (HN) H5N6 Archive Number: 20210919.8685382AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (19): CHINA (HUNAN) H5N6***********************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 17 Sep 2021Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-h5n6-avian-influenza-case-in-yongzhou-hunan-province-21089/Officials with the Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection (CHP) report monitoring an additional human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in mainland China.The case involves a 40-year-old woman living in Yongzhou in Hunan Province, who had prior exposure to a live poultry market before the onset of symptoms. She developed symptoms on 8 Sep 2021 and was admitted for treatment on the following day [9 Sep 2021]. The patient is in serious condition.From 2014 to date [17 Sep 2021], 43 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported in mainland China, with 4 out of 10 cases reported in just the past year.Avian influenza is caused by those influenza viruses that mainly affect birds and poultry, such as chickens or ducks. Clinical presentation of avian influenza in humans may range from flu-like symptoms (e.g. fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches) to severe respiratory illness (e.g. chest infection). Eye infection (conjunctivitis) and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g. nausea, vomiting and diarrhea) have also been reported. The incubation period ranges from 7 to 10 days. The more virulent forms can result in respiratory failure, multi-organ failure and even death. People mainly become infected with avian influenza virus through contact with infected birds and poultry (live or dead) or their droppings, or contact with contaminated environments (such as wet markets and live poultry markets). People in close contact with poultry are more susceptible to contracting avian influenza.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[To date, 43 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported in mainland China, the latest reported case being the 19th case in 2021.The public may visit the CHP's pages for more information: the avian influenza page (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/features/24244.html), the weekly Avian Influenza Report (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/resources/29/332.html), global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza (https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/global_statistics_avian_influenza_e.pdf), the Facebook page <(https://www.facebook.com/CentreforHealthProtection>), and the YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/c/ChpGovHkChannel). - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map:Hunan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8685382,341] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-19 19:23:42 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (20): Cambodia (SI) H9N2 Archive Number: 20210919.8668826AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (20): CAMBODIA (SIEM REAP) H9N2******************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 8 Sep 2021Source: Emerging Infectious Diseases [edited]https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/27/10/21-1039_articleCitation: Um S, Siegers JY, Sar B, et al. Human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) virus, Cambodia, February 2021. Emerg Infec Dis. 2021; 27(10); doi: 10.3201/eid2710.211039.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Abstract---------In February 2021, routine sentinel surveillance for influenza-like illness in Cambodia detected a human avian influenza A(H9N2) virus infection. Investigations identified no recent H9N2 virus infections in 43 close contacts. One chicken sample from the infected child's house was positive for H9N2 virus and genetically similar to the human virus.--Communicated by:Jurre SiegersInstitute Pasteur du Cambodge<jsiegers@pasteur-kh.org>[ProMED thanks Jurre Siegers for sharing the early release publication on human infection with avian influenza A/H9N2 virus in Cambodia.The reported case is a 3-year-old boy with a history of exposure to domestic poultry who presented with influenza-like illness in February 2021 and was confirmed to be infected with influenza A/H9N2 virus.H9N2 viruses circulate endemically in poultry from Cambodia, as they do in Bangladesh, Viet Nam, and China. Of avian influenza viruses (AIVs) detected in chickens in Cambodia in live bird markets (LBMs), 75% are H9N2. Whereas serosurveys indicate persons in Cambodia with poultry contact are exposed to H9N2, active human infections have not been detected.The authors conclude that "endemic H9N2 and other AIVs in poultry remain a concern for zoonotic infection. An interdisciplinary One Health approach is warranted to curb continuing expansion and emergence. Early detection and control in animal populations, enhanced biosafety, candidate vaccines, and prompt antiviral treatment might mitigate the risks of reassortment and continued evolution that could result in H9N2 viruses with increased mammalian adaptation or human-to-human transmission potential." - Mod.UBAThe 1st known infection by influenza A(H9N2) occurred in 1966 among turkeys in Wisconsin. This virus is currently regarded as the most widespread avian influenza virus subtype in poultry worldwide. According to OIE's criteria, spelled out in the International Manual, H9N2 is an LPAI virus (low pathogenicity avian influenza - in poultry). Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) is notifiable to the OIE, defined as "an infection of poultry by any influenza A virus that has been determined as high pathogenicity in accordance with the Terrestrial Manual." All naturally occurring HPAI strains isolated to date have been either of the H5 or H7 subtype.LPAI H9N2 is, thus, not OIE-notifiable.In addition to poultry, this virus has also been identified in wild birds, domestic mammals, and, occasionally, in humans.LPAI H9N2 causes considerable losses to the poultry industry. Since the early 1990s, vaccination against this virus has been used extensively in Asia and the Middle East using billions of inactivated vaccine doses. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Siem Reap [Siemreab] Province, Cambodia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8668826,3128] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-12 18:36:02 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (113): Pakistan (PB) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20210912.8663587AVIAN INFLUENZA (113): PAKISTAN (PUNJAB) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, OIE****************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 8 Sep 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=39324SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 5 Aug 2021Confirmed: 24 Aug 2021Reported: 8 Sep 2021Ended: 10 Aug 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 21 Feb 2019Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a determined zone of the country.Outbreak location: Vehari, Multan, PunjabStarted: 5 Aug 2021Epidemiological unit: farmEnded: 10 Aug 2021Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 3000 / 3000 / 3000 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: A commercial farm with poultry of Rhode Island Red (RIR) breed was hit by highly pathogenic avian influenza; all 3000 birds died. Control measures were implemented at nearby poultry farms. No further cases of highly pathogenic avian influenza are reported till now in the surrounding areas.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: The outbreak is under control and closed now.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: disinfection, movement control inside the country, quarantine, surveillance within containment and/or the protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultNational Reference Laboratory for Poultry Diseases (NRLDP), Pakistan Agricultural Research Council (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 24 Aug 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Citation: Ali M, Yaqub T, Shahid MF, et al. Genetic Characterization of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N8) Virus in Pakistani Live Bird Markets Reveals Rapid Diversification of Clade 2.3.4.4b Viruses. Viruses. 2021; 13(8): 1633; https://doi.org/10.3390/v13081633.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Abstract-------"The highly pathogenic (HPAI) avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses have undergone reassortment with multiple non-N1-subtype neuraminidase genes since 2008, leading to the emergence of H5Nx viruses. H5Nx viruses established themselves quickly in birds and disseminated from China to Africa, the Middle East, Europe, and North America. Multiple genetic clades have successively evolved through frequent mutations and reassortment, posing a continuous threat to domestic poultry and causing substantial economic losses. Live bird markets are recognized as major sources of avian-to-human infection and for the emergence of zoonotic influenza. In Pakistan, the A(H5N1) virus was first reported in domestic birds in 2007; however, avian influenza surveillance is limited, and there is a lack of knowledge on the evolution and transmission of the A(H5) virus in the country. We collected oropharyngeal swabs from domestic poultry and environmental samples from 6 different live bird markets during 2018-2019. We detected and sequenced HPAI A(H5N8) viruses from 2 chickens, one quail and one environmental sample in 2 markets. Temporal phylogenetics indicated that all novel HPAI A(H5N8) viruses belonged to clade 2.3.4.4b, with all 8 genes of Pakistan A(H5N8) viruses most closely related to 2017 Saudi Arabia A(H5N8) viruses, which were likely introduced via cross-border transmission from neighboring regions approximately 3 months prior to virus detection into domestic poultry. Our data further revealed that clade 2.3.4.4b viruses underwent rapid lineage expansion in 2017 and acquired significant amino acid mutations, including mutations associated with increased haemagglutinin affinity to human alpha-2,6 receptors, prior to the 1st human A(H5N8) infection in Russian poultry workers in 2020. These results highlight the need for systematic avian influenza surveillance in live bird markets in Pakistan to monitor for potential A(H5Nx) variants that may arise from poultry populations." - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Vehari, Punjab, Pakistan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8663587,58698] See Also
