View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-11 17:07:53 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (112): Europe (France) backyard poultry, HPAI H5N8 Archive Number: 20210911.8662208AVIAN INFLUENZA (112): EUROPE (FRANCE) BACKYARD POULTRY, HPAI H5N8******************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 10 Sep 2021 07:19 EDTSource: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/france-raises-bird-flu-risk-level-h5n8-found-backyard-poultry-2021-09-10/France has raised its bird flu alert level after a severe form of the virus was found among backyard poultry in the northeast, on top of cases in neighbouring Belgium and Luxembourg, the farm ministry said on Friday [10 Sep 2021].The highly contagious H5N8 strain of avian influenza was found this week among ducks, hens, turkeys and pigeons belonging to a household in the Ardennes region, with all the animals slaughtered as a precaution, the ministry said in a statement. "The health situation regarding highly pathogenic avian influenza is worrying. Since 1 Aug 2021, 25 cases have been detected in Europe among wild and captive birds," it said.Two cases of H5N8 were reported last week in Belgium -- one at a bird merchant and one at a private home -- and another at a home in Luxembourg that has been linked to the merchant in Belgium, the French ministry added. The latest cases involving the H5N8 strain of bird flu had prompted France to increase its risk assessment to "moderate" from "negligible," which would lead to poultry being confined indoors in some areas, it said.The outbreak in France would not compromise the bird flu-free status the country had just obtained again after a previous wave of H5N8 bird flu, the ministry added. Bird flu outbreaks can prompt importing countries, notably in Asia, to impose trade restrictions on poultry products.France culled around 3 million birds last winter in its southwestern duck-breeding region as it grappled with the spread of the virus from wild birds to poultry flocks. The massive outbreak led the government to agree to new biosecurity measures with the poultry sector. These included a requirement to confine flocks during risk periods and a commitment to reduce the density of flocks in the southwest, home to the country's duck-based foie gras pate industry.[Byline: Gus Trompiz and Sudip Kar-Gupta]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The 2020-2021 HPAI H5N8 epizootic observed in many European countries appears to have been one of the largest HPAI epizootics in Europe. It peaked in February 2021.An FLI (Germany) map presenting all HPAI H5 in Europe, since 1 Oct 2020, as of 2 Sep 2021, affecting poultry, wild birds, and hobby farms/petting zoos, is available at https://www.fli.de/de/aktuelles/tierseuchengeschehen/aviaere-influenza-ai-gefluegelpest/karten-zur-klassischen-gefluegelpest/. This map does not differentiate between the various AH serotypes. Such detailed information is available in the FAO-EMPRES last monthly "Global AIV with Zoonotic Potential situation update," published on 25 Aug 2021. Map 1 in the said report presents "Global distribution of AIV with zoonotic potential observed since 1 Oct 2020", available at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/Global_AIV_Zoonotic_Update/img/map1_2021_08_25.jpg. According to this map, most outbreaks in Europe during the addressed period were caused by HPAI H5N8 (violet).For detailed information on each country, including France, in the said situation update, see Table 1, "Highly pathogenic avian influenza viruses with zoonotic potential", at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/Global_AIV_Zoonotic_Update/situation_update.html.The media report does not specify the locality in which the outbreak in northeast France is located. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:France: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8662208,100] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-11 13:09:25 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (18): China (GX) H5N6 Archive Number: 20210911.8657500AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (18): CHINA (GUANGXI) H5N6*************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 9 Sep 2021Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-another-h5n6-avian-influenza-case-88663/amp/Hong Kong's Centre for Health Protection (CHP) reports monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in mainland China, the 18th case reported in the past year.The case involves a 48-year-old woman living in Liuzhou, Guangxi, who had contact with live domestic poultry before the onset of symptoms. She developed symptoms on 25 Aug 2021 and was admitted for treatment on 29 Aug 2021. The patient is in serious condition.From 2014 to date [9 Sep 2021], 42 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by Mainland health authorities.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Intensive surveillance should be continued to detect cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of these viruses, as the frequency of cases is increasing.According to the last FAO update dated 25 Aug 2021: "To date, 41 human cases of influenza A(H5N6) have been reported, 40 occurring in China and one in Lao People's Democratic Republic" (http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/Global_AIV_Zoonotic_Update/situation_update.html). Including the case from the above report, it makes a total of 42 cases to date (9 Sep 2021).According to reports received by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), various influenza A(H5) subtypes continue to be detected in birds in Africa, Europe, and Asia. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map of Guangxi, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8657500,355] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-10 18:49:50 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (110): Europe (Luxembourg) backyard bird, HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20210910.8659824AVIAN INFLUENZA (110): EUROPE (LUXEMBOURG) BACKYARD BIRD, HPAI H5N8, OIE************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 9 Sep 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=39256SummaryReport type: Immediate notificationStarted: [3 Sep 2021]Confirmed: [6 Sep 2021]Reported: 7 Sep 2021Reason for notification: 1st occurrence in the countryCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to the whole country.Outbreak location: Oligen, Betzdorf, GrevenmacherStarted: 3 Sep 2021Epidemiological unit: BackyardTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 60 / 14 / 14 / 46 / - / -EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Introduction of new live animalsControl measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: Traceability, zoning, stamping out, disinfestation, disinfection, movement control inside the countryDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultSciensano (foreign laboratory) / Birds / 1 / Real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 6 Sep 2021 / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[A press release published on 6 Sep 2021 by the Ministry of Agriculture, Viticulture and Rural Development mentioned: "The Administration of Veterinary Services (ASV) informs that, on September 6, 2021, a case of avian influenza type H5N8 was confirmed in a non-commercial farm in Olingen, following the import of poultry from a market in Belgium."In order to limit the spread of the virus to other farms, the ASV issues the following biosecurity precautionary measures to any keeper of poultry and birds:- Any transport and exhibition of live poultry is prohibited, except with special authorization from the ASV.- It is strongly recommended to confine the poultry indoors, respectively to cover the poultry runs with nets.- Feeding and watering must be done inside buildings.- Any abnormal poultry mortality should be reported to a veterinarian or to the Veterinary Services Administration."Throughout the year, the State Veterinary Medicine Laboratory conducts tests to monitor the avian influenza situation."Finally, the Administration of Veterinary Services would like to point out that the consumption of meat and eggs is without risk to public health" (in French, https://bit.ly/3tyo1So). - View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-08 10:24:47 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (109): Togo (MA), Botswana (KL) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20210908.8652258AVIAN INFLUENZA (109): TOGO (MARITIME), BOTSWANA (KGATLENG) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE***********************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1] Togo (Maritime): HPAI H5N1[2] Botswana (Kgatleng): HPAI H5N1, 1st report******[1] Togo (Maritime): HPAI H5N1Date: Mon 6 Sep 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=39070Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Togo---------------------------------------General informationReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 17 Aug 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 24 Aug 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 24 Mar 2019Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory, necropsyThis event pertains to the whole country.Outbreak location: Agodeka (Baguida township), Golfe (Lome), MaritimeDate of start of the outbreak: 17 Aug 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 1880 / 1040 / 879 / 1001 / 0 / 0Affected population: the farm is a laying hen and cockerel farm with 2 separate buildings approximately 50 m [164 ft] apart on 2 different plots of land belonging to the same owner. The farm is located in a conurbation, with the owner's family living in the plot where the disease started. This plot housed approximately 1000 layers (7 months old) at the start of the disease. At the time of the investigation, only 161 were still alive. The 2nd plot has a building that housed 650 cockerels and 190 pullets (3 months old). Signs of the disease were not observed in this building.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: the farm is located in a conurbation in plots where the owner's family lives. Biosecurity measures are almost non-existent. The owner's wife sells eggs from the farm to the market, a potential source of infection. Likely introduction of the virus by traders who come to buy eggs from the farm using their own trays which have been recycled several times. The poultry house is close to the Zio river valley, which is a biotope for birds.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; traceability; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; movement control inside the country; quarantine; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; official destruction of animal products; disinfection; stamping outDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result[Lome Central Veterinary Laboratory] (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / rapid test / 24 Aug 2021 / positive[Lome Central Veterinary Laboratory] (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / multiplex reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR multiplex) / 25 Aug 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map of Togo: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8652258,68581]******[2] Botswana (Kgatleng): HPAI H5N1, 1st reportDate: Mon 6 Sep 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=39075Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Botswana-------------------------------------------General informationReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 24 Jul 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 27 Aug 2021Reason for notification: 1st occurrence in the countryManifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory, necropsyThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: Bokaa, KgatlengDate of start of the outbreak: 24 Jul 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 25 / 8 / 8 / 17 / 0 / 0Affected population: exotic breed of chickens (Orpington) reared in a backyard.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: one chicken carcass was submitted by the farmer directly to Botswana National Veterinary Laboratory for post-mortem examination on [26 Jul 2021]. The farmer mentioned that he noticed abnormal deaths of his chickens without showing any sickness. By the time he sent the sample to the laboratory, he had lost 8 chickens out of 25. He indicated that before the sudden deaths, dark combs were noticed on the chickens.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: traceability; surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; stamping out; quarantine; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; official destruction of animal products; movement control inside the country; disinfection; control of wildlife reservoirs; ante and post-mortem inspectionsDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultBotswana National Veterinary Laboratory (NVL) (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 27 Aug 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The immediate notification report sent by Botswana responds to the request for information published in ProMED-posting 20210901.8638511. Unfortunately, HPAI subtype H5N1 has been officially confirmed for the 1st time in the country.Officially reported HPAI outbreaks (H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8 subtypes) in Sub-Saharan Africa, by date of onset (1 Oct 2020-11 Aug 2021), can be seen at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/situation_update.html. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Botswana: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8652258,68558] See Also

zoning; stamping out; quarantine; disinfestation; disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultSciensano National Laboratory / Birds / 1 / Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 1 Sep 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The previous outbreak of HPAI in Belgium, affecting captive birds, was reported on 10 Jun 2021, "highly pathogenic avian influenza type H5N8 was identified in a private keeper in Le Roeulx. Consequently, restricted zones have been established around this case: a temporary buffer zone of 500 m [1640 ft], a protection zone of 3 km [2 mi], and a surveillance zone of 10 km [6 mi]." Detailed information regarding the outbreaks of HPAI in captive birds is available at https://www.fasfc.be/animalsanimal-healthanimal-diseasesavian-diseasesavian-influenza/situation-belgium.A self-declaration of recovery of infection with high pathogenicity avian influenza viruses (HPAI) free status in poultry by Belgium, was approved and published by the OIE on 16 Aug 2021. The full document is available at https://www.oie.int/app/uploads/2021/08/2021-05-belgium-hpai-eng.pdf.More detailed information on the epidemiological situation of HPAI in Belgium is available at https://www.fasfc.be/animalsanimal-healthanimal-diseasesavian-diseasesavian-influenza/situation-belgium (last updated 6 Sep 2021). - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Belgium: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8652190,68580] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-06 17:37:09 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (17): China (HN) H9N2 Archive Number: 20210906.8647141AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (17): CHINA (HUNAN) H9N2***********************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 3 Sep 2021Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-h9n2-avian-influenza-case-confirmed-in-hunan-province-toddler-40738/Chinese health officials reported one new case of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) to the World Health Organization (WHO) this week. The case is a 20-month-old female from Changsha, Hunan Province, China, who had onset of mild illness on 23 Aug 2021 and was hospitalized on 24 Aug [2021].The child had a history of exposure to domestic poultry prior to illness onset, and no further cases were suspected among family members or any other close contacts at the time of reporting.This is the 15th case of avian influenza A(H9N2) reported from China in 2021. A total of 56 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) have been officially reported from China to WHO since December 2015.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Avian H9N2 influenza A viruses have caused repeated human infections in Asia since 1998. An H9N2 influenza virus infected a 5-year-old child in Hong Kong in 2003.Influenza A(H9N2) viruses are enzootic in poultry populations in parts of Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. Most human cases are exposed to the A(H9N2) virus through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments. Human infection tends to result in mild clinical illness.The continued presence of H9N2 influenza viruses in poultry markets in southern China increases the likelihood of avian-to-human interspecies transmission.Furthermore, the number of human infections with A/H9N2 avian influenza viruses has been higher in 2021 (15 cases, which includes the new case from Hunan, China, in the above report) compared with earlier years, which is a cause for concern and highlights the need for continuous monitoring and risk assessments of these viruses with pandemic potential. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map of Hunan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8647141,341] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-01 20:33:22 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (107): Europe (Russia) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20210901.8638782AVIAN INFLUENZA (107): EUROPE (RUSSIA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE**************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 1 Sep 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=38768Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Russia----------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 20 Aug 2021Confirmed: 26 Aug 2021Reported: 1 Sep 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 25 Jan 2021Causal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks (1)Outbreak location 1: Khudajberdinsky, Argayashskiy rayon, ChelyabinskStarted: 20 Aug 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 17 000 / 2013 / 2013 / - / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measures applied in domestic: zoning, surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone; quarantine; screening; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; movement control inside the country; disinfection; control of wildlife reservoirsDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultChelyabinskaya Veterinary Laboratory local laboratory/ birds / real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / [20-26 Aug 2021] / positiveFederal Centre for Animal Health (FGBI "ARRIAH") OIE reference laboratory / birds / real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / [20-26 Aug 2021] / positiveFederal Centre for Animal Health (FGBI "ARRIAH") OIE reference laboratory / birds / gene sequencing / [20-31 Aug 2021] / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>["HPAIV A(H5N1) is highly infectious for a number of bird species, including most species of domestic poultry. Unlike most other avian influenza viruses, this virus has also infected mammals, including cats, pigs, and tigers, and has shown to be able to transmit to humans. However, the virus remains poorly adapted to humans, and transmission from birds to humans is a rare event. Since the 1st detection of zoonotic transmission of HPAI A(H5N1), limited clusters of human cases have occurred, but no sustained human-to-human transmission has been observed but showed. Zoonotic transmission to humans from infected birds occurs either directly or through environmental contamination. Hence, almost all human infections have been related to close contact with infected or sick birds or their faecal products in domestic settings, e.g., in 'wet markets' in Asia or in backyard farming. The circulation of HPAI A(H5N1) in bird populations in different regions of the world has contributed to the emergence of different virus clades." - Mod.CRD(https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/zoonotic-influenza/facts/factsheet-h5n1)HealthMap/ProMED map of Chelyabinsk Oblast, Russia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8638782,424] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-09-01 19:00:09 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (106): Botswana (KL) poultry, HPAI susp, RFI Archive Number: 20210901.8638511AVIAN INFLUENZA (106): BOTSWANA (KGATLENG) POULTRY, HIGHLY PATHOGENIC AVIAN INFLUENZA SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION*************************************************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 1 Sep 2021Source: The Poultry Site [edited]https://www.thepoultrysite.com/news/2021/09/suspected-bird-flu-outbreak-identified-in-botswanaAnimal health authorities in Botswana have announced a suspected case of highly pathogenic bird flu at a backyard poultry farm in Bokaa village on 30 Aug [2021].The potential case of bird flu was identified in the Kgatleng district of Botswana. The country's ministry of agriculture has banned the movement of live birds, eggs, meat, and feathers within and out of the Bokaa area to contain the outbreak.Poultry producers are also being told to improve biosecurity protocols in their facilities and prevent contact between poultry and wild birds.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[A laboratory confirmation of the 1st record of HPAI in Botswana, including the identity of the causative agent, is requested.Notably, only 2 countries in Southern Africa have reported HPAI so far, namely South Africa (H5N1, H5N8) and Lesotho (H5). As far as concerning sub-Saharan Africa, all other sub-Saharan countries that have, so far, reported HPAI (either in domestic poultry or in wild birds) are situated in or adjacent to West Africa: Benin (A5), Cote D'Ivoire (H5N1), Ghana (H5N1), Lesotho (H5), Mali (H5N1), Mauritania (H5), Niger (H5N1), Nigeria (H5N1), Senegal (H5), and Togo (H5N1).For the location of the outbreak, affecting a backyard poultry farm in Bokaa village, see map at <tinyurl.com/xd4zcm42>. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Bokaa, Kgatleng, Botswana: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8638511,68558] See Also

the National Reference Laboratory tested the dead Anatidae positive for highly pathogenic H5N8.Outbreak location 3: Bunschoten, Bunschoten, UtrechtStarted: 16 Aug 2021Epidemiological unit: otherTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedMallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: one mallard was found dead in a wetland; control of wildlife reservoirs.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultWageningen Bioveterinary Research National Reference Laboratory, Lelystad National Laboratory / Mallard/Anatidae (unidentified) / 3 / Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 20 to 24 Aug 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[A few days ago the Netherlands reported cases in another wild waterfowl species, the greater white-fronted goose (see ProMED post 20210818.8604361). The HPAI epidemic of 2020-2021 is the largest that has occurred in Europe, with more than 3500 HPAI episodes reported in almost 30 European countries. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Farmers must apply stringent biosecurity measures.Recent information on the situation in Europe may be accessed at https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Avian-influenza-overview-February-May-2021_1.pdf. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of the Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8632118,104] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-25 11:48:00 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (104): Europe (Belgium) HPAI-free status, OIE, comment Archive Number: 20210825.8621036AVIAN INFLUENZA (104): EUROPE (BELGIUM) HPAI-FREE STATUS, OIE, COMMENT**********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 23 Aug 2021From: Matthew Stone <m.stone@oie.int> [edited]re: ProMED Avian influenza (102): Europe (Belgium) HPAI-free status, OIE 20210822.8614555--------------------------------------------------------------------------------To avoid any misperception amongst ProMED readers, please note that freedom from highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) is a self-declared status, and the OIE Delegate of the declaring country assumes full responsibility for the information contained in the self-declaration. The OIE procedure before publication ensures all the elements of the international standards (OIE Code and Manual) are addressed in the self-declaration, but does not assume responsibility for their verification. This is addressed in the disclaimer attached to all self-declarations published by the OIE on our website.This is distinct from the OIE Official Recognition of Status or Control Programmes, which is restricted to specific OIE Listed diseases (AHS [African horse sickness], BSE [bovine spongiform encephalopathy], CBPP [contagious bovine pleuropneumonia], CSF [classical swine fever], FMD [foot-and-mouth disease], PPR [peste des petits ruminants], rabies) and results in a Resolution endorsed by the OIE World Assembly of Delegates.--Matthew StoneDeputy Director General, International Standards and ScienceWorld Organisation for Animal Health (OIE)<m.stone@oie.int>[OIE's valuable contribution above, clarifying the difference between "official freedom" of an animal disease and "self-declared" freedom of animal diseases, is gratefully acknowledged and appreciated. OIE's web pages addressing 'self-declared-disease-status', including a disclaimer and a link to the 'Standard Operating Procedure' (SOP) for countries wishing to self-declare the freedom from a disease of their country, zone, or compartment, are available at https://www.oie.int/en/what-we-do/animal-health-and-welfare/official-disease-status/self-declared-disease-status/.A table including all self-declarations of (alphabetically presented) OIE member-countries, since 2000, last updated in January 2021, is available at https://www.oie.int/app/uploads/2021/05/eng-archive-2000-january-2021.pdf. According to the table, Belgium's self-declaration of countrywide freedom from HPAI was active between 29 Sep 2017 and 18 Nov 2020. Its recent re-activation is yet to be published in the said table. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Belgium: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8621036,99] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-25 11:41:14 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (16): China (Guangdong) H5N6 Archive Number: 20210825.8611614AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (16): CHINA (GUANGDONG) H5N6***************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Sat 21 Aug 2021 00:15 CSTSource: Qianlong, Chinanews.com report [in Chinese, trans., edited]http://china.qianlong.com/2021/0821/6181804.shtmlThe Guangdong Provincial Health Commission reported on the evening of 19 Aug 2021, one case of H5N6 was in Huizhou City. The patient is a 52-year-old female who currently lives in Boluo County, Huizhou City. The patient is currently being actively treated in designated hospital in Huizhou.Experts believe that this is an occasional case and the risk of transmission of the virus is low at this stage. Experts remind that citizens should continue to be vigilant and take the following measures to prevent H5N6 and other avian influenza:- wash hands frequently: wash hands after touching poultry, before meals and after going to the toilet;- cook poultry and eggs before eating;- seek medical attention early: if you have respiratory symptoms such as fever, cough, headache, and general malaise, you should go to the nearest medical and health institution as soon as possible. If you have been in contact with poultry before, you should take the initiative to tell your doctor;- do not eat dead poultry meat, do not buy poultry or bird products of unknown origin, and avoid going to live poultry markets as much as possible.[Editor: Zhan Yuquan]--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>[ProMED thanks Mahmoud Orabi for sharing this report on a human case of avian influenza A/H5N6 in China. - Mod.UBA]******[2]Date: Fri 20 Aug 2021Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/h5n6-avian-influenza-case-reported-in-guangdong-province-china-66190/The Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Hong Kong Department of Health reported an additional human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in China. This is the 2nd case reported from the mainland in 2 days.The case is a 52-year-old woman living in Huizhou, Guangdong Province. From 2014 to date, 40 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by mainland health authorities and 16 of the cases have been reported since December 2020.Avian influenza is caused by those influenza viruses that mainly affect birds and poultry, such as chickens or ducks.Clinical presentation of avian influenza in humans includes eye infection (conjunctivitis), flu-like symptoms (e.g. fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches), or severe respiratory illness (e.g. chest infection). The incubation period ranges from 7 to 10 days.The more virulent forms can result in respiratory failure, multi-organ failure, and even death. People mainly become infected with avian influenza virus through contact with infected birds and poultry (live or dead) or their droppings, or contact with contaminated environments (such as wet markets and live poultry markets). Human-to-human transmission is inefficient.People in close contact with poultry are more susceptible to contracting avian influenza. The elderly, children, and people with chronic illnesses have a higher risk of developing complications such as bronchitis and chest infection.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the 8 Aug 2021 WHO summary and assessment, from 23 Jun 2021 to 8 Aug 2021, 6 cases of influenza A(H5N6) virus infection were reported to WHO from China. Since 2014, mainland health authorities have notified a total of 37 human cases of avian influenza A (H5N6). There have been recent reports of additional cases from Sichuan Province, China in March, June, and July 2021, as well as in Laos in April 2021."All 6 recent cases were sporadic infections due to exposure to live poultry or live poultry markets. No suspected cases were detected among close contacts of these cases at the time of reporting. The 61-year-old woman who had mild illness was detected through influenza-like illness (ILI) surveillance." (https://cdn.who.int/media/docs/default-source/influenza/human-animal-interface-risk-assessments/influenza_summary_ira_ha_interface_08_08_2021.pdf)Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Intensive surveillance should be continued to detect cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of these viruses, as the frequency of cases is increasing.According to reports received by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), various influenza A(H5) subtypes continue to be detected in birds in Africa, Europe, and Asia. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map of Guangdong, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8611614,68522] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-23 21:35:22 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (103): Benin (OU) poultry, HPAI H5, OIE Archive Number: 20210823.8616558AVIAN INFLUENZA (103): BENIN (OUEME) POULTRY, HPAI H5, OIE**********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 20 Aug 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=38127Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Benin--------------------------------------------General informationReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 18 Aug 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 30 Apr 2008Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to the whole country.Outbreak location: Tohoue village, Seme-Kpodji, OuemeDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 6661 / 6626 / 6626 / - / - / 0Affected population: 11-month-old laying hens with digestive disorders and a drop in lay with a 50% mortality rate at the beginning. The outbreak is located in the village of Tohoue, which is close to Nigeria.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: Massive mortality up to 50% was observed the 1st 2 days following the onset of the disease in laying hens in a farm where the animals are kept in pens. The mortality to date is 6626 poultry birds.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: quarantineDomestic control measures to be applied: zoning; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; movement control inside the country; slaughter; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection; screening; control of wildlife reservoirsWild control measures to be applied: control of wildlife reservoirsDiagnostic test results: [not available][The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Officially reported HPAI outbreaks (H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8 subtypes) in Sub-Saharan Africa, by date of onset (1 Oct 2020-11 Aug 2021), can be seen at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/situation_update.html.The following information comes from an article by Kalonda et al.:Citation: Kalonda A, Saasa N, Nkhoma P, et al. Avian Influenza Viruses Detected in Birds in Sub-Saharan Africa: A Systematic Review. Viruses. 2020; 12(9): 993; https://www.mdpi.com/1999-4915/12/9/993/htm.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Abstract---------"In the recent past, sub-Saharan Africa has not escaped the devastating effects of avian influenza virus (AIV) in poultry and wild birds. This systematic review describes the prevalence, spatiotemporal distribution, and virus subtypes detected in domestic and wild birds for the past 2 decades (2000-2019). We collected data from 3 electronic databases, PubMed, SpringerLink electronic journals and African Journals Online, using the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses protocol. A total of 1656 articles were reviewed, from which 68 were selected. An overall prevalence of 3.0% AIV in birds was observed. The prevalence varied between regions and ranged from 1.1% to 7.1%. The Kruskal-Wallis and Wilcoxon signed-rank sum test showed no significant difference in the prevalence of AIV across regions, X2(3) = 5.237, p = 0.1553 and seasons, T = 820, z = -1.244, p = 0.2136. Nineteen hemagglutinin/neuraminidase subtype combinations were detected during the reviewed period, with southern Africa recording more diverse AIV subtypes than other regions. The most detected subtype was H5N1, followed by H9N2, H5N2, H5N8, and H6N2. Whilst these predominant subtypes were mostly detected in domestic poultry, H1N6, H3N6, H4N6, H4N8, H9N1, and H11N9 were exclusively detected in wild birds. Meanwhile, H5N1, H5N2, and H5N8 were detected in both wild and domestic birds, suggesting circulation of these subtypes among wild and domestic birds. Our findings provide critical information on the eco-epidemiology of AIVs that can be used to improve surveillance strategies for the prevention and control of avian influenza in sub-Saharan Africa."Conclusions"Our review of AIVs in sub-Saharan Africa has provided an insight into the ecology and epidemiological trends of AIVs in birds over a 20-year period (2000-2019). We found a considerable diversity of AIV subtypes in sub-Saharan Africa, with some subtypes being detected frequently in both wild and domestic birds. Furthermore, AIV was detected in wildfowl and domestic birds in both the wet and dry seasons, with viruses being detected in both Eurasian migratory and indigenous African wild birds. These results suggest a year-round perpetuation of AIVs in Afrotropical ecosystems, with seasonal variation. Continued surveillance, especially in wild birds, to better understand the eco-epidemiology of IAVs, along with improved biosecurity on poultry farms, enhanced extension services and engagement of various disciplines under a 'One Health' approach in tackling avian influenza could assist in mitigating the impact of AIV in sub-Saharan Africa." - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Oueme Department, Benin: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8616558,52171] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-22 21:06:07 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (102): Europe (Belgium) HPAI-free status, OIE Archive Number: 20210822.8614555AVIAN INFLUENZA (102): EUROPE (BELGIUM) HPAI-FREE STATUS, OIE*************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 21 Aug 2021Source: The Brussels Times [edited]https://www.brusselstimes.com/news/belgium-all-news/181914/belgium-declared-bird-flu-free-again/The World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) granted Belgium disease-free status for highly pathogenic avian influenza in poultry, or bird flu, this week.Belgium had been struggling with outbreaks of bird flu, resulting in 24 countries closing their markets to Belgian poultry, a significant blow to the industry."On 1 Nov 2020, a 'period of increased risk' was declared in Belgium after the highly pathogenic bird flu virus was detected in wild birds in the Netherlands," explained the Flemish infocentre for agriculture and horticulture (VILT)."As a result, additional biosecurity measures were taken to limit the spread of the virus, including the obligation to keep animals indoors. Nevertheless, in mid-November [2020], the virus was also detected in wild birds in Belgium, followed by several outbreaks in poultry and other domestic birds."Similar outbreaks occurred in France, and some of the cases in Belgium occurred at smallholder farms, including one in July [2021] in Moerzeke, near Hamme in East Flanders. The last outbreak in a commercial poultry farm, however, was over 3 months ago, according to VILT.Since then, no additional outbreaks have been reported in the commercial sector, which prompted Belgium to issue a self-declaration of being bird flu free dating from 29 Apr 2021. That declaration has now been validated by the OIE and published on its website.Other countries to recently issue self-declarations of being free from bird flu include Denmark, the Czech Republic, and the Netherlands.Elsewhere in Europe, however, cases of the virus are still being detected in wild birds."This shows that the virus is still actively circulating in these populations," said Belgium's Federal Agency for the Safety of the Food Chain (FASFC). "That is why vigilance is still required in Belgium and why it is still important to comply with the general biosecurity measures."The federal and regional authorities are jointly monitoring the situation in order to detect any new incidents of the virus at an early stage."Poultry farms are actively sampled," said the FASFC. "Poultry farmers and veterinarians also keep a so-called 'passive surveillance,' in which they are vigilant for abnormal mortality or symptoms that could indicate contamination with the virus."Now that Belgium has been granted bird-flu-free status, poultry trade with other countries can restart, according to FASFC.[Byline: Helen Lyons]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[According to Belgium's FASFC, between the end of November 2020 and mid-July 2021, 8 outbreaks caused by highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 virus were detected. This included 2 commercial poultry farms, a bird trader, and 5 small poultry holdings. In 6 of the outbreaks, HPAI H5N8 was identified as the causal agent; the remaining 2 remained defined as HPAI H5NX (Neuraminidase not typed). Restricted zones were established around all these contaminated sites.As recently reported from neighboring Netherlands (ProMED archive no. 20210818.8604361), HPAI H5N8 continues its circulation in wild waterbirds. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Belgium: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8614555,99] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-22 13:33:12 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (101): Cote d'Ivoire (CM) poultry, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20210822.8613872AVIAN INFLUENZA (101): COTE D'IVOIRE (COMOE) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 19 Aug 2021Source: Bloomberg [edited]https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-08-18/ivory-coast-announces-measures-to-curb-bird-flu-outbreakCote d'Ivoire has put several measures in place to curb a bird flu outbreak near the economic capital Abidjan.Lab tests confirmed the presence of the H5N1 type following the death of many chickens in traditional and modern farms in the town of Grand Bassam in recent weeks, Livestock and Fisheries Minister Sidi Toure said in a statement Wednesday [18 Aug 2021].The measures include strengthening the control of movement of poultry, its products and by-products and emergency sanitary slaughtering of all poultry present in the outbreak area, among others.It's the 1st outbreak of bird flu in the West African nation since 2015 when at least 12 000 chickens had to be slaughtered to stop the spread. [Byline: Leanne de Bassompierre and Baudelaire Mieu]--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[The new outbreak in Cote d'Ivoire has been preceded by several outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in West Africa since the start of the recent disease season (Oct 2020), including Nigeria, Benin, Togo, Burkina Faso, Senegal (and neighboring Mali). Please refer to FAO's map, "Global distribution of AIV with zoonotic potential observed since 01 October 2020" (HPAI H5N1 outbreaks presented as red circles), at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/Global_AIV_Zoonotic_Update/img/map1_2021_07_28.jpg (last updated 28 Jul 2021). The most recent outbreak in a Cote d'Ivoire neighboring country, Benin, had reportedly started on 27 Jul 2021 and has been reported to the OIE on 20 Aug 2021; the report is available at https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=38127. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Cote d'Ivoire: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8613872,52] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-19 18:52:28 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (15): India (HR) H5N1, confirmed, WHO Archive Number: 20210819.8601971AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (15): INDIA (HARYANA) H5N1, CONFIRMED, WHO*****************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 16 Aug 2021Source: World Health Organization [edited]https://www.who.int/emergencies/disease-outbreak-news/item/human-infection-with-avian-influenza-a(h5n1)-%EF%BD%B0-indiaOn 21 Jul 2021, the National IHR [International Health Regulations] focal point of India notified WHO of one human case of avian influenza A(H5N1) from Haryana state, northern India. This is the 1st reported case of human infection of influenza A(H5N1) virus in India.The patient was a boy under 18 years of age with a recently diagnosed underlying illness in June 2021. Shortly after immunosuppressive treatment was initiated at the hospital, he presented with fever, cough, upper respiratory symptoms, and breathing difficulty on 12 Jun [2021]. His condition progressed to acute respiratory distress syndrome, and he was mechanically ventilated but died on 12 Jul [2021]. In the past year, the boy resided with a family member who owned a butchery in Haryana state. Based on initial investigations, there were no reports of poultry sickness or deaths from a nearby poultry farm in the village where he resided. The source of infection is unknown at this time, and none of his family members have shown similar symptoms thus far.On 7 and 11 Jul 2021 respiratory samples from the patient tested positive by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) at the All India Institute of Medical Science hospital for influenza A and influenza B viruses but negative for SARS-CoV-2 and other respiratory viruses. On 13 Jul [2021], the samples were sent to National Institute of Virology, a WHO reference laboratory for influenza, for subtyping. Samples were tested for seasonal viruses of influenza A and influenza B, as well as avian influenza subtypes H5, H7, H9, and H10 by RT-PCR. On 15 Jul [2021], the samples tested positive for influenza A(H5N1) and influenza B/Victoria lineage viruses. Whole-genome sequencing and virus isolation is ongoing.Public health response----------------------Local and national health authorities have taken the following monitoring, prevention, and control measures:- Conducting further epidemiological investigation on the origin of infection of the case, including a multidisciplinary rapid response team (comprising public health and animal health officials) supporting the state of Haryana;- Strengthened surveillance, including enhanced monitoring of febrile cases (house-to-house surveys for fever surveillance conducted by health-care workers) within a 10 km [6.2 mi] radius of the patient's residence;- Disinfected the patient's residence and the surrounding environment;- Directed all health institutions in the district to report any suspected cases of human infection with avian influenza;- Closely traced and managed contacts of the case, including health-care workers at the medical facility where the case was provided care;- Performed risk communication activities to heighten public awareness, including for personal protective measures;- Conducted animal surveillance by the animal husbandry department.WHO risk assessment-------------------Available information and initial field investigations suggest that no additional cases have been suspected, indicating a low likelihood of human-to-human transmission. Further sporadic cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5) viruses may be reported because these viruses have been occasionally detected in poultry populations in India. The risk assessment will be reviewed as necessary, should further epidemiological or virological information become available.India has reported outbreaks of avian influenza A(H5N1) in poultry farms every year since it was first reported in a poultry farm in Maharashtra state in February 2006. In January and February 2021, Haryana state reported an outbreak of avian influenza A(H5N8) in Panchkula district, which severely affected poultry in the area. In that outbreak, samples collected from birds from 4 poultry farms tested positive for avian influenza A(H5N8).Should infected individuals from affected areas travel internationally, their infection may be detected in another country during travel or after arrival. If this were to occur, further community level spread is considered unlikely as this virus has not acquired the ability to transmit easily among humans.WHO advice----------The detection of this case does not change current WHO recommendations on public health measures and surveillance of influenza. The primary risk factor for human infection with avian influenza is direct or indirect exposure to infected poultry (live or dead) or wildlife, as well as contaminated environments such as live bird markets. Additional risk factors include slaughtering, defeathering, handling carcasses of infected poultry, and preparing poultry for consumption, especially in household settings.As at all times, the public should avoid contact with high-risk environments such as live animal markets/farms and live poultry, or surfaces that might be contaminated by poultry or bird faeces. Hand hygiene with frequent handwashing with soap and water or use of alcohol-based hand sanitizer is recommended.Good food safety practices such as keeping cooking environments clean, separating raw and cooked food, and cooking food thoroughly should also be followed. There is no evidence to suggest that influenza A(H5), A(H7N9), or other avian influenza viruses can be transmitted to humans through properly cooked poultry. There is no epidemiological evidence to suggest that people have been infected with avian influenza by consumption of eggs or egg products. However, eggs from areas with outbreaks in poultry should not be consumed raw or partially cooked (with runny yolk).Health-care workers performing aerosol-generating procedures should use airborne precautions. Standard contact and droplet precautions and appropriate personal protective equipment should be made available and used during epidemics.Due to the constantly evolving nature of influenza viruses, WHO continues to stress the importance of global surveillance to detect virological, epidemiological, and clinical changes associated with circulating influenza viruses that may affect human or animal health, as well as timely sharing of viruses to inform risk assessments.In the case of a confirmed or suspected human infection caused by a novel influenza virus with pandemic potential, including avian influenza or variant viruses, a thorough epidemiologic investigation should be conducted (even while awaiting the confirmatory laboratory results) on the history of exposure to animals, of travel, and contact tracing. The epidemiologic investigation should include early identification of unusual respiratory events that could signal human-to-human transmission of the novel virus. Additionally, clinical samples collected from the time and place that the case occurred should be tested and sent to a WHO Collaboration Centre for further characterization.All human infections caused by a novel influenza subtype are notifiable under the International Health Regulations [IHR (2005)], and State Parties to the IHR (2005) are required to immediately notify WHO of any laboratory-confirmed case of a recent human infection caused by an influenza A virus with the potential to cause a pandemic. Evidence of illness is not required for this report. WHO does not recommend any specific measures for travellers and advises against the application of any travel or trade restrictions in relation to this event based on the currently available information.--Submitted by ProMED Rapporteur Marianne Hopp[Additional resources/links are available via the source URL above.India is now the fourth country in the South Asian region that has reported a human case of avian influenza A/H5N1. Previously Pakistan (4), Bangladesh (8), and Nepal (1) have also reported human cases, with one death each. This is a follow-up report to an earlier post [20210722.8538183] that reported a suspected case of H5N8 influenza but Neuraminidase (N) subtype confirmation was unavailable at that time. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map:Haryana State, India: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8601971,303] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-18 11:15:55 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Botulism, avian - USA (02): (MN) waterfowl, susp Archive Number: 20210818.8604381BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA (02): (MINNESOTA) WATERFOWL, SUSPECTED************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 17 Aug 2021 9:48 AM CDTSource: Star Tribune [edited]https://www.startribune.com/duck-deaths-in-loring-park-lake-nokomis-tied-to-avian-botulism/600088565/In mid-August [2021], ducks suspected of dying from avian botulism were collected from the pond at Loring Park and at Lake Nokomis, both in Minneapolis."It's almost certainly botulism but without lab testing, we do not know, said Tami Vogel, communications director at the Wildlife Rehabilitation Center of Minnesota in Roseville."We see botulism cases flare in years of hot, drought conditions when shallow ponds/lakes become too low and an anaerobic condition occurs," she told us.Researchers were to examine the birds to confirm cause of death.[Byline: Jim Williams]--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. This pathogen is widespread in soil and requires warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. There are several types of toxin produced by strains of _C. botulinum_; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.Birds either ingest the toxin directly or may eat invertebrates (e.g. chironomids, fly larvae) containing the toxin. Invertebrates are not affected by the toxin and store it in their body. A cycle develops in a botulism outbreak when fly larvae (maggots) feed on animal carcasses and ingest toxin. Ducks and other birds that consume toxin-laden maggots can develop botulism after eating as few as 3 or 4 maggots.Healthy birds, affected birds, and dead birds in various stages of decay are commonly found in the same area. The toxin affects the nervous system by preventing impulse transmission to muscles. Birds are unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd eyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. Birds with paralyzed neck muscles cannot hold their heads up and often drown. Death can also result from water deprivation, electrolyte imbalance, respiratory failure, or predation.Prompt removal and proper disposal of carcasses by burial or burning (in accordance with applicable ordinances) are highly effective in removing toxin and maggot sources from the environment.Providing mildly affected birds with fresh water, shade, and protection from predators may help them recover from the intoxication. Botulism antitoxin is available but requires special handling and must be given early in the intoxication. Also, providing it to wild bird populations is extremely challenging and often unfeasible. Birds that survive a botulism outbreak are NOT immune to botulism toxin.Portions of this comment were extracted from https://www.usgs.gov/centers/nwhc/science/avian-botulism. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Minnesota, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8604381,3703] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-18 11:06:45 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (100): Europe (Netherlands) wild bird, HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20210818.8604361AVIAN INFLUENZA (100): EUROPE (NETHERLANDS) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N8, OIE*********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 11 Aug 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=37479Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Netherlands--------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 3 Aug 2021Confirmed: 9 Aug 2021Reported: 10 Aug 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 6 Jul 2021Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus [HPAI]Serotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks (1)Outbreak location 1: Eemdijk, Bunschoten, UtrechtStarted: 3 Aug 2021Epidemiological unit: not applicableTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedGreater white-fronted goose (_Anser albifrons_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 6 / 6 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: on [3 Aug 2021] 6 young greater white-fronted geese (_Anser albifrons_) were found dead on a wetland area. On [9 Aug 2021] the NRL [National Reference Laboratory] confirmed HPAI H5N8 virus in the samples from the greater white fronted geese.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measures at event levelWild control measures applied: official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; control of wildlife reservoirs.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultWageningen Bioveterinary Research National Reference Laboratory, Lelystad National Laboratory / Greater white-fronted goose / 1 / Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 9 Aug 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The HPAI epidemic of 2020-2021 is the largest that has occurred in Europe, with more than 3500 HPAI episodes reported in almost 30 European countries. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Farmers must apply stringent biosecurity measures.Recent information on the situation in Europe may be accessed at https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Avian-influenza-overview-February-May-2021_1.pdf. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of the Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8604361,68513] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-13 11:54:45 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (99): Cote d'Ivoire (CM) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20210813.8592884AVIAN INFLUENZA (99): COTE D'IVOIRE (COMOE) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE*******************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 11 Aug 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=37558Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Cote d'Ivoire------------------------------------------------General informationReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 15 Jul 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 29 Jul 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 23 Oct 2016Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory, necropsyThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.Outbreak location: village of Mondoukou, Grand Bassam, Sud Comoe, ComoeDate of start of the outbreak: 15 Jul 2021Epidemiological unit: villageTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 76 613 / 43 410 / 43 410 / - / - / -Affected population: the affected population is composed of chickens, guinea fowl, ducks, and quail.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: some 39 farms were identified in the village of Mondoukou. Samples were taken from three farms and found to be positive for the H5N1 avian influenza virus. The remaining 36 farms showed the same symptoms as the 3 farms that were diagnosed and also experienced mortality. Overall, the mortality observed was around 56.7% and varied according to species: broilers (63.4%), layers (26%), traditional chickens (65%), guinea fowl (98.8%), ducks (32%), turkeys (7.5%), and quails (35%).Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: quarantine; official destruction of animal products; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; movement control inside the country; screeningDomestic control measures to be applied: stamping out; disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and wasteDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result[Central Veterinary Laboratory], Bingerville (LCVB) (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / 29 Jul 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtype H5N1 continues to spread in West Africa (see ProMED posts listed below). Therefore, it should not be surprising that the disease has now been reported in Cote d'Ivoire. Establishing cooperative efforts between the affected countries in the area aimed at reducing the spread of the disease should be a priority.Officially reported HPAI outbreaks (H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8 subtypes) in Sub-Saharan Africa, by date of onset (1 Oct 2020-11 Aug 2021), can be seen at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/situation_update.html. This last FAO Sub-Saharan Africa HPAI situation update dated 11 Aug 2021, mentioned that in Cote d'Ivoire, "a refresher training was organized for field veterinary agents on sample collection and shipment for priority diseases including HPAI on 12-16 Apr 2021. Following the notification of HPAI in Senegal, Mauritania, Nigeria, Ghana and Togo, the focus of FAO ECTAD [Emergency Center for Transboundary Animal Diseases] Cote d'Ivoire is to increase awareness and vigilance in high-risk zones such as wild bird resting sites. As a result of increased active surveillance and vigilance in high-risk zones, information on suspected outbreaks including mortality of poultry was reported in the southeastern region of Grand Bassam during the Animal health technical working group meeting held on [5 Aug 2021]. FAO ECTAD Cote d'Ivoire is actively supporting national counterparts as per emergency request. Official communication on the situation is awaited." - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Ivory Coast: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8592884,68509.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-10 12:34:06 UTC Subject: PRO/AH> Botulism, avian - USA: (MA) waterfowl, susp Archive Number: 20210810.8584028BOTULISM, AVIAN - USA: (MASSACHUSETTS) WATERFOWL, SUSPECTED***********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 6 Aug 2021Source: News Channel 21, WCVB, CNN Newsource [edited]https://ktvz.com/cnn-regional/2021/08/06/officials-disease-likely-to-blame-for-significant-number-of-dead-ducks-in-massachusetts-river/The spread of a common waterfowl illness is believed to be the cause of a "significant" number of dead ducks seen recently in the Merrimack River. City of Lowell officials said they contacted the Massachusetts Division of Fisheries and Wildlife and were informed that the deaths are likely being caused by avian botulism."The National Park Service sent us a note saying that they had seen 8 ducks floating in the water," Marion Larson with Massachusetts Wildlife said. "The disease is called avian botulism, and the cause is an abundance of the toxin being present in the soil." Some sick birds are drowning, unable to hold their heads up while others can't breathe due to paralysis of their respiratory muscles. "Ducks, geese, swans, although swans seem to have a little bit less risk, and that probably has to do with their feeding habits," Larson said.There were 200 bird deaths around Massachusetts and New England last year [2020], including an outbreak that hit the lagoon at the Boston Public Garden in the fall. The water there was drained, but along the Merrimack River, it is not an option."We have been recommending that if there's any feeding activity, that it stop because you're congregating the birds together," Larson said. "We all know that certain diseases can pass very easily when you have crowds."Botulism in birds does not cause illness in humans, but people should not touch dead or ailing animals. "This is probably affecting local populations in the area, but overall, waterfowl populations are thriving," Larson said. Lowell city officials urged the public not to feed ducks by the River Walk in order to prevent ducks from congregating which could lead to further spread of the disease.[byline: Katy Preen]--communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[Avian botulism is a paralytic disease caused by ingestion of a toxin produced by the bacterium _Clostridium botulinum_. This pathogen is widespread in soil and requires warm temperatures, a protein source, and an anaerobic (no oxygen) environment in order to become active and produce toxin. Decomposing vegetation and invertebrates combined with warm temperatures can provide ideal conditions for the botulism bacteria to activate and produce toxin. Several types of toxin are produced by strains of _C. botulinum_; birds are most commonly affected by type C and to a lesser extent type E.Birds either ingest the toxin directly or may eat invertebrates (for example, chironomids, fly larvae) containing the toxin. Invertebrates are not affected by the toxin and store it in their body. A cycle develops in a botulism outbreak when fly larvae (maggots) feed on animal carcasses and ingest toxin. Ducks and other birds that consume toxin-laden maggots can develop botulism after eating as few as 3 or 4 maggots.Healthy birds, affected birds, and dead birds in various stages of decay are commonly found in the same area. The toxin affects the nervous system by preventing impulse transmission to muscles. Birds are unable to use their wings and legs normally or control the 3rd eyelid, neck muscles, and other muscles. Birds with paralyzed neck muscles cannot hold their heads up and often drown. Death can also result from water deprivation, electrolyte imbalance, respiratory failure, or predation.Prompt removal and proper disposal of carcasses by burial or burning (in accordance with applicable ordinances) is highly effective in removing toxin and maggot sources from the environment.Providing mildly affected birds with fresh water, shade, and protection from predators may help them recover from the intoxication. Botulism antitoxin is available but requires special handling and must be given early in the intoxication. Birds that survive a botulism outbreak are NOT immune to botulism toxin.Portions of this comment were extracted from https://library.dbca.wa.gov.au/static/Journals/082168/082168-34.pdf. - Mod. PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Massachusetts, United States: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8584028,4314.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-08-03 11:58:43 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (98): Togo (MA) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20210803.8565924AVIAN INFLUENZA (98): TOGO (MARITIME) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE*************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 2 Aug 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=37024Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Togo---------------------------------------General informationReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 28 Jul 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 30 Jul 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 24 Mar 2019Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory, necropsyThis event pertains to the whole country.Outbreak location: Sagbado, Golfe (Lome), MaritimeDate of start of the outbreak: 28 Jul 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 1590 / 129 / 129 / 1461 / - / -Affected population: laying hen farm with 2 flocks in production.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: the traceability investigation revealed that the bags used to transport the litter when it was changed had already been used several times and in other farms. The application of biosafety measures was not satisfactory. The affected locality is not very far from the border with Ghana, which also reported the disease ten days earlier. According to the investigation, this new outbreak does not appear to be epidemiologically linked to the outbreaks reported in the previous months in the localities of Djagblé and Klobatème (some 30 km [18.6 mi] away from the new outbreak), which have not yet been closed.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: stamping out; disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; official destruction of animal products; quarantine; movement control inside the country; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceabilityDomestic control measures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / Result[Lome Central Veterinary Laboratory] (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / rapid test / 29 Jul 2021 / positive[Lome Central Veterinary Laboratory] (national laboratory) / birds / 1 / multiplex reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR multiplex) / 30 Jul 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[In June 2021, Togo reported 2 outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 located in the Maritime region. The last follow-up report no 4, on 27 Jul 2021, mentioned that the epidemiological situation remains unchanged. The event still is continuing, see report at https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=36832.The current immediate notification mentions that "this new outbreak does not appear to be epidemiologically linked to the outbreaks reported in the previous months in the localities of Djagble and Klobateme (some 30 km [18.6 mi] away from the new outbreak), which have not yet been closed."Officially reported HPAI outbreaks (H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8 subtypes) in Sub-Saharan Africa, by date of onset (1 Oct 2020-14 Jul 2021), can be seen at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/situation_update.html. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Togo: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8565924,68488.] See Also
