View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-07-24 16:17:46 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (14): China (SC) H5N6 Archive Number: 20210724.8542205AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (14): CHINA (SICHUAN) H5N6*************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Fri 23 Jul 2021 20:08 HKTSource: Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region [in Chinese, machine trans., edited]https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202107/23/P2021072300857.htmThe Center for Health Protection of the Department of Health today [23 Jul 2021] is closely monitoring 3 new cases of human infection with avian influenza (H5N6) in the Mainland, and once again urged the public to keep [good personal, food,] and environmental hygiene.The 1st case involved a 51-year-old woman living in Xuanhan, Sichuan Province, who had been in contact with live poultry before becoming ill. She developed symptoms on 25 Jun 2021 and was admitted to the hospital for treatment on 2 Jul 2021. The patient died on 4 Jul 2021.The 2nd case involved a 57-year-old man living in Kaijiang, Sichuan Province, who had been in contact with live poultry before he became ill. He developed symptoms on 22 Jun 2021 and was admitted to the hospital on 5 Jul 2021 in critical condition.The 3rd case involved a 66-year-old man living in Tongnan, Chongqing, who had been in contact with live poultry before he became ill. He developed symptoms on 23 Jun 2021 and was admitted to hospital on 30 Jun 2021 in critical condition.Since 2014, the Mainland health authorities have notified a total of 35 human cases of avian influenza A (H5N6). A spokesperson for the Center for Health Protection said: "All new influenza A, including H5N6, are statutory notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong."If you go to the Mainland or other affected areas, please remember to avoid going to wet markets, live poultry markets or farms. When visiting relatives and friends, pay attention to whether there are free-range poultry. Do not buy live poultry or freshly slaughtered poultry, and avoid contact with poultry or birds or their droppings. When going to any place with live poultry, keep personal and hand hygiene at all times.After returning to Hong Kong from the affected area, if you develop symptoms, you should seek medical advice immediately and take the initiative to inform your doctor of the places you have been to so that [they] can diagnose and treat potential diseases as soon as possible. If you have ever seen any live poultry while traveling, you should inform your doctor because you may have been in contact with a contaminated environment. This will help diagnose a possible avian flu case and arrange the necessary investigation and appropriate treatment in a timely manner.Locally, the Center for Health Protection has formulated a series of monitoring and prevention and control measures, and will always remain vigilant, and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health departments to monitor the latest developments.The public should maintain personal, hand, food and environmental hygiene at all times, and pay attention to the following suggestions when handling poultry:- Avoid contact with poultry, birds, animals or their droppings;- When buying live chickens, do not touch the live chickens and chicken manure, and do not blow their tails. Wash the eggs stained with feces, use detergent to assist in washing, and immediately cook and eat. After touching chickens and eggs, wash hands thoroughly with soap and water;- Eggs should be cooked thoroughly until the yolk and egg whites are solidified. Do not eat raw eggs or sauces with raw eggs. Cook poultry thoroughly. If there is still pink gravy flowing out or the bone marrow is still bright red, re-cook the poultry until it is fully cooked;- Wash your hands frequently, especially before touching your mouth, nose or eyes, before handling food or eating, after going to the toilet, after touching public objects such as elevator handrails, elevator buttons or door handles, or when your hands are contaminated by respiratory secretions, such as coughing or after sneezing; and- Wear a mask if you have fever or respiratory symptoms, go to a hospital or clinic, or take care of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms.The public can refer to the thematic webpages of the Centre for Health Protection for more information: bird flu page, bird flu weekly report bird flu statistics around the world and affected areas, Facebook page and YouTube channel.--Communicated by:Mahmoud Orabi<ahstandards@gmail.com>******[2]Date: Fri 23 Jul 2021 08:59 HKTSource: HK News [in Chinese, machine trans., edited]https://bit.ly/3y3LHPTThe Health Protection Center announced that it is closely monitoring 3 new cases of human infection with avian influenza A (H5N6) in the Mainland, and all 3 patients live in Sichuan Province. The 1st case involved a 51-year-old woman living in Xuanhan, Sichuan Province who had been in contact with live poultry before the onset of illness. She developed symptoms on 25 Jun 2021 and was admitted to hospital on 2 Jul 2021 for treatment. She subsequently died on 4 Jul 2021.The 2nd case involved a 57-year-old man living in Kaijiang, Sichuan Province. He had been in contact with live poultry before he became ill. He developed symptoms on 22 Jun 2021 and was admitted to the hospital on 5 Jul 2021 in a critical condition. The 3rd case involved a 66-year-old man living in Tongnan, Chongqing. He had been in contact with live poultry before he became ill. He developed symptoms on 23 Jun 2021 and was admitted to the hospital for treatment on 30 Jun 2021. He is in critical condition.Since 2014, the Mainland health authorities have notified a total of 35 cases of human infection with avian influenza A (H5N6). The Centre for Health Protection urges citizens to avoid going to wet markets, live poultry markets or farms if they go to the Mainland or other affected areas, and pay attention to whether there are free-range poultry when visiting relatives and friends. After returning to Hong Kong from the affected area, if you develop symptoms, you should seek medical advice immediately and take the initiative to inform your doctor of the places you have been to so that [they] can diagnose and treat potential diseases as soon as possible.--Communicated by:Dan Silver<dgsilver@gmail.com>[ProMED thanks Mahmoud Orabi and Dan Silver for sharing the important reports on human cases of avian influenza A/H5N6 in China.Since 2014, Mainland health authorities have notified a total of 35 human cases of avian influenza A (H5N6). The 3 cases in the above report had histories of contact with live poultry and all are above 50 years of age. There have been recent reports of additional cases from Sichuan Province, China in March, June, and July 2021, as well as in Laos in April 2021.Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Intensive surveillance should be continued to detect human cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of these viruses, as frequency of cases is increasing. - Mod.UBAThe 1st human infection with (A)H5N6 avian influenza virus was reported from central China in 2014; the patient died. Avian influenza virus subtype H5N6 was identified in samples from contact poultry. Though the clinical signs in the affected poultry were mild, the virus was laboratory confirmed as highly pathogenic (HPAI). This strain has since been identified in additional countries in SE Asia. The most recent OIE report on the global situation of HPAI, from 15 Jan to 4 Feb 2021, is available at https://www.oie.int/app/uploads/2021/03/hpai---asof04022021.pdf. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Sichuan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8542205,350] See Also

be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the press release published on 16 Jul 2021 by the Ministry of Food and Agriculture of the Republic of Ghana (https://cdn.modernghana.com/files/717202141800-j5eq27t2gb-press-release.pdf), HPAI has been confirmed in the Greater Accra, Central, and Volta Regions. However, in this current immediate notification, the case in Volta has not yet been officially reported to the OIE.This press release also mentioned that: "Through effective surveillance and disease control management the Veterinary Services Directorate has prevented the extension of the disease into Ghana until now. "Cases of the Bird Flu disease were previously recorded in 2007, 2015, 2016, and 2018, with significant economic impact on affected poultry farmers. The zoonotic nature of the disease calls for public alert and vigilance to mitigate the possible impact on the poultry industry and public-health in general. "Accordingly, the Ministry announces the following measures for immediate compliance: 1. A total ban on the importation of Poultry and Poultry products from neighboring countries where the prevalence of the disease has been confirmed. 2. A ban on the movement of Poultry and Poultry Products within and from the affected regions and districts to other parts of the country, and strict inspection and issuance of permits to cover the movement of all poultry and poultry products from unaffected parts of the country. 3. Intensification of public awareness and sensitization by Regional Coordinating Councils and District Assemblies, especially in the affected areas".Highly pathogenic avian influenza virus subtypes H5, H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8 are circulating in the Sub-Saharan Africa. More detailed information and maps are available at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/situation_update.html (last update 14 Jul 201).For this HPAI event, the neuraminidase has not yet been typed. Determining the subtype and strain of this virus is very important. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Ghana: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8540822,53] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-07-22 21:36:40 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (13): India (HR), H5N8, susp., fatal,  RFI Archive Number: 20210722.8538183AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (13): INDIA (HARYANA), H5N8 SUSPECTED, FATAL, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION********************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: 20 Jul 2021Source: Social News, Indo-Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]https://www.socialnews.xyz/2021/07/20/india-sees-first-bird-flu-death-as-boy-succumbs-in-aiims/India on Tue 20 Jul 2021 reported its first bird flu death as an 11-year-old boy, who was undergoing treatment at AIIMS for it and succumbed to the disease.A senior All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) official said that the boy, who was infected with avian influenza, has died, and the entire staff concerned has been placed in isolation as a preventive measure.As per reports, bird flu outbreaks were reported across the country earlier this year [2021], including in Haryana where the H5N8 subtype -- which is not known to infect humans -- was detected.After the bird flu outbreaks, the Central government sounded an alert as cases were confirmed in Delhi also.A sample collected from the Red Fort had tested positive for bird flu in January [2021]. The Delhi government had then ordered the closure of the Ghazipur poultry market.More samples collected from the Delhi zoo had returned positive in February [2021]. According to the World Health Organisation, human cases of bird flu occur "occasionally" but when they do happen, the mortality rate is about 60%.[Byline: Gopi Adusumilli]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the above report, the 1st fatal case due to an avian influenza virus has been reported from India. The virus subtype involved in this incidence cannot be ascertained from the information provided in the article, though subtype H5N8 has been reported in bird outbreaks in 2021 in Delhi.Human infections with the A(H5N8) virus cannot be excluded, although the likelihood is low, based on the limited information obtained to date (https://www.who.int/publications/m/item/assessment-of-risk-associated-with-influenza-a(h5n8)-virus). In February 2021, Russian authorities reported 7 poultry farm workers aged 29 to 60 years infected with the A(H5N8) strain of avian influenza virus, although they showed no symptoms. "Based on available information, the risk of human-to-human transmission remains low, and WHO recommendations have not changed as a result of the incident." (https://www.euro.who.int/en/countries/poland/news/news/2021/3/avian-influenza-ah5n8-infects-humans-in-russian-federation). Further information on the confirmation of the avian influenza subtype in this case would be highly appreciated. More details on the above report can be accessed at the following links:https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/delhi/indias-first-bird-flu-death-reported-at-aiims-delhi/articleshow/84603287.cmsHere are other, briefer sources as complementary citations:https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/first-possible-human-infection-of-bird-flu-in-india-what-we-know-so-far-101626843053628.htmlhttps://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-07-21/boy-dies-of-bird-flu-in-first-such-case-of-human-death-in-indiahttps://www.reuters.com/world/india/india-reports-first-human-death-bird-flu-2021-07-21/. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED maps:India: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8538183,142Haryana State, India: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8538183,303] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-07-16 23:37:14 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (12): China (SC) H5N6 Archive Number: 20210716.8519755AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (12): CHINA (SICHUAN) H5N6*************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Wed 14 Jul 2021Source: AFD Blog [edited]https://afludiary.blogspot.com/2021/07/hong-kong-chp-notified-of-human-h5n6.html?m=1Just over 7 years ago (May 2014) we saw a report from Sichuan, China of the first known infection by HPAI [highly pathogenic avian influenza] H5N6 avian influenza in humans. At the time, H5N1 and (LPAI) [low pathogenic avian influenza] H7N9 were the biggest avian flu threats, with H10N8 and H9N2 (which is still very much with us) pulling up the rear. While H5N1 has declined markedly since 2015, and China's massive poultry vaccination program, which began in 2017 has -- at least temporarily -- subdued H7N9, we continue to see sporadic human infections with H5N6. Unlike the novel swine variants, and recent H10N3 and H5N8 human infections -- which have been mostly mild -- avian H5N6 tends to make humans severely ill, and death has been reported in nearly half of the 32 cases to date. Last month, Sichuan Province reported their 2nd human case -- and the 3rd reported by China since the first of the year [2021] -- which followed 4 cases reported in late 2020. Today's case (#33), announced today [14 Jul 2021] by Hong Kong's CHP, makes the 8th case reported in as many months. First the CHP's statement, then I'll return with a brief postscript.CHP closely monitors human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in SichuanThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today (14 July) closely monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in Sichuan Province, and again urges the public to maintain strict personal, food, and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.The case involves a 55-year-old man living in Bazhong City in Sichuan Province. He developed symptoms on [Wed 30 Jun 2021] and was admitted to hospital for treatment on [Sun 4 Jul 2021]. The patient is in critical condition. The patient had contact with live domestic poultry before the onset of symptoms.From 2014 to date, 32 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by the Mainland [China] health authorities. "All novel influenza A infections, including H5N6, are notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong," a spokesman for the CHP said.Travellers to the Mainland or other affected areas must avoid visiting wet markets, live poultry markets or farms. They should be alert to the presence of backyard poultry when visiting relatives and friends. They should also avoid purchasing live or freshly slaughtered poultry, and avoid touching poultry/birds or their droppings. They should strictly observe personal and hand hygiene when visiting any places with live poultry.Travellers returning from affected areas should consult a doctor promptly if symptoms develop, and inform the doctor of their travel history for prompt diagnosis and treatment of potential diseases. It is essential to tell the doctor if they have seen any live poultry during travel, which may imply possible exposure to contaminated environments. This will enable the doctor to assess the possibility of avian influenza and arrange necessary investigations and appropriate treatment in a timely manner.While local surveillance, prevention and control measures are in place, the CHP will remain vigilant and work closely with the WHO and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments.The public should maintain strict personal, hand, food and environmental hygiene and take heed of the advice below when handling poultry:- Avoid touching poultry, birds, animals or their droppings;- When buying live chickens, do not touch them and their droppings. Do not blow at their bottoms. Wash eggs with detergent if soiled with faecal matter and cook and consume the eggs immediately. Always wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling chickens and eggs;- Eggs should be cooked well until the white and yolk become firm. Do not eat raw eggs or dip cooked food into any sauce with raw eggs. Poultry should be cooked thoroughly. If there is pinkish juice running from the cooked poultry or the middle part of its bone is still red, the poultry should be cooked again until fully done;- Wash hands frequently, especially before touching the mouth, nose or eyes, before handling food or eating, and after going to the toilet, touching public installations or equipment such as escalator handrails, elevator control panels or door knobs, or when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing; and- Wear a mask if fever or respiratory symptoms develop, when going to a hospital or clinic, or while taking care of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms.The public may visit the CHP's pages for more information: the avian influenza page, the weekly Avian Influenza Report, global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza, the Facebook Page and the YouTube Channel.It is worth noting that following nearly 3 relatively quiet years from mid-2017 to early 2020, avian influenza activity in China -- and around the globe -- has been rising, with HPAI H5 viruses and LPAI H9N2 leading the way. China has reported 8 H5N6 human infections since November 2020, more than a dozen mild H9N2 infections, and at least 1 H10N3 infection. In addition, Laos has reported both a human H5N1 and a human H5N6 infection since last fall. In February of 2021, Russia reported the first confirmed human infections with avian H5N8 (see https://afludiary.blogspot.com/2021/02/russian-media-reports-7-human.html), and in May [2021] the CDC Added Zoonotic Avian A/H5N8 To Their IRAT List. Given the lack of influenza surveillance and reporting from many parts of the world, it is likely that additional cases go unreported. While we aren't anywhere near the levels of avian flu human infections we were seeing between 2003 and 2016, this recent uptick is worth our attention. Michael Coston@Fla_Medic--Communicated by:Mary Marshall <mjm2020@googlemail.com>******[2]Date: Wed 14 Jul 2021Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/h5n6-avian-influenza-case-reported-in-sichuan-province-china-82197/Hong Kong health officials report monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in Sichuan Province on the Mainland. The case involves a 55-year-old man living in Bazhong City in Sichuan Province. He developed symptoms on [Wed 30 Jun 2021] and was admitted to hospital for treatment on [Sun 4 Jul 2021]. The patient is in critical condition. The patient had contact with live domestic poultry before the onset of symptoms.This is the 32nd human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) reported by the Mainland health authorities since 2014.Avian influenza is caused by those influenza viruses that mainly affect birds and poultry, such as chickens or ducks. Clinical presentations of avian influenza in humans include eye infection (conjunctivitis), flu-like symptoms (e.g. fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches) or severe respiratory illness (e.g. chest infection). The incubation period ranges from 7 to 10 days.The more virulent forms can result in respiratory failure, multi-organ failure, and even death. People mainly become infected with avian influenza virus through contact with infected birds and poultry (live or dead) or their droppings, or contact with contaminated environments (such as wet markets and live poultry markets). Human-to-human transmission is inefficient.People in close contact with poultry are more susceptible to contracting avian influenza. The elderly, children, and people with chronic illness have a higher risk of developing complications such as bronchitis and chest infection.--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[To date, a total of 32 laboratory-confirmed cases (excluding the case above) of human infection with influenza A(H5N6) virus, including 19 deaths at the time of the IHR (International Health Regulations) report, have been reported to WHO from China since 2014 [https://bit.ly/3wMoHTO]According to reports received by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), various influenza A(H5) subtypes continue to be detected in birds in Africa, Europe, and Asia. With the continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans.Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. Surveillance should be continued to detect human cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of the viruses. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map:Sichuan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8519755,350] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-07-12 16:06:32 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (96): Europe (Sweden) wild bird, HPAI H5N4, OIE Archive Number: 20210712.8512938AVIAN INFLUENZA (96): EUROPE (SWEDEN) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N4, OIE***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 8 Jul 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=35736Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Sweden--------------------------------------------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 2 Mar 2021Confirmed: 28 Jun 2021Reported: 2 Jul 2021Reason for notification: New strain in the countryCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N4Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks (1)Outbreak location 1: Solvesborg, Solvesborg, BlekingeStarted: 2 Mar 2021Ended: 2 Mar 2021Epidemiological unit: otherTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedPeregrine falcon (_Falco peregrinus_): Falconidae-Falconiformes / - / 1 / 1 / - / - / -Affected population: a peregrine falcon was found dead. It was sent to the National Veterinary Institute for laboratory analysis as part of the national surveillance program for avian influenza.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild species.Epidemiological comments: in accordance with the OIE Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Article 10.4.1, point 8 (2019), this event does not change the disease-free status of Sweden as these are wild birds, and therefore do not fall within the OIE definition of poultry.Control measures applied in wild: official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; official destruction of animal products.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultNational Veterinary Institute (SVA) national laboratory / Peregrine falcon / 1 / Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / [28 Jun 2021] / PositiveNational Veterinary Institute (SVA) national laboratory / Peregrine falcon / 1 / Gene sequencing / [12 Mar to 28 Jun 2021] / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) has frequently caused infection and death of birds of prey (Falconiformes). Raptors may contract HPAI viruses by hunting or scavenging infected prey. Peregrine falcons (_Falco peregrinus_) regularly pray on Anseriformes [waterfowl], the main reservoir of avian influenza viruses, which make them prone to become infected. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Sweden: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8512938,68459] See Also

screening; disinfection; quarantine; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and wasteDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultAll-Russian Research Institute for Animal Health (FGBI-ARRIAH) OIE Reference Laboratory/ Dalmatian pelican / 1 / Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / [25 to 29 Jun 2021] / PositiveTyumenskaya veterinary Laboratory Local Laboratory / Dalmatian pelican / 1 / Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / [25 to 28 Jun 2021] / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The Dalmatian pelican (_Pelecanus crispus_) is the largest member of the pelican family with a range spanning across much of Central Eurasia. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-07-07 11:40:25 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (94): Europe (Denmark) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20210707.8499767AVIAN INFLUENZA (94): EUROPE (DENMARK) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, OIE**************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 6 Jul 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=35656Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Denmark------------------------------------------SummaryReport type: immediate notificationStarted: 4 Jul 2021Confirmed: 5 Jul 2021Reported: 6 Jul 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 21 Apr 2021Causal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: laboratoryThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaksSummary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks (1)Outbreak location 1: Iller, Sonderborg, Syddanmark [Southern Denmark]Started: 4 Jul 2021Ended: ongoingEpidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 38 000 / - / 198 / - / 0 / 0Affected population: on [4 Jul 2021], a clinical suspicion was reported to the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration. [The affected population was a poultry holding with approximately 38 000 laying hens]. On [5 Jul 2021], highly pathogenic avian influenza (subtype H5N8) was confirmed by the national reference laboratory. A 3 km [1.8 mi] protection zone and a 10 km [6.2 mi] surveillance zone were established. The animals are planned to be culled on [7 Jul 2021], and carcasses will be disposed of by rendering.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive.Epidemiological comments: the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has established zones of 3 and 10 km around the holding and is implementing the necessary measures in accordance with Council Directive 2005/94/EC.Control measures at event levelControl measures applied in domestic: traceability, zoning, movement control inside the countryControl measures to be applied in domestic: surveillance within containment and/or the protection zone; stamping out; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste, disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institut (national laboratory)Species / Test / Outbreaks / Test date / ResultBirds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 1 / 5 Jul 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The latest information about avian influenza in Denmark can be found at https://www.foedevarestyrelsen.dk/english/Animal/AnimalHealth/Animal%20diseases/Avian_influenza/Pages/default.aspxA map of HPAI detections in Europe during the period 1 Oct 2020 to 7 Jul 2021 can be seen at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2021/Map_AI_EU_2021-07-01.jpg. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Denmark: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8499767,68453] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-07-04 10:06:33 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (92): Viet Nam (QN) poultry, HPAI H5N8, 1st rep, RFI Archive Number: 20210704.8494698AVIAN INFLUENZA (92): VIETNAM (QUANG NINH) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, FIRST REPORT, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION****************************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 2 Jul 2021Source: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/vietnam-reports-first-h5n8-avian-flu-outbreak-poultry-2021-07-02/Viet Nam on Friday [2 Jul 2021] confirmed its 1st outbreak of H5N8 avian influenza at a chicken farm in the northern province of Quang Ninh.Samples from the farm in the province's Ha Long City tested positive to the virus a day earlier, the agriculture ministry said in a news release.It said the tests were conducted after around 200 chickens had been found dead at the farm last month [June 2021]."H5N8 not only kills poultry but also infects humans without leaving symptoms," the head of the province's animal health department, Tran Xuan Dong, said.The authorities had taken measures to prevent the disease from spreading further, it said, without elaborating.The World Health Organization (WHO) said last week [week of 21 Jun 2021] the risk of human-to-human spread of the H5N8 strain of bird flu appears low, after 7 people in Russia contacted the virus but were asymptomatic [see comment below].H5N8 outbreaks were reported last year [2020] in poultry or wild birds in Britain, Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Egypt, Germany, Hungary, Iraq, Japan, Kazakhstan, the Netherlands, Poland, Romania, and Russia, according to the WHO.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The mentioned A(H5N8) human infection in Russia was published in Eurosurveillance on 17 Jun 2021 (ref 1). The abstract follows."This study presents the isolation of influenza A(H5N8) virus clade 2.3.4.4b from a poultry worker during an outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N8) among chickens at a poultry farm in Astrakhan, Russia in December 2020. Nasopharyngeal swabs collected from 7 poultry workers were positive for influenza A(H5N8), as confirmed by RT-PCR and sequencing. The influenza A(H5N8) virus was isolated from one of the human specimens and characterised. Sporadic human influenza A(H5)2.3.4.4. infections represent a possible concern for public health." Subscribers are referred to Mod UBA's comments in 20210606.8426576.The 1st recorded HPAI H5N8 outbreak in poultry in Viet Nam, likely introduced by wild birds, is yet to be reported to the OIE.It will be interesting to note if surveillance in wild birds is operational in Viet Nam.Reference---------Pyankova OG, Susloparov IM, Moiseeva AA, et al. Isolation of clade 2.3.4.4b A(H5N8), a highly pathogenic avian influenza virus, from a worker during an outbreak on a poultry farm, Russia, December 2020. Euro Surveill. 2021; 26(24): 2100439. doi: 10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2021.26.24.2100439. PMID: 34142650; PMCID: PMC8212591; https://www.eurosurveillance.org/content/10.2807/1560-7917.ES.2021.26.24.2100439- Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Viet Nam: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8494698,17014] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-07-01 20:48:43 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (91): Togo (MA) poultry, HPAI H5N1, OIE Archive Number: 20210701.8489408AVIAN INFLUENZA (91): TOGO (MARITIME) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, OIE*************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 1 Jul 2021Source: OIE-WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System) 2021 [edited]https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=35394Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Togo---------------------------------------General informationReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 1 Jun 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 22 Jun 2021Reason for notification: recurrenceLast occurrence: 24 Mar 2019Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory, necropsyThis event pertains to the whole country.New outbreaks (2)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 2Outbreak location 1: Klobateme, Zio, MaritimeDate of start of the outbreak: 19 Jun 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 1000 / 189 / 189 / 811 / 0 / 0Affected population: First cases began on 19 Jun 2021; it is a flock of 1000 6-month-old layers in two buildings.Outbreak location 2: Djagble-Kleme, Zio, MaritimeDate of start of the outbreak: 1 Jun 2021Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedBirds / 1000 / 563 / 563 / 437 / 0 / 0Affected population: First cases started on [1 Jun 2021]; there are 2 flocks of laying hens with 500 animals each; one is being culled, but the owner has kept it until the 2nd flock reaches its peak of production; the other one is starting to lay. Both flocks are in a building separated on the whole width by a barrier made of bamboo wood.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: Two infected farms, which are approximately 5 km apart as the crow flies, each with a population of 1000 layers. Both infected farms are more or less located in urban areas. The 1st one is in a house with no physical separation between the rearing building (nor foot baths) and the house yard. There are almost no biosecurity measures applied. The 2nd farm is much more isolated, with some biosecurity measures. In both cases, eggs are sold on the premises without any biosecurity measures for the management of the trays. Given the numerous failures in the application of biosecurity measures, the precise source of the infection could not be determined through the traceability survey, although these 2 farms have in common the fact that the customers are served on the premises and inside the farm's fence.Control measures at event levelDomestic control measures applied: stamping out; disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; official destruction of animal products; quarantine; movement control inside the country; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceabilityDomestic control measures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS), Venezie (OIE reference laboratory) / birds / 1 / gene sequencing / 22 Jun 2021 / positiveLaboratoire central veterinaire de Lome (national laboratory) / birds / 2 / rapid test / 25 Jun 2021 / positiveLaboratoire central veterinaire de Lome (national laboratory) / birds / 2 / multiplex reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR multiplex) / 25 Jun 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[This immediate notification report complements the information already published on ProMED-mail posting 20210701.8488651.Officially reported HPAI outbreaks (H5N1, H5N6, and H5N8 subtypes) in Sub-Saharan Africa, by onset date (1 Oct 2020-9 Jun 2021), can be seen at http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/programmes/en/empres/HPAI_Africa/situation_update.html. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Maritime, Togo: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8489408,55242] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-07-01 11:29:45 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (90): Togo (MA) poultry, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20210701.8488651AVIAN INFLUENZA (90): TOGO (MARITIME) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 29 Jun 2021 3:29 PM CESTSource: Reuters [edited]https://www.reuters.com/business/healthcare-pharmaceuticals/togo-culls-birds-quarantines-area-following-avian-flu-outbreak-2021-06-29/Togo has culled hundreds of birds, quarantined a poultry farm, closed a local bird market, and banned the movement of poultry following an outbreak of the highly pathogenic H5N1 avian flu, the government said on Tuesday [29 Jun 2021].Over 800 birds have been culled, Batasse Batawui, director of livestock at Togo's Ministry of Agriculture, told Reuters.The government said in a statement that the birds were incinerated and eggs destroyed to stop the spread.It added that the poultry farm, around 15 km (9.3 mi) north of the capital, Lome, has been quarantined, and the local poultry and feed stock market closed for 30 days.[Byline: John Zodzi, Bate Felix, editing: Aaron Ross]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[According to information available from OIE-WAHIS (OIE World Animal Health Information System), the previous HPAI H5N1 event in Togo took place in 2018, affecting backyard poultry in Kpessi (Agbedrafo), starting 27 Mar 2018, continuing until 25 Oct 2018, reported as "resolved" on 25 Mar 2019 (see, with map, at https://wahis.oie.int/#/report-info?reportId=24922).The current outbreak has not yet been officially notified to the OIE. - Mods.CRD/ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Togo: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8488651,55242] See Also

/ 3 / 0 / 3 / 0 / 0Great Crested Grebe (_Podiceps cristatus_): Podicipedidae-Procellariiformes/ - / 2 / 0 / 2 / 0 / 0Great Cormorant (_Phalacrocorax carbo_): Phalacrocoracidae-Trogoniformes/ - / 2 / 0 / 2 / 0 / 0Outbreak location 2: Beloe, Piy-Khemskiy rayon, TuvaStarted: 29 May 2021Epidemiological unit: Not applicableTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered or killed for commercial use / VaccinatedLittle Grebe (_Tachybaptus ruficollis_): Podicipedidae-Procellariiformes / - / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0 / 0Tufted Duck (_Aythya fuligula_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0 / 0Black-headed Gull (_Larus ridibundus_): Laridae-Charadriiformes / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0 / 0Common Pochard (_Aythya ferina_): Anatidae-Anseriformes / - / 2 / 0 / 2 / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: As part of the active monitoring of avian influenza conducted in the Russian federation from [23 May to 29 May 2021] in the republic of Tuva (scientific expedition), samples were collected from wild birds for laboratory testing at the Federal State-Financed Budgetary Institution "ARRIAH". Wild birds were clinically healthy and die-off was not reported in birds. Samples were taken in the republic of Tuva: Ovyursky Raion, Uvs Lake, Piy-Khemsky Raion, Beloye Lake and Kyzylsky Raion. The total number of samples taken was 125. Samples taken from wild birds in Kyzylsky Raion tested negative for AI virus. A total of 7 samples taken in Piy-Khemsky Raion, Beloye Lake tested positive for H5 and among them 3 samples tested positive for Н5N8, the material was taken from birds of such species as: (_Aythya ferina_) - 2, pos. A/H5; (_Larus ridibundus_) - 1, pos. A/H5; (_Aythya fuligula_) - 1 pos. A/H5, (_Podiceps ruficollis_) - 3, pos. A/H5N8. A total of 7  samples taken in Ovyursky Raion, Uvs Lake tested positive for Н5, the material was taken from birds of such species as: (_Phalacrocorax carbo_) - 2, pos. A/H5; (_Podiceps cristatus_) - 2- pos. A/H5; (_Larus ridibundus_) - 3- pos. A/H5.Control measures applied in wild: surveillance within containment and or the protection zone; screening; disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultAll-Russian Research Institute for Animal Health (FGBI-ARRIAH) OIE Reference Laboratory/ Little Grebe, Great Crested Grebe, Great Cormorant, Common Pochard, Black-headed Gull, Tufted Duck/ 2 / Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / [29 May to 11 Jun 2021] / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[From 2014 onwards HPAI H5 clade 2.3.4.4 viruses caused outbreaks across the Eurasian region, affecting both poultry and wild birds, with abundant genetic reassortments yielding subtypes H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N4, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8. - Mod.PBMHealthMap/ProMED map:Tuva Republic: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8481136,409] See Also

official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; surveillance outside containment and/or the protection zone; zoningDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultHarbin National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory (OIE reference laboratory) / black-necked grebe / virus isolation / 11-20 Jun 2021 / positiveHarbin National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory (OIE reference laboratory) / black-necked grebe / real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 11-17 Jun 2021 / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[A few days ago, there was a report of thousands of black-necked grebes dead due to HPAI H5N8 in Shaanxi, another Chinese province bordering with Ningxia Hui on the east (see Avian influenza (86): China (SX) wild bird, HPAI H5N8, OIE, archive no. 20210621.8464004). Black-necked grebes (_Podiceps nigricolis_) are aquatic birds that breed in vegetated areas of freshwater lakes across Europe, Asia, Africa, northern South America, and the southwest and western United States. After breeding, this bird migrates to saline lakes to moult. For a picture go to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black-necked_grebe#/media/File:Black-necked_Grebe_Schwarzhalstaucher.jpg. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map:Yinchuan, Ningxia Autonomous Region, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8480747,11486] See Also

control of wildlife reservoirs.Diagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Outbreaks / Test / Test date / ResultWageningen Bioveterinary Research National Reference Laboratory, Lelystad National Laboratory / Eurasian buzzard / 1 / Real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR) / [4 Jan to 4 Feb 2021] / positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The HPAI epidemic of 2020-2021 is the largest that has occurred in Europe, with more than 3500 HPAI episodes reported in almost 30 European countries. Wild birds appear to be playing an important role in the HPAI epidemic. Most wild birds reported infected have been Anseriformes (swan, ducks, geese), followed by birds of prey. Wild migratory waterbirds contribute to the propagation of HPAI viruses. Farmers must apply stringent biosecurity measures.Recent information on the situation in Europe may be accessed at https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/Avian-influenza-overview-February-May-2021_1.pdf. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of the Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8466648,68431] See Also

surveillance outside containment and/or the protection zone; disinfection; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and wasteDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultHarbin National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory (OIE reference laboratory) / Black necked Grebe / Virus isolation / 5 Jun 2021 / PositiveHarbin National Avian Influenza Reference Laboratory (OIE reference laboratory) / Black necked Grebe / Real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) / 29 May 2021 / Positive[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Black-necked grebes (_Podiceps nigricollis_) are aquatic birds that breed in vegetated areas of freshwater lakes across Europe, Asia, Africa, northern South America, and the southwest and western United States. For a picture go to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black-necked_grebe#/media/File:Black-necked_Grebe_Schwarzhalstaucher.jpg.This report is describing a large die-off of this bird. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-06-21 13:36:52 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (84): China (GX) H9N2, dog, zoonotic potential susp, RFI Archive Number: 20210621.8463888AVIAN INFLUENZA (84): CHINA (GUANGXI ZHUANG) H9N2, DOG, ZOONOTIC POTENTIAL SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION*************************************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 19 Jun 2021 [accessed]Source: Chinese Journal of Zoonoses [in Chinese, abstract in English, edited]http://www.rsghb.cn/CN/abstract/abstract24760.shtmlref: Li S, Sun X, Kong Z, et al. Whole genome sequencing analysis of canine H9N2 subtype influenza virus isolates from Guangxi and its pathogenicity experiments in mice. Chinese Journal of Zoonoses, 2021; 37(5): 398-403. doi: 10.3969/j.issn.1002-2694.2021.00.061--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Abstract--------To analyze the whole genome sequence and pathogenicity of H9N2 subtype influenza virus carried by pet dogs in Guangxi, we amplified and sequenced the whole genome by RT-PCR. The amino acid homology and evolutionary tree were analyzed in DNA-Star and MEGA 6.0 software, and pathogenicity was studied through mouse infection experiments. 8 gene segments of 13 H9N2 strains were derived from 5 different lineages, which belonged to the new genotype. The amino acid sequence identity was 99.0% with respect to A/equine/Guangxi/3/2011 isolated from Guangxi. 6 internal genes were closely related to the H7N9 strain from human influenza virus in 2013. The HA cleavage site of all strains was RSSR-(cleavage site)-GLF, thus indicating low virulence. The amino acid sites HA226, NA119, NP375, and PB2 showed some changes, among which HA226 was changed to leucine L, which binds human SAalpha2, 6-Gal. In BALB/c mice infected with H9N2 virus isolated from healthy dogs, the virus did not replicate in vivo, but the strains Ca/GX/8 and Ca/GX/10 from symptomatic dogs replicated in vivo and caused clear clinical symptoms but not death. The virulence of the virus was enhanced after passage in mice, a finding speculated to be caused by the changes in amino acids at positions PA623 and 611 of PB2. A total of 13 H9N2 subtype influenza virus strains obtained from dogs in Guangxi have avian origin, specifically bind human receptors, and have a complex genetic evolution relationship, thus posing a great threat to mammals and humans. Therefore, prevention and control measures must urgently be strengthened.--Communicated by:ProMED Rapporteur Dan Silver[Subscribers are referred to the (copied, edited) recent commentary by Mod.USB, in 20210508.8345139:"It's worth mentioning that influenza A(H9N2) viruses are enzootic in poultry populations in parts of Africa, Asia, and the Middle East. Most human cases are exposed to the A(H9N2) virus through contact with infected poultry or contaminated environments. Human infection tends to result in mild clinical illness.Avian H9N2 influenza A virus has caused repeated human infections in Asia since 1998. An H9N2 influenza virus infected a 5-year-old child in Hong Kong in 2003. The human H9N2 influenza virus, A/Hong Kong/2108/03, is of purely avian origin and is closely related to some viruses circulating in poultry in the markets of Hong Kong. The continued presence of H9N2 influenza viruses in poultry markets in southern China increases the likelihood of avian-to-human interspecies transmission. Since the mid-1990s, 2 lineages of H9N2 influenza A viruses have become established in domestic poultry in southern China, Duck/HK/Y280/97 (Y280-like) and Quail/HK/G1/97 (G1-like) viruses, which are predominantly found in chickens and quail, respectively. These viruses have been sporadically introduced into humans and cause a flu-like illness. In the meantime, H9N2 influenza Y280-like viruses were also isolated from domestic pigs in Hong Kong in 1998. These findings indicate that the interspecies transmission of H9N2 influenza virus from avian to mammalian hosts continues to occur and poses a persistent threat for humans.Furthermore, the number of human infections with A/H9N2 avian influenza viruses has been higher in 2021 (13 cases including the new case from China [covered in https://afludiary.blogspot.com/2021/05/hk-chpwho-wpro-report-another-h9n2-case.html] as of 8 May 2021 -- compared with earlier years, which is a cause for concern and highlights the need for continuous monitoring and risk assessments of these viruses with pandemic potential."Further studies of the dog-derived A(H9N2) virus strain, while checking its pathogenicity rate in birds, are warranted. It will be interesting to note if and what contact the investigated pet dogs had with poultry, or if they were fed with uncooked poultry meat. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Guangxi Autonomous Region, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8463888,355] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-06-14 18:43:59 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (83): Iraq (WA) poultry, HPAI H5N8 susp, spread, RFI Archive Number: 20210614.8447815AVIAN INFLUENZA (83): IRAQ (WASIT) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8 SUSPECTED, SPREAD, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION************************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sun 13 Jun 2021Source: Al-Mada (Baghdad) [in Arabic, trans., edited]https://almadapaper.net/view.php?cat=239317[The following report, based upon the above and 4 additional Iraqi media sources in Arabic, has been translated and submitted by a reliable source who preferred to remain unnamed. ProMED-mail is very grateful to the submitter]. Media news articles [in Arabic, translated, edited] reported in [13-14 Jun 2021] that Wasit (Governorate's) Agriculture Directorate clarified that the avian influenza infection (most likely HPAI H5N8) that has been reported, was in one of the unauthorized poultry farms in the Numaniyah district, north of the governorate.The Director of (Wasit) Agriculture, Arkan Al-Shammari, said in a press statement that was followed by Al-Mada newspaper, that "the Directorate has taken precautionary measures in this regard, [involving] the poultry breeders in the surrounding areas at a distance of 3 km [approx. 1.8 mi], which represents the focus of the infection."Al-Shammari pointed out that "veterinary teams carried out diagnostic field visits in the areas surrounding the index farm and took samples to avoid the spread of the infection to neighboring farms."It is noteworthy that the Minister of Agriculture, Muhammad Karim al-Khafaji, revealed today [Sun 13 Jun 2021] the recording of cases of avian influenza in Wasit, noting that "the ministry is working seriously to end this disease in that province or Basra or other provinces that recorded some outbreaks, while referring to the ministry's efforts to compensate the owners of the farms affected by the disease.Wasit Governorate is a governorate in eastern Iraq, south-east of Baghdad and bordering Iran (map https://reliefweb.int/map/iraq/iraq-wassit-governorate-reference-map-2020-5-may-2020). --Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Earlier media reports from Iraq, kindly submitted by the same source, dated 4 Jun 2021 and published in 20210605.8425720, informed about suspected HPAI outbreak on a poultry farm in the Khor Al-Zubair area in Basrah governorate. Reportedly, the suspicion of HPAI was lab-confirmed but no final typing has been published ("most likely HPAI H5N8"). Wasit governorate is situated south-east of Baghdad, bordering Iran on its east. A map pf Iraq's governorates is available at https://www.google.co.il/search?q=iraq+governorates. Basrah governorates, Iraq's most south-east governorate, borders Iran and Kuwait. It is separated from Wasit by the governorate Missan. Final typing results of the causative HPAI agent (most probably, H5N8) are anticipated and Further information from knowledgeable sources on the above incident will be appreciated. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Iraq: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8447815,89] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-06-12 15:47:14 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (81): Europe (Albania) poultry, HPAI H5N8, 1st outbreak Archive Number: 20210612.8443314AVIAN INFLUENZA (81): EUROPE (ALBANIA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, FIRST OUTBREAK*************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 10 Jun 2021From: Kujtim Mersini <mersini2003@yahoo.com> [edited]Three outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 have been confirmed in backyard poultry flocks in Albania (2 in the central part and one in the north of the country). Up to now, about 320 birds have died and the disease mortality in affected farms has ranged from 48% up to 100%, with 100% in chicken and turkeys with lower rates in ducks and geese. The Veterinary Services have set up protection and surveillance zones around outbreak locations and have commenced culling operations.Notification of the Ministry of Agriculture:"The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development [MARD] is closely following the monitoring of the epidemiological situation in the bird population in our country. Following the announcement given by the World Organization for Animal Health, about the presence of the Avian Influenza virus in some countries of the region and beyond, by order of Minister Milva Ekonomi, a plan of protection measures was drafted."First, the entry of birds into the territory of our country from countries that have confirmed the presence of the disease was banned. A National Crisis Center has been set up at the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development to direct and coordinate the action plan. After analyzing samples from suspicious cases in backyard birds, at the Institute of Food Safety and Veterinary (ISUV), the presence of Avian Influenza (Avian Influenza) type H5N8 was confirmed. The disease is present only in 3 outbreaks, located respectively in the Administrative Unit Fushe-Kruje, in the Administrative Unit Dajt and in the Administrative Unit Bujan."The Veterinary Service carried out the elimination of affected and suspicious birds and took measures to prevent further spread of the disease. Subsequently, the Ministerial Order prohibits at the national level the trade of live birds in open spaces and in live animal markets. The movement of birds to slaughterhouses is allowed, provided accompanied by a veterinary health certificate."Regarding intensive, commercial holdings (complexes), so far there are no suspected cases. The level of Biosafety in these complexes is according to European standards and is being rigorously monitored by the Veterinary Service. It is important to note that products and by-products originating from these birds do not pose a risk to consumer health. MARD brings to the attention of the public the observance of hygiene and high temperature cooking of all products of animal origin."The National Authority of Veterinary and Plant Protection (AKVMB) continues to monitor the situation for early detection of new cases and their isolation."--Communicated by:Kujtim Mersini, DVM, PhDResearcher<mersini2003@yahoo.com>[ProMED is grateful to Dr. Mersini for the above information.Subscribers are referred to Mod.CRD's commentary in 20210601.8415504, addressing the 2020-2021 HPAI epizootic observed in European countries during the 2020/2021 season, which appears to be one of the largest and most devastating HPAI epizootics recorded in Europe so far. It also includes a link to the FLI (Germany) map presenting all HPAI outbreaks in Europe, affecting poultry, wild birds, and hobby farms/petting zoos between 1 Oct 2020 and 27 May 2021, at https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2021/Map_AI_EU_2021-05-27.jpg.Following its 1st HPAI H5N8 event, Albania becomes the 29th European country affected by the virus during this season. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Albania: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8443314,72] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-06-12 22:49:10 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (11): China (Sichuan) H5N6 Archive Number: 20210612.8437106AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (11): CHINA (SICHUAN) H5N6*************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Tue 8 Jun 2021 19:45 HKTSource: Government of Hong Kong Centre for Health Protection [edited]https://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/202106/08/P2021060900449.htmThe Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health (DH) is today (8 Jun 2021) closely monitoring a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in Chengdu, Sichuan Province, and again urged the public to maintain strict personal, food, and environmental hygiene both locally and during travel.The case involved a 49-year-old woman living in Chengdu. She developed symptoms on 13 May [2021] and was admitted for treatment on 16 May [2021]. The patient is now in serious condition. From 2014 to date, 31 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by the Mainland health authorities."All novel influenza A infections, including H5N6, are notifiable infectious diseases in Hong Kong," a spokesman for the CHP said.Travellers to the Mainland or other affected areas must avoid visiting wet markets, live poultry markets, or farms. They should be alert to the presence of backyard poultry when visiting relatives and friends. They should also avoid purchasing live or freshly slaughtered poultry and avoid touching poultry/birds or their droppings. They should strictly observe personal and hand hygiene when visiting any place with live poultry.Travellers returning from affected areas should consult a doctor promptly if symptoms develop and inform the doctor of their travel history for prompt diagnosis and treatment of potential diseases. It is essential to tell the doctor if they have seen any live poultry during travel, which may imply possible exposure to contaminated environments. This will enable the doctor to assess the possibility of avian influenza and arrange necessary investigations and appropriate treatment in a timely manner.While local surveillance, prevention, and control measures are in place, the CHP will remain vigilant and work closely with the World Health Organization and relevant health authorities to monitor the latest developments.The public should maintain strict personal, hand, food, and environmental hygiene and take heed of the advice below when handling poultry:- Avoid touching poultry, birds, animals, or their droppings;- When buying live chickens, do not touch them and their droppings. Do not blow at their bottoms. Wash eggs with detergent if soiled with faecal matter, and cook and consume the eggs immediately. Always wash hands thoroughly with soap and water after handling chickens and eggs;- Eggs should be cooked well until the white and yolk become firm. Do not eat raw eggs or dip cooked food into any sauce with raw eggs. Poultry should be cooked thoroughly. If there is pinkish juice running from the cooked poultry or the middle part of its bone is still red, the poultry should be cooked again until fully done;- Wash hands frequently, especially before touching the mouth, nose, or eyes, before handling food or eating, and after going to the toilet, touching public installations or equipment such as escalator handrails, elevator control panels, or door knobs, or when hands are dirtied by respiratory secretions after coughing or sneezing; and- Wear a mask if fever or respiratory symptoms develop, when going to a hospital or clinic, or while taking care of patients with fever or respiratory symptoms.The public may visit the CHP's pages for more information: the avian influenza page (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/features/24244.html), the weekly Avian Influenza Report (https://www.chp.gov.hk/en/resources/29/332.html), global statistics and affected areas of avian influenza (https://www.chp.gov.hk/files/pdf/global_statistics_avian_influenza_e.pdf), the Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/CentreforHealthProtection), and the YouTube channel (https://www.youtube.com/c/ChpGovHkChannel).--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>******[2]Date: Wed 9 Jun 2021Source: CIDRAP (Center for Infectious Disease Research and Policy) [edited]https://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2021/06/news-scan-jun-09-2021China has reported another human H5N6 avian flu case, which involves a 49-year-old woman from Sichuan province, according to a statement yesterday [Tue 8 Jun 2021] from Hong Kong's Centre for Health Protection (CHP). Sichuan province is in the country's southwest.The patient's symptoms began on 13 May [2021], and she was hospitalized on 16 May [2021], where she is listed in serious condition. The report did not say how she was exposed to the virus.China and a few other countries have reported H5N6 outbreaks in poultry since 2014, but China and Laos are the only ones that have reported human cases, which can often be serious or fatal. The latest case would raise the global total to 33, all but one in China.--Communicated by:Mary Marshall<mjm2020@googlemail.com>[According to reports received by the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE), various influenza A(H5) subtypes continue to be detected in birds in Africa, Europe, and Asia. With the continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans.The 1st avian influenza virus (AIV) H5N6 strain was isolated in March 2014 from a domestic duck in Guangdong Province, China. Since then, the H5 subtype has gradually become the main cause of the sporadic AIV infections in poultry in southern China. To date, a total of 31 laboratory-confirmed cases (excluding the case above) of human infection with influenza A(H5N6) virus, including 8 deaths at the time of the IHR (International Health Regulations) report, have been reported to WHO from China since 2014 (https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20210528.pdf?sfvrsn=30d65594_137). The above reports do not mention the nature of exposure of the case with poultry or products thereof.Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map:Sichuan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8437106,350] See Also

A total of 5 HPAI H5N1 outbreaks -- 4 in Gauteng and one outbreak in North West. All affected farms have been quarantined, with control measures being implemented."Genetic evaluation has confirmed that the outbreak reported in commercial layers on [13 Apr 2021] in Gauteng [see ProMED 20210414.8307559] and the one on commercial broiler-breeders in the North West seem to have been caused by non-identical AI strains. These 2 outbreaks were, therefore, more likely to have been caused by separate introductions. It is essential for everyone across the country to remain on high alert."It must be mentioned that no human infection, due to these circulating strains, had been reported in Europe and thus the zoonotic risk to people is very low, the consumer has no reason to be concerned."- Mod.CRDIn April and May 2021, several outbreaks of HPAI H5N1 in many poultry farms have been reported in South Africa. HPAI H5 outbreaks have been numerous and occurring in different parts of the country. Some had different strains, which means that they come from separate origins. One of these outbreaks was caused by HPAI H5N8, while all the others were caused by H5N1. This report describes wild bird species (geese, gulls, and wild birds kept in a zoo) that were found positive during those outbreaks. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of South Africa: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8441060,4335] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-06-06 17:04:08 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (10): Russia (AS) H5N8, China (JS) H10N3 Archive Number: 20210606.8426576AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (10): RUSSIA (ASTRAKHAN) H5N8, CHINA (JIANGSU) H10N3***************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: 3 Jun 2021Source: Sputnik News [abridged, edited]https://sputniknews.com/world/202106031083066176-two-cases-of-bird-flu-strains-in-humans-recorded-in-2021-russias-consumer-health-watchdog-says/Two incidents of transmission of bird flu viruses to humans have been recorded in 2021, Anna Popova, the head of Russia's consumer health watchdog Rospotrebnadzor, told Sputnik on Thu 3 Jun 2021."This year [2021] alone, we have 2 viruses of animal flu, in particular birds, which began to infect humans. One of them was reported by our scientists at the Vector Centre in February 2021; this is the H5N8 virus, which we have known of for a long time. The 2nd case, reported this week by our Chinese colleagues, is H10N3. A person contracted bird flu," Popova said on the sidelines of the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum (SPIEF). The official said that the goal now is to "learn lessons" from the COVID-19 pandemic and get ready "so that no infection is critically dangerous for us."The World Health Organization's spokesperson told Sputnik on Tuesday [1 Jun 2021] that WHO is conducting a risk assessment of a human case of a strain of bird flu jointly with China, after China's National Health Commission confirmed the 1st human case of the H10N3 strain of bird flu.There have been no previously reported cases of human-to-human transmission of the H10N3 infection in the world, with the virus considered to be low pathogenic among birds. Experts believe the case marks "accidental transmission of the virus from bird to human," adding that the risk of large-scale spread is extremely low.--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The 1st 7 human cases of avian influenza A/H5N8 were reported in February 2021 from poultry farm workers who participated in a response operation to contain an avian influenza A(H5N8) outbreak detected in a poultry farm in Astrakhan Oblast in the Russian Federation. The laboratory confirmation of the 7 specimens was performed by the State Research Centre for Virology and Biotechnology (VECTOR, WHO H5 Reference Laboratory). The ages of the 7 positive cases ranged between 29 to 60 years, and 5 were female [https://www.who.int/csr/don/26-feb-2021-influenza-a-russian-federation/en/].These cases with PCR-positive results were clinically asymptomatic. Infections with avian influenza viruses of the same clade (H5 clade 2.3.4.4) have been reported from China since 2014 in people with exposure to infected birds. The likelihood of human infections with influenza A(H5N8) viruses has been considered to be low.It is imperative that, with these new cases, the current WHO recommendations on public health measures and surveillance of animal and seasonal human influenza should continue to be implemented. Respiratory transmission occurs mainly by droplets, disseminated by unprotected coughs and sneezes. Short-distance airborne transmission of influenza viruses may occur, particularly in crowded, enclosed spaces. Hand contamination, direct inoculation of virus, exposure to infected birds or virus-contaminated materials or environments are potential sources of infection.When avian influenza viruses are circulating in an area, the people involved in specific, high-risk tasks such as sampling sick birds, culling and disposing of infected birds, eggs, and litter, and cleaning of contaminated premises should be trained on how to protect themselves and on proper use of personal protective equipment (PPE). People involved in these tasks should be registered and monitored closely by local health authorities for 7 days following the last day of contact with poultry or their environments.Due to the constantly evolving nature of influenza viruses, WHO continues to stress the importance of global surveillance to detect virological, epidemiological, and clinical changes associated with circulating influenza viruses that may affect human (or animal) health and timely virus sharing for risk assessment.Thorough investigation of all potential novel influenza human infections is warranted. All human infections caused by a novel influenza subtype are notifiable under the International Health Regulations (IHR), and State Parties to the IHR are required to immediately notify WHO of any laboratory-confirmed case of a recent human infection caused by a new influenza A subtype with the potential to cause a pandemic (please see case definitions for diseases requiring notification under the IHR). Evidence of illness is not required.In the case of a confirmed or suspected human infection, a thorough epidemiological investigation of history of exposure to animals, of travel, and contact tracing should be conducted, even while awaiting the confirmatory laboratory results. The epidemiological investigation should include early identification of unusual respiratory events that could signal person-to-person transmission of the novel virus. Clinical samples collected from the time and place that the case occurred should be tested and sent to a WHO Collaboration Center for further characterization. - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map:Russia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8426576,98] See Also

INFORMATION********************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 4 Jun 2021Source: Al-Mirbad (Baghdad) [in Arabic, machine trans., edited]https://www.almirbad.com/detail/89441A statement from the [Basrah] governorate's office, a copy of which was obtained by Al-Mirbad, says that since information about the death of poultry in the Safwan areas, west of Basrah, was received and samples analyzed by the competent authorities, suspecting the emergence of bird flu disease, the governor, Asaad Al-Eidani, directed the formation of a crisis unit to follow up on the matter and investigate the facts about infection with the disease, especially confirming the recent analyses and results.The statement added that the unit began holding its 1st meetings in the presence of officials from Basrah health, the relevant hospital, national security, operations command and some concerned parties, while urgent and strict measures will be taken to control the situation and limit its spread as quickly as possible.A security source told Al-Mirbad earlier today, Friday [4 Jun 2021], that samples taken from a poultry farm in the Khor Al-Zubair area in Basrah governorate to Baghdad laboratories were confirmed to be infected with bird flu, while a security force went to quarantine the premises and workers, and the Zubair Agriculture Directorate confirmed the death of thousands of chickens in poultry farms due to bird flu.--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Basrah province is situated in south east Iraq bordering Kuwait on its south.ProMED is indebted to the reliable source forwarding the above report, who added also the following summary and additional sources: "Media news articles on 4 Jun 2021 reported that samples taken from a poultry farm in the Khor Al-Zubair area in Basrah governorate to Baghdad laboratories were confirmed to be infected with avian influenza (most likely HPAI H5N8), while a security force went to quarantine the fields and workers. Governor (of Basrah) Asaad Al-Eidani ordered the formation of a higher committee to manage the incident and contain the disease, before it spread. The process of burying the infected chickens will take place tomorrow, Saturday [5 Jun 2021], under the supervision of a specialized medical team." The additional sources:1. https://tinyurl.com/c8p5223f2. https://www.dijlah.tv/index.php?page=article&id=2870083. https://baghdadtoday.news/ar/news/155276/AOfficial notification of the event, including the final lab-confirmed identity of the pathogen, is anticipated. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Basrah governorate, Iraq: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8425720,1915.] See Also
