View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-02-13 22:11:27 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (35): Japan (CH), Nepal (KT), poultry, HPAI H5N8 Archive Number: 20210213.8189507AVIAN INFLUENZA (35): JAPAN (CHIBA), NEPAL (KATHMANDU), POULTRY, HPAI H5N8**************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this post:[1] Nepal (Kathmandu), poultry[2] Japan (Chiba), poultry******[1] Nepal (Kathmandu), poultryDate: Fri 12 Feb 2021 7:30 a.m. NPTSource: My Republica (Nepal) [edited]https://myrepublica.nagariknetwork.com/news/bird-flu-cases-confirmed-in-tarkeshwar/?categoryId=81Bird flu has been confirmed in Sanglekhola of Tarkeshwar Municipality in the district.The flu has been detected among chickens and ducks reared there. According to Chief of the Livestock Department of the Municipality, Dhanapati Ray, the viral disease has been detected among chickens and ducks reared by 2 locals, [PT] and [ST].The flu was confirmed following a sample test conducted at the Tripureshwar-based central laboratory.With this, the local authorities have urged all to adopt extra precaution to prevent the flu from spreading further.--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[Nepal reported to the OIE on 30 Jan 2021 its 1st HPAI outbreak in 2021, identifying the causative agent as HPAI H5N8; see, with map, at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=37973 and in 20210202.8156270. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Kathmandu, Central Region, Nepal: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8189507,2877]******[2] Japan (Chiba), poultryDate: Thu 11 Feb 2021Source: ANI via Business World [edited]http://www.businessworld.in/article/Over-350-000-chickens-to-be-culled-over-bird-flu-in-Japan-s-Chiba-prefecture/11-02-2021-376365/About 356 000 chickens will be culled in the Japanese prefecture of Chiba over a new outbreak of the bird flu, Japanese media reported on Thursday [11 Feb 2021].The authorities introduced a quarantine to prevent the movement of eggs and chickens from the area around the hit farm, the Kyodo news agency reported.This is the 10th outbreak of the bird flu in the Chiba prefecture where some 4.6 million chickens have already been culled.Bird flu outbreaks have also been discovered in the prefectures of Kagawa, Fukuoka, Hyogo, Miyazaki, Hiroshima, Nara, Oita, Wakayama, Okayama, Shiga, Kochi, Tokushima, Gifu, Kagoshima, Toyama, and Ibaraki.According to the Ministry for Agriculture, some 9.3 million domestic birds have already been culled to prevent the spread of the disease.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map:Chiba Prefecture, Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8189507,17032][The HPAI H5N8 event in Japan started 4 Nov 2020; so far, 43 outbreaks in poultry and 13 in wild birds have been reported to the OIE. Their summary, epidemiological comments, and a map, last updated 28 Jan 2021 (update No. 10), are available at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=36435.HPAI strains, in particular H5N8, have been spreading throughout Eurasia, from the British Isles to Japan, since the fall of 2020, affecting backyard holdings as well as commercial poultry farms. Please refer to OIE's interactive HPAI global map, covering the period 1 Oct 2020 - 12 Feb 2021, available at https://tinyurl.com/y3tzsrug. For the Japanese and Nepal clusters, click on Japan/Nepal and zoom in to the required resolution.Eurasia has been experiencing extreme cold weather (frost and snowfall) since the late fall months of 2020. This may have triggered winter movements of migratory birds and thereby contributed to the spread of wild-bird-transmitted diseases outside the actual migration period (Ref: Keller I, Korner-Nievergelt F, Jenni L: Within-winter movements: a common phenomenon in the common pochard _Aythya ferina_. J Ornithol. 2009; 150: 483-494; doi: https://doi.org/10.1007/s10336-008-0367-x; https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10336-008-0367-x). - Mod.AS] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-02-12 17:21:53 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (33): Latvia (JM) wild bird, HPAI H5N8, 1st rep Archive Number: 20210212.8187063AVIAN INFLUENZA (33): LATVIA (JURMALA) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N8, FIRST REPORT*************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 10 Feb 2021Source: LSM.LV (Latvian Public Broadcasting) [edited]https://eng.lsm.lv/article/society/environment/first-cases-of-avian-flu-detected-in-latvia.a392348/Laboratory tests have confirmed highly pathogenic avian influenza for 2 dead swans in Jurmala, Dzintaru Beach. This is the 1st case of avian influenza in Latvia, the Food and Veterinary Service (PVD) said [10 Feb 2021].The Ministry of Agriculture intends, on the basis of information provided by the PVD, to impose additional biosecurity measures for poultry keepers throughout the country, including ban of keeping poultry outdoors in order to prevent direct or indirect contact with wild birds.The PVD calls on owners of birds not to let them outside or keep them in fenced structures before any restrictions are imposed, to avoid contact of poultry with wild birds, particularly water birds (swans, ducks), and refrain from purchasing poultry in other European countries during the winter and forthcoming spring months.Poultry owners should notify the PVD immediately if signs of disease are observed in birds: significantly decreased intake of food and water, increased mortality.On the other hand, citizens are asked to report on dead wild water birds by calling the PVD trust phone 67027402 or by informing the local authority of the nearby PVD.Under no circumstances should birds be brought home or taken to animal shelters."This influenza is highly contagious, highly pathogenic, which means that all infected birds are exposed to death and extinction sooner or later," said Madara Volka, head of the monitoring department of infectious diseases of the PVD.Highly pathogenic avian influenza is an acute, highly contagious avian infectious disease characterized by high mortality. The clinical signs of the disease are sudden and rapid development of the disease, fatigue, withdrawal of food, disheveled feathers, wobbling, choking, etc. The virus's spreaders are wild birds, particularly waterfowl, for which the disease can occur without the symptoms.Poultry can be infected by coming into contact with infected wild birds, for example by accessing ponds and other bodies of water. Similarly, birds may be infected with contaminated feed or objects (footwear, clothing, equipment) on which the virus has landed.In 2021, highly pathogenic avian influenza in wild birds has been detected in 20 European countries and in poultry -- in 16 European countries.Avian influenza subtypes circulating in European countries do not endanger human health, but the disease is a serious threat to the poultry sector in Latvia.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Some migratory flyways of Anatidae that may carry HPAI viruses pass over or near Latvia. For example, the North Sea flyway joins the wetlands of northwestern Russia to western Europe wintering sites and runs through Scandinavia, the Baltic basin, and the North Sea. The OIE report (see ProMED post 20210211.8185113) states the strain detected is H5N8. - Mod.PMB[HealthMap/ProMED map of Latvia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8187063,56164] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map of Latvia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8185113,56164The latest OIE avian influenza report mentioned that: "In Europe, the 1st outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 were reported in August 2020 in Russia, in both poultry and wild birds. Since then, a new wave of epizootic outbreaks of H5N8 has been continuously reported in several European countries especially in wild birds, but also in poultry starting from mid-October [2020]. The H5N8 virus has also reassorted with other wild bird influenza viruses to form new strains of H5N5 and H5N1 HPAI virus, which were also reported by countries. There has been continued virus change by genetic reassortment in wild birds resulting in other H5 subtypes like H5N3 and H5N4 also reported by few countries in the current epidemic wave.""To summarize, the current HPAI H5 epidemic is still progressing in Europe, Asia, and Africa causing severe impact due to dead and culled birds in the infected premises. It is more likely that the source of introduction in these outbreaks is through migratory wild birds and onward local spread. A similar situation of H5N8 epizootics associated with wild bird migration occurred in 2016/17. Report of increased number of outbreaks in wild birds indicate periods of heightened risk in countries due to migratory flyways during this season. Consequently, improving on-farm biosecurity measures is a priority to reduce the likelihood of exposure to poultry."Veterinary Authorities in the affected countries have responded to contain outbreaks in poultry with stamping out measures, heightened surveillance, and recommendations to poultry owners to increase biosecurity".Source: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) Report no 21: 15 Jan to 4 Feb 2021, World Animal Health Information and Analysis Department; available at https://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/HPAI___asof04022021.pdfAs was mentioned in ProMED-mail posting 20210205.8166203, given the presence HPAI H5N8 in the region, there is a high likelihood that this recent outbreak reported by Bulgaria is also associated with this same subtype.To date, no human cases of infection with HPAI H5N8 have been reported. - Mod.CRD] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[During a 10 Feb 2021 press conference, the minister of agriculture of Algeria mentioned that "the source of this virus is migratory birds, and we [Algeria] have put all regions on alert in anticipation of any emergency." He stressed that "the epidemic was contained in Ain Fakroun town, which appeared in there." (See https://www.poandpo.com/agrifish/algeria-declares-state-of-emergency-over-bird-flu/)In the African continent, HPAI subtype H5N1 has been recently reported in wild birds and poultry in Senegal and in wild birds in Mauritania. Outbreaks of HPAI subtype H5N8 are still present in South Africa. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Oum el Bouaghi, Oum el Bouaghi, Algeria: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8183060,16673] See Also

Outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 re-emerged in eastern Asia in the last part of 2020. The high sequence homology with isolates in Europe during the winter season 2019-2020 suggests that the variants currently causing outbreaks in Asia came from Europe, perhaps via bird migration. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map:Jiangsu Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8182954,342] See Also

animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredYellow-legged Gull: _Larus michahellis_ (Laridae) / 1 / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Affected population: The sick yellow-legged gull (_Larus michahellis_) was shot on [1 Feb 2021] on the bank of the river Rhein.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Yellow-legged Gull: _Larus michahellis_ (Laridae) / 100 / 0 / 0 / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: Samples of the gull were sent to the National Reference Center for Poultry and Rabbit Diseases (NRGK, Zurich, Switzerland), where they tested positive for avian influenza of the subtype H5 in RT-qPCR. Confirmation and sequencing analyses were carried out at the Institute of Virology and Immunology (IVI, Mittelhausern, Switzerland) where highly pathogenic avian influenza of the subtype H5N4 was confirmed on [4 Feb 2021]. It is the 1st confirmation of this subtype in Switzerland. However, this is the same strain already confirmed recently in the region of Lake Constance in Germany. Following confirmation of highly pathogenic avian influenza in wild birds on the German side of Lake Constance, the FSVO and the Cantons concerned preventively established control and surveillance zones along the shores of the lake and parts of the river Rhein on [25 Jan 2021]. A control zone of a width of one km was established along the shores of Lake Constance and along the shores of nearby parts of the river Rhein. In the Canton of Schaffhausen, the control zone includes almost the entire territory. Poultry in the control zone area are obliged to be kept such that contact between poultry and wild birds is prevented. The surveillance zone covers a 3-km wide zone along the shore of Lake Constance and along the shores of nearby parts of the river Rhein. In the surveillance zone, poultry holders are obliged to notify veterinarians or the cantonal authorities about any suspicious symptoms of disease in poultry. The affected gull was found within the existing control zone.Control measuresMeasures applied: surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultNational Reference Centre for Diseases of Poultry and Rabbits (NRGK) (National laboratory) / Yellow-legged Gull: _Larus michahellis_ / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 4 Feb 2021 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. The H5N8-infected animal was detected in the ongoing national surveillance program on wild birds. Neither the Hong Kong Wetland Park nor Mai Po Nature Reserve nor any poultry farms are located within 3 km [1.9 mi] of the outbreak location. No spread of disease was evident. The date of end of the outbreak is the same as the date the bird was found (28 Jan 2021).Control measuresMeasures applied: screening, disinfection, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type: Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Department (national laboratory)Species / Test / Test date / ResultPeregrine falcon: _Falco peregrinus_ (Falconidae) / immunohistochemical test / 29 Jan 2021 / positivePeregrine falcon: _F. peregrinus_ (Falconidae) / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 29 Jan 2021 / positivePeregrine falcon: _F. peregrinus_ (Falconidae) / virus isolation / 31 Jan 2021 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated The most affected animals are young. Djoudj National Bird Park host thousands of Palaearctic and Afrotropical migratory birds. It is a feeding, reproduction, and refuge site for many bird colonies. Each year, colonies of great white pelicans come to reproduce at a nesting box located not far from the wharf, along the Djoudj backwater.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Great White pelican: _P. onocrotalus_ (Pelecanidae) / 9.25 / 9.25 / 100 / 9.25Pink-backed pelican: _P. rufescens_ (Pelecanidae) / 0 / 0 / - / 0*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive.Epidemiological comments: Following a report of deaths in young white pelicans by the curator from the Djoudj National Bird Park on 14 Jan 2021, the commander/veterinarian and curator of the Gueumbeul Wildlife Reserve carried out an investigation onsite on 23 Jan 2021. Samples were sent, and the National Laboratory for Animal Husbandry and Veterinary Research of Dakar confirmed the disease (highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1) on 28 Jan 2021. Out of a total of 8922 birds, 822 deaths and cases were recorded, representing morbidity and mortality rates of 9.21%. Young animals are more affected (810) than adults (12).Control measuresMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; control of wildlife reservoirs; disinfection; process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultNational Livestock and Veterinary Research Laboratory in Dakar - Senegalese Agricultural Research Institute (ISRA) (national laboratory) / great white pelican: _P. onocrotalus_ / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 28 Jan 2021 / positiveISRA / great white pelican: _P. onocrotalus_ / reverse transcription/polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 28 Jan 2021 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map of Saint-Louis, Senegal: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8168009,53305][This immediate notification from Senegal complements the information already published in ProMED-mail posting 20210201.8155983.HPAI viruses emerged in western Africa in 2006 and reemerged in 2015. No outbreaks of HPAI had been reported in Senegal until very recently (end of 2020; ProMED posting 20210108.8085504), when an outbreak in a poultry farm due to H5N1 was documented 200 km [124 mi] south of Djoudj bird sanctuary. This is the 1st report in the neighboring Mauritania. The temporal and spatial correlation between these 2 outbreaks strongly suggests they might be linked. - Mod.PMB] See Also

All measures have been taken immediately to eradicate the outbreak, it said.The last outbreak of the disease in Bulgaria was registered in June 2020, the statement added.--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The causative agent is most likely the same HPAI H5N8 strain circulating throughout Europe since the start of the current winter season, introduced by migrating birds. This is yet to be lab confirmed and reported to the OIE. The previous event in Bulgaria, terminated in June 2020, was caused by HPAI H5N8.For the location of Slavyanovo, in the Pleven region, see map at <tinyurl.com/1rqq6aki>. - Mod.AS] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-02-04 06:51:22 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (24): Germany (BB) poultry, HPAI H5N8, spread Archive Number: 20210204.8164212AVIAN INFLUENZA (24): GERMANY (BRANDENBURG) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, SPREAD**********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 3 Feb 2021Source: Thomson Reuters Foundation News [edited]https://news.trust.org/item/20210203065403-29p1u/An outbreak of bird flu [avian influenza] on a farm in the eastern German state of Brandenburg has forced authorities to begin slaughtering about 14 000 turkeys, the state government said on Wednesday [3 Feb 2021], reporting the 3rd outbreak there in recent weeks. Type H5N8 bird flu was confirmed in a farm in the Uckermark area, the Brandenburg state government said.A series of outbreaks of bird flu have been reported in Germany and elsewhere in Europe in past months with wild birds suspected to be spreading the disease.Sweden planned to cull around 1.3 million chickens after bird flu was found on a farm in the country, Sweden's Board of Agriculture said on 25 Jan 2021.The risk to humans from the disease is considered low, but past outbreaks among farm birds have resulted in extensive slaughtering programmes to contain the spread.[byline: Michael Hogan, editing: Simon Cameron-Moore]--communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[The current event in Brandenburg is preceded by 2 earlier HPAI H5N8 outbreaks affecting poultry in this German state, notified to the OIE in reports submitted on 30 Dec 2020 and 25 Jan 2021. The summaries, maps, and links to both are available at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=37383. The current outbreak in turkeys is yet to be officially reported. This Brandenburg thread started on 27 Dec 2020.Germany currently suffers HPAI H5N8 outbreaks affecting its poultry in 7 additional states, reported in separate threads to the OIE since November 2020. The largest outbreak has been affecting Lower Saxony. To view all recent outbreaks, in Germany and elsewhere, please refer to OIE's global HPAI map (which covers also other HPAI strains), at http://tinyurl.com/16ad6ssx (click on Germany to recentre, zoom in for the required resolution).Notably, most of the outbreaks (as well as the cases in wild birds, which are not presented on this map) are concentrated along Europe's northern coastal regions, from UK/France in the west all the way to the northern parts of Poland, reaching Lithuania in the east and including southern Sweden. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8164212,68142.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-02-01 16:00:54 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (22): Senegal, wild bird, HPAI H5N1 Archive Number: 20210201.8155983AVIAN INFLUENZA (22): SENEGAL, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N1***************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 29 Jan 2021Source: Successful Farming, a Reuters report [edited]https://www.agriculture.com/markets/newswire/update-1-hundreds-of-dead-pelicans-in-senegal-test-positive-for-h5n1-bird-fluSome 750 pelicans found dead in a UNESCO World Heritage site in northern Senegal last week [18 - 24 Jan 2021] have tested positive for H5N1 bird flu, the head of the parks authority told Reuters on [Fri 29 Jan 2021]. Rangers found the pelicans on [23 Jan 2021] in the Djoudj bird sanctuary, a remote pocket of wetland near the border with Mauritania and a resting place for birds that cross the Sahara Desert into West Africa each year. The birds were incinerated and the park is closed, said Bocar Thiam, Senegal's parks director.The sanctuary is a transit place for about 350 species of birds but only pelicans were found dead.This month [January 2021], Senegal reported an outbreak of H5N1 on a poultry farm in the Thies region about 120 mi [about 193 km] south, resulting in the culling of about 100 000 chickens. It is not clear if the 2 outbreaks are linked.--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HPAI viruses emerged in western Africa in 2006 and reemerged in 2015. No outbreaks of HPAI had been reported in Senegal until very recently (end of 2020; ProMED archive number 20210108.8085504), when an outbreak in a poultry farm due to H5N1 was documented 200 km (about 124 mi) south of Djoudj bird sanctuary. The temporal and spatial correlation between these 2 outbreaks strongly suggests they might be linked. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map:Senegal: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8155983,48] See Also

One outbreak (submitted) was confirmed as positive to HPAI subtype H5N3 on 8 Jan 2021.Total animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredScolopacidae (unidentified): Scolopacidae (incognita) (Scolopacidae) / - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The last outbreak assessment report no. 13 for the cases of HPAI in the UK and Europe, published on 26 Jan 2021 by DEFRA-APHA, mentions: "Looking at the overall trends in Europe, there was a small increase in the number of wild bird cases in the first 3 weeks of January [2021] following the decrease in rate of new cases in November/December [2020], although this is considerably smaller than the increase in wild bird cases report in early 2017 (so far). To 25 Jan 2021, this year there have been 93 wild bird cases of 844 in total since October [2020], of which 38 were reported to OIE on 22 Jan. At this stage in the 2016/17 epizootic, there had been 625 wild bird cases, with cases rising to over 1000 by mid-February 2017 in the 2nd peak. For poultry, overall, the number of outbreaks reported are reducing (particularly in Germany and Poland). The exception is France, which has reported a large increase in numbers as H5N8 spreads though the duck industry in the southwest. In southeast Europe, HPAI has not obviously spread, with a few wild bird cases on the Black Sea in Romania and the Czech Republic and no further reports in Hungary." The full report is available at <tinyurl.com/3hroaud4>.The fact that HPAI subtype H5N8 and other subtypes HPAI H5N5, H5N4, N5N3 and H5N1 currently circulating in the European continent have been detected in wild birds is indicative that these viruses are being distributed wherever these wild birds migrate. Poultry producers, small and large alike, must therefore implement all the biosecurity measures necessary to protect their flocks from exposure and infection. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED maps:Puglia, Apulia, Italy: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8148832,16580Ilfov, Romania: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8148832,68118Normandy, France: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8148832,68119Northern Ireland, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8148832,17415Bavaria, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8148832,3744Baden-Wurttemberg, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8148832,4181Lower Saxony, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8148832,2856] See Also

Birds were kept in a private garden in Lugo (Province of Ravenna). Carcasses were submitted for necropsy examination at the regional reference laboratory and a pool of organs was collected from the 2 birds for avian influenza detection (M gene and H5 real-time), resulting positive. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map of India: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8138104,142Asia has been a hot spot for HPAIV outbreaks for more than 20 years and most of the new lineage strains and genetic reassortments were produced within or near this region. Outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 re-emerged in eastern Asia in the last part of 2020. The high sequence homology recently observed with isolates in Europe during the winter season 2019-2020 suggests that the variants currently causing outbreaks in Asia came from Europe, perhaps via bird migration. With regards to HPAI H5N1, the Indian Subcontinent has experienced outbreaks in domestic poultry and other birds almost every year since the 1st report in 2006. Since November 2016, also subtype H5N8 outbreaks were reported in India, Pakistan, and Nepal. - Mod.PMB] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>*****[3] Czech Republic (South Bohemian Region): Swan, H5N8Date: Fri 22 Jan 2021Source: OIE, WAHID [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37796Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds) Czech Republic-------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 22 Jan 2021 from Dr. Zbynek Semerad, Director General, State Veterinary Administration, Veterinary Administration, Prague, Czech RepublicSummaryReport type: Immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 20 Jan 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 21 Jan 2021Reason for notification: Recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 25 Mar 2020Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic and advanced)This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Zlivicky rybnik, Cizova, Pisek, Jihocesky [South Bohemian Region]Date of start of the outbreak: 20 Jan 2021Outbreak status: resolved on 21 Jan 2021Epidemiological unit: Not applicableTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / SlaughteredMute Swan: _Cygnus olor_ (Anatidae) / - / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveControl measuresMeasures applied: official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; control of wildlife reservoirs; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultsState Veterinary Institute Prague (National laboratory) / Mute Swan / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 21 Jan 2021 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>["In Europe, the 1st outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 were reported in August 2020 in Russia in both poultry and wild birds. Since then, a new wave of epizootic outbreaks of H5N8 have been continuously reported in several European countries, especially in wild birds, but also in poultry starting from mid-October 2020.The H5N8 virus has also reassorted with other wild bird influenza viruses to form new strains of H5N5 and H5N1 HPAI virus, which were also reported by countries. A similar situation of H5N8 epizootics associated with wild bird migration occurred in 2016/17. It is more likely that the source of introduction in these outbreaks is through migratory wild birds and onward local spread. Reports of increased numbers of outbreaks in wild birds indicate periods of heightened risk in countries due to migratory flyways during this season. Consequently, improving on-farm biosecurity measures is a priority to reduce the likelihood of exposure to poultry." (Source: OIE-Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) Report No. 20: 25 Dec 2020 to 14 Jan 2021; https://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/HPAI_asof14012021.pdf. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED maps:Finland: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8132562,118Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8132562,101Czech Republic: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8132562,110] See Also

received on [and dated] 21 Jan 2021 from Dr Ali Al-Qattan, Deputy of Director General of Animal Wealth, Animal Wealth, Public Authority of Agriculture Affairs and Fish Resources, Safat, KuwaitSummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 4 Nov 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 8 Nov 2020Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 28 Dec 2016Manifestation of disease: Clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), necropsyThis event pertains the whole country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Sulaibiyah, Al JahrahDate of start of the outbreak: 4 Nov 2020Outbreak status: resolved on 9 Nov 2020Epidemiological unit: BackyardTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 112 / 24 / 8 / 104 / 0Affected population: Pheasants and geeseOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 21.43 / 7.14 / 33.33 / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: The affected population consisted of pheasants and geese. Birds showed clinical signs of avian influenza. Relevant samples were collected and tested at National Laboratory and confirmed as highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8. Further investigation on the relevant samples was carried out by the OIE Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza, United Kingdom. Highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 was reconfirmed on [15 Jan 2021]. Immediately after the confirmation of the National Laboratory, stamping out policy was adopted; carcasses were disposed of with application of appropriate disinfection procedures on [9 Nov 2020]. Active surveillance was carried out. There are no commercial poultry farms within a 5-km radius. The outbreak of this event is considered resolved on [9 Nov 2020].Control measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, traceability, quarantine, official destruction of animal products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, control of wildlife reservoirs, disinfection, ante and post-mortem inspections, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultCentral Veterinary and Research Laboratory (national laboratory) / birds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 8 Nov 2020 / positiveAnimal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) Weybridge, United Kingdom (OIE Reference Laboratory) / birds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 15 Jan 2021 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Since October 2020, HPAI H5N8 has been reported from Africa, Europe and Asia.The OIE's most recent situation report on HPAI, from 25 Dec 2020 to 14 Jan 2021, mentioned that: "In the reporting period, 215 new HPAI outbreaks were reported in domestic birds (subtypes H5, H5N1, H5N5, H5N6, and H5N8) in Asia, Europe, and Africa and 79 new outbreaks in non-poultry (subtypes H5, H5N1, H5N5 and H5N8) in Asia and Europe. In addition, 794 HPAI outbreaks in poultry and non-poultry are still ongoing in Europe, Asia, and Africa, involving different subtypes, namely H5, H5N1, H5N2, H5N3, H5N5, H5N6, H5N8, and H7N9. The number of new and ongoing outbreaks reported by countries notably in Asia and Europe continue to be significant during this period." See report at https://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/HPAI_asof14012021.pdf. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Al Jahrah Governorate, Kuwait: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8132321,25995] See Also

It is divided into 3 separate epidemiological units. Clinical signs (high mortality) were seen in unit 1 on [17 Jan 2021].Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 0.43 / 0.43 / 100 / 49.53*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: A protection zone (3 km) [approx. 1.8 mi] and a surveillance zone (10 km) [approx. 6.2 mi] have been put in place around the establishment. All other restrictions and necessary measures according to Directive 2005/94/EG are/will be applied. Birds in the epidemiological unit (unit 1) are currently being euthanized. The birds in all the other epidemiological units are closely monitored and are put under official surveillance.Control measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; stamping out; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: Official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultNational Veterinary Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time PCR / 18 Jan 2021 / PositiveNational Veterinary Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / Virus sequencing / - / PendingFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED	<promed@promedmail.org>["Wild birds, particularly wild migratory water birds, are considered to be the main reservoir of avian influenza viruses. There is a constant risk of avian influenza being introduced into Ireland from wild birds particularly from November onwards each year as this is when migratory birds arrive and congregate on wetlands, mixing with resident species. Cold, short winter days also increase the risk of avian influenza due to increased virus survival times in the environment". Source: https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/50ce4-avian-influenza-bird-flu/Further information on the Avian Influenza situation in Ireland, can be seen at https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/50ce4-avian-influenza-bird-flu/#avian-influenza-updates (latest update 15 Jan 2021).A detailed overview as of 19 Jan 2021 on the situation in EU Member States and the adopted measures is given in the document titled "Chronology of event" available at https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/ad_control-measures_hapai_chrono_2021.pdf. "This document summarizes basic information on the outbreaks of Avian Influenza (AI) in several EU Member States and related EU action. It focuses on the animal health aspects." A series of outbreak maps of the HPAI affected European countries can be seen at https://izsvenezie.com/documents/reference-laboratories/avian-influenza/europe-updates/HPAI/2020-1/map.pdf(last update 21 Jan 2021). - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED maps:Lower Saxony, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8123930,2856Louth, Leinster, Ireland: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8123930,46533Kalmar, Sweden: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8123930,62790] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-01-20 15:55:36 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (01): China (GD) H9N2, alert Archive Number: 20210120.8111218AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (01): CHINA (GUANGDONG) H9N2, ALERT**********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 16 Jan 2021Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/h9n2-avian-influenza-case-reported-in-guangdong-province-china-82113/World Health Organization (WHO) reports one new case of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) virus in China during the 1st week of 2021.The case was a 1-year-and 4-month-old male from Yunfu, Guangdong Province, China, who had exposure to domestic poultry prior to the onset of illness. He developed mild symptoms on [28 Dec 2020] and was admitted to a hospital on [29 Dec 2020]. As of [4 Jan 2021], no family cluster was reported. This is the 1st case to be reported from China in 2021.In addition, 6 new cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) virus were reported on [9 Dec 2020].The cases were retrospectively detected through influenza-like illness surveillance (ILI) between July 2019 and December 2020. No deaths were reported among the reported cases and all 6 reported mild symptoms. 5 of the cases had exposure to poultry and one case had no clear poultry exposure. No family clusters were reported from any of the 6 cases.In 2020, there were 13 cases reported from China. A total of 42 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) in China have been reported since December 2015.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The WHO weekly avian influenza update no 774 further notes:"Additionally, on [9 Dec 2020], 6 new cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) virus were reported in the Western Pacific Region. The cases were retrospectively detected through influenza-like illness surveillance (ILI) between July 2019 and December 2020. No deaths were reported among the reported cases and all 6 reported mild symptoms. 5 of the cases had exposure to poultry and one case had no clear poultry exposure. No family clusters were reported from any of the 6 cases. In 2020, there were 13 cases reported from China. A total of 42 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H9N2) in China have been reported since December 2015." (https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20210108.pdf)."H9N2 avian influenza viruses have become globally widespread in poultry over the last 2 decades and represent a genuine threat both to the global poultry industry but also humans through their high rates of zoonotic infection and pandemic potential. H9N2 viruses are generally hyperendemic in affected countries and have been found in poultry in many new regions in recent years."Studies have reported how "reassortants between H9N2 viruses and human seasonal influenza viruses are able to efficiently transmit between ferrets and there is, therefore, a real danger eventually such a reassortant could emerge in the field.""Several H9N2 viruses have human receptor binding, pH stable HA proteins that could potentially allow efficient transmission between humans whilst other H9N2 viruses contain internal gene cassettes that allow extremely efficient replication in humans (i.e., genotype 57). Overall there is a clear risk of both intersubtypic H9N2/human influenza virus reassortant emergence as well as an intrasubtyptic human binding HA/efficient mammalian polymerase reassortant emergence, either of which could potentially pose a high zoonotic and pandemic threat." (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6669617/). - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map of China https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8111218,334] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-01-19 20:23:25 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (14): Iraq (SD) poultry, HPAI H5N8 Archive Number: 20210119.8118153AVIAN INFLUENZA (14): IRAQ (SALAH AD-DIN) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 16 Jan 2021Source: IND News [edited]https://ind.news/iraq-reports-bird-flu-outbreak/A bird flu outbreak has been detected in Iraq's Salahudin [Salah ad-Din] province, authorities said, adding that all protective measures have been taken to contain the spread of the virus."The laboratory tests proved that poultry in Samarra city, some 120 km north of the Iraqi capital Baghdad, was infected with bird flu," Ammar Khalil, governor of the province, said in a statement on Friday [15 Jan 2021].Khalil said that about 60 000 chickens were infected with bird flu in the city, calling on poultry owners and citizens in Samarra to be on the highest alert to confront the virus, according to the statement.In a separate statement, the Iraqi Ministry of Agriculture said that it had taken all protective measures to prevent the spread of the detected H5N8 strain of avian influenza virus to other poultry fields in Salahudin.It said that after the discovery of the infection in 2 poultry fields in Samarra, the Ministry's Veterinary Department held a meeting, and an emergency plan was approved to control the disease.The Ministry pointed out that all the chickens in the fields infected with the virus were culled, and the fields' halls were sanitised, in addition to blocking and scanning a 3-km area surrounding the fields.--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[According to other media sources, an additional 190 000 chickens have been reported as affected in the mentioned location.For the location of Samarra, please see map at https://tinyurl.com/y2uzwvjx. Out of the 3 countries bordering northern Iraq, HPAI H5N8 has been reported by Iran (20201223.8041976). The others are Turkey and Syria.HPAI H5N8 has been reported since October 2020 from numerous Eurasian countries, reflecting the seasonal bird-migration-related pattern curve while presenting its highest incidence since 2016.Recent press releases of India's government, addressing the spread of the disease in wild and domestic birds, are available at https://pib.gov.in/PressReleseDetail.aspx?PRID=1688263 and https://pib.gov.in/PressReleseDetail.aspx?PRID=1687623. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Salah Al-Din Governorate, Iraq: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8118153,19576] See Also

34(02) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37615Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Hong Kong (SAR-PRC)--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 14 Jan 2021 from Dr Thomas Sit, Chief Veterinary Officer/Assistant Director (Inspection & Quarantine), Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government, Hong Kong, (SAR-PRC)SummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 6 Jan 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 13 Jan 2021Reason for notification: New strain of a listed disease in the countryCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza A [AI] virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)This event pertains to the whole country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak 1: Mai Po, Hong KongDate of start of the outbreak: 6 Jan 2021Outbreak status: resolved on 6 Jan 2021Epidemiological unit: Natural parkAffected animals:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredUnidentified: Incognita (Incognita) / - / 2 / - / 0 / 0Affected population: Two fecal environmental samplesEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: an intensive surveillance system is in place for avian influenza virus including screening at Mai Po Nature Reserve in Hong Kong. 2 faecal environmental samples were collected for the routine academic surveillance study by the University of Hong Kong on [6 Jan 2021] and subsequently tested positive for H5N8.Control measuresMeasures applied: screening; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultCentre of Influenza Research, School of Public Health, Li Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine, University of Hong Kong (regional reference laboratory) / NA / virus isolation / 13 Jan 2021 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Eastern Asia has been a hot spot for HPAIV outbreaks for more than 20 years, and most of the new lineage strains and genetic reassortments were produced within or near this region.Outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 re-emerged in eastern Asia in the last part of 2020. The high sequence homology with isolates in Europe during the winter season 2019-2020 suggests that the variants currently causing outbreaks in Asia came from Europe, perhaps via bird migration. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Hong Kong: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8113830,198] See Also

34(02) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37605Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Cambodia-----------------------------Information received on [and dated] 14 Jan 2021 from Mr. Phannara Tan, Director General, General Directorate of Animal Health and Production, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Phnom Penh, CambodiaSummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 5 Jan 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 11 Jan 2021Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 26 Apr 2019Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)This event pertains to the whole country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Preak Tachraeng, Preak Norean, Aek Phnom, Battambang [Batdambang]Date of start of the outbreak: 5 Jan 2021Outbreak status: resolved (13 Jan 2021)Epidemiological unit: villageTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 1990 / 1827 / 1827 / 163 / 0Affected population: Avian influenza affected poultry in backyard farms.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, in percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 91.81 / 91.81 / 100 / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: On [9 Jan 2021], a provincial veterinarian received information about sick-dead poultry from a farmer in the village. He then went there to check and collect samples from the affected poultry and sent them to the National Animal Health and Production Research Institute, which confirmed positive to H5N1 on 11 Jan [2021].Control measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, stamping out, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zoneDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultNational Animal Health and Production Research Institute (NAHPRI) (national laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positiveInstitute Pasteur, Cambodia (regional reference laboratory) / birds / real-time PCR / 11 Jan 2021 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[Cambodia has been experiencing HPAI H5N1 since 2005. This is the 1st outbreak of HPAI associated with serotype H5N1 since 2018 (see https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=27724). However, the serotypes H5 and H7 of low pathogenic avian influenza can mutate into a highly pathogenic virus. 34(02) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37535Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Hungary------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 11 Jan 2021 from Dr. Lajos Bognar, Deputy State Secretary Chief Veterinary Officer, Food Chain Safety Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Budapest, HungarySummaryReport type: Immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 4 Jan 2021Date of confirmation of the event: 6 Jan 2021Reason for notification: Recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 8 Jun 2020Manifestation of disease: Clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (2)Outbreak location 1: Acs, Komarom-EsztergomDate of start of the outbreak: 4 Jan 2021Outbreak status: resolved 6 Jan 2021Epidemiological unit: farmAffected animals:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 47 596 / - / 150 / 47 446 / -Affected population:  Fattening turkeysOutbreak location 2: Acs, Komarom-EsztergomDate of start of the outbreak: 4 Jan 2021Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: farmAffected animals:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 36 976 / - / - / 36 976 / 0Affected population:  Fattening turkeysSummary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 2Total animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 84 572 / ** / 150 / 84 422 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: In the 1st affected holding, 47 596 turkeys have been kept in 12 pens. In one of these pens, where 3900 9-week-old turkeys were kept, on [2 and 3 Jan 2021], a drop in feed and water intake, and on [4 Jan 2021], increased mortality rate and watery diarrhea have been observed. In the other holding 36 976 turkeys were kept. On [4 Jan 2021] in this holding, the drop in feed and water intake has been observed. From the 2 holdings, samples were taken and sent to the National Reference Laboratory (NRL) on [ 4 Jan 2021]. The highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 strain was confirmed on [6 Jan 2021]. The epidemiological investigation is ongoing. The most likely source of infection is wild birds. The virus isolation and the phylogenetic examination are ongoing.Control measuresMeasures applied: Movement control inside the country; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type: Veterinary Diagnostic Directorate (national laboratory)Species / Test / Test date / ResultBirds / Nucleotide sequencing / 6 Jan 2021 / PositiveBirds / Real-time PCR / 6 Jan 2021 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED	<promed@promedmail.org>******[2] Hungary (Komarom-Esztergom): wild bird, H5N8Date: Mon 11 Jan 2021Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; 34(02) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37540Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Hungary-------------------------------------------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 11 Jan 2021 from Dr. Lajos Bognar, Deputy State Secretary Chief Veterinary Officer, Food Chain Safety Department, Ministry of Agriculture, Budapest, HungarySummaryReport type: Immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 22 Dec 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 6 Jan 2021Reason for notification: Recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 20 Mar 2020Manifestation of disease: Clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: Laboratory (advanced)This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (2)Outbreak location 1: Szomod, Komarom-EsztergomDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Dec 2020Outbreak status: resolved 23 Dec 2020Epidemiological unit: Natural parkAffected animals:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredGreat Egret: _Ardea alba_ (Ardeidae) / - / 1 / 1 / - / -EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: A great egret (_Ardea alba_) was found dead on [22 Dec 2020] in Komarom-Esztergom county around the locality of Szomod. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-01-11 12:09:27 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Salmonellosis, avian - North America: (Pacific Northwest) songbird Archive Number: 20210111.8091844SALMONELLOSIS, AVIAN - NORTH AMERICA: (PACIFIC NORTHWEST) SONGBIRD******************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sun 10 Jan 2021Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/british-columbia-salmonella-outbreak-reported-in-pine-siskins-48868/The Wildlife Rescue Association of British Columbia [Canada] is reporting a salmonella outbreak in pine siskins.They say increased reports of sick and dying birds have been noted across the Pacific Northwest, from Oregon to British Columbia.Any bird can be impacted by _Salmonella, however, pine siskins seem to be most vulnerable. This is potentially due to their social nature, flocking, and feeding in close association with each other making it easy for the disease to be passed from bird to bird.In 2020, 127 pine siskins were admitted, which is a 13-fold increase from what we saw in the last 2 years. In December [2020] alone, 75 pine siskins were admitted and suspected to be infected with _Salmonella_.Since the New Year began [2121], 36 pine siskins suspected of _Salmonella_ poisoning have been brought in, and more are coming in every day.Salmonellosis is primarily transmitted by fecal contamination of food and water by sick birds, although it can also be transmitted through bird-to-bird contact. High traffic spots, such as bird feeders, create a source point of transmission and can exacerbate the spread of this deadly disease. Removing the feeders completely is the best solution to encourage birds to disperse, thereby minimizing the potential for infection. If you choose to keep your feeders up, they must be properly maintained to foster a healthy bird environment.--Communicated by: ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[It would be important to know which strain of _Salmonella_ is implicated, as that determines its zoonotic potential or the risk to domestic animals. A common _Salmonella_ isolated from passerine birds is _S. enterica_ serovar Typhimurium which can cause diarrhea in humans and livestock.Being gregarious, siskins are particularly susceptible to contagion. For a picture of a pine siskin (_Spinus pinus_) go to https://www.allaboutbirds.org/guide/assets/photo/67276581-720px.jpg. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of the Pacific Northwest in the United States and Canada: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8091844,68029] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map:Kosice, Kosicky, Slovakia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8087952,57643][The following information comes from the European Commission's Animal Disease website section on avian influenza, available at https://ec.europa.eu/food/animals/animal-diseases/control-measures/avian-influenza_en (accessed on 9 Jan 2021).Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in 2020"During 2020, 2 distinct epidemic seasons of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) were observed in the European Union. The 1st HPAI epidemic season started on 31 Dec 2019, with the 1st outbreak in poultry confirmed in Poland. A new HPAI virus of subtype H5N8 (2020) was involved in the outbreak. By March [2020], the disease was confirmed in Poland, Czechia, Germany, Hungary, Slovakia, and Romania. The H5N8 (2020) subtype of the HPAI virus was responsible for all of these outbreaks. The most affected Member State was Hungary, after the virus entered in the area with a high density of duck and geese holdings. Outbreaks of HPAI were also detected in Bulgaria between March and June 2020, but the virus involved was of subtype H5N8, which also circulated in Bulgaria in 2018-2019. The last outbreak in poultry related to the 1st epidemic season of HPAI was confirmed on 5 Jun 2020."Only 3 wild birds were found infected with HPAI during the 1st half of 2020 (in Germany and Poland). The virus involved was the same as the one detected in the poultry farms."The 2nd HPAI epidemic season started at the end of October 2020 when the 1st cases were reported in wild birds in the Netherlands. Again, the 1st HPAI virus detected was of H5N8 subtype, different from the one that circulated in the 1st half of the year [2020]. Since then and until the end of 2020, a high number of dead and sick wild birds, mostly of migratory species, were found to be infected with HPAI viruses of subtypes H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, and H5N3 being detected by several EU countries and the United Kingdom. The largest number of cases in wild birds were reported in the northern part of Germany, in Denmark, and in the Netherlands. Between October and end of December 2020, the disease was also confirmed in poultry in Croatia, Denmark, France, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Poland, Sweden, and the United Kingdom."See the map with the distribution of the HPAI detected during 2020, separated by epidemic season [at https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/ad_control-measures_hapai_chrono_2020_map.pdf].HPAI- Latest developments 2021"The HPAI epidemic season, which started in October 2020, will continue in 2021. Outbreaks and cases in wild birds continued to be confirmed by several EU countries. This map [from 1 Oct 2020 to 5 Jan 2021, https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/ad_control-measures_hapai_chrono_2021_map.pdf] represents the distribution of the HPAI detections." - Mod.CRD] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-01-08 18:01:56 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (05): Senegal (TH) poultry, HPAI H5N1, 1st rep, OIE Archive Number: 20210108.8085504AVIAN INFLUENZA (05): SENEGAL (THIES) POULTRY, HPAI H5N1, FIRST REPORT, OIE***************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 7 Jan 2021Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2021; 34(01) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37472Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Senegal------------------------------------------Information received on 7 Jan 2021 from Dr. Mbargou Lo, Director of Veterinary Services, Directorate of Veterinary Services, Ministry of Livestock and Animal Productions, Dakar, SenegalSummaryReport type: Immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 23 Dec 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 30 Dec 2020Report date: 6 Jan 2021Date submitted to OIE: 7 Jan 2021Reason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease in the countryCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N1Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsyThis event pertains a defined zone within the whole country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Ndiakhat, Pout, ThiesDate of start of the outbreak: 23 Dec 2020Outbreak status: Resolved on 7 Jan 2021Epidemiological unit: FarmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 100 000 / 58 000 / 58 000 / 42 000 / 0Affected population: Layers whose age range is between [9-18] months and [18-24] months. Poultry are kept in closed buildings with an automatic feed and water supply system. The poultry farm is located away from households.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 58 / 58 / 100 / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: The disease was detected by the farm manager on 23 Dec 2020, through a drop in water consumption and the recording of high fatalities. The morbidity and mortality rates are 58% and the lethality rate is 100%. The main clinical signs observed are oedema, cyanosis, congestion of the crests and barbs and prostration.Control measuresMeasures applied: Movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; quarantine; official destruction of animals products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; control of wildlife reservoirs; disinfection; process to inactivate the pathogenic agent in products or by-products; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: TraceabilityDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultDakar National Laboratory for Livestock and Veterinary Research (LNERV) (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 30 Dec 2021 / PositiveDakar National Laboratory for Livestock and Veterinary Research (LNERV) (national laboratory) / Birds / RRT-PCR / 30 Dec 2021 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[This is the 1st time that Senegal reports highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI). HPAI subtype H5N1 is endemic in some countries of the African continent.The following information comes from a scientific article titled "Evolution of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry, Togo, 2018," published December 2019 in the Emerging Infectious Diseases journal by the CDC:"In 2015, highly pathogenic avian influenza A(H5N1) viruses reemerged in poultry in West Africa. We describe the introduction of a reassortant clade 2.3.2.1c virus into Togo in April 2018. Our findings signal further local spread and evolution of these viruses, which could affect animal and human health."Relatively little is known about the emergence, prevalence, and circulation of animal influenza viruses in Africa. Highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 clade 2.2 viruses emerged in Africa in 2006 (cases were reported from Egypt, Nigeria, Cote d'Ivoire, Benin, Togo, Ghana, Sudan, Djibouti, and Cameroon), although the virus was only maintained long term in Egypt. We conducted surveillance in domestic poultry in Cote d'Ivoire, Benin, and Togo during 2008-2010 but were unable to find virologic or serologic evidence for influenza A virus circulation. Several factors, such as type of hosts, climate, and animal density, might have provided unfavorable conditions for the virus' circulation in the region."In early 2015, HPAI H5N1 viruses of clade 2.3.2.1c were reported in Nigeria, followed closely by detections in Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Niger, Cameroon, and Togo. These viruses could be clustered into 2 genetic subgroups; cluster WA1 viruses were detected in Ghana, Burkina Faso, Cote d'Ivoire, Nigeria, and Niger, and cluster WA2 viruses were detected in Niger, Cote d'Ivoire, and Nigeria. In this study, we aimed to determine the origin and evolution of HPAI A(H5N1) viruses responsible for poultry outbreaks in Togo in April 2018 in the context of viruses from surrounding countries."Reference:Fusade-Boyer M, Pato PS, Komlan M, et al. Evolution of Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza A(H5N1) Virus in Poultry, Togo, 2018. Emerg Infect Dis. 2019; 25(12): 2287-9. https://dx.doi.org/10.3201/eid2512.190054- Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Thies, Senegal: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8085504,44501] See Also

It is divided into 12 buildings (1-12) that forms 7 separate epidemiological units. Each epidemiological unit has its own staff with strict biosecurity including a considerable distance between the units. Symtoms (high mortality) have only been seen in house 7, which forms an epidemiological unit with house 8.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 1.08 / 1.08 / 100 / 1.08*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: A protection zone (3 km) [approx. 1.8 mi] and a surveillance zone (10 km) [approx. 6.2 mi] have been put in place around the establishment. All the poultry in this epidemiological unit (house 7 and 8) will be euthanized. All other restrictions and necessary measures according to Directive 2005/94/EG are/will be applied, including a prohibition of transportation of live birds, hatching eggs and not heat-treated poultry products in this area.Control measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: Official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultNational Veterinary Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time PCR / 3 Jan 2021 / PositiveNational Veterinary Institute (national laboratory) / Birds / Virus sequencing / 3 Jan 2021 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED	<promed@promedmail.org>[According to the information provided to the OIE, in 2020 Sweden reported 2 events associated to HPAI subtype H5N8. View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2021-01-05 11:17:15 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Die-off, avian - India: (HP) migratory waterbird, avian influenza susp. Archive Number: 20210105.8072963DIE-OFF, AVIAN - INDIA: (HIMACHAL PRADESH) MIGRATORY WATERBIRD, AVIAN INFLUENZA SUSPECTED*****************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 4 Jan 2020 04:50:01 PM ISTSource: Daiji World, Indo Asian News Service (IANS) report [edited]http://www.daijiworld.com/news/newsDisplay.aspx?newsID=787881With the toll of migratory waterbirds rising to over 1800, and almost half of them being endangered bar-headed goose visiting the Pong wetlands, the Himachal Pradesh wildlife authorities on Monday [4 Jan 2021] suspected avian influenza as the cause.Chief Conservator Wildlife of Pong wetlands -- one of the largest in northern India, Upasna Patyal, said the reason for the deaths is still a mystery. Their carcasses have been sent to different laboratories to determine the cause of death."The death of birds could be attributed to bird flu. We are expecting to get results by Tuesday evening [5 Jan 2020]. As a protocol, we have imposed prohibitory orders," she said.The local administration has already sounded an alert by banning all human activities within a 10-km [6.2-mi] radius of the Pong wetlands in Kangra district.The bird flu can spread to human beings and turn fatal.Besides the bar-headed goose, the other species were the shoveler, the river tern, the black-headed gull, and the common teal.Some birds -- including the bar-headed goose -- were seen acting strangely before their deaths, she said. "When you're seeing that birds are not able to take the flight despite healthy wings, it's really disturbing. At some distance, you find their carcasses," she said.The bird carcasses were sent to the Indian Veterinary Research Institute in Bareilly, the Regional Disease Diagnostic Laboratory in Jalandhar, and the Wildlife Institute of India in Dehradun to know their cause of death.The Rajasthan government last week [week of 28 Dec 2020] sounded an alert after confirmation of avian influenza in crows that died in Jhalawar district. Indore in Madhya Pradesh has also reported the death of crows.The mass mortality of poultry birds was reported at one of the largest poultry belt at Barwala near Panchkula in Haryana.According to the Bird Count India, a partnership comprising organizations and groups, over the past 7-10 days there have been reports of wild birds dying in separate incidents at different locations in the country.That wild bird die-off is not necessarily worrying. But it is possible that some of these recent deaths are out of the ordinary, with large numbers dying or reports of diagnoses of H5N1 (avian influenza).At the moment, no-one knows whether these are causes of larger concern, but it is worth keeping an eye on the situation. "If you encounter a wild bird that is dead or dying, do not approach it, and under any circumstances do not touch it given the possibility (however small) that it might be infected with avian influenza. H5N1 is a highly contagious virus that can cause severe illness in people," it warned.Sensing the gravity of the situation, Nature Conservation Foundation (NCF) scientist KS Gopi Sundar told IANS that it's something an alarming situation."We are getting reports of the deaths of birds in nature across India. It's likely to be a disease because the deaths are occurring in multiple locations involving multiple species. It is a dangerous situation and needs multi-stakeholder intervention on priority," he said.At the Pong wetlands, preliminary findings of their post mortem have ruled out poisoning as the cause of their death, wildlife officials said.Every winter, the Pong wetlands are home to over 100 000 birds of nearly 114 species. Among them the bar-headed goose, the northern pintail, the Eurasian coot, the common teal, the common pochard, the northern shoveler, the great cormorant, the Eurasian wigeon, and the ruddy shelduck are notable.According to the Bombay Natural History Society (BNHS), the Pong wetlands are the one wintering grounds in the globe to hold such a large congregation of bar-headed geese.Most of the wetlands in India have been regularly getting bar-headed geese every winter. But Pong is the only habitat that holds the largest influx of bar-headed geese every winter, a BNHS ornithologist told IANS.[Byline: Anthony Janzen]--Communicated by:ProMED from HealthMap Alerts<promed@promedmail.org>[Bar-headed geese (_Anser indicus_) breed in central Asia in colonies of thousands (see picture at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bar-headed_goose#/media/File:Bar-headed_geese.jpg.). On 30 Apr 2005, an outbreak of highly pathogenic H5N1 influenza was detected in a large group of this species in Qinghai lake in western China. The diseased geese showed paralysis, unusual head tilt, staggering, and neck thrill. About 3000 geese died. Brown-headed and black-headed gulls and cormorants also died in that episode. Qinghai lake is a major stop-over of the Central Asian Flyway. Bar-headed geese and other wildfowl migrate south to winter as far south as India. - Mod.PMBMaps of India: http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm and https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8072963,304] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[As was mentioned in the latest OIE situation report for Avian influenza (24 Dec 2020) "the H5N8 virus has also reassorted with other wild bird influenza viruses to form new strains of H5N5 and H5N1 HPAI virus." Source: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) Report No. 19: 4 to 24 Dec 2020. World Organization for Animal Health - OIE https://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/HPAI_asof24122020.pdf. The fact that HPAI subtypes H5N8, H5N5, H5N3, and H5N1 currently circulating in the European continent have been detected in wild birds is very indicative that these viruses are being distributed wherever these wild birds migrate. Poultry producers, small and large alike, must therefore implement all the biosecurity measures necessary to protect their flocks from exposure and infection. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Slovenia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8070826,115] See Also
