Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED<promed@promedmail.org>[The latest OIE situation report for Avian influenza (24 Dec 2020) mentions that "In Europe, the 1st outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 were reported in August 2020 in Russia in both poultry and wild birds. Since then, a new wave of epizootic outbreaks of H5N8 [has] been continuously reported in several European countries especially in wild birds, but also in poultry starting from mid-October [2020]. The H5N8 virus has also reassorted with other wild bird influenza viruses to form new strains of H5N5 and H5N1 HPAI virus, which were also reported by countries. A similar situation of H5N8 epizootics associated with wild bird migration occurred in 2016/17. A few Asian countries also reported HPAI H5N8 outbreaks in poultry and/or wild birds. It is more likely that the source of introduction in these outbreaks is through migratory wild birds and onward local spread. Report of increased number of outbreaks in wild birds [indicates] periods of heightened risk in countries due to migratory flyways during this season. Consequently, improving on-farm biosecurity measures is a priority to reduce the likelihood of exposure to poultry." Source: Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) Report No. 19: December 4 to December 24, 2020. See details of outbreaks and updated map at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000037316_20201228_142527.pdfOn 28 Dec 2020, a second outbreak was also reported in Kiev, see follow-up report No.1 at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000037331_20201228_190831.pdfTyping of the viral neuraminidase for the current event and for the one reported on 2 Dec 2020 has not yet been reported. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Kiev, Ukraine: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8055805,1892] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-12-29 05:53:36 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (119): Germany (SN) poultry, HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20201229.8053392AVIAN INFLUENZA (119): GERMANY (SAXONY) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, OIE***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 25 Dec 2020Source: OIE, WAHIS [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37308Information received on [and dated] 25 Dec 2020 from Dr Dietrich Rassow, director for animal health and animal welfare, chief veterinary officer, Directorate of Animal Health and Animal Welfare, Federal Ministry of Food and Agriculture, Berlin, GermanySummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 24 Dec 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 25 Dec 2020Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 1 Feb 2017Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced)This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak 1 (20-015-00513): Grimma, Leipzig, Sachsen [Saxony]Date of start of the outbreak: 24 Dec 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 9000 / 75 / 75 / 0 / 0Affected population: Geese for breeding. Highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8 confirmed.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 0.83 / 0.83 / 100 / 0.83*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; control of wildlife reservoirs; zoning; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Unfortunately, HPAI continues to spread in Germany.HPAI subtype H5N3 has been isolated from wild birds, and subtypes H5N8 and H5N5 have been isolated from both domestic poultry and wild birds. The outbreaks have occurred in the states of Bavaria, Berlin, Brandenburg, Bremen, Hamburg, Hesse, Lower Saxony, Mecklenburg-West Pomerania, North Rhine-Westphalia, Saxony, and Schleswig-Holstein. Coastal areas more affected than other areas.A detailed overview as of 23 Dec 2020 on the situation in EU member states and the adopted measures is given in the document "Chronology of Main Events", available at https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/ad_control-measures_hapai_chrono_2020.pdf: "This document summarizes basic information on the outbreaks of avian influenza (AI) in several EU member states and related EU action. It focuses on the animal health aspects."A map of HPAI outbreaks confirmed in different EU member states and in the UK can be seen at https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/ad_control-measures_hapai_chrono_2020_map.pdf (latest update 23 Dec 2020). - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Saxony, Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8053392,4206] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-12-27 12:31:07 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (08): China (HN) H5N6, new case Archive Number: 20201227.8043141AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (08): CHINA (HUNAN) H5N6, NEW CASE*********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: 22 Dec 2020Source: Xinhua [machine trans. edited]https://www.yicai.com/news/100885613.htmlAccording to the Hunan Provincial Center for Disease Control and Prevention, on the evening of 21 Dec 2020, a human case of H5N6 avian influenza was confirmed in Ningyuan County, Yongzhou City, Hunan Province. The patient is currently receiving treatment, and his vital signs are stable. Local live poultry trading has been suspended from 20 Dec 2020.It is understood that the patient contracted the disease at a live poultry trading market in Ningyuan County. He was sampled on 19 Dec 2020 by the Yongzhou CDC for H5N6 avian influenza virus nucleic acid testing, and the result was positive. Currently, the patient is being treated in an ICU ward of a hospital in Ningyuan County. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he is still on a ventilator.From 20 Dec 2020, live poultry trading in all farmers' markets in Ningyuan County will be suspended. At present, Ningyuan County has completed cleanup and elimination of the 8 major farmer's markets in the county and 44 farmer's markets in towns. The relevant departments have monitored close contacts of the patient.According to disease control experts, H5N6 is a subtype of influenza virus. The source of the virus is poultry. There is no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[2]Date: Mon 21 Dec 2020Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-h5n6-avian-influenza-case-in-hunan-province-media-report-36622/The official state-run press agency of the People's Republic of China, Xinhua reported today [21 Dec 2020] a confirmed human case of H5N6 avian influenza [in] Ningyuan County, Yongzhou City, Hunan Province. It is believed the patient contracted the disease at a live poultry trading market in Ningyuan County.This is the 26th human H5N6 avian flu infection reported since 2014.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[With continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans.Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected.Even though there is no confirmation of the disease in poultry, other people with possible contact should be traced and followed up as well as those in contact with the human case to rule out the possibility of human-to-human transmission.As per the IHR (2005) decision instrument for the assessment and notification of events that may constitute a public health emergency of international concern, a case of human influenza caused by a new subtype is unusual or unexpected and may have serious public health impacts, and thus shall be notified to WHO (https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241580496). - Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map:Hunan Province, China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8043141,341] See Also

Yakage-Town 1; a dead _Falco peregrinus_ (Peregrine Falcon) was collected on [4 Dec 2020] and tested against avian influenza virus. Mitoyo-City 1; a dead _Buteo japonicus_ (Eastern buzzard) was collected on [8 Dec 2020] and tested against avian influenza virus. The Tottori University conducted RT-PCR and gene sequencing tests and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N8. Izumi-City 1; a dead _Grus monachal_ (Hooded crane) was collected on [18 Dec 2020] and tested against avian influenza virus. The Kagoshima University conducted RT-PCR and gene sequencing tests and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N8. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED map of Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8039475,67958The last outbreak assessment report no. 10 for the cases of HPAI in the UK and Europe, published on 21 Dec 2020 by DEFRA-APHA, mentions that "Since [15 Dec 2020] in the United Kingdom there have been 3 further outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 in poultry, including the first in Scotland, and an outbreak of HPAI H5N1 in poultry. There have also been many cases of HPAI H5N8 in wild birds, and smaller numbers of cases of HPAI H5N1 (2 reports) and HPAI H5N5 (6 reports) also in wild birds. Elsewhere in Europe, HPAI H5N8 has been reported in poultry in France and Poland. HPAI H5N8 in wild birds has been reported in Denmark, Germany, Italy, Norway, Poland, and Slovenia with HPAI H5N1 also in wild birds in Italy. HPAI H5Nx (N untyped) has been reported in poultry in the Netherlands, and in wild birds in the Netherlands and in France." The full report is available at https://tinyurl.com/ybmtxrn8.Maps of the HPAI cases detected in Germany and Europe from 1 Jul to 17 Dec 2020 can be seen at:https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_D/2020/Map_AI_D_2020-12-17.jpg and https://www.fli.de/fileadmin/FLI/Images/Tierseuchengeschehen/H5N8/Karten_EU/2020/Map_AI_EU_2020-12-17.jpg, respectively. - Mod.CRD] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-12-19 21:49:09 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (113): UK, poultry, captive bird, HPAI H5N8, spread, control Archive Number: 20201219.8031759AVIAN INFLUENZA (113): UK, POULTRY, CAPTIVE BIRD, HPAI H5N8, SPREAD, CONTROL****************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] HPAI H5N8, poultry, Orkney, Scotland[2] HPAI H5N8, poultry and captive birds, Derbyshire, England******[1] HPAI H5N8, poultry, Orkney, ScotlandDate: Fri 18 Dec 2020Source: BBC News [edited]https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-scotland-north-east-orkney-shetland-55360415A flock of chickens from an Orkney farm has been culled in Scotland's 1st serious case of bird flu since 2016. A 6-mile (10 km) control zone has been set up on the island of Sanday. Thirty-nine free-range laying chickens died of bird flu, and the 11 remaining birds in the affected flock were put down.The controls include restrictions on the movement of poultry, carcasses, eggs, used poultry litter and manure, and restrictions on bird gatherings.Scotland's Chief Veterinary Officer Sheila Voas said the risk to human health from the H5N8 Avian Influenza was very low.Bird keepers have been urged to comply with an order to house birds that came into effect on 14 Dec 2020.The last case of the H5N8 strain was found in a dead peregrine falcon in Dumfries and Galloway 4 years ago. Other less serious strains have been detected since then.Ms Voas said, "We have already made clear that all bird keepers -- whether major businesses or small keepers with just a few birds -- must ensure that their biosecurity is up to scratch to protect their birds from disease and prevent any contact between their birds and wild birds."Keepers who are concerned about the health or welfare of their flocks should seek veterinary advice immediately. Your private vet or local Animal and Plant Health Agency office will also be able to provide practical advice on keeping your birds safe from infection."Any dead wild swans, geese, ducks, or gulls; falcons or other birds of prey; or 5 or more dead wild birds of other species in the same location should be reported to the Defra dead wild bird helpline."She added that avian influenzas pose a very low food-safety risk for UK consumers, and it does not affect the consumption of poultry products including eggs.Because of the number of cases in Europe and in England, the risk of bird flu is currently judged to be very high for wild birds, high for poultry where there is poor biosecurity, and medium for poultry with protection measures in place.A number of swans were recently found dead near the Hampshire coast and on the Isle of Wight, and there were culls in Warwickshire and Worcestershire.Earlier cases have included 2 farms in Norfolk, East Anglia, and a wildlife centre in Gloucestershire. All 10 500 turkeys at a farm in North Yorkshire were culled following an outbreak.Rural Affairs Minister Mairi Gougeon said Scottish cases were not "unexpected" given the cases in wild and captive birds elsewhere in the UK. "We ask that the public remain vigilant and report any findings of dead wild birds," she added.NFU Scotland animal health policy manager Penny Middleton described it as "disappointing.""It is now a legal requirement for all bird keepers, whether they have one hen in the back garden or a large poultry business, to keep their birds indoors and to follow strict biosecurity measures to limit the spread of avian influenza and keep out the disease," she said. "It's crucial that everyone remains vigilant and reports any signs of disease -- both in domestic birds and in wild birds -- at the earliest opportunity."--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[A statement confirming the identity of the casual pathogen has been published on 18 Dec 2020 by the local Orcadian, citing an official announcement: "A flock of birds from a farm on Sanday has tested positive for H5N8 avian influenza. In order to limit the further spread of disease, appropriate restrictions have been imposed on the premises and any identified contact premises" (https://www.orcadian.co.uk/bird-flu-confirmed-in-orkney/). - Mod.AS]******[2] HPAI H5N8, poultry and captive birds, Derbyshire, EnglandDate: Tue 15 Dec 2020Source: FarmingUK [edited]https://www.farminguk.com/news/bird-flu-outbreak-in-poultry-at-premises-in-derbyshire_57203.htmlThe UK has recorded a 2nd outbreak of bird flu in a matter of days, after Defra today [Tue 15 Dec 2020] confirmed highly pathogenic avian influenza in poultry and captive birds at a premises in Derbyshire. Avian influenza, of the H5N8 subtype, has today (15 Dec 2020) been confirmed at a premises near Willington, Derbyshire. A 3 km [1.9 mi] protection zone and a 10 km [6.2 mi] surveillance zone have been put in place around to limit the risk of the disease spreading, Defra said.It comes after highly pathogenic bird flu was confirmed in captive birds at a non-poultry premises in Worcestershire on Sunday [13 Dec 2020].The news comes as mandatory housing measures were rolled out across the UK from yesterday [Mon 14 Dec 2020].It is now a legal requirement for all farmers and poultry keepers to keep their birds indoors following a string of outbreaks. They will need to follow strict biosecurity measures to limit the spread of avian influenza and eradicate the disease.The risk of incursion of bird flu is "very high" for wild birds, "medium" for poultry with high biosecurity, and "high" for poultry with poor biosecurity.A joint statement from Britain's 3 chief veterinary officers (CVOs) said, "Whether you keep just a few birds or thousands, from 14 Dec 2020 onwards, you will be legally required to keep your birds indoors. We have not taken this decision lightly, but it is the best way to protect your birds from this highly infectious disease."Just last week, outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza were confirmed at 2 turkey farms in Norfolk.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Since late November 2020, HPAI H5N8 has been reported to affect poultry and/or captive non-poultry birds as well as wild birds in numerous European countries. This includes France, Netherlands, Ireland, Belgium, Germany, Sweden, Slovenia, Croatia, and Poland. HPAI H5N8 has also been repeatedly reported from Israel, situated on main flyways of wild birds, migrating in the autumn months from their nesting grounds in Europe and Asia and to the wintering grounds in Africa.Subscribers are referred to Mod.CRD's commentary in 20201214.8018047. The abstract of an overview paper, cited in the said commentary, follows:"Between 15 Aug and 7 Dec 2020, 561 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus detections were reported in 15 EU/EEA countries and UK in wild birds, poultry, and captive birds, with Germany (n=370), Denmark (n=65), and the Netherlands (n=57) being the most affected countries. The majority of the detections have been reported in wild birds (n=510), primarily in barnacle goose, greylag goose, and Eurasian wigeon. Raptors have also been detected infected, particularly common buzzard. The majority of the birds had been found dead or moribund; however, there are also reports of HPAI virus infection in apparently healthy ducks or geese.A total of 43 HPAI outbreaks were notified in poultry, with signs of avian influenza infection being observed in at least 33 outbreaks; the most likely source of infection was indirect contact with wild birds. A total of 3 HPAI virus subtypes, A(H5N8) (n=518), A(H5N5) (n=17), and A(H5N1) (n=6), and 4 different genotypes were identified, suggesting the occurrence of multiple virus introductions into Europe. The reassortant A(H5N1) virus identified in EU/EEA countries has acquired gene segments from low-pathogenic viruses and is not related to A(H5N1) viruses of e.g., clade 2.3.2.1c causing human infections outside of Europe.As the autumn migration of wild waterbirds to their wintering areas in Europe continues, and given the expected local movements of these birds, there is still a high risk of introduction and further spread of HPAI A(H5) viruses within Europe. The risk of virus spread from wild birds to poultry is high, and Member States should enforce in "high risk areas" of their territories the measures provided for in Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2018/1136. Detection of outbreaks in breeder farms in Denmark, the Netherlands, and United Kingdom highlight also the risk of introduction via contaminated materials (bedding/straw) and equipment. Maintaining high and sustainable surveillance and biosecurity, particularly in high-risk areas, is of utmost importance. Two human cases due to zoonotic A(H5N1) and A(H9N2) avian influenza virus infection were reported during the reporting period. The risk for the general population as well as travel-related imported human cases are assessed as very low."Subscribers are encouraged to visit the full report; its citation follows:EFSA (European Food Safety Authority), ECDC (European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control), EURL (European Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza), Adlhoch C, Fusaro A, Gonzales JL, Kuiken T, Marangon S, Niqueux E, Staubach C, Terregino C, and Baldinelli F. Scientific report: Avian influenza overview August - December 2020. EFSA Journal. 2020; 18(12): 6379, 57 pp. doi: 10.2903/j.efsa.2020.6379.- Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:Orkney, Scotland, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8031759,6187Derbyshire, England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8031759,4229] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-12-18 17:47:13 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (112): UK, wild bird, HPAI H5N5 Archive Number: 20201218.8029519AVIAN INFLUENZA (112): UNITED KINGDOM, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N5***********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 15 Dec 2020 15:26 GMTSource: Wales News [edited]https://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/bird-flu-swans-geese-wales-19461000Bird flu has been reported in different animals in 2 parts of Wales as a high alert warning has been issued across the UK.Newport City Council posted that wild geese and swans in the city had tested positive for the "highly pathogenic avian influenza HPAI H5N5". The Department of Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (Defra) has also said a case has been reported in the past week [7-13 Dec 2020] in a little grebe, a type of water bird, in Carmarthenshire.Nearly 150 cases have been reported across the UK since the beginning of November [2020], prompting advice to the general public and bird owners. One of the largest outbreaks was reported this week at a wild bird rescue centre near Droitwich Spa in Worcestershire on 13 Dec 2020. All birds on the premises had to be humanely culled.The risk level has been increased to "very high" for wild birds and "medium" level for poultry. Anyone who sees a dead bird is asked not to touch it -- and if you see a dead or visibly sick bird, particularly swans, geese, ducks, gulls or birds of prey, they should be reported to Defra through 03459 335577.Anyone who keeps birds must now keep them inside, as new rules are in place due to the increased number of cases across both England and Wales. Bird keepers must also follow strict biosecurity measures. The rules have been tightened after Defra issued a warning in November [2020] about bird flu potentially being on the rise.The risk to public health is said to be very low, and the Food Standards Agency said that on the basis of current scientific evidence it posed a very low safety risk for UK consumers. Defra has also pointed out that avian flu is not linked to coronavirus.[Byline: Cathy Owen]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Currently, HPAI viruses appear to be propagating quickly in Europe. During the epidemic of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 virus in Europe in 2016-2017, HPAI viruses of subtype H5N5 were also isolated, although in a more limited number. Experiments in primary chicken and duck cells revealed only minor differences in cytopathogenicity and replication kinetics between H5N5 genotypes and H5N8. Results of a recent study by Bergervoet et al. (1) led to the conclusion that the limited spread and the differences in geographical distribution of HPAI H5N5 viruses compared with H5N8 are related to the timing of the reassortment events and introduction into Europe rather than changes in virus pathogenicity or replication kinetics. However, a similar scenario is observed this year (2020), so other explanations might be operating. - Mod.PMBReference1. Bergervoet SA, Ho CKY, Heutink R, et al. Spread of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N5 viruses in Europe in 2016-2017 appears related to the timing of reassortment events. Viruses. 2019; 11(6): 501. https://doi.org/10.3390/v11060501HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8029519,40] See Also

/ 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Affected population: One highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus has been detected on [4 Dec 2020] in a wigeon (_Mareca penelope_) sampled after being shot in a hunting area.Outbreak location 2: [Valle Figheri, Campagna Lupia, Venezia, Veneto]Date of start of the outbreak: 4 Dec 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: otherAffected animalsSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredCommon teal: _Anas crecca_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0Affected population: One highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus was detected on [4 Dec 2020] in a captured common teal (_Anas crecca_) sampled intra vitam.Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 2Total animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredWigeons: _Mareca penelope_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Common teal: _Anas crecca_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 0 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: One highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N1 virus belonging to the 2.3.4.4 B clade has been detected in a wigeon (_Mareca penelope_) sampled after being shot in a hunting area in the province of Venezia (Valle Drago, Jesolo) and in a common teal (_Anas crecca_) sampled intra vitam after being captured in the province of Venezia (Valle Figheri, Campagna Lupia). The HA sequence is closely related to those of HPAI strains currently circulating in Northern Europe. Characterization of the full genome is in progress.Control measuresMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (national laboratory) / common teal / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Dec 2020 / positiveExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (national laboratory) / wigeons / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 10 Dec 2020 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Venezia, Veneto, Italy: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8025563,6323]*****[5] Italy (Rovingo-Veneto): wild bird, HPAI H5N5Date: Wed 16 Dec 2020Source: OIE, WAHIS (World Animal Health Information System), weekly disease information 2020 [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=37139Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Italy-------------------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 16 Dec 2020 from Dr Davide Lecchini, Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate General for Veterinary Health and Veterinary Medicinal Products (DGSAF), Ministry of Health, Rome, ItalySummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 28 Nov 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 4 Dec 2020Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 21 Mar 2017Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] A virusSerotype: H5N5Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced), necropsyThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (1)Outbreak location 1: [Valle Chiusa, Porto Tolle, Venezia, Veneto]Date of start of the outbreak: 28 Nov 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: otherTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredCommon teal: _Anas crecca_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Affected population: One virus among those detected in common teals (_Anas crecca_) has been characterized as the H5N5 subtype.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: Highly pathogenic influenza H5 viruses belonging to the 2.3.4.4 B clade have been detected in 5 common teals (_Anas crecca_), 2 wigeons (_Mareca penelope_), and one mallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_) sampled after being shot in a hunting area in the province of Rovigo (Valle Chiusa, Porto Tolle). The HA sequences of these viruses are closely related to those of HPAI strains currently circulating in Northern Europe. Characterization of the full genome is in progress.Control measuresMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (national laboratory) / common teal / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Dec 2020 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[HealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Porto Tolle, Veneto, Italy: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8025563,58564][Unfortunately, HPAI continues to spread in Europe. The fact that HPAI subtypes H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 currently circulating in the European continent have been detected in wild birds is indicative that these viruses spread wherever these wild birds migrate. Poultry producers, small and large alike, must implement all the biosecurity measures necessary to protect their flocks from exposure and infection.A map of the cases of HPAI outbreaks confirmed in different EU Member States and in the UK can be seen at https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/animals/docs/ad_control-measures_hapai_chrono_2020_map.pdf (latest update 9 Dec 2020)."As the autumn migration of wild waterbirds to their wintering areas in Europe continues, and given the expected local movements of these birds, there is still a high risk of introduction and further spread of HPAI A(H5) viruses within Europe. The risk of virus spread from wild birds to poultry is high, and Member States should enforce in 'high risk areas' of their territories the measures provided for in Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2018/1136." Source: European Food Safety Authority, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and European Union Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza. https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/sites/default/files/documents/avian-influenza-overview-august-december-2020_0.pdf. - Mod.CRD] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-12-15 20:07:28 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (110): poultry, HPAI, Japan, H5, South Korea (CN) H5N8, spread Archive Number: 20201215.8021132AVIAN INFLUENZA (110): POULTRY, HPAI, JAPAN, H5, SOUTH KOREA (SOUTH JEOLLA) H5N8, SPREAD****************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgIn this update:[1] Japan, HPAI H5, poultry[2] Korea, HPAI H5N8, poultry******[1] Japan, HPAI H5, poultryDate: Mon 14 Dec 2020Source: Singapore Food Agency [abridged, edited]https://www.sfa.gov.sg/docs/default-source/default-document-library/2020-12-14_trade-circular---hpai-outbreak-in-oita-wakayama-okayama-and-shiga-prefecture-japan.pdfJapan has reported outbreaks of H5 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in poultry [in the following municipalities/prefectures, namely in] Saeki city, Oita prefecture [date of confirmation, 10 Dec 2020], Kinokawa city, Wakayama prefecture [date of confirmation, 10 Dec 2020], Mimasaka city, Okayama prefecture [date of confirmation, 11 Dec 2020], and Higashiomi city, Shiga prefecture [date of confirmation, 13 Dec 2020].--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org> [The said information was included in a circular distributed by Singapore's Food Safety Agency to local meat and egg traders addressing import restrictions. Additional information on the outbreak in Mimasaka (in the western Japan prefecture of Okayama), is available athttps://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20201211/p2a/00m/0na/018000c. This event led to the culling of some 640 000 chickens kept at the farm. The prefectural government has issued movement restrictions forbidding poultry farms within a 3-km radius of the infection site from transporting chickens or eggs outside their facilities and is also restricting poultry farms within a 10-km radius from taking their chickens and eggs outside that sphere.Since submitting to the OIE on 6 Nov 2020 its immediate notification on the H5 avian influenza event that reportedly had started in the Kagawa prefecture on 4 Nov 2020 (20201109.7928569), Japan has submitted 3 follow-up reports, the most recent one on 18 Nov 2020. All came from the same prefecture. The causative agent was reported to be HPAI H5N8. Links to all said reports, addressing the 1st 5 outbreaks, and an interactive map presenting their locations as of 18 Nov 2020, are available at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=36435.The event's summary as of 18 Nov 2020 is as follows:Total outbreaks = 5 (submitted)Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 478 000 / 2068 / 2068 / 475 932 / 0It is likely that the 2 additional outbreaks in Kagawa reported on 20 Nov 2020 (20201122.7962047) as well as later events from additional prefectures in Japan addressed in the above circular from Singapore have been caused by the same HPAI H5N8 virus strain, but this is subject to confirmation. In case confirmed, they were/are expected to be officially notified.The virus is suspected to have been introduced into Japan from the continent by migrating birds, signaling the migration season. - Mod.AS]******[2] Korea, HPAI H5N8, poultryDate: Sat 5 Dec 2020Source: Yonhap News Agency [edited]https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20201205002200315South Korea confirmed another case of highly pathogenic avian influenza (AI) at a duck farm in a southern county on Saturday [5 Dec 2020], putting quarantine authorities on high alert.The latest case was reported at a duck meat farm in South Jeolla Province's Yeongam County, 308 km south of Seoul, according to the provincial government. It marks the 3rd highly pathogenic AI case reported at a poultry house this year [2020] and the 1st such case confirmed in South Jeolla Province in 3 years.Having blocked access to the affected farm and culled its ducks, local authorities plan to cull nearly 500 000 ducks and chickens in 10 nearby farms within a 3-km radius as a precautionary measure, the regional government said.The municipality also designated the areas within a 10-km radius of the infected farm, which house 44 duck and chicken farms, as a special zone subject to heightened quarantine.Movement of poultry to and from poultry farms in South Jeolla province has also been prohibited for 30 days.Local quarantine authorities launched an epidemiological investigation into the affected area to trace the source of the latest AI case."The initial infection source (of the latest case) has yet to be found, as no report of suspected infection or symptoms has been filed by other farms in nearby areas," an official at the regional government said. "We elevated the quarantine level to the highest to curb the spread."Since South Korea recorded the 1st outbreak of highly pathogenic AI in 32 months in late October 2020 in Cheonan, 92 km south of Seoul, more than 10 cases have been additionally confirmed, putting quarantine authorities on high alert against potential mass outbreaks.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>[The above outbreak in ducks was notified to the OIE in follow-up report No. 1, submitted on 5 Dec 2020 (outbreak No. 2 in the report, which addresses also another, distant outbreak in poultry). The report is available, with an interactive map showing both outbreaks, at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36888. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED maps:Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8021132,156South Korea: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8021132,195] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-12-15 15:59:06 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (07): China (JS) H5N6 Archive Number: 20201215.8016080AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (07): CHINA (JIANGSU) H5N6*************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[1]Date: Sat 12 Dec 2020Source: Outbreak News Today [edited]http://outbreaknewstoday.com/china-reports-h5n6-avian-influenza-death-in-jiangsu-province-76848/Chinese health authorities report a human case of avian influenza A(H5N6) in an 81-year-old female farmer from Changzhou of Jiangsu Province.The individual had exposure to live chickens at home prior to developing symptoms on [16 Nov 2020]. She was hospitalized and subsequently passed away on [27 Nov 2020].From 2014 to date, 25 human cases of avian influenza A(H5N6) have been reported by the Chinese health authorities.Avian influenza is caused by those influenza viruses that mainly affect birds and poultry, such as chickens or ducks.The clinical presentation of avian influenza in humans includes eye infection (conjunctivitis), flu-like symptoms (such as fever, cough, sore throat, muscle aches) or severe respiratory illness (such as chest infection). The incubation period ranges from 7 to 10 days.The more virulent forms can result in respiratory failure, multi-organ failure, and even death. People mainly become infected with avian influenza virus through contact with infected birds and poultry (live or dead) or their droppings, or contact with contaminated environments (such as wet markets and live poultry markets). Human-to-human transmission is inefficient.People in close contact with poultry are more susceptible to contracting avian influenza. The elderly, children, and people with chronic illness have a higher risk of developing complications such as bronchitis and chest infection.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[2]Date: Fri 11 Dec 2020 21:46 HKTSource: RTHK [in Chinese, trans., edited]https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/ch/component/k2/1564874-20201211.htmThe Centre for Health Protection is closely monitoring a new case of human infection with avian influenza [AI] H5N6 in the Mainland. The patient was an 81-year-old female farmer in Changzhou City, Jiangsu Province. Before she developed symptoms on [16 Nov 2020], she had contact with live chickens at home and died on [27 Nov 2020] after admission.The spokesperson said that since 2014, the Mainland health authorities have reported a total of 25 cases of human infection with avian influenza H5N6, reminding the public to avoid visiting wet markets, live poultry markets, or farms if they go to the Mainland or other affected areas. If you return to Hong Kong from the affected area, you should seek medical advice immediately if you develop symptoms.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[China's 1st H5N6 strain was isolated in March 2014 from a domestic duck in Guangdong Province. Since then, the H5 subtype has gradually become the main cause of the sporadic AIV infections in poultry in southern China. To date, a total of 24 laboratory-confirmed cases (excluding the case above) of human infection with influenza A(H5N6) virus, including 7 deaths at the time of the IHR (International Health Regulations) report, have been reported to WHO from China since 2014 (https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20201204.pdf)Epidemiological investigations have confirmed that most cases of H5N6 human infection had contact with infected poultry. Live poultry markets (LPMs) and backyard poultry flocks (BPFs) are 2 major risk factors for human infections. It had also been noticed that in many provinces, human infections of AIVs decreased gradually after closing LPMs.Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments. Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected.With continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans.Surveillance should be continued to detect human cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of the viruses. For more information on confirmed cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5) virus reported to WHO, visit http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/en/.For the WHO avian influenza monthly risk assessments visit http://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/HAI_Risk_Assessment/en/. - Mod.UBAMaps of China: https://www.chinadiscovery.com/china-maps/china-provincial-map.html and https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8016080,31232] See Also

control of wildlife reservoirs; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: No other measuresDiagnostic test resultsFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (FLI) (national laboratory)Species / Test / Test date / ResultCygnus (unidentified) / Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 10 Dec 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The following abstract comes from a scientific report on Avian influenza overview August - December 2020, published on 11 Dec 2020, which is available below:Abstract"Between 15 August and 7 December 2020, 561 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus detections were reported in 15 EU/EEA countries and UK in wild birds, poultry and captive birds, with Germany (n=370), Denmark (n=65), the Netherlands (n=57) being the most affected countries. The majority of the detections have been reported in wild birds (n=510), primarily in barnacle goose, greylag goose, and Eurasian wigeon. Raptors have also been detected infected, particularly common buzzard. The majority of the birds had been found dead or moribund, however, there are also reports of HPAI virus infection in apparently healthy ducks or geese. A total of 43 HPAI outbreaks were notified in poultry; with signs of avian influenza infection being observed in at least 33 outbreaks; the most likely source of infection was indirect contact with wild birds. A total of 3 HPAI virus subtypes, A(H5N8) (n=518), A(H5N5) (n=17) and A(H5N1) (n=6), and 4 different genotypes were identified, suggesting the occurrence of multiple virus introductions into Europe. The reassortant A(H5N1) virus identified in EU/EEA countries has acquired gene segments from low pathogenic viruses and is not related to A(H5N1) viruses of e.g. clade 2.3.2.1c causing human infections outside of Europe. As the autumn migration of wild waterbirds to their wintering areas in Europe continues, and given the expected local movements of these birds, there is still a high risk of introduction and further spread of HPAI A(H5) viruses within Europe. The risk of virus spread from wild birds to poultry is high and Member States should enforce in 'high risk areas' of their territories the measures provided for in Commission Implementing Decision (EU) 2018/1136. Detection of outbreaks in breeder farms in Denmark, the Netherlands and United Kingdom, highlight also the risk of introduction via contaminated materials (bedding/straw) and equipment. Maintaining high and sustainable surveillance and biosecurity, particularly in high-risk areas is of utmost importance. Two human cases due to zoonotic A(H5N1) and A(H9N2) avian influenza virus infection were reported during the reporting period. The risk for the general population as well as travel-related imported human cases are assessed as very low".ReferenceEuropean Food Safety Authority, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and European Union Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail	<promed@promedmail.org>[The following information on Avian Influenza affecting poultry farms in the Netherlands in 2020 was published on 7 Dec 2020 by the Wageningen University and Research: "Bird flu (H5) has been diagnosed at laying hen farm in Den Bommel, the Netherlands, by Wageningen Bioveterinary Research. It probably concerns low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI). There are no other poultry farms within the 1-km (0.63 mi) zone of this farm. To prevent the virus from spreading, the farm is culled by the Dutch Food and Consumer Product Safety Authority (NVWA). In total, this concerns approximately 25 000 animals.Low pathogenic bird flu is less infectious than highly pathogenic bird flu. However, the serotypes H5 and H7 of low pathogenic avian influenza can mutate into a highly pathogenic virus. Therefore, strict measures must be taken.In the 10-km (6.2 mi) zone around this farm the transport ban applies. This ban covers poultry, eggs, poultry manure and used bedding, as well as other animals and certain products from commercial poultry companies". The complete article and an updated outbreak map of Avian influenza in the Netherlands are available at https://www.wur.nl/en/Research-Results/Research-Institutes/Bioveterinary-Research/show-bvr/Bird-flu-at-poultry-farms.htm. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8017821,104] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The 1st case of HPAI subtype H5N8 was reported from China (Liaoning province) on 24 Oct 2014 (see reports below).In 2017, 2 cases of HPAI H5N8 were reported in Hubei and Shanxi provinces. The affected population was wild birds. See event summary and map at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=22407Wild birds can normally carry avian influenza viruses in their respiratory or intestinal tracts but they do not commonly get sick. They have historically been known as reservoirs and vectors of AI viruses. Around the world, surveillance measures have been put in place to monitor occurrence and characteristics of AI viruses in wild birds. Avian influenza viruses do not cause disease in wild birds, but it is very likely that wild birds might spread the virus via their migratory flyways. National authorities are strongly encouraged to raise awareness and establish cooperation mechanisms with hunters and other individuals who may come into contact with wild birds in order to provide early information on sick or dead wild birds.Source: OIE Avian Influenza Portal https://www.oie.int/animal-health-in-the-world/avian-influenza-portal/what-is-avian-influenza/. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of China: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=8003821,67930] See Also

The municipality is located in a wetland area considered as being at particular risk with regard to avian influenza linked to migration corridors.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Brent Goose: _Branta bernicla_ (Anatidae)/ ** / ** / 100 / ***Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter**Not calculated because of missing informationEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: animal in transit, contact with wild speciesEpidemiological comments: The first-line diagnosis limited to the M protein was confirmed by the national reference laboratory by a rapid, unofficial method and then by a sequencing method. 33(49) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36887Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Ukraine------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] on Sat 5 Dec 2020 from Dr. Olga Shevchenko, Deputy Head, State Service of Ukraine on Food Safety and Consumer Protection, Ministry of Agrarian Policy and Food of Ukraine, Kyiv, UkraineSummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 2 Dec 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 4 Dec  2020Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 4 Mar 2020Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] virusSerotype: H5Nature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic)This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaksSummary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Kandybyne, Nova Odesa, NikolayevDate of start of the outbreak: 2 Dec 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: backyardTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / SlaughteredBirds / 10 / 10 / 10 / 0 / 0Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 100 / 100 / 100 / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; quarantine official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; zoning; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: No other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type: Odesa Regional State Laboratory of State Service of Ukraine on Food Safety and Consumer Protection (Regional Laboratory) Species / Test / Test date / ResultBirds / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 4 Dec 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail	<promed@promedmail.org>[Given the presence HPAI H5N8 in the region, there is a high likelihood that these recent outbreaks reported by France and Ukraine are also associated with this same subtype. "In Europe, the 1st outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 were reported in August 2020 in Russia in both poultry and wild birds. Since then, a new wave of outbreaks of H5N8 have been continuously reported in several of the European countries especially in wild birds but also in poultry starting from mid-October. The H5N8 virus has also reassorted with other wild bird influenza viruses to form new strains of H5N5 and H5N1 HPAI virus, which were also reported by countries. A few Asian countries also reported HPAI H5N8 outbreaks in poultry and/or wild birds. It is more likely that the source of introduction in these outbreaks is through migratory wild birds and onward local spread. Report of increased number of outbreaks in wild birds indicate periods of heightened risk in countries due to migratory flyways during this season. Consequently, improving on-farm biosecurity measures is a priority to reduce the likelihood of exposure to poultry". Source: OIE-Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) Report No 17: 23 Oct 2020 to 12 Nov 2020; https://tinyurl.com/y5uzaomb. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED maps:France: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7998763,100Ukraine: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7998763,123] See Also

33(49) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36857Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Poland-----------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 3 Dec 2020 from Dr Bogdan Konopka, chief veterinary officer, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development, General Veterinary Inspectorate, Warszaw, PolandSummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 1 Dec 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 2 Dec 2020Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 13 May 2020Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza [HPAI] virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced)This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Nakory, Suchozebry, siedlecki (1426), Mazowieckie [Masovia/Mazovia]Date of start of the outbreak: 1 Dec 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / SlaughteredBirds / 117 108 / 18 278 / 1703 / - / 0Affected population: the outbreak of highly pathogenic avian influenza of subtype H5N8 was confirmed in the commercial farm with turkey broilers.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 15.61 / 1.45 / 9.32 / ***Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter**Not calculated because of missing informationEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveControl measuresMeasures applied: screening; traceability; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; control of wildlife reservoirs; zoning; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type: National Veterinary Research Institute (national laboratory)Species / Test / Test date / ResultBirds / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 2 Dec 2020 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[This is the 2nd case of HPAI subtype H5N8 reported in domestic poultry.The following press release was published on 30 Nov 2020 by the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (the information has been translated and edited from Polish to English):A research conducted by scientists from the State Veterinary Institute - The State Research Institute in Pulawy confirms that the H5N8 virus strain detected in Poland is not dangerous for consumers and does not endanger public health.The analysis of the entire genome of the H5N8 influenza virus strain detected in Poland indicates its high degree of similarity to the HPAI H5N8 virus strains currently present in Europe, indicating their common origin and lack of risk to human health.Studies on the identification of molecular markers of human health risks have not shown that the H5N8 virus detected in the country has characteristics indicating increased infectivity and pathogenicity for humans, and in this respect is no different from other viruses currently detected in Europe.However, the results do not allow for precise identification of the geographical area from which the virus came to Polish, as the same level of genetic similarity occurs both in virus sequences detected in countries west of Poland (that is, Germany, Denmark, Belgium, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom) and east of our country (Russia). In view of the numerous cases of infections in wild birds in Europe, they should be considered as the most likely vector for the introduction of the virus into Poland. The results of the studies also indicate that the current situation is unrelated to the HPAI H5N8 epidemic in Europe in the 2019/2020 season.See the information (in Polish) at https://tinyurl.com/y3k7t55j. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Poland: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7991285,64624] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-12-02 19:58:44 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (102): Europe, wild bird, poultry, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, spread Archive Number: 20201202.7988670AVIAN INFLUENZA (102): EUROPE, WILD BIRD, POULTRY, H5N8, H5N5, H5N1, SPREAD, OVERVIEW*************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Wed 2 Dec 2020Source: Animal & Plant Health Agency (APHA), UK [abridged, edited]https://science.vla.gov.uk/flu-lab-net/docs/H5_SituationReport_021120.pdfSummary of highly pathogenic avian influenza H5 activity in Europe: 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------A total of 582 detections of HPAI H5 have been reported in Europe between 27 Oct 2020 and 28 Nov 2020. This new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant was originally detected in poultry in Iraq in May 2020 with subsequent detections in Russia and Kazakhstan. It seems likely that migratory waterfowl played a key role in the incursion of this virus into Europe with over 500 detections in wild birds and spillover events into commercial poultry and captive birds.This situation report provides an overview of the virological, epidemiological, and ornithological characteristics of this new epizootic, which involves H5N8, H5N5 and H5N1 subtypes suggesting local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. We describe the geographical distribution and the variety of avian hosts demonstrating susceptibility to this emerging virus.The 582 detections of HPAI H5 comprise 35 detections in poultry (6%), 8 in captive birds (1%) and 539 wild bird events (93%). Previous epizootics in Europe have had varied clinical and epidemiological presentations; the 2016/17 H5N8 epizootic affected both wild birds and poultry with over 2800 events recorded between October 2016 and July 2017. The H5N6 epizootic in 2017/18 primarily affected wild birds (80 events) with only 7 events in poultry and captive flocks.--Communicated by:Adam BrouwerAnimal and Plant Health Agency - OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian InfluenzaAPHA-Weybridge, UK<adam.brouwer@apha.gov.uk>[The authors of the above useful APHA situation report are Adam Brouwer, Nicola Lewis, Elliot Whittard, David Stroud, Ashley Banyard, Rowena Hansen, and Ian Brown. We are indebted to the submitter and his peers.The following section, excerpted from the above-cited report, deserves inclusion:H5 HPAI (2.3.4.4b of putative African origin for some gene segments) was present in European poultry from 2 Jan 2020 to the last detection on 4 Jun 2020, with H5N8 detected in Eastern Europe with extensive spread within poultry in Hungary (276 events) and Poland (35 events).There were 6 detections in wild birds of a closely related virus to the poultry-associated H5N8 between Jan and Mar 2020 suggesting a relatively low incidence in wild birds.Iraq reported H5N8 in poultry in May 2020 with a new H5N8 2.3.4.4b clade variant genetically distinct from the previous 2020 strains in Europe. Genetically similar H5N8 viruses were subsequently detected in southern central Russia, northern Kazakhstan and south-western Russia. In western Europe, HPAI H5 in wild birds was suspected when there was an initial detection in Eurasian wigeons in the Netherlands on 16 Oct 2020 with disease confirmed on 27 Oct with one bird positive for H5N8 and 4 positive for H5N1. The H5N8 virus was similar to that reported in Russia, Kazakhstan and Iraq whilst the H5N1 characterisation suggested local reassortment with wild bird Eurasian avian LPAI genes. Detections in poultry followed with initial H5N8 cases in the Netherlands and the UK submitted to national reference laboratories on 28 Oct and 2 Nov 2020, respectively. Subsequently there has been a substantial increase in cases (principally H5N8) in wild birds particularly in northern Europe and spillover events to commercial poultry and captive birds involving reports from 14 European countries to date [28 Nov 2020].Nearly all detections of HPAI H5 in wild birds have been found close to coastlines with significant clusters of cases in the Jutland peninsula and within the extensive Wadden Sea -- a continuous intertidal wetland stretching from Denmark to the Netherlands and where many of the Danish, German and Dutch cases occurred. However, wild bird cases also occurred in inland areas in those and other countries, with a 2nd cluster of wild bird detections in the Netherlands.The lack of detections in other countries in Northern Europe does not imply that HPAIv is absent -- rather that a combination of varied disease prevalence and the sensitivity of wild bird surveillance programmes has inhibited detection thus far.---The report includes a table presenting details of the 582 reported HPAI H5 disease events in Europe, 27 Oct - 28 Nov 2020, for the 14 addressed European countries. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Europe: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7988670,6010] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[This is the 1st case of HPAI subtype H5N8 in domestic poultry. All previous cases reported in 2020 affected wild birds. See reports below.Part of the following information was published on 29 Sep 2020 by the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs (MAFRA): "As a result of studying arrival status of winter migratory birds recently (by Ministry of Environment), the arrival of representative winter migratory birds, ducks and wild geese has been confirmed. As such, to prevent avian influenza (AI), MAFRA will strengthen quarantine measures such as disinfection of migratory bird sites and urged poultry farms to comply with quarantine rules.... It is urged for poultry farms nationwide to strictly adhere to quarantine rules such as blocking access to visitors and vehicles, installing nets to block wild birds and rodents, applying quicklime around the access road to farmhouses and livestock facilities, disinfecting and wearing dedicated boots before entering the livestock facilities, cleaning and disinfecting before work. In particular, during the Chuseok holiday period, it is emphasized that visitors are restricted from entering poultry breeding facilities and that farms are urged to strictly comply with the prohibition of visiting migratory birds."See the complete information at https://tinyurl.com/yytlo6lz. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:North Jeolla Province, South Korea: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7986533,6602] See Also

The site where the bird was found is near the Santona, Victoria and Joyel Marshes Nature Reserve.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Peregrine falcon:_Falco peregrinus_(Falconidae)/ ** / ** / ** / ***Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter**Not calculated because of missing informationEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Contact with wild species.Epidemiological comments: The Santona and Noja Marshes Nature Reserve is considered to be an area at special risk for the introduction of avian influenza, according to Order APA/2442/2006. Since 11 Nov 2020, and given the epidemiological situation in Europe, it was decided not to allow competent authorities to make exceptions to the measures to be applied in this kind of area. These measures are: a) Using birds of Anseriformes and Charadriiformes Orders as decoys is prohibited. (b) Breeding ducks and geese with other species of poultry is prohibited. (c) Rearing free-range poultry is prohibited. (d) Giving poultry water from water reservoirs accessible to wild birds is prohibited, unless water can be treated to ensure inactivation of possible avian influenza viruses. (e) Outdoor water reservoirs required for poultry welfare will be sufficiently protected against wild waterfowl. f) Poultry or other captive birds are prohibited in animal assembly centers defined in Article 3.7 of Law 8/2003 of 24 Apr 2020 on animal health, including livestock shows, exhibitions and cultural celebrations, as well as any concentration of poultry or other captive birds outdoors. In this respect, birds kept in premises authorized for sale to private individuals as pet birds, and poultry kept in commercial premises for subsequent retail sale to private individuals, will not be considered captive birds.Control measuresMeasures applied: official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultCentral Veterinary Laboratory, Algete (National laboratory) / Peregrine falcon / real-time PCR / 27 Nov 2020 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. It was taken care of but died the next night and was then sent to the National Veterinary Institute for laboratory analysis as a part of the national surveillance program for avian influenza.Outbreak location 2: Lund, Lund, Lund, Skane LanDate of start of the outbreak: 12 Nov 2020Outbreak status: resolved 12 Nov 2020Epidemiological unit: villageTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBarnacle Goose:_Branta leucopsis_(Anatidae)/ - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Affected population: The bird was skinny and apathetic when found. After euthanizing, it was sent to the National Veterinary Institute for laboratory analysis as a part of the national surveillance program for avian influenza.Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 2Peregrine falcon: _Falco peregrinus_(Falconidae)/ - / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0Barnacle Goose: _Branta leucopsis_(Anatidae)/ - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Peregrin falcon: _Falco peregrinus_(Falconidae)/ ** / ** / 100 / **Barnacle Goose: _Branta leucopsis_(Anatidae)/ ** / ** / 100 / ***Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter**Not calculated because of missing informationEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with wild speciesControl measuresMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultNational Veterinary Institute (National laboratory) / Barnacle Goose / real -time PCR/ 25 Nov 2020 / positiveNational Veterinary Institute (National laboratory) / Barnacle Goose / virus sequencing / 26 Nov 2020 / positiveNational Veterinary Institute (National laboratory) / Peregrine falcon / real -time PCR/ 25 Nov 2020 / positiveNational Veterinary Institute (National laboratory) / Peregrine falcon / virus sequencing / 26 Nov 2020 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>["Several factors can contribute to the spread of avian influenza (AI) viruses, such as: globalisation and international trade; farming and sale (live bird markets); wild birds and migratory routes.Wild birds can normally carry AI viruses in their respiratory or intestinal tracts, but they do not commonly get sick, which allow them to carry the viruses long distances along their migration flyways.Wild birds, as natural hosts and reservoirs for all types of avian influenza viruses, play a major role in the evolution, maintenance, and spread of these viruses. The main wild species involved have proved to be waterfowl, gulls, and shorebirds; however, the virus seems to pass easily between different bird species.The incidence of infection appears to be seasonal, with the highest isolation rate being in juvenile birds in the fall of the year.Several routes of exposure of wild bird viruses to poultry have been documented or suspected of being the origins of outbreaks. Direct exposure to wild birds is the most likely transmission factor.Therefore, limiting exposure of poultry to wild birds through confinement rearing and other biosecurity measures provides an opportunity to reduce the risk of introduction of avian influenza virus from wild birds, and consequently is key to decreasing the risk of evolution into highly pathogenic forms, exposure and infection of humans, and recombination with human viruses components to form viruses that can not only infect humans but readily transmit among humans;" Source: https://www.oie.int/en/animal-health-in-the-world/avian-influenza-portal/what-is-avian-influenza/.The following abstract comes from a scientific article titled "Enterotropism of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N8 from the 2016/2017 epidemic in some wild bird species," which is available in ref. 1:Abstract:"In 2016/2017, H5N8 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) virus of the Goose/Guangdong lineage spread from Asia to Europe, causing the biggest and most widespread HPAI epidemic on record in wild and domestic birds in Europe. We hypothesized that the wide dissemination of the 2016 H5N8 virus resulted at least partly from a change in tissue tropism from the respiratory tract, as in older HPAIV viruses, to the intestinal tract, as in low pathogenic avian influenza (LPAI) viruses, allowing more efficient faecal-oral transmission. Therefore, we determined the tissue tropism and associated lesions in wild birds found dead during the 2016 H5N8 epidemic, as well as the pattern of attachment of 2016 H5N8 virus to respiratory and intestinal tissues of four key wild duck species. We found that, out of 39 H5N8-infected wild birds of 12 species, four species expressed virus antigen in both respiratory and intestinal epithelium, one species only in respiratory epithelium, and one species only in intestinal epithelium. Virus antigen expression was association with inflammation and necrosis in multiple tissues. The level of attachment to wild duck intestinal epithelia of 2016 H5N8 virus was comparable to that of LPAI H4N5 virus, and higher than that of 2005 H5N1 virus for 2 of the 4 duck species and chicken tested. Overall, these results indicate that 2016 H5N8 may have acquired a similar enterotropism to LPAI viruses, without having lost the respirotropism of older HPAI viruses of the Goose/Guangdong lineage. The increased enterotropism of 2016 H5N8 implies that this virus had an increased chance to persist long term in the wild waterbird reservoir."Reference:1. Caliendo, V., Leijten, L., Begeman, L. et al. Enterotropism of highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N8 from the 2016/2017 epidemic in some wild bird species. Vet Res 51, 117 (2020) https://doi.org/10.1186/s13567-020-00841-6. - Mod.CRD] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-11-30 19:55:03 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (99): UK, wild bird, HPAI H5N8 Archive Number: 20201130.7982468AVIAN INFLUENZA (99): UNITED KINGDOM, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N8**********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 27 Nov 2020 3:01 PMSource: Lancashire News [edited]https://www.lancs.live/news/lancashire-news/bird-flu-outbreak-confirmed-blackpools-19358822An outbreak of bird flu at a Blackpool park has resulted in the deaths of 9 swans. Last week [16-22 Nov 2020], officials from the RSPCA and the Department for Environmental and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) were called to Stanley Park lake in Blackpool.They were responding to reports from residents at the seaside resort who spotted the bodies of several swans. Concerned park goers theorised that the animals, whose bodies were also spotted on the lake bank and the island, could have been subject to attacks but it was later confirmed to be the result of a disease.Defra has now confirmed that 9 of the swans which had died at Stanley Park lake had tested positive for Avian Influenza H5N8. The 1st deceased swan was discovered at Stanley Park on [Sun 15 Nov 2020]. The RSPCA and DEFRA were both contacted that day.Public Health England has confirmed that the risk to public health is very low.The RSPCA have been in attendance at the park regularly since and DEFRA removed a number of swans for further investigation and analysis. It was confirmed to the council that a number of the swans tested were positive for Avian Influenza H5N8.We have been advised that the park can remain open to the public as the risk is very low, however, an area around the lake will be zoned off as a precaution.There have been a small number of cases of Avian Influenza also detected in other parts of England. There have been a number of confirmed reports of avian influenza in wild birds including geese and swans in the Netherlands and northern Germany in recent weeks. These wild birds are all on the waterfowl flyway from breeding grounds in western Russia, where the H5N8 strain was reported in poultry in mid-October [2020].[Byline: Rachel Howarth]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Currently, HPAI viruses appear to be propagating quickly in Europe, the subtype H5N8 belonging to clade 2.3.4.4 in particular. This subtype has been causing outbreaks in Asia, Europe and North America since 2014. Migratory wild birds have been implicated in the propagation of H5N8 (https://science.sciencemag.org/content/354/6309/213) and domestic ducks play a major role in the maintenance of this subtype (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/tbed.13406). Preventive measures should be taken at the domestic-wildlife interface. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map:Lancashire, England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7982468,913] See Also

/ 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Outbreak location 2: Porto Tolle, Rovigo, VenetoDate of start of the outbreak: 14 Nov 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: otherAffected animalsSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredMallard: _Anas platyrhynchos_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Mallard: _Anas platyrhynchos_ (Anatidae) / - / 1 / 0 / 1 / 0Eurasian Wigeon: _Anas Penelope_ (Anatidae) / - / 2 / 0 / 2 / 0EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: HPAI H5 viruses belonging to the 2.3.4.4 B clade have just been detected in northeast Italy in 4 hunted wild birds, namely 2 wigeons (_Mareca Penelope_) and one mallard (_Anas platyrhynchos_) sampled in a hunting area in Rovigo province (Ca Zuliani, Porto Tolle) and one common teal (_Anas crecca_) shot in a hunting area in Venice province (Valle Figheri, Campagnia Lupia). The HA sequence surrounding the cleavage site is highly related to that of HPAI currently circulating in Northern Europe. Identification of the NA subtype and characterization of the full genome is in process.Control measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, screening, control of wildlife reservoirs; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (National laboratory) / Common Teal / real-time PCR / 20 Nov 2020 / positiveExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (National laboratory) / Eurasian Wigeon / real-time PCR / 20 Nov 2020 / positiveExperimental Zooprophylactic Institute of the Venezie-Padova (National laboratory) / Mallard / real-time PCR / 20 Nov 2020 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing.
