View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-11-27 17:06:11 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (96): Iran (MK) HPAI, wild bird, H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20201127.7976081AVIAN INFLUENZA (96): IRAN (MARKAZI) HPAI, WILD BIRD, H5N8, OIE***************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Mon 23 Nov 2020Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2020 [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36756Highly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry including wild birds), Iran------------------------------------------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 23 Nov 2020 from Dr. Ali Safar Maken Ali, Head, Iran Veterinary Organization (IVO), Ministry of Jihad-e-Agriculture, Tehran, IranSummaryReport type: Immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 19 Nov 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 20 Nov 2020Reason for notification: Recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 4 Feb 2018Manifestation of disease: Clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic influenza A virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory (basic), necropsyThis event pertains to the whole country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Meyghan Lake, MarkaziDate of start of the outbreak: 19 Nov 2020Outbreak status: Resolved on 20 Nov 2020Epidemiological unit: Natural parkTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredGreylag goose: _Anser anser_ (Anatidae) / - / 26 / 26 / 0 / 0Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Greylag goose: _Anser anser_ (Anatidae) / ** / ** / 100 / ***Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter**Not calculated because of missing informationEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Contact with wild speciesEpidemiological comments: The event was reported based on Iran Veterinary Organization's HPAI epidemio-surveillance program. The aim is to close the event; in the protection zone and surveillance zone, trace back and trace forward activities are ongoing.Control measuresMeasures applied: Screening; quarantine; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; disinfection; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: Surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; zoningDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultCentral Veterinary Laboratory of Iran Veterinary Organization (CVL) (national laboratory) / Greylag goose / Real-time PCR / 23 Nov 2020 / PositiveProvincial Veterinary Laboratory of Markazi (local laboratory) / Greylag goose / Real-time PCR / 20 Nov 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>["Wild birds can normally carry AI (avian influenza) viruses in their respiratory or intestinal tracts but they do not commonly get sick, which allow them to carry the viruses on long distances along their migration flyways.... Therefore, limiting exposure of poultry to wild birds through confinement rearing and other biosecurity measures provides an opportunity to reduce the risk of introduction of avian influenza virus from wild birds." Source: OIE Avian Influenza Portal (https://tinyurl.com/y33q66mm).Some countries in the Middle East are located along wild bird migratory routes, suggesting a likely source of transmission and spread of the virus along such routes. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Markazi, Iran: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7976081,67904] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-11-25 16:29:08 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (95): UK, wild bird, HPAI H5N8 Archive Number: 20201125.7971718AVIAN INFLUENZA (95): UNITED KINGDOM, WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N8**********************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 24 Nov 2020Source: DorsetECHO [edited]https://www.dorsetecho.co.uk/news/18894981.weymouth-goose-highly-contagious-strain-bird-flu/It has been confirmed that the strain of bird flu found in a dead goose in Weymouth is highly pathogenic -- leading to a warning for bird keepers to remain alert for signs of disease to protect their flocks.The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) has also confirmed that a swan has tested positive for the H5N8 strain of avian influenza in Poole, although it is not yet known whether the strain is highly infectious.The wild goose was found dead near Weymouth 2 weeks ago [10 Nov 2020] and tested positive for the high pathogenicity avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 during routine surveillance by the Animal and Plant Health Agency. HPAI is highly contagious among birds and can spread rapidly throughout poultry flocks.A spokesman for DEFRA said: "Bird keepers should remain alert for any signs of disease, report suspected disease immediately and ensure they are maintaining strong biosecurity measures on their premises."Chief Veterinary Officer Christine Middlemiss added: "It is important now more than ever that bird keepers ensure they are doing all they can to maintain and strengthen good biosecurity on their premises to ensure we prevent further outbreaks."According to DEFRA, in addition to the 2 cases in Dorset, birds near Stroud in Gloucestershire, Dawlish in Devon, Ormskirk in Lancashire, Boston in Lincolnshire, Godmanchester in Cambridge and Rochford in Essex have tested positive for avian influenza H5N8.Public Health England (PHE) has advised that the risk to public health from the virus is very low, and the Food Standards Agency has advised that avian influenzas pose a very low food safety risk for UK consumers. Properly cooked poultry and poultry products, including eggs, are safe to eat.Dr. Gavin Dabrera, Consultant in Acute Respiratory Infections at PHE, said: "To date, there have been no human cases of infection with influenza A (H5N8) confirmed by the World Health Organisation and the risk to public health is very low."Our advice regarding contact with wild birds remains the same -- make sure to wash your hands thoroughly with soap after coming into contact with any animal and do not touch any sick or dead birds."[Byline: Josie Klein]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Currently, HPAI viruses appear to be propagating quickly in Europe, the subtype H5N8 belonging to clade 2.3.4.4 in particular. This subtype has been causing outbreaks in Asia, Europe and North America since 2014. Migratory wild birds have been implicated in the propagation of H5N8 (https://doi.org/10.1126/science.aaf8852), and domestic ducks play a major role in the maintenance of this subtype (https://doi.org/10.1111/tbed.13406). Preventive measures should be taken at the domestic-wildlife interface. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7971718,40] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-11-24 12:44:46 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (94): Croatia (KK) poultry HPAI H5N8, OIE Archive Number: 20201124.7968466AVIAN INFLUENZA (94): CROATIA (KOPRIVNICA-KRIZEVCI) POULTRY HPAI H5N8, OIE**************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 21 Nov 2020Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2020; [edited] https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36690Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Croatia------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 21 Nov 2020 from Dr Tatjana Karacic, Assistant Minister, Chief Veterinary Officer, Veterinary Services, Ministry of Agriculture, Zagreb, CroatiaSummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 17 Nov 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 21 Nov 2020Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 7 Jun 2017Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced). necropsyThis event pertains to the whole country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Delovi, Delovi, Novigrad Podravski, Koprivnicko-Krizevacka [Koprivnica-Krizevci]Date of start of the outbreak: 17 Nov 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / SlaughteredBirds / - / - / 4315 / - / -EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: Increased mortality was observed on the commercial fattening turkey farm in Delovi (municipality: Novigrad Podravski) in the county: Koprivnica-Krizevci with approx. 70 000 animals, [on 17 Nov 2020]. Samples were taken and sent to Croatian Veterinary Institute-Poultry Centre in Zagreb. Avian influenza subtype H5N8 was detected in the pooled samples. On [21 Nov 2020] HPAI subtype H5N8 is confirmed. Implementation of disease control measures according to the Directive 2005/94/EC as well as epidemiological investigation is still ongoing.Control measuresMeasures applied: stamping out; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses; by-products and waste; disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultCroatian Veterinary Institute, Poultry Centre (national laboratory) / Birds / real-time PCR / 18 Nov 2020 / PositiveCroatian Veterinary Institute, Poultry Centre (national laboratory) / Birds / virus sequencing / 21 Nov 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>["In Europe, the 1st outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 were reported in August 2020 in Russia in both poultry and wild birds. Since then, a new wave of outbreaks of H5N8 has been continuously reported in several of the European countries especially in wild birds but also in poultry starting from mid-October [2020]. The H5N8 virus has also reassorted with other wild bird influenza viruses to form new strains of H5N5 and H5N1 HPAI virus, which were also reported by countries. A few Asian countries also reported HPAI H5N8 outbreaks in poultry and/or wild birds. It is more likely that the source of introduction in these outbreaks is through migratory wild birds and onward local spread. Report of increased number of outbreaks in wild birds indicate periods of heightened risk in countries due to migratory flyways during this season. Consequently, improving on-farm biosecurity measures is a priority to reduce the likelihood of exposure to poultry." (Source: OIE-Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) Report No 17: 23 Oct 2020 to 12 Nov 2020; https://tinyurl.com/y5uzaomb).- Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Croatia: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7968466,67895] See Also

33(48) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36683Low pathogenic avian influenza (poultry), Italy-----------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 20 Nov 2020 from Dr Davide Lecchini, Chief Veterinary Officer, Directorate General for Veterinary Health and Veterinary Medicinal Products (DGSAF), Ministry of Health, Rome, ItalyReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 17 Nov 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 18 Nov 2020Reason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 20 Jun 2020Manifestation of disease: sub-clinical infectionCausal agent: Low pathogenic avian influenza [LPAI] virusSerotype: H5Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (advanced)This event pertains to a defined zone within the countryNew outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak 1 (LPAI_4_2020_PV): Gallivola, Pavia, Lombardia [Lombardy]Date of start of the outbreak: 17 Nov 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / SlaughteredBirds / 11 214 / 8 / - / - / -Affected population: the positivity concerns a breeding of _Gallus gallus_ and ducks located in the municipality of Galliavola, in the province of Pavia.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 0.07 / ** / ** / ***Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter** Not calculated because of missing informationEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: The positivity concerns a breeding of _Gallus gallus_ and ducks located in the municipality of Galliavola, in the province of Pavia. So far, positivity has only been confirmed on a serological basis by H5 subtype specific haemagglutination inhibition tests. No clinical signs or increased mortality were reported in this flock. Further investigations and sampling are underway to detect the active circulation of the virus and to identify and characterize the strain responsible for seroconversion. Based on the absence of clinical signs, it is believed that seropositivity can be attributed to an LPAI infection.Control measuresMeasures applied: surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; stamping out; disinfection; vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type: Experimental Zooprophylactic Institute (IZS) of Venice, Padua (national laboratory)Species / Test / Test date / ResultBirds / haemagglutination inhibition test (HIT) / 18 Nov 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[In June 2020, Italy detected one outbreak of LPAI subtype H5N3. The affected population was an ostrich farm located in the municipality of Suzzara, Province of Mantova, Region of Lombardy.This event was resolved on 20 Jun 2020. See the report and updated map at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000034819_20200625_114921.pdf"Low pathogenicity avian influenza (LPAI) viruses typically cause little or no clinical signs in infected poultry. The LPAI virus is excreted through infected birds' feces and respiratory secretions. It spreads primarily through direct contact between healthy and infected birds. It can also be spread through indirect contact with contaminated equipment and materials."To prevent cases of LPAI, poultry producers must use special preventative measures and precautions on the farm. If LPAI is detected, farms must be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected. AI viruses are inactivated by heat and drying. They are also very sensitive to most disinfectants and detergents. To ensure thorough disinfection, organic material must first be cleaned from the environment". (Source: https://tinyurl.com/y6ev7lre). - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Italy: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7968361,67894] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-11-22 05:19:45 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (92): Japan (KG) poultry, HPAI H5N8, susp Archive Number: 20201122.7962047AVIAN INFLUENZA (92): JAPAN (KAGAWA) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, SUSPECTED******************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 20 Nov 2020Source: Reuters [edited]https://in.reuters.com/article/instant-article/idINKBN2800BXJapan's Kagawa prefecture will cull 850 000 chickens at 2 poultry farms after the country detected a bird flu outbreak earlier this month [November 2020], the local government said in a statement on Friday [20 Nov 2020].These will be the 6th and 7th [outbreaks] of the avian flu in western Kagawa prefecture and the biggest cull to be done at one time since the country's 1st bird flu outbreak [in poultry] was detected more than 2 years [ago], an official at the prefecture said.Chickens at the 2 farms in Mitoyo city tested positive in a preliminary examination for avian influenza on Thursday [19 Nov 2020] after the farms had notified the prefectural government of an increase in the number of dead chickens. The local government said it has confirmed the infection was a highly pathogenic strain of H5 bird flu from genetic tests on Friday [20 Nov 2020].The prefecture has already culled about 460 000 chickens for the past 4 [outbreaks], the official said.Japan's last [sic] outbreak of bird flu occurred in January 2018, when 91 000 chickens at a farm in Sanuki city, also in Kagawa prefecture, were culled due to the H5N6 strain of bird flu, according to the agriculture ministry.[byline: Yuka Obayashi]--communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Since submitting to the OIE on 6 Nov 2020 its immediate notification on the H5 avian influenza event that reportedly had started in the Kagawa prefecture on 4 Nov 2020 (20201109.7928569), Japan has submitted 3 follow-up reports, the most recent one on 18 Nov 2020. The causative agent was reported to be HPAI H5N8. Links to all said reports, addressing the 1st 5 outbreaks, and an interactive map presenting their locations as of 18 Nov 2020, are available at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=36435.The event's summary as of 18 Nov 2020 is as follows:Total outbreaks = 5 (submitted)Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 478 000 / 2068 / 2068 / 475 932 / 0Most likely, the 2 additional outbreaks addressed in the above media report are caused by the same HPAI H5N8 virus strain. The virus is suspected to have been introduced into Japan from the continent by migrating birds. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Kagawa prefecture, Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7962047,3534.] See Also

/ 1 / 1 / 0 / 0Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Anserinae (unidentified): Anserinae (incognita) (Anatidae) / ** / ** / 100 / ***Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveControl measuresMeasures applied: Official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, control of wildlife reservoirs, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: No other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (national laboratory) / Anserinae (unidentified) / Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 13 Nov 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The fact that HPAI subtype H5N8 and other subtypes (HPAI H5N5 and H5N1) currently circulating in the European continent have been detected in wild birds is very indicative that these viruses are being distributed wherever these wild birds migrate. Poultry producers, small and large alike, must therefore implement all the biosecurity measures necessary to protect their flocks from exposure and infection.The following abstract comes from a scientific report on Avian influenza overview in EU/EEA and the UK -- update on 19 Nov 2020, which is available in ref 1:Abstract--------Since 16 Oct 2020, outbreaks of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) viruses have been reported in several EU/EEA countries -- Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, the Netherlands, and Sweden -- as well as in the United Kingdom. As of 19 Nov [2002], 12 pm, 302 HPAI A(H5) detections have been reported, with the majority of the detections referring to wild birds (n = 281), and a few related to outbreaks in poultry (n = 18) and captive birds (n = 3). Most of the detections in wild birds were in wild waterbirds, being barnacle goose the most affected species (n = 110), followed by greylag goose (n = 47), Eurasian wigeon (n = 32), mallard (n = 14), and common buzzard (n = 13). Three HPAI virus subtypes were identified -- A(H5N8), A(H5N5) and A(H5N1) -- with A(H5N8) being the most reported subtype (n = 284). Phylogenetic analysis indicated that the viruses evolved from a single progenitor virus that went through multiple reassortment events. Based on the ongoing autumn migration of wild waterbirds to their wintering areas in Europe, there is a continued risk of further introduction of HPAI A(H5) viruses into Europe. Furthermore, given the expected movements of both migratory, and resident wild birds in Europe during winter, there is a high risk of further spread of HPAI A(H5) viruses within Europe. No genetic markers indicating adaptation to mammals have been identified in the viruses analysed so far, and no human infection due to avian influenza viruses detected in the recent outbreaks has been reported. For that reason, the risk to the general population remains very low. However, following the precautionary principle, people should avoid touching sick or dead birds unprotected to minimise any potential risk.Reference1. European Food Safety Authority, European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control and European Union Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Currently, HPAI viruses appear to be propagating quickly in Europe, the subtype H5N8 belonging to clade 2.3.4.4 in particular. This subtype has been causing outbreaks in Asia, Europe, and North America since 2014. Migratory wild birds have been implicated in the propagation of H5N8 (DOI: 10.1126/science.aaf8852), and domestic ducks play a major role in the maintenance of this subtype (DOI: 10.1111/tbed.13406). Preventive measures should be taken at the domestic-wildlife interface. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map:Belgium: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7955803,99] See Also

The holding consists of approximately 25 000 animals. The animals in the holding were tested due to increased mortality in the holding. The animals at the infected holding will be culled, and the carcasses will be disposed by rendering.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / ** / 6 / ** / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter**Not calculated because of missing informationEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comment: the Danish Veterinary and Food Administration has established zones of 3 and 10 km around the holding and are implementing the necessary measures in accordance with Council Directive 2005/94/EC.Control measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, traceability, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, stamping out, disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultStatens Serum Institute (national laboratory) / Bird / Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 16 Nov 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. See reports at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36457 and https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=36520.On 17 Nov 2020, the French Minister of Agriculture and Food placed the country on high-risk alert. The alert requires all poultry farms to keep animals indoors or install protective netting to prevent contact with wild birds. Source: https://www.thepoultrysite.com/news/2020/11/france-on-high-alert-for-bird-flu-outbreaks and https://tinyurl.com/y4et7wbn. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED maps:France: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7954116,100Denmark: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7954116,111] See Also

Therefore, sporadic human cases are not unexpected."With continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans. Surveillance should be continued to detect human cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of the viruses." Source: WHO: Avian influenza update number 766 -- 6 Nov 2020 https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20201106.pdf. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Laos: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7947613,67857.] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-11-13 07:58:39 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (06): Laos (SL) H5N1, WHO Archive Number: 20201113.7939962AVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (06): LAOS (SARAVAN) H5N1, WHO*****************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: 6 Nov 2020Source: WHO/WPRO [edited]https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/wpro---documents/emergency/surveillance/avian-influenza/ai-20201106.pdfAvian influenza weekly update number 766Human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus--------------------------------------------------Between [30 Oct and 5 Nov 2020], one new case of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus was reported to WHO in the Western Pacific Region. The case is a one-year old female from Saravan province, who had exposure to domestic poultry. She developed cough, fever, and difficulty breathing on [13 Oct 2020]. On [16 Oct 2020], she was hospitalised and had her sample collected. She was discharged on [19 Oct 2020]. All household contacts tested negative for Influenza A.As of [5 Nov 2020], a total of 239 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported from 4 countries within the Western Pacific Region since January 2003 (Table 1). Of these cases, 134 were fatal, resulting in a case fatality rate (CFR) of 56 percent. The last case was reported from Lao PDR, with an onset date of [13 Oct 2020] (one case, no death).Table 1 (available at the source URL above): Cumulative number of laboratory-confirmed human cases (C) and deaths (D) of influenza A(H5N1) virus infection reported to WHO, by date of onset (January 2003 to 5 Nov 2020), Western Pacific Region.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Influenza viruses are constantly changing and animal flu viruses can change such that they may gain the ability to infect easily and spread among people. Whenever avian influenza viruses are circulating in poultry, there is a risk for sporadic infection and small clusters of human cases due to exposure to infected poultry or contaminated environments.Human infections with novel avian influenza virus like Asian H5N1 are concerning because of their pandemic potential.Globally, from January 2003 to 5 Nov 2020, there were 862 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus reported from 17 countries. Of these 862 cases, 455 were fatal (CFR of 53%). As of 5 Nov 2020, a total of 239 cases of human infection with avian influenza A(H5N1) virus were reported from 4 countries within the Western Pacific Region (Cambodia, China, Laos, and Viet Nam) since January 2003. Of these cases, 134 were fatal, resulting in a case fatality rate (CFR) of 56%. The most recent case is the one reported above from Laos, with an onset date of 13 Oct 2020 (one case, no death) (https://www.who.int/influenza/human_animal_interface/H5N1_cumulative_table_archives/en/).With continued incidence of avian influenza due to existing and new influenza A(H5) viruses in poultry, there is a need to remain vigilant in the animal and public health sectors. Community awareness of the potential dangers for human health is essential to prevent infection in humans. Surveillance should be continued to detect human cases and early changes in transmissibility and infectivity of the viruses. -Mod.UBAHealthMap/ProMED map of Laos: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7939962,67857] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[3] England (Herefordshire), poultry, HPAI H5N8Date: Thu 12 Nov 2020Source: Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (DEFRA) and the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) [abridged, edited]https://www.gov.uk/guidance/avian-influenza-bird-flu#latest-situationHighly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 was confirmed on [10 Nov 2020] in broiler breeder chickens at a premise near Leominster, in Herefordshire. A 3km [approx. 1.8 mi] Protection Zone and 10km [approx. 6.2 mi] surveillance zone have been put in place around the infected premises.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The conclusion of the last outbreak assessment report for the cases in both LPAI and HPAI in UK and Europe, published on 10 Nov 2020 by DEFRA-APHA, mentioned that:"As a consequence of the H5N8 HPAI poultry outbreak in the UK, and in Germany and the Netherlands; as well as the increasing HPAI H5N8 events in wild birds in the UK, Ireland and the Netherlands and Germany this week, and the known migration routes on to the UK from these countries; the risk of HPAI incursion in wild birds in the UK is High. The overall risk of infection of poultry in the UK is Medium; although it should be noted that the risk of introduction to individual premises depends upon the level of biosecurity implemented on farm to prevent direct or indirect contact with wild birds. We recommend biosecurity measures should be maintained or strengthened, as required."We strongly recommend that all poultry keepers (including backyard keepers) review their biosecurity measures and business continuity plans, as the risk has now increased. Keepers should familiarize themselves with government guidance on good biosecurity and how to report suspicion of disease appropriately". The full report is available at https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/934708/hpai-europe-201110.pdfFurther information on these new cases in the UK, including the restrictions and movement controls, can be seen at Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs' (DEFRA) and the Animal and Plant Health Agency's (APHA) "Guidance on Avian Influenza (Bird Flu)" website at https://www.gov.uk/guidance/avian-influenza-bird-flu#latest-situation, (latest update 12 Nov 2020).Further details of findings of HPAI in wild birds in Great Britain is available at https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/avian-influenza-in-wild-birds. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7938593,279] See Also

control of wildlife reservoirs; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (FLI) (national laboratory)Species / Test / Test date / ResultGruidae (unidentified) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 7 Nov 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[After circulating in countries in Asia, H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 group A was introduced into Europe during the winter of 2014-15. During and after the winter of 2016, a related, but genetically distinct influenza H5N8 virus was detected in Europe; in addition, reassortant influenza H5N5 and H5N6 viruses emerged. Because the influenza season progressed along the fall migratory routes for wild birds from Siberia across Asia into Europe, large numbers of dead wild birds and outbreaks in poultry flocks were associated with H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 group B. Overall, 24 of the 31 European Union countries, neighboring countries, Israel, and countries in the Middle East were facing large avian influenza outbreaks in poultry or wild birds during that period. Since the end of 2019, HPAI H5N8 outbreaks have been reported in Europe in poultry and in captive and wild birds. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7931494,101] See Also

33(46) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36435Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Japan----------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 6 Nov 2020 from Dr Norio Kumagai, Director, Chief Veterinary Officer, Animal Health Division, Food Safety and Consumer Affairs Bureau, Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, Tokyo, JapanSummaryReport type: immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 4 Nov 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 4 Nov 2020Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 14 Jan 2018Manifestation of disease: clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)This event pertains to a defined zone within the countryNew outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak 1: Mitoyo-City, KagawaDate of start of the outbreak: 4 Nov 2020Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: farmTotal animals affectedSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 330 000 / 2000 / 2000 / 328 000 / 0Affected population: poultry (broilers)Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 0.61 / 0.61 / 100 / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusiveEpidemiological comments: On 4 Nov 2020, the local veterinary service in Kagawa Prefecture received a notification from a domestic broilers farm on an increase in the number of dead birds. The samples were sent to the laboratory of the local veterinary service (Seibu Livestock Hygiene Service Centre; LHSC) and the samples collected from dead birds were positive for influenza A virus by antigen-capture kits. On 5 Nov 2020, the LHSC conducted RT-PCR and RRT-PCR tests and confirmed that the subtype was H5. On 6 Nov 2020, the National Institute of Animal Health (NIAH) conducted the sequencing test and confirmed that the subtype of the virus was H5N8 and causative virus was determined as high pathogenicity avian influenza. Stamping-out policy applied to the affected farm. Destruction of all the susceptible birds in the affected farm is being implemented. Movement and shipment restrictions are imposed on the farms within a radius of 3 km [1.9 mi] and 3-10 km [1.9-6.2 mi] of the affected farm respectively.Control measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; quarantine; stamping out; disinfection; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultSeibu Livestock Hygiene Service Centre (local laboratory) / Birds / real-time reverse transcriptase / polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 5 Nov 2020 / PositiveSeibu Livestock Hygiene Service Centre (local laboratory) / Birds / reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 5 Nov 2020 / PositiveNational Institute of Animal Health (national laboratory) / Birds / gene sequencing / 6 Nov 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-MBDS<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>[According to a media report published on 8 Nov 2020, another outbreak was confirmed at a poultry farm in the city of Higashikagawa in Kagawa Prefecture. This same source describes that during the month of October, highly pathogenic avian influenza virus was found in wild duck droppings in the city of Monbetsu, Hokkaido. Avian influenza H5N8 subtype was isolated on 24 Oct 2020 by Hokkaido University. (https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2020/11/08/national/bird-flu-shikoku-kagawa/)."Wild birds, as natural hosts and reservoirs for all types of avian influenza viruses, play a major role in the evolution, maintenance, and spread of these viruses. The main wild species involved have proved to be waterfowls, gulls, and shorebirds, however, the virus seems to pass easily between different bird species."The incidence of infection appears to be seasonal, with the highest isolation rate being in juvenile birds in the fall of the year. Several routes of exposure of wild bird viruses to poultry have been documented or suspected of being the origins of outbreaks. Direct exposure to wild birds is the most likely transmission factor."Therefore, limiting exposure of poultry to wild birds through confinement rearing and other biosecurity measures provides an opportunity to reduce the risk of introduction of avian influenza virus from wild birds, and consequently is key to decrease the risk of evolution into highly pathogenic forms, exposure, and infection of humans, and recombination with human viruses components to form viruses that can not only infect humans but readily transmit among humans".Source: OIE Avian Influenza Portal https://www.oie.int/en/animal-health-in-the-world/avian-influenza-portal/what-is-avian-influenza. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map of Japan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7928569,3534] See Also

Other populations migrate between Russia and eastern Asia. In South Korea, HPAIV was detected from Mandarin duck samples in 2010 (H5N1), 2014 (H5N8) and 2016, suggesting that Mandarin ducks are a major host species for H5 HPAIV and can disseminate the virus throughout South Korea and into other countries. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED-mail maps:South Chungcheong Province, South Korea: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7924133,11799Gyeonggi Province, South Korea: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7924133,4245] See Also

On 5 Nov 2020, Statens Serum Institute confirmed highly pathogenic influenza A virus (H5N5) in the samples from the falcon.EpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Contact with wild speciesEpidemiological comment: According to Article 10.4.1.8 of the Terrestrial Animal Health Code, Member Countries should not impose bans on the trade in poultry and poultry commodities in response to notification on the presence of any influenza A virus in birds other than poultry.Control measuresMeasures applied: Vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: No other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type: Statens Serum Institute (national laboratory)Species / Test / Test date / ResultPeregrine falcon / Reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) / 5 Nov 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Highly pathogenic avian influenza has frequently caused infection and death in birds of prey (Falconiformes). Raptors may contract highly pathogenic avian influenza virus H5N1 by hunting or scavenging infected prey. Peregrine falcons (_Falco peregrinus_) regularly prey on Anseriformes, the main reservoir of avian influenza viruses, which make them prone to become infected. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Denmark: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7924131,111] See Also

Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[2] England (Cheshire) poultry, HPAI H5N8Date: Tue 3 Nov 2020Source: Press Release - Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs (DEFRA) and the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) [edited]https://www.gov.uk/government/news/avian-influenza-bird-flu-identified-at-cheshire-broiler-breederAvian influenza of the H5N8 strain was confirmed at a farm near Frodsham in Cheshire on [2 Nov 2020].Testing today [on 3 Nov 2020] has confirmed that this is a highly pathogenic strain related to the virus currently circulating in Europe.All 13 500 birds at the farm will be humanely culled to limit the spread of the disease. A 3-km Protection Zone and a 10-km Surveillance Zone have been put in place around the infected site to limit the risk of the disease spreading.This case is unrelated to the H5N2 strain which was confirmed at a small commercial premises near Deal in Kent on Mon 2 Nov 2020 [see OIE report above. - Mod.CRD].Public Health England (PHE) advises that the risk to public health from the virus is very low, and the Food Standards Agency advises that avian influenza poses a very low food safety risk for UK consumers. Properly cooked poultry and poultry products, including eggs, are safe to eat.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Netherlands has reported, since 17 Oct 2020, HPAI H5N8-infected mute swans (_Cygnus olor_) and a Eurasian Wigeon (_Mareca penelope_) found dead in 3 sites. This is the 1st outbreak of H5N8 HPAI officially reported in the Netherlands since the last detection of H5N8 HPAI in April 2017 in wild mallards; it is also the 1st HPAI outbreak in western Europe this season.The H5N8 HPAI introduction in the country is most likely related to wild bird migration.Germany reported a case in a wild bird on 30 Oct 2020 (20201103.7912764). The case involved a Eurasian Wigeon found ill in Hamburg, subsequently testing positive for HPAI and euthanized. Germany has been on high alert for HPAI since the beginning of October 2020 and increased surveillance efforts. There have been further outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 in Russia, including outbreaks in poultry in the west of the country on 27 Oct 2020 following previous outbreaks in poultry, and cases in wild water-birds in southern central Russia, along the border with Kazakhstan, and in northern Kazakhstan's poultry.The said and additional information is available in DEFRA's updated assessment of 30 Oct 2020 (Ref: VITT/1200 HPAI in Europe, at https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/932205/hpai-netherlands-poa-201030.pdf). The assessment is a reminder that the Eurasian Wigeon is strongly migratory and is a common winter visitor to Great Britain.On 30 Sep 2020, ECDC (the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control) published a warning on increased risk of HPAI introduction. The warning followed HPAI outbreaks among wild and domestic birds in western Russia and Kazakhstan over the past few months. This region is a known autumn migration route for wild water birds heading to Europe.The warning indicated that northern and eastern Europe are very vulnerable to new outbreaks, given past experience. When HPAI was detected in the same area of Russia in the summers of 2005 and 2016, epidemics followed in northern and eastern Europe: "If the pattern is repeated this year [2020], HPAI is expected to arrive in the same areas of Europe in autumn or winter. Subsequent spread to countries in southern and western Europe is also possible." The warning, urging EU states to step up surveillance and biosecurity measures to guard against possible new outbreaks of avian influenza this year [2020], is available at https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/news-events/avian-influenza-eu-alert-new-outbreaks.Subscribers are encouraged to visit the recent commentary by wildlife moderator PMB on the HPAI situation in Europe at https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7912764.The risk of transmission of avian influenza viruses to the general public in Europe remains very low. However, to minimize the risk of transmission to humans, people are advised not to not touch dead birds without wearing appropriate personal protective equipment. - Mod.AS][Further information on these cases in the UK, including the restrictions and movement controls, can be seen at Department for Environment, Food & Rural Affairs' (DEFRA) and the Animal and Plant Health Agency's (APHA) "Guidance on Avian Influenza (Bird Flu)" website at https://www.gov.uk/guidance/avian-influenza-bird-flu#latest-situation, (latest update 3 Nov 2020)."Wild birds migrating from mainland Europe during the winter period can spread the disease to poultry and other captive birds. There are some simple measures that all poultry keepers, whether they are running a large commercial farm, keeping a few hens in their back garden, or rearing game birds, should take to protect their birds against the threat of avian flu:"These include:- Keeping the area where birds live clean and tidy, controlling rats and mice and regularly cleansing and disinfecting any hard surfaces- Cleaning footwear before and after visits- Placing birds' feed and water in fully enclosed areas that are protected from wild birds, and removing any spilled feed regularly- Putting fencing around outdoor areas where birds are allowed and limiting their access to ponds or areas visited by wild waterfowl- Where possible, avoid keeping ducks and geese with other poultry species." - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED map:England, United Kingdom: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7913786,279] See Also

control of wildlife reservoirs; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (FLI) (national laboratory)Species / Test / Test date / ResultAnatidae (unidentified) / real time (PCR) / 30 Oct 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[After circulating in countries in Asia, H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 group A was introduced into Europe during the winter of 2014-15. During and after the winter of 2016, a related, but genetically distinct influenza H5N8 virus was detected in Europe; in addition, reassortant influenza H5N5 and H5N6 viruses emerged. Because the influenza season progressed along the fall migratory routes for wild birds from Siberia across Asia into Europe, large numbers of dead wild birds and outbreaks in poultry flocks were associated with H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 group B. Overall, 24 of the 31 the European Union countries, neighboring countries, Israel, and countries in the Middle East were facing large avian influenza outbreaks in poultry or wild birds during that period. Since the end of 2019 HPAI H5N8 outbreaks were reported in Europe in poultry, captive birds, and wild birds.Mute swans (_Cygnus olor_) have been naturally infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza virus subtypes H5N1 and H5N8, with similar pathological consequences. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Germany: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7912764,3715] See Also

33(45) [edited]https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=36360Highly pathogenic avian influenza, Netherlands--------------------------------------------------------Information received on [and dated] 30 Oct 2020 from Dr. Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, NetherlandsSummaryReport type: Immediate notificationDate of start of the event: 29 Oct 2020Date of confirmation of the event: 29 Oct 2020Reason for notification: Recurrence of a listed diseaseDate of previous occurrence: 10 Jul 2018Manifestation of disease: Clinical diseaseCausal agent: Highly pathogenic avian influenza virusSerotype: H5N8Nature of diagnosis: Clinical, laboratory (advanced)This event pertains a defined zone within the country.New outbreaks (1)Summary of outbreaksTotal outbreaks: 1Outbreak location: Altforst, GelderlandDate of start of the outbreak: 29 Oct 2020Outbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)Epidemiological unit: FarmTotal animals affected:Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / SlaughteredBirds / 35 750 / 10 500 / 400 / 35 350 / 0Affected population: Broiler parent stock poultryOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 29.37 / 1.12 / 3.81 / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusiveControl measuresMeasures applied: Movement control inside the country, screening, stamping out, control of wildlife reservoirs, zoning, disinfection, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: No other measuresFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[This immediate notification confirms the information already published in ProMED-mail 20201030.7902659.On 17 Oct 2020, the Netherlands reported HPAI H5N8 in 2 mute swans (_Cygnus olor_); the dead mute swans were found in a wetland area in Kockengen, Utrecht. See the report at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review? page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=36235.The following 3 paragraphs are excerpted from the OIE Avian Influenza Portal (https://www.oie.int/en/animal-health-in-the-world/avian-influenza-portal/what-is-avian-influenza/):Wild birds, as natural host and reservoir for all types of avian influenza viruses, play a major role in the evolution, maintenance, and spread of these viruses. The main wild species involved have proved to be waterfowls, gulls, and shorebirds; however, the virus seem to pass easily between different bird species.The incidence of infection appears to be seasonal, with the highest isolation rate being in juvenile birds in the fall of the year. Several routes of exposure of wild bird viruses to poultry have been documented or suspected of being the origins of outbreaks. Direct exposure to wild birds is the most likely transmission factor.Therefore, limiting exposure of poultry to wild birds through confinement rearing and other biosecurity measures provides an opportunity to reduce the risk of introduction of avian influenza virus from wild birds, and consequently is key to decrease the risk of evolution into highly pathogenic forms, exposure and infection of humans, and recombination with human virus components to form viruses that can not only infect humans but readily transmit among humans.---The Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza (HPAI) Report No. 16, from 2 to 22 Oct 2020, World Animal Health Information and Analysis Department, is available at https://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Animal_Health_in_the_World/docs/pdf/OIE_AI_situation_report/HPAI_asof22102020.pdf. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Gelderland Province, Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7905813,10617] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-10-30 11:47:31 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (74): Netherlands (GE) poultry, HPAI H5N8 susp Archive Number: 20201030.7902659AVIAN INFLUENZA (74): NETHERLANDS (GELDERLAND) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8 SUSPECTED***************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Thu 29 Oct 2020 9:36 CETSource: Volkskrant [in Dutch, trans., abridged, edited]https://www.volkskrant.nl/nieuws-achtergrond/zeer-besmettelijke-vogelgriep-geconstateerd-op-pluimveebedrijf-in-gelderland~bbe94ef2A highly contagious form of bird flu has been diagnosed at a poultry farm with 35 000 animals in Altforst, Gelderland. The sector is alarmed because this year's [2020] contamination is early and has entered a barn where high hygiene standards are maintained."What is still to come?" asks Hennie de Haan, chairman of the Dutch Poultry Farmers' Union (NVP). "The bird migration, with which the virus spreads, has only just started. Moreover, this is a company where very careful work is done and the animals do not come outside. That it got in there anyway puzzles and worries us."It is the 4th time in 7 winters that bird flu has been diagnosed in the Netherlands. It has never gotten as bad as in 2003, when the industry seemed doomed. Hundreds of poultry farms were affected and millions of animals had to be culled. As now, it concerned the serious, so-called highly pathogenic variant of bird flu; highly contagious and almost acutely lethal to poultry.Professor of farm animal health care Arjan Stegeman (Utrecht University) finds the concerns from the sector justified. "A massive amplification of the virus is possible," he says. "It is realistic to think that multiple infections will follow." According to Stegeman, it is now important that poultry farmers pay extra attention to hygiene.He says it is plausible that faeces from wild water birds entered the stable in Altforst via, for example, a boot from the pasture. "This can happen in the river area, where porters such as wigeons forage." The infected animals are believed to have flown in from Russia, where outbreaks had already occurred.Although people are only sporadically infected by the variant of the current virus, employees of the company in Altforst are given a flu shot as a precaution. In 2003 the virus did spread to humans, but only to those involved who had worked very intensively around the infected animals. A Dutch vet died at the time from the effects of bird flu.The breeding plant in Altforst, with chickens and roosters for the production of hatching eggs for the meat industry, will be culled. There are no companies within a kilometer, so preventive clearing is not necessary. A transport ban applies to the 25 poultry farmers within a radius of 10 kilometers [6.2 mi] and they will be tested for bird flu within 3 kilometers [1.9 mi]."This outbreak will immediately have major economic consequences for our export position," says Gert-Jan Oplaat of the association of the Dutch poultry processing industry. "Countries will lock their borders for us." Products outside the closed zone may be officially exported, but according to Oplaat, "there are always countries that say: the Netherlands is small, we don't get anything from there."All commercial poultry farms had been obliged to keep chickens and other birds indoors for a week. This obligation followed the diagnosis of bird flu in 2 wild mute swans in the province of Utrecht.In addition to the commercial housing obligation, zoos, petting zoos, and owners of hobby birds are also obliged to screen their poultry and waterfowl to prevent these animals from coming into contact with wild waterfowl.Bird flu first appeared in China in 1996, after which it spread and subsequently was not effectively controlled in Southeast Asia. "It gave the virus the chance to constantly switch to wild birds," says professor Stegeman. "Eventually the virus adapted to wild waterfowl, which are hardly affected by it themselves.[Byline: Pieter Hotse Smit]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[The major 2003 HPAI epizootic in the Netherlands mentioned in the media report above, which involved nearly 500 reported human infections (see archive 20051221.3649), was caused by HPAI H7N7.The official report of the current outbreak in Altforst (see map at https://goo.gl/maps/XwJe4gyKZxAV1F426) is yet to become available; most likely, it has been caused by the same virus strain, HPAI H5N8, discovered in 2 mute swans found dead on 17 Oct 2020 in a wetland in Kockengen (50 km/31 mi from Altforst, both in the Utrecht province, central Netherlands). This region includes considerable number of poultry farms.The major 2003 HPAI epizootic in the Netherlands mentioned in the media report above was caused by HPAI H7N7. On top of poultry, wild, and pet birds, this event involved several hundred human infections (reviewed in archive no. 20051221.3649).The Netherlands is included among the world's leading poultry producers. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map of the Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7902659,67808] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-10-26 20:45:17 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (72): Kazakhstan (NK) poultry, wild, HPAI H5N8, epidemiology Archive Number: 20201026.7892464AVIAN INFLUENZA (72): KAZAKHSTAN (NORTH KAZAKHSTAN) POULTRY, WILD, HPAI H5N8, EPIDEMIOLOGY******************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Fri 23 Oct 2020 From: Ian Brown <Ian.Brown@apha.gov.uk> [edited] 20201006.7838872 20200919.7796269Re: PRO/IN> Highly pathogenic H5N8 in Kazakhstan [20200919.7796269, 20200926.7815554, 20201006.7838872] We report here emerging results of analyses of highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N8 viruses in the north of the Republic of Kazakhstan. Recently HPAI viruses of the H5N8 subtype have caused outbreaks in the Russia Federation in July [2020] and in the Republic of Kazakhstan since September [2020]. Viruses detected in domestic ducks, geese, chickens and a single mute swan in the Republic of Kazakhstan in September 2020 were of the A/H5N8 subtype and had a multi-basic cleavage site motif consistent with a highly pathogenic phenotype in galliform birds (PLREKRRKRGLF) and belong to A/H5 GsGd clade 2.3.4.4b. For all gene segments the Kazakhstan viruses cluster together in phylogenetic trees, with the closest genetic relatives for a putative ancestral strain last detected in around 2017/2018. However long branch lengths from these putative ancestral relatives for each gene to current outbreak strains suggest undetected maintenance of Kazakhstan-like viruses as a complete genotype from emergence likely in early 2018 through to detection in September 2020. No subsequent information on the detection, circulation or spread of this emergent H5N8 virus is currently available, prior to the detection of the viruses in Kazakhstan. The viruses can be clearly distinguished in all gene segments from those of H5N8 viruses that caused widespread outbreaks in Europe during the first half of 2020. The phylogenetic tree topology, the lack of evidence for reassortment with LPAI gene segments from either domestic or wild anseriforms, the relatively short branch lengths within the Republic of Kazakhstan cluster linked by a long branch to ancestral strains suggests a) a very similar virus is responsible for all outbreaks in Kazakhstan, and b) long-term and under-surveilled but continued circulation is more likely to have occurred in galliform poultry in unknown regions/locations.The threat of this virus to the poultry sector through winter 2020/21 remains, along with the potential for re-spillover and diffusion mediated by wild birds; risk mitigation - proportional to previous years - is required.This work was done through close collaboration between the AI International Reference Laboratory, APHA-Weybridge, the Royal Veterinary College UK, Kazakh Scientific Research Veterinary Institute, Almaty and the National Veterinary Reference Centre, Nur-Sultan, Republic of Kazakhstan. --Professor Ian H. Brown, MIBiol PhDHead of Virology DepartmentDirector of OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza and Newcastle DiseaseOIE Reference Laboratory for Swine InfluenzaAnimal and Plant Health Agency (APHA)Weybridge, UK<Ian.Brown@apha.gov.uk>[Kazakhstan reported on 16 and 17 Sep 2020 outbreaks of HPAI H5 on its northern territories, affecting, respectively, wild birds (unidentified Anatidae and Corvidae) and poultry (species not given); both notifications were included in 20200919.7796269, which was accompanied by the following commentary by Mod. CRD: "Since August 2020, Russia reported 39 outbreaks of HPAI [highly pathogenic avian influenza]. All were associated with the H5 hemagglutinin subtype, but only 2 of the 39 have been fully characterized as H5N8. These outbreaks occurred in both domestic poultry and wild birds and were located in Omsk, Kurgan, Tyumen, and Chelyabinsk oblasts. These oblasts border the North Kazakhstan region. See reports and updated maps at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=35477, https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=35280, and https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=35614."For this HPAI event from Kazakhstan, the neuraminidase has not yet been typed. Determining the subtype and strain of this virus is very important". The current report from OIE/FAO International AI Reference Laboratory, for which Prof Brown and his colleagues are gratefully acknowledged, provides detailed information on the strain circulating in Kazakhstan. Complementary data of the H5 AI strain circulating on the Russian side of North Kazakhstan, compared to the Kazakh strain, will be helpful. Recently, HPAI outbreaks have been reported to the OIE from the Karachay-Cherkessia Republic in the North Caucasus region of Southern Russia (poultry, H5, 20201006.7840560) and from central Israel (poultry & wild, H5N8, 20201015.7864774, 20201014.7861465). Both are located on flyways of migrating birds from central/northern Asia. Details on their respective genotyped profiles will be helpful. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:North Kazakhstan, Kazakhstan: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7892464,19923] See Also

On [20 Oct 2020], the National Reference Laboratory confirmed highly pathogenic influenza virus H5N8 in the samples from the 2 dead mute swans.Control measuresMeasures applied: vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultWageningen Bioveterinary Research National Reference Laboratory, Lelystad (national laboratory)/ mute swan / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 20 Oct 2020 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[After circulating in countries in Asia, H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 group A was introduced into Europe during the winter of 2014-15. During and after the winter of 2016, a related, but genetically distinct influenza H5N8 virus was detected in Europe; in addition, reassortant influenza H5N5 and H5N6 viruses emerged.Because the influenza season progressed along the fall migratory routes for wild birds from Siberia across Asia into Europe, large numbers of dead wild birds and outbreaks in poultry flocks were associated with H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 group B. Overall, 24 of the 31 the European Union countries, neighboring countries, Israel, and countries in the Middle East were facing large avian influenza outbreaks in poultry or wild birds during that period. Since the end of 2019 HPAI H5N8 outbreaks were reported in Europe in poultry, captive birds, and wild birds.Mute swans (_Cygnus olor_) have been naturally infected with highly pathogenic avian influenza virus subtypes H5N1 and H5N8, with similar pathological consequences. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED map of Netherlands: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7891356,67785] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-10-26 17:44:21 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (71): South Korea (HN) H5N8, wild bird Archive Number: 20201026.7890373AVIAN INFLUENZA (71): SOUTH KOREA (SOUTH CHUNGCHEONG) H5N8, WILD BIRD*********************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sun 25 Oct 2020 10:55 AM KSTSource: The Korea Herald, Yonhap News Agency report [edited]http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20201025000073A highly pathogenic avian influenza (AI) case was reported in South Korea on [Sun 25 Oct 2020], marking the 1st virulent bird flu case in the country in 32 months. The virulent avian influenza strain of H5N8 was discovered from a fecal sample collected from wild birds on [Wed 21 Oct 2020] in Cheonan, 92 km [approx. 57 mi] south of Seoul, according to the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs.The discovery marked the 1st highly pathogenic AI case confirmed in the country since the H5N6 case, which is similarly virulent to H5N8, reported in the nearby Asan region in February 2018.Highly pathogenic AI is very contagious and can make poultry very sick and even cause death.The ministry has already restricted the movement of poultry and other livestock at 188 farms within a 10-km [approx. 6.2 mi] radius of the area after discovering a H5-type AI strain in the area earlier [see comment].Authorities placed a travel ban on people and vehicles within a 500-meter [approx. 0.3 mi] radius of the location where the H5N8 strain was discovered. The purchase and sale of poultry at local markets in Cheonan will also be suspended until the travel ban is lifted."Given the precarious situation, we ask that all farms remain vigilant in terms of disease control as highly pathogenic AI cases could break out at farms at any given moment," a ministry official said.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[According to OIE's terrestrial code, avian influenza is defined as "an infection of poultry caused by any influenza A virus of the H5 or H7 subtypes". The S. Korean authorities have applied immediate preventive measures after the detection of H5N8 influenza A virus in a fecal sample of wild birds (thus non-poultry), even before its high pathogenicity established and serotyping completed. According to the Code, "Infection with influenza A viruses of high pathogenicity in birds other than poultry, including wild birds, should be notified----"; "However, a Member Country should not impose bans on the trade in poultry and poultry commodities in response to such a notification". This relates to international trade, though countries are eligible to maintain more stringent policy intranationally. The measures undertaken in S.Korea by the veterinary authorities are meant to prevent the introduction of the pathogen into poultry farms. The severity of the currently applied policy reflects past experience. During 2014, South Korea suffered a major HPAI H5N8 epizootic, devastating its poultry industry, which was shown to be introduced by migrating birds from China. According to the OIE reports, a total of 212 outbreaks were recorded before declaring the event resolved (in Mar 2015), leading to the culling of nearly 4.7 million birds (see, with map at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/temp/reports/en_fup_0000017334_20150313_170102.pdf). For the location of Cheonan, see map at https://tinyurl.com/y2xvr6sa.Further details are expected in an OIE notification. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Cheonan-si, South Chungcheong Province, South Korea: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7890373,15392] See Also

Most likely, the virus has been introduced by migratory birds.Control measuresMeasures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, quarantine, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: no other measuresDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Laboratory (national laboratory) / black swan / pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / - / pendingKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Laboratory (national laboratory) / black swan / real-time reverse transcriptase/polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 14 Oct 2020 / positiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[After circulating in countries in Asia, H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 group A was introduced into Europe during the winter of 2014-15. During and after the winter of 2016, a related, but genetically distinct, influenza H5N8 virus was detected in Europe; in addition, reassortant influenza H5N5 and H5N6 viruses emerged. Because the influenza season progressed along the fall migratory routes for wild birds from Siberia across Asia into Europe, large numbers of dead wild birds and outbreaks in poultry flocks were associated with H5N8 virus clade 2.3.4.4 group B. Overall, 24 of the 31 European Union countries, neighboring countries, Israel, and countries in the Middle East were facing large avian influenza outbreaks in poultry or wild birds during that period. Since the end of 2019, HPAI H5N8 outbreaks were reported in Europe in poultry, captive birds, and wild birds, and Israel confirmed the infection in a Bonelli's eagle (_Aquila fasciata_) found with neurological symptoms in the Jordan Valley.The black swan (_Cygnus atratus_) is a large waterbird, a species of swan that breeds mainly in the southeast and southwest regions of Australia. For a picture, go to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_swan#/media/File:Black_Swan_2_-_Pitt_Town_Lagoon.jpg. - Mod.PMBHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Jerusalem, Yerushalayim, Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7864774,6292] See Also

The farm is divided into 4 pens. The morbidity and mortality occurred in one-half of a divided pen. The farm is situated near fishponds; it is the season of birds' migration, and aquatic migrating birds are resting and feeding in these ponds.Outbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*Birds / 5.71 / 2.29 / 40 / 100*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughterEpidemiologySource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Most likely by wild migrating birdsEpidemiological comments: Epidemiological investigation is ongoing. The last time that the virus was diagnosed in Israel was in January 2020 in a Bonelli's eagle in the desert. The last time that it was diagnosed in a commercial farm was in the north of the country in April 2019, in a turkey farm.Control measuresMeasures applied: Movement control inside the country, quarantine, zoning, vaccination prohibited, no treatment of affected animalsMeasures to be applied: Surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; official disposal of carcasses, by-products, and waste; stamping out; disinfectionDiagnostic test resultsLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / ResultKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Laboratory (national laboratory) / Birds / Pathogen isolation by egg inoculation / 13 Oct 2020 / PositiveKimron Veterinary Institute, Avian Diseases Laboratory (national laboratory) / Birds / Real-time reverse transcriptase / polymerase chain reaction (RRT-PCR) / 13 Oct 2020 / PositiveFuture reportingThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.[The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[This outbreak was already published in ProMED-mail 20201013.785921. The following has been extracted from the OIE Avian Influenza Portal (https://www.oie.int/en/animal-health-in-the-world/avian-influenza-portal/what-is-avian-influenza/):Several factors can contribute to the spread of avian influenza viruses, such as:- Globalization and international trade;- Farming and sale (live bird markets);- Wild birds and migratory routes.Wild birds, as natural host and reservoir for all types of avian influenza viruses, play a major role in the evolution, maintenance, and spread of these viruses. The main wild species involved have proved to be waterfowls, gulls, and shorebirds; however, the virus seem to pass easily between different bird species.The incidence of infection appears to be seasonal, with the highest isolation rate being in juvenile birds in the fall of the year. Several routes of exposure of wild bird viruses to poultry have been documented or suspected of being the origins of outbreaks. Direct exposure to wild birds is the most likely transmission factor.Therefore, limiting exposure of poultry to wild birds through confinement rearing and other biosecurity measures provides an opportunity to reduce the risk of introduction of avian influenza virus from wild birds, and consequently is key to decrease the risk of evolution into highly pathogenic forms, exposure and infection of humans, and recombination with human viruses' components to form viruses that can not only infect humans but readily transmit among humans. - Mod.CRDHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Haifa District, Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7861465,35084] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-10-13 20:13:00 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (66): Israel (HA), H5N8, poultry  Archive Number: 20201013.7859214AVIAN INFLUENZA (66): ISRAEL (HAIFA), H5N8, POULTRY***************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Tue 13 Oct 2020Source: PoultryMed [edited]https://www.poultrymed.com/Poultrymed/Templates/showpage.asp?DBID=1&LNGID=1&TMID=178&FID=2948&PID=0&IID=78684A broiler breeder farm with 35 000 birds in Metzer (near Ma'anit, Central Israel) has been diagnosed with highly pathogenic avian influenza H5N8.The property has been quarantined, and movement controls are in place to stop any birds, eggs, and equipment from leaving the premises. A Restricted Area (3 km) [1.86 mi] is in place around the property, and a Control Area (10 km) [6.21 mi] across a wider area has also been created. The farm will be depopulated.--Communicated by:Nati Elkin<nati@poultrymed.com>[This is the 1st HPAI H5N8 event of the season [2020], probably introduced by migrating birds.Israel experienced its most recent case of HPAI H5N8 on 27 Jan 2020, when a Bonelli's Eagle (_Aquila fasciata_) was found with neurological signs in the Jordan valley. The eagle had a transmitter, so it could be established that on 1 Jan 2020 it entered the Jordan valley from the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan and, from then on, stayed in the Jordan valley, on the Israeli side of the Jordan river. The eagle was brought alive to the Wildlife hospital in the Safari of Ramat-Gan and was put there in quarantine, eventually euthanized on 3 Feb 2020. This case was reported to the OIE; see, with map, athttps://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapEventSummary&reportid=33117.For the location of the current case, in Kibbutz Metzer (Haifa district), see map at https://tinyurl.com/yxry3znw.Israel is located on main flyways of migrating birds. In the autumn, mainly September to November, extremely large numbers of birds leave their nesting grounds in Europe and Asia and cross Israel on their way to the wintering grounds in Africa.Alertness is warranted in the Eastern Mediterranean region. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map:Haifa, Haifa, Israel: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=7859214,15194] See Also
