View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-01-08 17:03:09 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (03): United Kingdom (Northern Ireland) poultry, suspected, RFI, NOT Archive Number: 20200108.6877259AVIAN INFLUENZA (03): UNITED KINGDOM (NORTHERN IRELAND) POULTRY, SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION, NOT********************************************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.org[ProMED has received the following information from Professor Ian H. Brown, MIBiol PhD, Director of OIE/FAO International Reference Laboratory for Avian Influenza and Newcastle Disease, Weybridge, UK (see 20200124.691319):Investigations of the suspicious case in poultry in Northern Ireland excluded involvement with notifiable avian influenza (H5 and H7 subtypes) plus Newcastle disease.][1]Date: Wed 8 Jan 2020Source: BBC News [edited]https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-51011718The authorities are investigating a suspected case of a notifiable bird disease on a poultry farm in County Fermanagh. It was discovered 4 days ago [4 Jan 2020] when a vet became concerned about increased mortality among the broiler birds.Tests are being run to see if it is bird flu or another disease called Newcastle disease. It will be several days before final results are back. Restrictions have been put in place on the farm as a precautionary measure.The Department of Agriculture Environment and Rural Affairs can order the culling of birds to prevent disease spreading. Farmers have been urged to step up their biosecurity.The disease risk increases in winter with the arrival of migratory birds which can carry them. In recent years bird flu has been confirmed in wild birds on several occasions.Last month [December 2019], the H5 strain of bird flu was detected at a commercial poultry business in Suffolk; 27 000 chickens were culled there [see commentary].Poultry is an important part of the Northern Ireland agri-food sector. The latest figures show there are about 26 million birds on farms here. The majority of them are bred for meat, but there are a substantial number of laying hens too. Annual turnover from poultry is about GBP 709 million (USD 928 million) and it employs almost 6000 people.[Byline: Conor Macauley]--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>******[2]Date: Tue 7 Jan 2020Source: Carlow Live [edited]https://www.carlowlive.ie/news/news/506642/carlow-farmers-bird-flu-alert-after-suspected-outbreak-at-a-poultry-farm-in-ireland.htmlFarmers across Ireland have been warned to step up biosecurity measures as a suspected outbreak of bird flu is being investigated at a poultry farm in Fermanagh. A spokesperson for the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs (DAERA) in Northern Ireland said that officials are investigating the suspected presence of a "notifiable avian disease" (NAD) in a broiler breeder flock in Fermanagh.A private veterinary practitioner contacted DAERA on [2 Jan 2020] with concerns over increased bird mortality at the premises. The DAERA spokesperson said a veterinary enquiry at the holding started that evening. Testing has already started on samples taken from birds to detect the presence of serious bird diseases like avian influenza and Newcastle disease. The results are expected to take several days, and restrictive measures are in place on the farm.The spokesperson added: "All bird keepers are urged to remain vigilant, and if they suspect any signs of the disease in their flocks, they must report it immediately to DAERA."All poultry keepers, including backyard flock keepers and those keeping game birds and pet birds, need to act now and maintain high levels of biosecurity at all times in order to reduce the risk of transmission of avian flu to their flocks."--Communicated by:ProMED-mail<promed@promedmail.org>[Last month's (December 2019) H5 outbreak in Suffolk, mentioned in section [1] above, was caused by a low-pathogenic H5N3 virus strain. The relevant veterinary inquiry, followed by culling and other control measures, was undertaken following reports of a drop in egg production. Reportedly, the cleansing and disinfection activities were completed and effective as of 18 Dec 2019 (see OIE follow-up report no. 2 at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=32776).The results of the laboratory tests of the current event in Northern Ireland, as well as of the epidemiological investigation, are anticipated.Two H5 highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) subtypes have been circulating in Europe in recent years, namely, H5N8 and (a European reassortant strain of the H5N6 HPAI virus) H5N6. Their circulation was observed mainly during the relevant season (December through March), synchronic with decreasing temperatures and wild bird migration movements.H5N8 HPAI was 1st introduced into Eastern Europe in mid-October 2016; it has been detected in 30 of 43 European countries, particularly in Western and Eastern Europe. In 2019, the reported number of infections decreased drastically, and the disease affected mainly domestic poultry in Bulgaria and the Russian Federation. HPAI H5N8 has recently been reported from Poland.The last report of the H5N6 HPAI strain occurred in Denmark in January 2019. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:Northern Ireland: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=6877259,197] See Also

View printable version   Share this post:       Published Date: 2020-01-06 21:55:23 UTC Subject: PRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (02): Poland (LU, WP) poultry, HPAI H5N8, spread Archive Number: 20200106.6874145AVIAN INFLUENZA (02): POLAND (LUBELSKIE, WIELKOPOLSKIE) POULTRY, HPAI H5N8, SPREAD**********************************************************************************A ProMED-mail posthttp://www.promedmail.orgProMED-mail is a program of theInternational Society for Infectious Diseaseshttp://www.isid.orgDate: Sat 4 Jan 2020Source: Press release, Poland's Chief Veterinary Officer [in Polish, machine trans. abridged, edited]https://tinyurl.com/yhg7nx4aSummary of the epizootic situation associated with highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) in poultry during the period 31 Dec 2019-3 Jan 2020.Based on the results of tests received from the national reference laboratory for avian influenza, i.e. the National Veterinary Institute - National Research Institute in Pulawy, a total of 7 new outbreaks of HPAI H5N8 have been confirmed in poultry during the said period, of which 3 were in 2019 and 4 in 2020.Outbreak No. 2019/1 involved a farm including 12 089 turkeys in the town of Stary Uscimow, commune of Uscimow, Lubartow poviat, Lublin province.Outbreak No. 2019/2 involved a farm including 9500 turkeys in the town of Stary Uscimow, commune of Uscimow, in the Lubartow poviat, Lublin province.Outbreak No. 2019/3 involved a farm including 20 600 turkeys in the town of Stary Uscimow, commune of Uscimow, Lubartow poviat, Lublin province.Outbreak No. 2020/1 involved a farm including 12 900 guinea fowls in the town of Stary Uscimow, commune of Uscimow, Lubartow poviat, Lubelskie [Lublin] province.Outbreak No 2020/2 involved a farm including 36 069 laying hens in Topola Osiedle, municipality of Przygodzice, Ostrow poviat, Greater Poland province. This is the primary outbreak of avian influenza of the H5N8 subtype.Outbreak No. 2020/3 involved a farm including 36 poultry of various species (chickens, ducks, pigeons). The farm is located in Wolka Orlowska, Izbica commune, Krasnystaw poviat, Lublin province.Outbreak No. 2020/4 involved a farm including 43 poultry of various species (chickens, ducks, geese). The farm is located in Olchowiec Kolonia, commune of Zolkiewka, Krasnystaw poviat, Lublin province.As of Sat 4 Jan 2020, 10:00 am, no cases in wild birds have been recorded.In all the said outbreaks (2019 and 2020), the Veterinary Services implemented eradication procedures as prescribed for highly pathogenic avian influenza in poultry.--Communicated by:ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>[The outbreak No. 2019/1 above has been reported to the OIE in Poland's immediate notification submitted 2 Jan 2020 (20200102.6867443). According to the OIE report, the new HPAI H5N8 in Poland started 30 Dec 2019. According to the above update report, the primary outbreak in the current HPAI H5N8 event in Poland was No 2020/2, located in another province, namely Wielkopolskie (Greater Poland province).Several neighboring countries have published their undertaken preventive measures in view of the new Polish event and its spread. The previous HPAI H5N8 event in Poland started October 2016 and was resolved April 2017. Between October 2016 and March 2017, 113 outbreaks were reported. The affected population was both domestic and wild birds. See event summary and map at https://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=21457. Additional information on the Polish poultry industry is available in the commentary by Mod.CRD in 20200102.6867443. - Mod.ASHealthMap/ProMED map available at:Poland: https://promedmail.org/promed-post?place=6874145,113] See Also
